DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances I give notice that, five sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Fisheries Notices Nos. NPF 9, 10, 11, 12, 13 and 14 and No. ORF 15 made under section 8 of the Fisheries Act 1952, be disallowed.
I seek leave to make a short statement on the concerns of the Committee.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —These instruments appear to have drafting defects of a magnitude which make it appropriate to place a notice of disallowance upon them. The Committee believes that the drafting, presentation and access of delegated legislation should be of a standard not less than that of Acts. Anything less is a breach of parliamentary propriety. The principal difficulty is with a key clause in one of the notices which is then, in effect, incorporated in other notices thus tainting those others as well as the original. In addition, there are other drafting defects in the notices some of which could affect validity. For example, one notice was not signed. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement of the concerns of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
FISHERIES NOTICES NOS. NPF 9, 10, 11, 12, 13 AND 14

All of these Notices, which prohibit the taking of prawns in certain areas subject to certain conditions, relate to the Northern Prawn Fishery. They all were made on 19 March 1991 and tabled on 16 May 1991, which was 14 sitting days later, or virtually at the end of the period during which tabling is required. The Committee normally waits until the end of the further 15 sitting days after tabling before giving a protective notice of motion of disallowance. However, on the present Sitting Pattern, this would be a date in August. This would mean that apparently defective instruments could be in operation for some five months before the Committee need have a satisfactory reply or, failing a satisfactory reply, be able to recommend appropriate action to the Senate. Accordingly, the Committee is giving notice for five sitting days hence, which will allow two weeks to resolve the matter.

The Committee has suggested previously that it may be appropriate to reduce the time during which disallowable instruments of delegated legislation are required to be tabled from 15 sitting days to five. This would reduce the possibility of defective instruments being in force for months before the Committee obtains undertakings in respect of them.

The concerns of the Committee relate not to the substantive provisions of these instruments but to their form and drafting. It is a breach of parliamentary propriety if delegated legislation is defective in these areas. There is also the question of invalidity for uncertainty. Delegated legislation, which is necessarily made under the authority of an Act of Parliament, must not be drafted to a lesser standard than Acts.

In Fisheries Notice NPF 9 one paragraph is drafted in such an ambiguous way that it is not possible to tell whether it effects its stated purpose. This is important, because it is a key provision, referred to and in effect incorporated by later provisions of the same Notice and by provisions of NPF 10, 11 and 12 and probably 13 and 14. Therefore, all of these instruments appear similarly defective. There is also a typographical error in NPF 9.

Fisheries Notice NPF 11 refers in one provision to ``proclaimed waters referred to in paragraphs 4 and 5''. There is no reference to proclaimed waters in paragraph 4. It appears that the provision should have referred to paragraphs 5 and 6.

Fisheries Notice NPF 12 refers in one provision to ``activities prohibited by paragraph 4''. There are no activities prohibited by paragraph 4. It appears that the provision should have referred to paragraphs 5 or 6 or both. NPF 12 refers in another provision to ``periods specified in paragraph 4''. There are no periods specified in paragraph 4. It appears that the provision should have referred to paragraph 5.

Fisheries Notices NPF 13 and 14 refer to ``equipment as defined in Fisheries Notice No.NPF 9'', without further qualification. Virtually every one of the substantive provisions of NPF 9 defines equipment, as does the interpretation provision and a schedule. It is assumed that the key paragraph of NPF 9 is meant, but as described earlier that provision is defective. In any event, the cross-reference should be made specific.

In NPF 14 a provision refers to ``proclaimed waters referred to in paragraphs 4 and 6''. There are no references to proclaimed waters in either of these paragraphs but there are such references in paragraphs 5 and 7.
FISHERIES NOTICE NO. ORF 15

This Notice, one of 12 Fisheries Notices tabled on 16 May 1991, refers to the Orange Roughy Fishery. It was not signed. All of the other Notices tabled on that day, and the other 10 Fisheries Notices and Plans of Management made this year, all carry facsimiles of separate signatures by the Minister, together with a hand written date. In ORF 15 there is a blank space where the facsimile signature usually appears, although the date is hand written as usual. Therefore, there is at least a presumption that the instrument was never signed and is of no effect.

QUARANTINE AMENDMENT BILL 1991
The purpose of this Bill is to introduce amendments to the Quarantine Act 1908. The amendments do not reflect major changes in policy by the Government.

The Quarantine Act provides that the expenses of keeping goods in quarantine until such time as the risk of the introduction of diseases and pests can be assessed as minimal are a legal charge against the goods.

However, it is unclear whether the Quarantine Act permits the enforcement of that legal charge against the goods by their retention and sale or whether the Commonwealth must surrender the goods to their owners when the goods have completed their quarantine.
Accordingly these amendments provide that the Commonwealth may retain possession of the goods, over which it holds a statutory legal charge, until such time as:
* the expenses owing for quarantine have been paid;
* suitable arrangements have been made by the owner for payment of the expenses; or
* as a last resort, the Commonwealth may sell the goods and apply the proceeds of the sale to the debt owing to the Commonwealth.

The amendments are necessary because the Commonwealth has been deprived of substantial revenue by owners or importers not paying their lawful debts for quarantine services. That situation is to be avoided in future.

As an example of the revenue lost, there was a recent case where valuable animals that had undergone extensive quarantine had to be released and the Commonwealth is in the position of suing for the recovery of $1.5m with little likelihood of recovering the full amount.

In addition, another large program known as the scrapie freedom assurance program, which involves a large number of animals held in quarantine for many years to address risks presented by diseases which are slow to appear, is coming to an end. The animals involved in this program are quarantined in various places throughout Australia and have attracted substantial highly subsidised charges of up to $900,000 for services provided by the Commonwealth in ensuring that the animals are free from disease and may be released for breeding purposes. The animals are due for release early in 1992.

Although highly subsidised valuable services have been provided by the Commonwealth over a period of approximately seven years, the importers have disputed the outstanding debt. These amendments allowing the Commonwealth to retain possession of the animals will ensure that the Commonwealth's bargaining position over payment of the debt is not weakened.
Of course, the amendments apply to any goods undergoing quarantine now or in the future
* not just to the animals in the scrapie freedom assurance program.
The amendments add a new provision to the Act enabling the Commonwealth and the owner to enter into an agreement about the payment of quarantine expenses.

In the event that agreement cannot be reached, the owner's rights over the goods are well protected by the provision requiring the Commonwealth to serve a notice advising that if, at the end of 30 days after the notice is given to the owner of the goods, any expenses relating to quarantine are still outstanding, the goods may be sold.
This Bill has no financial impact but will allow the Commonwealth to more easily enforce payment of charges for quarantine services.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991
One purpose of this Bill is to make a number of amendments to the Health Insurance Act 1973.

The first of these amendments will clarify the intent of `professional service' as defined in Section 3 of the Health Insurance Act, by introducing the notion of ``clinical relevance'' to that definition. Technically, as the legislation currently stands, a medical practitioner could itemise an account and claim Medicare benefits for a service where a physical attendance on the patient occurs, but during which no ``clinically relevant service'' takes place.
The proposed amendment requires that a ``professional service'' be related to a medical examination, treatment, diagnosis or test that is necessary for the appropriate treatment of the patient.
Clause 4 of the Bill has the purpose of specifying explicitly what has previously been implicit in the current legislation.

The purpose of the changes in clauses 5 and 6 of this Bill is to require the proprietor of a pathology laboratory, the approval for which has been revoked, to take all reasonable steps to inform the providing practitioner and the patient that a Medicare benefit will not be payable in respect of the pathology service, and to require the Minister to advertise such a decision.

Medicare benefits for pathology services are only payable where a number of criteria are met. One of these is that the laboratory premises where the services are rendered must meet certain standards. These standards are defined by the Minister and are adopted from standards and guidelines set by the National Pathology Accreditation Advisory Council. The Commonwealth contracts an independent organisation-the National Association of Testing Authorities-to carry out assessment of these premises.

There have been occasions recently where pathology laboratories have failed to reach an acceptable standard of operation and the approval has been revoked. The Department has become aware that the operators of some of these revoked premises have continued to perform pathology services without informing either the referring practitioners or the patients. (No charges have been raised against the patient.)
The provisions in these clauses are similar to those offences relating to the disqualification of a practitioner in section l9D of the Health Insurance Act 1973.
A further purpose of this Bill is to make a number of amendments to the National Health Act 1953 and the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act 1986 in relation to nursing home matters.

The Bill contains a measure to facilitate the release of information about nursing homes to the public. The secrecy provisions of the National Health Act currently prevent, in most cases, the release of any information about a person or a nursing home collected in the course of administering the Act. This has the effect of making it extremely difficult for the Department or the Minister to give out any information at all about nursing homes to prospective residents, current residents or to members of the public.

This new measure will enable necessary information to be made available to the public, while at the same time preserving the privacy of individual nursing home residents and the proprietor's right to a review of the information except in urgent circumstances.

Three types of information will be able to be released if this Bill is passed. Firstly, the Bill enables the public release of the action plans prepared by a nursing home indicating how the home will be improved so as to meet the prescribed standards of care. Action plans apply to homes that have been found not to meet the standards, and are the proprietor's indication of the changes to be made in the practices of that home.

Secondly, the Bill enables release of basic facts about a nursing home: its name, address, number of beds, fees charged and similar descriptive information necessary if a person wants to make an informed choice about a nursing home.

Thirdly, the Bill enables release of information concerning action that is to be taken to suspend or revoke a nursing home's approval, or to vary the conditions of its approval, or to suspend benefits for new admissions to that home. Proprietors will have 30 days to make submissions to the Minister about this information, except where the situation is urgent. If urgent release of information is necessary to protect the welfare or interests of residents, then such information may be released immediately. In most cases this will occur where a home is being closed down, and it is necessary to give advance warning to the residents, their families, the staff, other nursing homes or hospitals, and State health authorities that the residents have to be moved.

A further measure in this Bill provides an additional sanction which may be used in regard to a nursing home that has breached one or more conditions of its approval. Currently, the only available sanction is the suspension or revocation of approval of the home. This is a drastic penalty, which is only imposed as a last resort, as it severely disrupts the lives of the residents who have to be transferred elsewhere. This Bill enables Commonwealth benefits to be stopped for any new admissions occurring after the date of determination that the conditions have been breached. This penalises the nursing home while at the same time enables the care of existing residents to continue. This sanction is already available for use when standards of care are not met; this measure extends this sanction to apply to breaches of any of the conditions of approval.
The Bill also contains some technical amendments to enable proclamation of a section of a 1986 Act concerning the listing of Government nursing homes.

I now turn to the amendments proposed under Part 5 of the Bill. These will introduce more flexible arrangements for the administration of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. Such as decentralising the administration of the Individual Patient Usage Scheme, and making it possible for evaluation fees to be paid in instalments by sponsors seeking to include goods in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods.

The Individual Patient Usage (IPU) Scheme has been in operation for more than 10 years, to cover situations where there is a genuine need to treat a patient with a drug which has not been approved for supply in Australia. Such situations can be divided into two broad categories.

One category covers situations where a patient is suffering from a disease rarely seen in Australia, treatable by a well-recognised drug which no drug company wishes to market routinely in Australia. In such cases, approval to use the drug in question would be routinely given under the IPU Scheme.

The other category covers cases of urgent clinical need, where a patient is suffering from a serious disease which is either incurable by routinely available drugs, or which has failed to respond to such drugs. In such cases, approval to use an unproven drug on an experimental basis may be given, provided there is some scientific rationale for such treatment.

Under the present scheme, IPU approvals have been administered centrally. Any doctor seeking such approval must telephone a Medical Officer of the Therapeutic Goods Administration in Canberra, who decides such applications in accordance with criteria designed to take account of the factors I have mentioned. Two problems with this centralised system have emerged in recent years. Firstly, the volume of requests is now running at some twenty thousand per annum, and secondly, the growing complexity of medical practice has made it increasingly difficult for Medical Officers in Canberra, on the basis of a telephone call, to weigh up the pros and cons of using an unregistered drug.

The Government has therefore decided to make provision for IPU approvals to be delegated, under Regulations to be made for this purpose, to doctors outside the Australian Public Service-in general, to specific staff members of major hospitals. The general criteria which they will use will be the same as those used in the centralised Scheme (which will continue as an alternative). The doctor granting IPU approval will always be someone other than the prescriber, and the arrangement in each hospital will be under the general supervision of the hospital's ethics committee.

Part 5 of the Bill also contains amendments providing for Regulations to be made to introduce a scheme that will allow sponsors to pay their evaluation fees by instalments when they apply to register their products in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG). This measure follows a recommendation of the Industry and Government Consultative Committee, established to advise the Minister on the schedule of fees and charges to be paid in connection with the manufacture of therapeutic goods, and the inclusion and retention of goods in the ARTG.

Changes will also be made to alter the effect of the Secretary's action in grouping therapeutic goods under Part 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Act. At present this is to render a whole group of goods that have been grouped to be single goods for the purposes of Part 3 of that Act. However this creates difficulties in cases where only one product within a group may be required to be withdrawn from the market, yet the cancellation provisions under the Act must be applied to all the goods in the same group where they are treated as ``single therapeutic goods''. To overcome this and similar difficulties, the changes proposed will mean that individual goods that have been grouped will retain their status as separate goods, but will only be identified as belonging to a particular group warranting common or uniform treatment for certain purposes such as the payment of fees and charges, and the assignment of a common registration or listing number in the ARTG.

Other amendments included in Part 5 of the Bill deal with the introduction of fees, comparable to those payable under the Freedom of Information Act 1982, for processing the release of information in the ARTG to the public. Provision is also made to allow sponsors to apply, upon payment of a fee, to alter conditions attaching to the registration or listing of their goods in the ARTG where such alterations require further processing by the Therapeutic Goods Administration, and for the lodgement and supply of information under the Act by electronic means.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
THERAPEUTIC GOODS (CHARGES) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

This Bill is to be considered cognately with the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 (The Portfolio Bill). The amendments contained in this Bill arise as a consequence of amendments being made to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 by the Portfolio Bill.

The Portfolio Bill makes a number of amendments to Part 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Act. One of these relates to the effect of the secretary exercising his power to make Determinations to group therapeutic goods where, for example, they share common characteristics or where they share both common characteristics and a common manufacturer. At present, the effect of grouping therapeutic goods under section 16 of the Therapeutic Goods Act is to render each group of goods to be single goods for a range of administrative and other purposes under Part 3 of that Act including the application of charges. Thus, for example, each group of goods entered in the Register by the same person is treated as single goods and attracts one annual registration or listing charge.

However, following amendments to be introduced by the Portfolio Bill, the effect of the Secretary's action in grouping goods will no longer be to render such goods ``single goods''. Instead, each product included within the same group will retain their separate status as individual goods, and will only be identified as belonging to a particular Gazetted Therapeutic Goods Group, or a Gazetted Therapeutic Devices Group so as to attract, amongst the same group of goods, common or uniform treatment.

To preserve the policy intention that grouped goods should continue to attract only a single annual charge, rather than an annual charge for each product included in a group of goods that is separately registered or listed, amendments to the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Act 1989 are necessary to achieve this result and to match the changes made by the Portfolio Bill.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
HEALTH LEGISLATION (PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

The Bill before the Senate amends the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 and the National Health Act 1953 to implement substantial reforms to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) which were announced in the 1990 Budget.

These changes to the administration of the Scheme involve the introduction of a checking system whereby pharmacists will be connected on-line to the Health Insurance Commission's (HIC) computer, or more correctly, the Commission's eligibility file, to allow immediate verification of a patient's entitlement to either free pharmaceutical benefits, concessional benefits or general benefits.

No one would deny, not even the Opposition, the right of the Government to protect taxpayers' money, in providing that only those eligible to receive benefits do in fact receive them. To do no less would be scandalous.

Since November 1986 pharmacists have had the responsibility to satisfy themselves that the person claiming a benefit under the PBS was in fact entitled to that benefit. The introduction of the new checking system is but one more way for pharmacists to satisfy themselves that the benefit being claimed is legitimate. This system provides a level of accuracy not possible before.

Under the new system, the pharmacist seeks confirmation from the HIC's eligibility file that the benefit the patient is claiming is one to which that person is entitled. Clearly the pharmacist can satisfy himself or herself as to the patient's claim in any number of ways.

The patient may be well known to the pharmacist; the patient may tender any number of current cards provided by the Department of Social Security to prove eligibility to a benefit. The patient could tender a Medicare card or a passport. All might satisfy the pharmacist and in such cases many pharmacists may choose not to use the on-line system to check eligibility. Where the on-line system is used, however, the pharmacist is guaranteed payment at the level indicated by the HIC's system. This guarantee applies even if HIC's eligibility file is incorrect.

Let me expand on that point. The HIC eligibility file is not a new one. It is a file of information currently available to the HIC. It is information that has been and is still used to check the eligibility of persons receiving dispensed prescriptions, but this check presently occurs only after the benefit has been supplied. While recovery action would be undertaken by the HIC in the most blatant cases of wrongful claiming, a post examination system like this is clearly inefficient and unsatisfactory. The Commonwealth Auditor-General has already pointed this out in a report on the PBS.
The eligibility file is currently made up of data provided under law by the Departments of Social Security and Veterans' Affairs and the Health Insurance Commission.
On-line eligibility testing is to be extended to cover testing of eligibility for participation in the PBS generally.

This Bill makes it clear that Australian taxpayers are only going to pay for pharmaceutical benefits supplied to those persons who have a legitimate right to those benefits and that benefits will only be available to eligible residents of this country. Thus the flow of taxpayer-subsidised drugs to persons either overseas or just passing though this country is to stop.

Eligibility to pharmaceutical benefits will be limited to those persons who can receive the benefits of the Australian health system through Medicare. I make no apology for this move for surely no one would argue that the Australian taxpayer should be asked to foot the bill for drugs provided to overseas visitors and residents of other countries. The generous subsidies available under the PBS for expensive medications like insulin and ACE inhibitors mean that losses to the Australian community from abuse by tourists can be significant.

What changes will pharmacy customers experience? They may not even notice any change, for the pharmacist, while preparing the prescription, will call up the eligibility file on-line by entering the patient's basic details, that is, those that are already on the prescription prepared by the patient's doctor. The pharmacist will be provided with one of only four messages and this is a very important point for those of us with a serious intention to protect privacy to note. The messages will be that the patient has general entitlement; a concessional entitlement; entitlement to pharmaceutical benefits without charge; or that there is no record of the patient. Even if this information is wrong the pharmacist will be paid the full amount applicable.

If the patient disagrees with the level of entitlement indicated on-line, the pharmacist can choose to accept the further evidence the patient might tender or charge the patient the applicable higher rate, pointing out that the patient has under these provisions a right to a refund if the claim is later proven.

I point out that under the provisions of this Bill the patient is still protected against the high cost of pharmaceutical drugs. If a patient is not recorded as being eligible for free or concessional drugs the most that a pharmacist can charge is $15, provided that the patient is registered with Medicare. Even if the patient is not so registered the most a pharmacist can charge is the Commonwealth price for any listed drug. This price is the price the manufacturer and the Minister have agreed will be the price to pharmacists, plus the mark-ups and fees determined by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, which are added to the base cost.

Should a patient later be able to prove eligibility to general, concessional or free benefits, the provisions in the Bill will permit the patient to receive from the Commission a refund of the difference between what the patient paid and the correct price.

I turn now to a very important issue, but one which has been somewhat dishonestly exploited in the debate on these PBS reforms. I refer of course to the issue of privacy. This Government is committed to ensuring that Australians are protected from misuse of personal data collected in the course of the administration of Government programs. It has enacted privacy legislation and appointed a Privacy Commissioner and in relation to the PBS not only abides by the information privacy principles provided for under the Privacy Act but is also governed by very strict secrecy provisions of the National Health Act. The information to be made available to pharmacists to enable them to be guaranteed that they will be paid the full amount of the benefit they provide to a customer is, as I have described and as is set out under the definition of status information in the Bill, very limited information. Indeed, it tells a pharmacist less about a person than many other sources of information currently provided by claimants and certainly less than the pharmacist probably already knows because of the professional health care relationship involved.

Yet, the introduction of these eligibility checking arrangements has been the subject of much debate and concern. To understand why we need to consider particular historical and timing factors. The Government's announcement in the Budget last year of an on-line checking system followed an earlier proposal from the Health Insurance Commission for a fully interactive system involving two-way transmission of information and uncertainties about whether data from the Medicare and PBS programs would be kept separate. In addition the precise nature of the information to be provided to pharmacists on-line was not then fully specified.

The announcement was also contemporaneous with others involving the use of data-matching and Tax File Number collection and although these were for different programs and purposes there was some understandable early confusion.
All that is behind us now, I am pleased to say.
We now know that the status information is tightly defined and limited and that it will go only one way, from the HIC to the pharmacist.

We know that the information to be provided by the Departments of Social Security and Veterans' Affairs to the HIC will be similarly tightly defined and limited and will certainly not contain Tax File Number information.

And through the constructive and detailed involvement of the Privacy Commissioner it has been decided that guidelines will be developed to ensure that improper entry into the HIC's data base will be made impossible; such guidelines to be agreed between HIC and the Privacy Commissioner under section 27 of the Privacy Act.

The Privacy Commissioner and the HIC will also review and, if necessary, strengthen and make more specific, procedures within the HIC for maintaining the functional separation of Medicare claims and PBS claims data.

As to the area of particular concern to some patients; the in-pharmacy interaction between pharmacists and their patients about eligibility matters, The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has accepted the recommendation of the Privacy Commissioner that there should be a set of standards developed between his office and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia for inclusion in the pharmacists' professional code of conduct.

The final provisions of the Bill will require all pharmacists to submit their claims for reimbursement to the Commission electronically. This is just the final step in the introduction of this most desirable change.

No one could claim that the Government has not foreshadowed that it has wanted to introduce this measure. We first introduced electronic transfers of claims in 1986 with an incentive payment to encourage participation. This scheme was very successful and over 50 per cent of pharmacists took up the offer. The numbers of pharmacists transmitting claims data via the Claims Transmission System (CTS) has continued to grow even though pharmacists joining the System since late 1988 have not been eligible for incentive payments.

But not all pharmacists have taken up the system. This is perhaps understandable in some cases where the pharmacist was waiting for and has now applied for the amalgamation or closure packages presently available and such pharmacists are excluded from these provisions. Clearly those pharmacists who are already receiving additional support under the PBS because of isolation will not be required to join the CTS and the Bill makes provision for those pharmacists for whom it is impractical because of power supplies or line difficulties to be connected to the CTS to make application to the Secretary of the Department of Community Services and Health for an exemption because of their circumstances.

Furthermore the Government has, in a package of measures aimed at assisting with the completion of universality of this system, agreed to a payment of $1000 to each pharmacist joining the CTS to assist with the initial cost and payments of $250 to assist those pharmacists who may need to upgrade their computer facilities.
Pharmacists currently submitting manual claims will further gain through shorter payment times and the increased accuracy the system offers.
It is estimated that prevention of the free flow of drugs to destinations overseas and to those not eligible here in Australia will save the community $6 million in a full year.
Eligibility testing is estimated to save in the order of $12 million in 1991/92, $34 million in 1992/93 and $40 million each year thereafter.
Expenditure will amount to $12.7 million in 1991-92, $14.8 million in 1992/93, $13.7 million in 1993/94 and $14.2 million in 1994/95.
The extension of the CTS to all pharmacists will save the Government a further $6 million in a full year.
These reforms underscore the Government's commitment to responsible financial management while maintaining the protection this Scheme offers.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That the Quarantine Amendment Bill 1991 and the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Telecommunications Bill 1991 and related Bills on telecommunications issues which we have before us this morning are very important pieces of legislation. This legislation package could greatly advance Australia's economic recovery and will affect every one of us in a very great way. Telecommunications is the very foundation of our Australian way of life in the late twentieth century and without telecommunications, the business, government and social fabric of this country would grind to a halt. But it has been widely recognised, both within and outside the industry, that our telecommunications industry, to become internationally competitive and to keep up with the rapid technological changes which are taking place, requires urgent and extensive reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition-the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia-supported the Government's initial tentative moves in this direction in 1989 when it introduced the Australian Telecommunications Bill, although, quite justifiably, we criticised its limitations which were evident even then. We will be supporting in principle this package of telecommunications legislation which has been introduced in 1991, with the exception of the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporations Bill 1991, which brings about a merger of Telecom and OTC Ltd and sets up a new regulatory regime. I will elaborate the reasons for our not supporting that later.

At the outset, I stress that these Bills are a step in the right direction, a step forward that we in the coalition have been advocating for a long time. The primary Telecommunications Bill provides for network competition and full competition in all other services, the licensing of the general and mobile telecommunications service providers, access rights of licence holders to networks and services of other licensees, a scheme of payment by the carriers for universal obligations and an enhanced role for Austel-the Australian Telecommunications Authority.

As usual, the Government has not gone far enough. It has not the fortitude to make any decisions which are necessary to put this country back on the rails but which might be a bit difficult or unpleasant because they involve stepping on the toes of its union mates. The only so-called difficult decisions this Government has made are those which, although making it unpopular with some sections of the community, are not detrimental to its masters in the trade unions.

These Bills being debated today reflect the dead hand of the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association. That is why the Government has neither the courage to make the telecommunications industry truly competitive nor the inclination to ensure that its capital base is secured with a sound commercial structure. Instead, the Government is creating a one-sided duopoly, whose regulator, Austel Pty Ltd, remains firmly under government control.

These Bills are really nothing more than a cobbled together bundle of legislation that is yet another example of this Government's incompetence, ineptitude and hypocrisy. When it is not too busy squabbling over its leadership, this Labor Government spends its time trying to appease its union mates. The introduction of these Bills presents a unique opportunity for Australia to become a world leader in telecommunications, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region, but their structure is such that the new telecommunications organisation, Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation (AOTC), which will emerge from this legislation, will be badly hampered by the lack of realistic competition, flexibility and capital input and will indeed suffer severe capital shortfall because of the proposed merger fee that Telecom will be forced to pay.

There is no doubt that telecommunications must be the fastest growing and most rapidly changing industry in the world today. It is essential that the Australian telecommunications industry is given both the opportunity and the ability to keep up with the globalisation of telecommunications that is taking place. It cannot afford to be hampered by outmoded and short-sighted legislation which has suffered because its architects were playing politics amongst themselves rather than looking to the national interests.

Australia already has a good reputation in this field and is uniquely positioned to expand into the Asian market. The Asia-Pacific region, although a fast growing industrial community, is nevertheless underdeveloped in its telecommunications structure. To illustrate this, it is interesting to note that in Australia there is one telecommunications line for every two people. New Zealand and Japan reflect a similar figure. But in Indonesia there is only one line for 200 people and in China it is only one line for 500 people. When one considers the huge populations of those countries, some 175 million in Indonesia and 1.1 billion in China, it is possible to see the vast opportunities that await the industry there, as their economies grow and demand for telecommunications facilities multiplies. Not only are we geographically well placed to expand into this region, but we also have much of the technology needed to do so.

As I said, telecommunications is changing rapidly. To keep pace with those technological changes, enormous amounts of capital outlay will be required. However, the structure of the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Bill 1991 is such that the new corporation will be denied the flexibility to cope with twenty-first century technology.

Let us look first at the question of competition-or rather the lack of it-which the Government is attempting to introduce in this legislation. It has always been the philosophical political base of those on our side of the chamber that free market forces are the best way to achieve economic efficiencies. Even the Australian Labor Party has come, albeit belatedly and reluctantly, to adopt this view, although, I might add, on a very selective basis. It was for this reason that the Labor Government finally decided to dismantle the airline duopoly which existed up until October last year.

The Government realised that a duopoly does not create true competition. We ended up with a two-airline scenario where timetables and fares were identical and the travelling public had no real choice. Yet here we have the Government proposing just such a duopoly for our telecommunications industry, except that even that will be a very one-sided duopoly. One of the players, AOTC, will be a giant corporation with certain vital advantages over its competitor, the new duopolist. The new competitor will have to purchase the debt-ridden Aussat to be in the running and it will have to purchase its core delivery services from its competitor, AOTC, which will have delivery rights as well as distribution rights.

That seems to me to be a very unbalanced situation. It is unreasonable, I believe, to assume that there will be any leeway for real competition in such a structure. It falls far short of the micro-economic reform which this Government claims to be striving to achieve. It certainly did not happen with the two-airline agreement and I cannot see how it will possibly happen in this instance.

The proposed duopoly will be established by licence under ministerial negotiation. The licence will guarantee that there will be no other competition beyond the duopoly until 1997-a period of some five or more years. At the same time, many of the details, such as the licence conditions, definition of basic carriage services, the fees for interconnection services, environmental protection provisions, and even the fee that Telecom will be obliged to pay for the purchase of OTC, are not highlighted in this legislation. Rather, they are to be decided by ministerial discretion and regulation, after the legislation is passed.

We in the Opposition are very concerned about the lack of true competition, and we give notice that when we win government-as we most assuredly will after the next election-we will open up this duopoly to further competition before 1997. We will not feel compelled to pay any compensation for the changes that we initiate. So, we put firmly on notice now for any potential bidder wishing to be involved in this duopoly, that when we come to office it will in fact be open competition that we will introduce.

I should add that any change to the duopoly by a coalition government will be undertaken only after consultation with the duopolists and there will be no unilateral negation by legislation of existing agreements. The coalition is committed, as part of its program to achieve full and effective competition, to the privatisation of Telecom. Privatisation will ensure that AOTC has the ability to raise the additional capital it will need to accommodate the technological changes it will be required to make.

Telecom, by its own admission in a submission to the Department of Finance last month, is in financial strife; a liquidity squeeze is, I believe, the expression that Telecom used. This was part of the rationale given for an increase in local telephone charges announced recently. If one does not believe what Telecom itself has said, one has only to look at its debt equity position to realise its precarious position.

Compared to other major players in international telecommunications, Telecom Australia fares badly. Its debt ratio figure is 53 per cent. The debt ratio figure for British Telecom, by comparison, which is often touted as an example, is only 36 per cent. The figure for Bell Canada is 40 per cent; Bell South, 39 per cent; Telecom New Zealand, 32 per cent; and the figure for Cable and Wireless from the United Kingdom is a low 23 per cent. By comparison, the newly merged Telecom-OTC, as a result of this legislation, will have a debt ratio figure of 51 per cent, which is only slightly better than the figure for the existing Telecom.

If that is not enough, we should look at another financial indicator, and I refer to interest rate cover comparisons; that is, the profit before interest and income tax expense divided by the total interest. For Telecom Australia, the figure is a dangerously low 2, compared to Telecom New Zealand's 3.2, Bell South's 4.2, British Telecom's 6.6, and the figure of 7.4 for Cable and Wireless. Again, the new structure, at 2.4, will be only marginally better than the existing Telecom.

By both measures, Telecom and its successor compare unfavourably with its international competitors and both its debt ratio and interest cover must be improved if it is to compete successfully internationally. However, to give credit where it is due, the Government has to some extent recognised this and has converted some of Telecom's debt to equity-about $1,088m worth. But as usual, and as is typical of this Government, it simply does not go far enough. With its proposal to impose a fee of $1 billion to $1.5 billion on Telecom for the purchase of OTC, in effect, it is taking back with one hand what it has given with the other. Not only is Telecom's ability to raise further funds severely hampered with this sort of balance sheet but its immediate capital assets will be severely depleted if it has to pay this merger fee.

Despite a healthy cash flow, Telecom has to invest in an enormous capital expenditure program if it is to avoid being left behind in the telecommunications industry. This present Hawke Labor Government has indicated it is not prepared to put extra money into Telecom. The coalition is not suggesting for one moment that it should be up to the hard-pressed Australian taxpayers to bail out yet another struggling Government institution. Telecom is also constrained from raising further loans because it is subject to Loan Council ceilings. The only way left for Telecom to raise extra funds is from private investment and that means privatisation.

The major flaws in this legislation are the failure to provide for the present and future capital needs of AOTC and the restriction of the provision for future privatisation. But, of course, this Labor Government is not prepared to privatise Telecom because its union mates and, in particular, the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association (ATEA), are ideologically opposed to it. They are opposed to privatisation because they are afraid of having to compete in the marketplace outside the protection of a public sector monopoly.

If Telecom is not provided with additional funding to enable it to capitalise on the opportunities now before it, it is destined to become moribund and that will mean job losses both for ATEA members and for unions in a host of associated industries. It could well be that the ultimate effect of the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Bill will be the negation of gains in micro-economic reform, limited as they are, that have been made in the parent Bill, the Telecommunications Bill.

The air of uncertainty enveloping this legislation is a minefield for every individual concerned with technology. This atmosphere is not helped by the fact that Austel, as the industry regulator, will remain under Government control and will be subject to ministerial direction. It remains a matter of great concern to us in the Opposition that Austel will be acting as an instrument of government rather than as an independent arbitrator. We are concerned, for example, that the fees for the interconnect service will be set by Austel, outside the legislation itself, at a level that suits government revenue raising requirements rather than at realistic market rates based on cost efficiency.

We would not like to see the fee structure used as a means to indefinitely prop up an inefficient competitor. The fees charged should ultimately be a matter of negotiation between the parties directly concerned. The coalition would prefer to see Austel making full and complete reports to the Parliament rather than to an individual Minister. Austel must have the mettle to be effective and it must not allow any carrier to ride roughshod over it, as Telecom has been known to do in the past. It is essential that Austel be allowed to carry out its competitive charter and for that reason its independence is a matter of vital importance. There is too much detail which is unspecified and which is left to the discretion of the Minister.

As well as the matter of interconnect fees, there is the Minister's discretion with regard to the granting of licences. The Minister is empowered to make a decision to grant or refuse a licence without explanation. The Minister may also make a written agreement with a carrier that will provide for the payment of compensation by the Commonwealth if it should contravene the agreement. There are far too many grey areas and far too many questions requiring answers, some of which I have already touched upon, such as questions regarding the licensing provisions, definitions of service and details of fees to be charged.

But what about the proposal for pay television on which the Government also seems to be unable to reach a decision? What about the third mobile licence? When will that eventuate? It is the coalition's view that the issuing of a licence for a third mobile carrier is a matter of utmost priority. The advent of mobile telephones is perhaps one of the most popular if not the fastest growth area in telecommunications. The demand for mobile telephones is escalating and costs are coming down.

I contend, and I am certainly not alone in this belief, that the humble telephone connected to a wall socket will be a thing of the past in just a few years. As the convenience of being able to be reached at any time in any place becomes an accepted part of life, the demand for mobile telephones will exceed supply if networks are not expanded. It is irrelevant whether they are regional licences or just one national licence; the fact remains that there must be greater scope for expansion with an additional mobile telephone network.

I am also concerned about the consideration of consumer interests. The coalition believes that Austel should have stronger direction to protect the public interest. On the question of timed local calls, the definition of a business is not sufficiently clear. I am particularly concerned about rural customers. I am not criticising the present service by Telecom to the rural sector, but I am gravely concerned that new provisions after 1993 for delivery of the carrier service to the first telephone socket or the first main distribution frame on a property will severely disadvantage isolated properties. It could make installation fees for a new service on large rural properties prohibitive. We cannot avoid community service obligations, but the provision of community services must be specifically highlighted and their costs fairly apportioned.

I have outlined in some detail the areas of the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Bill which are causing me concern and which I am unable to support. All of the amendments which the Opposition will be moving at the second reading and committee stages, and which I heartily support, seek to redress at least some of the imbalances and inefficiencies inherent in the legislation. In line with our stated policy for the achievement of full and effective com- petition, our amendments will move to allow open competition earlier than is provided in the Government's legislation. Our amendments condemn the structure of the Bill as not meeting the intent of greater competition and privatisation. They delete the clause which limits the ability of the Government to sell shares in AOTC. They reject the concept of a merger fee. They require the tabling of financial statements and a memorandum and articles of association prior to commencement and they criticise AOTC's capital structure.

I have already explained why the Opposition is moving these amendments, and I just remind honourable senators that if these amendments are not supported we will be left with a scrabble bag of legislation which falls far short of meeting even the Government's stated aims of making our telecommunications industry truly competitive. We will end up with a government owned and controlled megastructure, the capital base of which will be sadly depleted and which will be unable to fund the ongoing modernisation which is so vital to Australia's participation in the globalisation of telecommunications. It will mean yet another missed opportunity for Australia, an opportunity that favourably awaits us if only we have the will and the vision to utilise it.

I repeat that this legislation is a valuable chance for Australia to build the foundations of a new export industry which could make a significant contribution to our economic salvation. To permit this legislation passage in its present form would be a great tragedy for this industry. We would be failing in our duty as an opposition if we were to allow this Government to take the money and run and, in so doing, to fall short of its obligations to achieve micro-economic reform. As I said, while the Opposition will not be opposing this Bill in the second reading stage, it will certainly be moving an amendment in that stage and significant amendments in the committee stage. I wholeheartedly support and commend the amendments which we will be moving and I urge the Senate to wholeheartedly support them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly to the Telecommunications Bill and allied Bills and not canvass the matters that have already been canvassed thus far. The Bills as they are presented to us are an attempt to reflect the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) late last year that it was the decision of the Government to promote competition and dynamism in the telecommunications industry; to guarantee community service obligations in telecommunications; to maintain quality of telecommunications services; to maintain Telecom Australia and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission in full public ownership; and to maintain maximum possible Australian ownership in the industry to ensure the effective regulation and to remove from Telecom and OTC all government imposed constraints which limit their ability to respond effectively to competition and which do not serve the broader national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of those particular objectives, many of them, or perhaps all of them, are unexceptionable. I am not too sure, however, that the Bill takes full cognisance of those principles in some respects. Most speakers have indicated the enormous effect that the telecommunications industry has on the general public and will have on the daily lives of individuals. It already has a considerable influence on individuals, and of course that influence will grow over the years to come.

If that is the case, if that is accepted all round the chamber, the question must be asked as to why one area is not specifically attended to in this legislation. That area impinges on the principle contained in the statement of the Prime Minister and the Minister-that is, that the policy should guarantee community service obligations in telecommunications, that it should serve the broader national interests and that it should protect the consumer. Therefore, why are there not specific provisions in this legislation that will deal with a code of practice to be observed by Telecom and OTC and the other player in the game-in other words, the two carriers.

I refer to widespread community concerns about the material content now provided by service providers through Telecom lines in the areas of computer pornography and 0055 services. There has been a great deal of debate in this chamber, and more particularly in the community, about the nature of these services and whether they are appropriate-whether it is appropriate that carriers such as Telecom and now the other carrier should be used as agents for material which is exploitative of women, harmful to those receiving it and, irrespective of what people say, not able to be kept from particularly the young and immature in our community.

This matter had been considered by Telecom. Telecom in fact had contracts with service providers which were quite specific. Those contracts with service providers established certain message standards. I quote from 0055 operational requirements, which is an attachment to the contract with the service providers. It says:
Standard 1.1
(a) This standard has been prepared with regard to the following principle:-
That all persons calling any 0055 Information Service are entitled to protection from exposure to messages of an indecent, obscene or sexually suggestive nature.

The Service Provider will not provide ``knowingly or negligently'' on any 0055 number allocated to it, any information which in any way may be interpreted as indecent, obscene, offensive or sexually titillating or denoting sexual suggestion or sexual fantasy.

So it goes on. These are the attachments to the agreements made between Telecom and the service providers. However, because of certain amendments to legislation which occurred in 1989 and which took out some of the provisions of the 1975 legislation, there is some doubt as to whether the requirements under those agreements can be enforced. Frankly, it is important to put that well beyond doubt. It is also important to tackle the question of computer porn, which is again extremely exploitative of women, and it is certainly not in the public interest that the communications services of the carriers, whether Telecom, OTC or the other carrier, be used by the `sexploitagents' to make a fast buck.

The question arises: what should be done about this? Clearly, it would be in the public interest, in the interests of those large numbers of people who have petitioned this Parliament and who are concerned about this question, and indeed in the interests of Telecom and OTC, that this matter be dealt with by Austel. The rationale for placing the code of practice in the Telecommunications Bill and class licence conditions is clear. The regulation of content standards of 0055 recorded services and other entertainment services should lie with Austel and not be left to the two carriers to negotiate with service providers.

The two carriers should have equal responsibilities. Telecom should not have a more onerous responsibility in this particular respect than the second carrier. If only Telecom is required to have content standards, what of the second carrier? Clearly, this is a matter that should be the function of Austel, which is the regulatory body. The Telecommunications Bill gives Austel the responsibility and power to include various conditions in class licences under Part 10 of the current legislation, Division 3, and to include other conditions that it considers are necessary or desirable to achieve the objects of Part 10.

As I understand it, class licences are the types of licences which would be issued to service providers to provide 0055 recorded services and other entertainment services. Placing the code of practice in legislation and under the control of Austel rather than placing it in a contract between the carriers and service providers avoids any problems or doubts as to whether the carriers could enforce such a code against the service providers. It also covers the situation as to how the new carrier, the new player in the field, should operate. Indeed, it upholds the principle of the interests of the public which, of course, this Parliament should uphold.

I do not want to go into the lurid details of the material that is currently, or proposed to be, sent through the telecommunications lines by particular sexploit entrepreneurs. Suffice it to say that unless we deal with this subject now whilst we can, it will be too late. We have the opportunity here and now to deal with the matter whilst we have this legislation before us. I believe it is consistent with the principles that were enunciated by the Government in 1990, and with the view generally expressed around the chamber, that whilst there should be competition, there should not be a situation where one particular carrier, namely Telecom, is placed at a significant disadvantage or advantage-whatever the case may be-in respect of a matter such as this.

We are talking about matters of principle-a code of practice which should be observed by both carriers. I have requested that amendments be drawn so as to reflect that principle. Those amendments are currently being drawn. The first part of the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition condemns the Government's failure to allow reasonable time for consideration of the measure. To the extent that we have only received this legislation in this chamber this week, I agree with that, although I understand that an exposure draft has been around for some time. I must admit that either I did not get that exposure draft or I have not focused on it, but whichever it is, we have a problem now. Our problem is that not only my amendments, but also some other amendments, are not ready to be distributed in the chamber.

I hope that, after the second reading stage, the Government will postpone consideration of this Bill to a later hour this day-or, indeed, until the next sitting week-so that detailed work can be undertaken on the amendments and they can be properly before the chamber. I ask the Government to consider postponing consideration of this Bill until the next sitting week, or have it go to the usual committee stage tomorrow. In either case, I will do my utmost to get the amendments to the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on only one aspect-albeit a very important aspect-of this package of telecommunications Bills, that is, the environmental consequences of these Bills. The background to what I wish to say I think is best summarised in a High Court of Australia decision which was given last year in relation to the powers which the Commonwealth may or may not exercise concerning environmental protection. The High Court found in the Brophy case that the many pieces of Federal legislation did not specify whether the Commonwealth was bound with respect to environmental protection. But, nonetheless, it ruled on the generality of the principle that, if the Parliament had seen fit to legislate to bind persons, including corporations, in the general community, it was reasonable to assume that the Commonwealth would also be bound by the same provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many pieces of Federal legislation which are silent on the question of whether the environmental provisions shall or shall not apply. The application of both Federal and State laws in relation to the protection of the environment has been specifically written out of this major package of legislation. In its place there is a weak and rather befuddled attempt to put in place a code of practice. That is really the crux of what I wish to speak about.

When this package first emerged I signalled to the electorate and, of course, to the Government and the Opposition that the Australian Democrats were very concerned about this exclusion from the applicability of State and Federal law in relation to environmental protection. Subsequently, when the package of Bills came into the House of Representatives, Mr Chaney, the shadow Minister for the environment, had a great deal to say about this. Whether he became aware of that independently or whether my earlier media comments signalled to him that this was an area of concern, I do not know.

I would like to begin by quoting extensively from what Mr Chaney had to say in the House of Representatives in relation to these exclusions because I think it is particularly important that the Opposition in the Senate, members of which have so far been remarkably silent on these important provisions, may take note of what its shadow Minister said. Amongst other things, Mr Chaney said:
I simply wish to focus on some of the . . . environmental concerns.
I want to use this opportunity to draw attention to the issues of principle which I think are raised . . .
. . . The Minister referred . . . to the question of powers and immunities and pointed out:
. . . the general carriers will continue to have Telecom's existing powers in relation to land.
Telecom's total immunity from suit under the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Act 1989, has been removed but Austel has been given the power to limit the carriers' tort liability.

I would say . . . that the Opposition welcomes the removal of that total immunity. I think that immunity should be given only where it is absolutely essential. There is no reason why governments or corporations should operate free from the law of the land that binds all other citizens.
There Mr Chaney enunciated precisely the principle which lies behind what I wish to say this morning and which lies behind some of the amendments which we wish to move. He went on:
. . . network related activities are exempt from State and Territory laws, and the carrier will be able to engage in those activities, despite any State or Territory law.
There he referred specifically to environmentally damaging activities. He continued:

I think the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) is on record as saying that she and the Government support the application of the toughest pollution standards. I think that in those circumstances it is appropriate that the Parliament should very carefully examine any legislation that potentially provides exemption from pollution standards which are applied to other citizens and to corporations by the laws of the States, which have the primary constitutional responsibility in this area.

As I will show later, we have discovered a major loophole in this legislation which would not have allowed the application of a code of practice with respect to Commonwealth law-specifically, the environmental impact proposals legislation. Mr Chaney went on:

The Minister may recall that, with respect to the government instrumentalities legislation which the Government brought down some time ago but which it has since withdrawn, the Opposition objected to the proposition that there should be a general exemption from the application of State laws, with the State law being applied only if it was specifically brought back in.
In other words, Mr Chaney was adducing a more general principle which should apply to Federal law, not just to the package with which we are dealing this morning. He further went on to say:
When one looks at clause 116, one finds a very broad potential exemption indeed. That provides:
The regulations may provide that specified carriers may engage in specified exempt activities:
(a) despite specified laws of a State or Territory; or
(b) despite any law of a State or Territory.

Indeed, we have under this clause a power, by regulation, to exempt in a very broad sense, from any law at all, the corporations which will be operating under this group of Bills. That is the first issue which I would wish to raise with the Government . . .
I emphasise that for the benefit of the few Opposition senators who are in the chamber. Mr Chaney went on to say:

In the view of the Opposition . . . it would be desirable for the regulation making power to be structured or delineated by giving a broad generic description of the types of matters which could properly be considered as exempt activities, rather than simply having a total freedom to exempt from the operation of any law. That is not unreasonable . . . It would seem to me, at least as a starting point, that we should not have an exemption provision which is any wider than the subjects which are covered in the national code in clause 117 . . . Why is it that we have this unlimited power to exempt? Why can the Government not provide for some delineation, some classification, of the laws to which clause 116 would apply?
The second concern which I raise with the Government is that it is provided in clause 117 that the national code which can be put in place is to have the status of disallowable instrument.

Mr Chaney then went on to explain that, as all honourable senators would know, disallowable instruments can merely be allowed or disallowed. They do not allow for public participation in their formulation, nor do they allow for amendment. He continued:

The third point of concern that I raise with the Government is that the obligations to comply with the national code do not seem to be enforced in any serious way. There do not appear to me to be any serious provisions relating to compliance with the code, or rather to non-compliance with the code. I have not been able to find any application of monetary penalties or any provisions for judicial review for acting beyond power, any provisions for civil liability or, indeed, anything else.
Further on in the same speech he said:

I understand that there is in existence . . . what is described as a memorandum of understanding between the Australian Telecommunications Corporation and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories concerning the application of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. This document was entered into in 1989.
As I will show later on, we have discovered a major flaw which indicates that the application of that legislation could not be made applicable under this package of Bills. Mr Chaney went on to say:

. . . we . . . find that most of what I might call the broad acre or external activities of the Corporation under the existing memorandum of understanding are subject to the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.
That is simply untrue. He continued:
In those circumstances, it seems unnecessary for this legislation to provide an exemption of the breadth that has been granted.
He concluded that section of his speech by saying that:

It seems to me that that memorandum of understanding represents a pretty reasonable approach to achieving a balance between the commercial requirements of the Telecommunications Corporation and the environmental concerns, which are the concerns of the Opposition . . .

While other bits and pieces in Mr Chaney's speech are relevant, I have established the point that Mr Chaney, at least in terms of what he said, was expressing very considerable doubts about the sense and the good environmental management practice which lies behind a package of legislation which excludes from the new telecommunications carriers the application of both Federal laws, specifically the environmental impact proposals legislation, and, in a very broad and general sense, the application of a plethora of State planning, zoning and environmental protection laws. In answer to the queries raised by Mr Chaney in his speech in the House of Representatives, the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, wrote to Mr Chaney and made a number of points, some of which, as I will show, are frankly incorrect. In his letter, Mr Beazley said, among other things:
First, it is only possible for a Government to regulate in respect of ``exempt activities'' which the carriers engage in. ``Exempt activities'' are defined in clause 5.

Unfortunately, for the Government, while the general definition is given in clause 5, the definition of `exempt activities' is further defined and qualified in clause 116. Clause 116 effectively excludes the application of the environmental impact proposals legislation with respect to the code of practice.
The Minister goes on-and this is rather disingenuous and, I believe, naughty of the Minister:
Second, as you noted in your comments, the approach in clause 116 means that there can be no exemption from State laws without regulations being made.
It is certainly true that the exemption is made by way of regulation, but the implication is that environmental protection is also picked up by that mechanism. That is also unsatisfactory.

The Minister confirms the concerns expressed by Mr Chaney and certainly shared by the Democrats that, in relation to Austel's supervision of environmental protection, Austel can do certain things, not once a breach had occurred but once a breach had occurred and the carrier had been warned to correct the breach and had subsequently failed to do so. The Minister confirms that clause 119 says:
AUSTEL can give the carrier a specific direction . . .
Not that Austel must give the carrier a specific direction when it is in breach of an environmental provision. This whole process is well beyond the reach of any public intervention.
Finally, I again quote from the Minister's letter, which says, among other things:
I can assure you that it is the Government's intention-
I think there is a word missing here-
will be subject to the EP(IP) Act-
that is, the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act-
until the Code has been developed and is in place.
I again stress that, as we have discovered, that is simply untrue because of the way this legislation has been worded.

I turn from those two letters to make some general remarks about the environmental exclusion clauses of the legislation. When we first began analysing this legislation, we were quite aghast at the exemptions from the environmental laws of the Commonwealth, States and Territories that were contained in it. Some of our most significant concerns have been addressed by the Government, which has indicated its acceptance of some amendments. But other concerns about the provisions of these Bills have not drawn a satisfactory response from the Minister. More generally, we remain dismayed that some of the provisions in these Bills were included in the first place. That is the first point I would like to establish.

Following the High Court decision to which I referred in my opening remarks, it seems to us that the Government is embarking quite deliberately on a process of excluding the Commonwealth from responsibility under Commonwealth and State environmental protection laws and in its place is setting, presumably with respect to the operation of every department, something like a code of practice. That will become an incredibly messy and totally unsatisfactory way of doing business. I can do no better than reflect the words of Mr Chaney when he said that if the Parliament sees fit to impose provisions for environmental protection on all other persons and corporations, it should be appropriate that those provisions are also imposed on the Commonwealth.

Yesterday, we received legal advice confirming our analysis that this legislation completely excluded the Federal environment Minister and her or his Department from any role in the assessment of the environmental impact of proposed activities of telecommunications carriers by exempting the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation from the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. Quite simply, that has come about because the exemptions with respect to State law are picked up by way of the code of practice. But the wording in the Bills before us fails to adequately pick up that latter piece of legislation. So under this legislation there is no way that that can be invoked.

Interestingly, that major flaw was discovered in my office by Richard Bolt, to whom I pay a considerable compliment for closely analysing this legislation. It is perhaps a mark of the inevitable failure of adequately supervising legislation-when we are faced with a large number of Bills jammed up late in the session, being pushed through the Parliament and not being properly supervised-that even the legal advisers who presumably frame this legislation make these quite major errors. Having picked this up, Richard Bolt referred it to Mr Rob Fowler, a long time lecturer in environmental law in the law faculty of Adelaide University, who confirmed this defect. If it is possible for people like that to read through legislation and pick up these defects, it again makes one worry about the adequacy of supervision in relation to the framing of legislation or the care being shown by the Government with respect to environmental protection. It may indicate laxity in either or both those respects.

This defect would have set an extraordinary and dangerous precedent for environmental impact assessment in Australia. This is despite the fact that no-one is under any illusion that the assessment procedures under the Environmental Impact Act are inadequate; they are not. Indeed, the Democrats have been calling for them to be strengthened for years. My predecessor as the Democrats environment spokesperson, former senator Norm Sanders, tried unsuccessfully to amend the Act to strengthen the independence and transparency of the process. He later exposed the total inadequacy of the preliminary draft environmental impact statement (EIS) for the proposed development of naval facilities at Jervis Bay.

But for all its faults, the EIS process is all we have at this stage. It does provide the public and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism, and Territories some oversight of the development proposals. It can provide a brake on the most undesirable of those proposals.

It is distressing to find that apparently Minister Kelly has quite willingly virtually written herself out of this legislation. That again does not indicate a Minister who is particularly careful with respect to properly discharging her responsibility to care for the environment. The Minister for Transport and Communications has agreed to remove the exemption from this Act, but we cannot comprehend how it got there in the first place. The Minister's office and Department did not administer the environment impact Act and they do not understand how it works. The environment Minister's office and Department does administer the Act. It is one of the most important Federal environment laws, yet Mrs Kelly apparently approved this exemption without any qualms. This is incomprehensible and a fundamental failure of the Minister's responsibilities.

This is an appropriate time to call for a thorough overhaul of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, to ensure that the proposed environmental protection agency has a strong set of environmental impact assessment procedures to work with. In contemplating the establishment of an environmental protection agency, or authority-I am not too sure what it will be called in Australia-similar to what has been established in the United States federally and in some States of Australia, which presumably will have some general oversight in regard to the establishment of appropriate standards, it is somewhat peculiar that the Federal Government should at this time choose to write the application of Federal and State law out of this legislation and put in place a code of practice that is to be supervised by an organisation like Austel, which on the Minister's own admission will not have the legislative power, competence, or indeed the environmental expertise to judge these matters that are put under its control.

The Telecommunications Bill 1991 narrows the exemption from State or Territory laws which Telecom now enjoys. The Minister can only exempt certain activities from those laws, by regulation. The Democrats believe that no such power should be available. We believe that there should be the application of State laws to these bodies, and we can point to numerous instances where, in the recent past, Telecom with its existing exemptions has engaged in activities that are contrary to State planning, zoning and environmental protection laws. This has caused very considerable disquiet in the local communities and there has been no legislative mechanism properly to correct or to supervise those activities.
