The Democrats believe that no such power should be available, but we recognise that our view will not prevail. Contrary to all the nice words that the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) put down in his speech, we have been led to believe that the Opposition will not carry through with its expressed concerns and will not support us on making those State laws applicable. We believe that, at the very least, there should be no exemption from environmental, cultural heritage and Aboriginal laws, and we will move amendments to that effect during the committee stage.

As I have indicated, the Bill proposes a national code to provide a regulatory framework for those activities that are exempted from State or Territory laws. We have serious reservations about this code. We have not even seen the code, and yet we have been enjoined by the Government in bringing forward this legislation to support it, with simply a promise that the code would be put in place. If the Government was serious about environmental protection, surely it could have brought forward the code at the time when it brought in the legislation that contains these exclusions.

I acknowledge that the code has the potential to have stronger environmental protection provisions than the existing State and Territory legal regime, but the likely outcome is a lowest common denominator code that is weaker than it should be. There is an important point in that, that if the Federal Government is going to legislate by way of introducing a code under regulations, which is stronger, then no harm is done by leaving in place the existing and, by implication, weaker protective measures. The Constitution is quite clear that, if one piece of Federal legislation contains provisions that exceed those of the States, then the law of the Commonwealth shall prevail. Again, one finds a great logical difficulty in accepting the Government's argument that it wants to write out these provisions and then to include them by way of a code of practice-which it protests may be even stronger than what we have in place at the present time. There is an inconsistency in that argument.

There are also practical difficulties. The code will rapidly become an unwieldy instrument, if it seeks to incorporate adequate environmental impact assessment procedures. The task of developing the code is going to be tortuous, and the Minister's Department has no real idea of what it will end up looking like. Again, I point to the multitude of environmental protection laws that are present in the States, and if the Government is going to proceed down this sort of road with respect to every one of its instrumentalities, exclude them and then write in codes of practice, it seems to us that it will finish up with a very messy and unwieldy set of environmental protection measures which, simply because of their complexity, will probably be full of loopholes. So it poses a great danger for the Commonwealth to go down that road. It would be far better to substantially strengthen the legislation that is already in place.

The Democrats accept that, unfortunately, the code will become a reality, so we will move amendments to give the public a role in its development and enforcement. I simply put on the record here that we have gained the support of both the Government and the Opposition in relation to our proposal for a public inquiry once the draft code has been released. We welcome that provision because it is absolutely appropriate in an area in which the technology is rapidly changing, and many of the potential environmental impacts of this technology cannot even be foreseen, looking only a few years into the future. The widest public consultation must occur and that consultation must have a very significant impact on the drafting of the code of practice.

In summary, the Democrats have very serious concerns about the general direction in which the Government is going, as evidenced by this legislation: excluding Government instrumentalities from the application of existing environmental protection law and relying instead on a code of practice. We believe, as the honourable member for Pearce himself has said, that, where the Commonwealth has legislated for environmental protection and imposed those conditions on other persons, on other corporations, it should seek to observe those same conditions itself. If it seeks stronger provisions, such provisions should apply uniformly to everybody and not exclusively to one person or corporation. This may be the first of many Bills of this ilk, although we hope that that is not the case. However, if it is, we will be expressing reservations in respect of any other such Bills that appear before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the Telecommunications Bill 1991 and allied Bills, which constitute a major package of reform from the Labor Government. I have been involved in these proposals as a member of the Caucus telecommunications working group and as a member of the ministerial advisory committee, established by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley), to advise him and members of the industry about the drafting of the legislation. I want to put on record here my appreciation, as a member of both those committees, of the work of the people who worked on those committees, and particularly the experts who provided us with information, whether from the Department or from the various industry bodies. The ministerial advisory committee had representatives from the full range of the telecommunications industry in Australia and overwhelming unanimity was reached on most of the fundamental issues contained in these Bills. Many of the suggestions that they made were taken up by the Minister and the Government. Having regard to such monumental legislation which is detailed and technical, I think these Bills are as good as we will get.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not doubt that at some time in the near future someone will find an odd clause here or there where there has been an error in drafting and so on. But, in view of the content and nature of these Bills, those hiccups will be small and will not deflect from the major changes that the Government has put to the Parliament with these Bills. Before I deal with a couple of specific things, I wish to comment upon the justification that the Government has made for these changes.

On my part, I have been interested in telecommunications for a long time. In the Whitlam Government I was Principal Private Secretary to the last Postmaster-General in Australia, Senator Bishop, when he put the Bill through parliament to break up the old Postmaster-General's Department into what is now the two corporations. At that stage that was a major change. That change lasted some 16 years until we have before us today these changes. So I have had a genuine interest all of that time.

I believe that the changes in allowing competition in the model before us, which is a duopoly model, is the best for the nature of Australia. I do not support open slather competition because I believe that in an economy the size of Australia-a country with a dispersed population in a continent almost as big as continental America and with only 17 million people compared with 250 million people-one has to adjust one's model of telecommunications to meet the circumstances of Australia. It is absolutely no use comparing ourselves with the model that either the Americans, the Canadians, the British or any other country have adopted because none of them have the peculiar geography and population descriptions that we have.

The proposals before us will mean that we will get the best balance by providing a community service with competition and thereby guaranteeing that all citizens of Australia have access to telecommunications services, which I think is a social right in a modern society. This model also provides for competition, which means that the consumers get some opportunity to make judgments about the sort of service they want under the prices they want.

One thing must be made quite clear: there is no system of telecommunications in the world that is totally and utterly deregulated. No-one proposes that anywhere in the world. It is a unique industry. There has to be a bottom line where the Government says, `These are the rules and the parameters in which this industry will have to work, otherwise sections of the community will miss out'. That is the model that we will have in Australia.

I do not believe anybody, except possibly a very small fringe on the far right of our community, would argue against the need for government monitoring, government regulation, to protect the public interest. This model that the Government has put forward is the best to give ourselves an opportunity to have a telecommunications industry which not only provides the best possible system for Australia but also gives ourselves an opportunity to sell our technical expertise, whether it be in the hardware or software area, or in the services area, to the region of the world where telecommunications has got the biggest growth rate; that is, the Asia-Pacific region.

One expert said, in one of the briefings I had, that between the time when Alexander Graham Bell invented the telephone and the present time some 450 million telephones have been connected in the world. It is estimated that in the next 15 years in the Asia-Pacific region a further 400 million telephones will be connected as those economies grow, with consumers and households wanting to have a telecommunications service. In 15 years we will get a doubling of the number of telephone connections in the world, which has already taken over a century to achieve.

We are best placed as a modern economy to get part of that action, so to speak. I believe that the model before us gives us that opportunity in two ways. Firstly, the merger of the Australian Communications Corporation (Telecom) and OTC Ltd provides us with a public enterprise that is big enough to go out and sell its services and its expertise. Secondly, we have a privately owned competitor and carrier which will also be developing a system and using its expertise in Australia to go out and sell its services to the Asia-Pacific region.

As part of that process of providing the competitive model we will also be able to encourage Australian industry in the manufacturing area and particularly in software and in those service areas which are called intellectual properties and so on, where it is the brain power of people that one sells not the actual hardware. That is where the big profit will be in telecommunications in the future. We will be well placed to develop those subsidiary industries in our own telecommunications industry and to get that benefit and, as I say, to go into that region.

One of the unfortunate aspects of the present system has been that much of the private sector has said, `Telecommunications is left to Telecom. There is nothing for us in it. Telecom has got a monopoly. We are not interested'. By having this competitive model, private enterprise will see that there is an opportunity to become involved in Australia and see opportunities for investment. When one gets further players in the field providing the value-added services, et cetera, that to me means that we can build a base for further export services.

I wish to comment on the remarks made particularly by the Australian Democrats. Senator Kernot, the spokesman for the Democrats on telecommunications, has said there are two areas of these Bills that it has trouble with. One is about the wide level of ministerial discretion given in the Bills to the Minister. I understand the debate in this place at any time about the argument of powers between the Minister, or the Executive, and the powers of the Parliament. The point about what is the best range of balance is always arguable. I am not going to be dogmatic and say that in these Bills we have got it absolutely correct. If the Democrats have legitimate areas to raise where it believes that some of these discretions should be turned from ministerial into parliamentary, then they ought to be looked at.

I want to say to the Democrats: for goodness sake, do not tie down a system in which there is no continuity in regulation and in setting the guidelines where they could always be overturned in parliament because that would be counterproductive to the development of an expanding but stable telecommunications industry. But I take the Democrats' point because in any major legislation it is legitimate for the Parliament to say, `These regulations or these ministerial discretions ought to be under supervision of the Parliament'. But let us make sure that we get the balance right between either side of the argument.

The other area that Senator Kernot raised was the question of the merger of OTC and Telecom and the merger fee. I want to say to the Democrats in particular: do not fall for the line that the Opposition is putting, that it is opposing the merger fee because it thinks that it is some sort of financial rort. The Opposition wants the Democrats to vote against the merger fee and/or the merger itself, because if the merger fails it will be so much easier for the Opposition-if it wins the next election or any subsequent election-to privatise Telecom and OTC separately. Mr Smith, the spokesman for the Liberal Party of Australia in the lower House, has made it quite clear why it opposes the merger fee. The Opposition wants to leave Telecom much better cashed up, to use his words, so that it can be more easily sold off at a higher price. We really have what the Liberal Party is about in opposing the merger and the merger fee.

The Opposition wants to leave as much money in the pot so that it can flog off Telecom at a higher price, in my view, to cover its other promises which are to change the Income Tax Act and to remove the capital gains tax so that the losses in revenue in those areas will be recouped by having a `cashed up', as the Opposition calls it, Telecom to sell off at a higher price.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government wants to starve them of funds.

—Senator Spindler has interjected that we want to starve it of funds. I think that nothing is further from the truth. I want to say that, when we put this proposal forward to merge Telecom and OTC, we are creating an organisation that next year is anticipated to have revenue of about $11 billion, assets of around $20 billion and growth rates in the demand for services and income going up at 10 per cent, 12 per cent or maybe 8 per cent of those of the not so active economies of other countries. Everyone suggests that, by the end of the decade, the merged OTC and Telecom will have revenues of about $25 billion because of the demand for telecommunications services.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the Democrats-if they are in support of private enterprise-that, in merging these two organisations, we will have the biggest public enterprise in the Southern Hemisphere, and it will be the major player in the biggest industry in Australia at the turn of the century. In the year 2000, 25 per cent to 30 per cent of gross domestic product in Australia will be in telecommunications services and information distribution, dominated by a public enterprise-and people say that we are selling out and giving it all to the private sector.

I would suggest-this may be a point that the Opposition disagrees with-that, by the year 2000, a competitor would be lucky to have, at the most, 15 per cent to 20 per cent of the telecommunications services market. Those are the figures of the potential competitors. They do not expect to take over three-quarters of Telecom's business, but they want to get into areas that will be profitable to them. In effect, they accept the fact that Telecom, merged with OTC, will be the dominant player and will set the standard for Australian telecommunications.

The Democrats seem to be concerned about the financial structure. There are arguments about this, and I do not disagree. My friends in Telecom have been knocking on my door for two or three years complaining that they should have more access to public borrowings, and more access to Loan Council moneys. I point out that the recent decision by the Australian Government has meant that, for this coming financial year, Telecom has basically got what it wanted. It will have loan money available, through the Loan Council, of over $600m. It has got all that it basically sought and that, plus its own internally generated profit which will be able to be reinvested, will give it an investment program of several billion dollars to continue to expand the network to meet the demands of the Australian people.

I know that a further argument is being put-I am sympathetic to it-that the new merged carrier, government owned, should be removed from the restrictions of the public sector borrowing requirements. It should have more flexibility to borrow money to meet the commercial demands so that it can compete. I am sympathetic to that view. In what has just been decided, it has got what it wanted from the Australian Government. The Government has understood the requirement that, in the new environment that is coming for the new merged carrier, it must have access to adequate funds otherwise it may not be able to compete.

I say to Senator Spindler and to the Democrats who are here that what we are proposing for Telecom is not to starve it. None of us in the Government want it to starve. We do want it to grow, and it will grow. There are enormous opportunities for it to grow. There are a number of internal reforms that will have to be carried out in the management of Telecom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't your Government transfer $1 billion?

—Senator Spindler interjects about the merger fee. I make no bones about it; I have always supported the merger fee. I shall tell Senator Spindler why. In the private sector if one company the size of Telecom was buying a company the size of OTC, it would not be get it for nothing. OTC is a company which last year had revenues of over $1 1/2 billion and it had a profit before tax of around $400m. Nowhere in the private sector Senator Spindler could say, `I can take that over and get nothing for it'.
—They are both public enterprises.

—They both are public enterprises, owned by the Australian people through the Australian Government. The argument I have is that, over the past 100 years, the Australian public has invested billions of dollars of public money in the establishment of the telecommunications system in this country. But there are other areas of public sector investment that have received nowhere near the amount of money that the telecommunications system has received to establish itself.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not decry Telecom getting one cent of the money that it has received. I am interested in the idea that there are other areas of the public sector that have been starved. For example, the national rail system has not got anywhere near the contribution of public sector money that Telecom has received. I do not think it is unreasonable for those people who demand a decent rail system in this country to say, `Well, shouldn't there be some return to the public sector of all the money we have had invested in telecommunications? You are in an industry that even if you are blind drunk and blindfolded, you can make a lot of money out of it because it is a growth area. Yet if for social and economic reasons we need to rebuild a decent rail system, we are going to need at least $1 billion'. The National Rail Freight Corporation suggests that to get that system up and running will require $800m over five years.
Senator Spindler interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Spindler probably knows-he saw the national conference of the Australian Labor Party in September last year-we took on these changes. In the debate that took place there amongst members of the government it was made quite clear that the proceeds of the sale of assets are not automatically to go into the black hole of Treasury, so to speak, but are to be reinvested in infrastructure in this country. The No. 1 priority that we are all agreed on is rail because this country needs a decent rail system.

SPEECH.PARA: I say that it is not unreasonable to ask Telecom over a number of years to make a payment to contribute to the reinvestment in rail, which has been starved of funds because of the State system of rail in Australia under our constitution. I say to Senator Spindler: you should not have a blind spot in saying that there will be no merger--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Schacht, please address your remarks through the chair.

—I am sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President, that Senator Spindler and I are having a debate across the chamber. This is a fundamental point in this debate that has to be dealt with. I respect the Democrats for raising the issue in the way in which they have because it is a point that has to be carried through. I say to the Democrats that there are many of us in the Government, certainly a majority, who do not believe that any merger fee or any money got from the sale of any of those assets, whether it is Australian Airlines Ltd, the minority shareholding in Qantas Airways Ltd, Aussat Pty Ltd, or whatever, should just be lost in Treasury as a way of reducing a deficit or boosting a surplus.

SPEECH.PARA: The commitment by the Government has been that that money should go into reinvesting in Australia's infrastructure. Senator Spindler can ask, `Why don't you get money from somewhere else?'. That would mean that we either raise taxes or we run a bigger deficit. If the Democrats want to raise those issues and tell the Australian people that they will have to pay increased taxation, they can do so. But Senator Spindler knows the argument he will get.

Above all else, I say to the Democrats: do not fall for the old three-card trick that the Opposition is putting-namely, stop the merger because Telecom should not pay the merger fee. The Opposition does not want the merger at all so that it can make it easier to privatise both bodies--

TALK.START.PARA: —We know that.
—I am just saying that, if the Democrats vote against the merger on the basis that they oppose the fee--
—We are not voting against the merger.
—We will have to see how the Democrats phrase their amendments. I have not seen their amendments, but I am sure that the Government will look at them with great interest. I certainly will.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I say to the Democrats that I do not think it is unreasonable to ask for a merger fee. I think it can be sorted out and paid in a way that does not threaten the financial viability of the new carrier. None of us want to threaten its future viability. We want it to be a strong, prosperous, commercially oriented enterprise that provides service to the Australian people and returns a profit to the Australian people. I do not think it is unreasonable, therefore, to say to Telecom or to the new entity, `Because you are merging we have increased your profitability, and because OTC is in a strong financial position it is not unreasonable for the Government to ask for a modest merger fee. If OTC were in the private sector, you would not be paying $1 billion for it; you would be paying a lot more'.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is not in the private sector.

—Senator Kernot has again raised some of the points that Senator Spindler has raised, so I will not go over them. I conclude on one point about OTC. It is a very good body. It has a very strong reputation, which Senator Alston in his remarks went to some length to support. I support it pretty strongly, but I do not think we should get carried away about the financial position of OTC. It operated in an area of monopoly in which it was impossible to lose money.
—And using Telecom's infrastructure.

—That is true. But OTC, if it were left where it is now, in the coming decade would gradually disappear and dwindle away, because the new technologies that are now available would mean that its profitability and its exclusive monopoly would just decline. It would not be able to maintain its position in a monopoly situation because technology would overcome it. That is another reason why it is time for it to be merged with Telecom in a carrier. I note the Democrats' interjections that they are not against the merger, just against the fee.
—You haven't made it privatisation-proof in your legislation.

—I think we have made it as privatisation-proof as possible. If all these Bills go through, the only way the Opposition, if it got into government, could privatise it would be to put another Bill through here. If Telecom and OTC are left unmerged, as they are at the moment, OTC could be privatised tomorrow without legislation. We are putting it in the Bill that the merged carrier cannot be privatised unless a Bill authorising such action comes through both Houses of Parliament. So we are protecting the new carrier.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that the Government is interested in looking at reasonable proposals about the merger fee-I certainly am-but I say to the Democrats: please do not throw the baby out with the bath water, because if you get into the dirty bath water with the Opposition you will lose the lot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to take up the time of the Senate for too long because there will, no doubt, be an extended debate during the committee stage when all of these matters will be covered. Senator Coulter has left, but I dare say that he will hear about what I have to say. I want to cover two matters. Firstly, I thought the contributions by members of the Opposition on the question of a regulator were extraordinary, considering the divergence of views that they expressed during the debate yesterday. They do not seem to have a policy on that. Secondly, I want to address some fundamentally inaccurate matters that were put to the Senate by Senator Coulter, who seems to have a fundamental misunderstanding of the current immunity which Telecom enjoys from compliance with environmental and planning laws and what precisely the Government is proposing to do about that.

SPEECH.PARA: On the subject of regulatory models, we have an extraordinary divergence of views on the Opposition benches, with contributions made yesterday by Senator Panizza, Senator Bishop and Senator Alston, who is the shadow Minister. Senator Alston exhorted us to make our independent regulator, Austel, the same as Oftel, the British model. But later in the same debate a trenchant position was taken by Senator Bishop-who only ever takes trenchant positions-who said that we did not need an independent regulator at all. Perhaps Senator Bishop and Senator Alston need to get together fairly urgently prior to the committee debate to work out what the Opposition policy on this fundamentally important question is.

Senator Bishop said specifically that we should follow the New Zealand model, which has no regulator. I would like to know some time during the committee stage of the debate whether the Liberal Party does have a policy on this vitally important question. It does not appear to have one. Senator Panizza had his own views on the question of whether or not we need a regulator. He agreed with Senator Bishop when he said that we did not because Britain-where they have Oftel, a model which Senator Alston wants us to adopt-has the highest local telephone call charges in the world and we have the second highest charges. I do not want to delay the Senate unduly by talking about the holes in that argument because the comparisons are flawed.

Many others countries in the world-the United States is a classic example-have widely diverging regimes of local call charges that differ from network to network and, indeed, from city to city. The fact is that in Australia we have untimed local calls on which there is no restriction and a flat charge applied, and when we compare that with other systems in the world which have timed telephone calls we very rapidly reach a position of having one of the lowest charging regimes for local calls in the world. I am sorry to have to tell Senator Panizza that that is a fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a bit more to it than that.

—Of course there is a bit more to it, but I am not going to bore the Senate to tears more unduly than I need to by getting back into that debate. It is a very difficult comparison and not nearly as clear-cut as Senator Panizza might like to have it. But the one thing he did make a clear-cut statement about was that we do not need a body like Oftel, and that Senator Bishop was right-we do not need a regulator; we want to get into this pure market. As Senator Schacht pointed out quite correctly, there are a few fundamental structural flaws to that nice, clean argument applying in Australia. We need an Australian solution, as I have said in respect of the shipping and aviation industry. The same things apply.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a test for it that honourable senators can look to. We have deregulated the aviation industry, and what I predicted-and one did not need be a Rhodes scholar to work it out-has turned out to be the case. The natural structure of the Australian aviation market, tiny by international comparisons with widely dispersed, low population centres, a relatively low level of traffic by international standards and an enormous country to cover, has determined that, in the seven months since deregulation started-and there is no bar on how many people may enter that market-we have only one new entrant, which is exactly what everyone thought we would get, that is, Compass Airlines Pty Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we still have parallel scheduling.

—We do not. Senator Kernot lives in a dream world. I thought when she made this comment yesterday that she must be one of the most infrequent fliers in the country. She is ignoring the most fundamental flaw in that argument. It is a silly argument because parallel scheduling-that is, cluster scheduling-is determined in a deregulated market in the same way in which it was determined in a regulated market, namely, by the marketplace. Senator Kernot is fundamentally wrong. A myth existed-I do not want to go too far down this track-that under the two airlines agreement we had this business of parallel schedules which were determined by the two airlines agreement. It was a nonsense, and has been for 20 years, in the sense that, prior to our deregulating the market, Australian Airlines Ltd serviced only 25 per cent of the ports that it was serving 20 years ago, and had itself tried by commercial competition with Ansett Airlines of Australia to deregulate its schedules. The market responded.

SPEECH.PARA: The commercial realities of timetables are very important. The reason that the airlines construct the timetables they do is that the market responds to them very quickly. They schedule their flights at the time when the majority of the market wants to fly. That happened in a regulated market under the two airlines agreement and it is continuing to happen under the new deregulated market that we now have in Australia. Senator Kernot should come and live in the real world rather than the unreal world in which she lives. The facts are that, when airlines change schedules, there is a response from the marketplace.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought we were on Telecom.

—But the same argument applies. I am saying that that is a very useful recent model in terms of deregulation which one can look at when talking about the results dictated by the market. There is natural monopoly in Australia because of our very small market, which will exist effectively in this country probably for the rest of my lifetime. No doubt the market will change over time as the population builds up and the market improves. But for Senator Kernot to say that deregulation has changed nothing in terms of the schedules is palpable nonsense. I conclude by saying-and I could go for hours about it-that Senator Kernot should look at the new airline schedules between Canberra and Sydney.
—You can't get here.

—What! There are 16 Ansett shuttle flights a day that were not there before deregulation and are there now just on that one route. As for Telecom, we have to create the kind of climate in the marketplace that will assist competition rather than simply do as the Opposition does, which is to utter the word `competition' and expect it simply to happen.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bishop would do very well to talk to people in industry and business and the users of these systems who are saying that Austel is playing an essential role at present. Its role will become even more important in ensuring that real network competition can get started on a fair and equitable basis.

The competitive safeguards which the Government is proposing to implement under Austel are recognised around the world as being the most innovative, comprehensive and pro-competitive there are. In New Zealand, the Government decided to allow network competition some three or four years ago, but competition has not got started yet. I would ask Senator Panizza to have a look at the position. The putative competitor in New Zealand has not yet got one per cent of the market. Why is that the case? Because the New Zealand Commerce Commission simply does not have the power adequately to address the system of the power of the market itself, and in this world, where there are not level playing fields, the power of the incumbent monopolist which is already in place providing the service.

Competition does not just happen because one says that one believes in competition, even though those opposite cannot work out a common position among themselves. One has to create the conditions to allow it to happen and to happen on a fair and efficient basis. That is what this package of Bills does, I think more effectively than any other system that is currently in place in the world. I say again that that is the general view in the industry internationally. It is felt that this is a comprehensively better way to proceed than most of the efforts that have been attempted elsewhere. I will be interested to see whose views prevail this afternoon in the committee stage-Senator Bishop's and Senator Panizza's view or Senator Alston's view on the question of a regulator.

Let me now address what Senator Coulter said in debate. I had some difficulty understanding whether Senator Coulter was simply assuming that we were changing an existing situation in removing from Telecom some obligation that it had to comply with State environmental and planning laws. It has never been obliged to, it has always been exempted, and we are imposing on Telecom, for the first time in its existence, a necessity to comply with a set of environmental laws at State and Federal level as well. It has always been obliged to comply with the Commonwealth processes, but that involves only a tiny part of its total operations, which are fundamentally affected to a far greater degree by State and local laws which Telecom has never before been obliged to comply with.

I think that we have now established, even though the quantum may be argued, that this Government has set the protection of the environment as a prime objective of its policy making. The Government proposes that a national planning code will be developed to provide a predictable and national approach to the development of telecommunications infrastructure-for the first time. It will maximise protection of the environment and set in place appropriate design standards and planning procedures. It will cover the majority of the facilities which currently are exempted from the application of State laws.

The code will impose more comprehensive obligations and restrictions on both carriers than those that apply currently to either Telecom or OTC. This represents a considerable winding back of Telecom's current exemption from all State, Territory or local government law. For the first time, telecommunications facilities will be subject to external environmental regulation and accountability. The result will be uniform processes which will also enable the second carrier to roll out its network in the shortest possible time-in other words, to provide some real competition quickly. The carriers will be required to consult fully in advance with State and local governments regarding the development of telecommunications facilities. To suggest, as Senator Coulter has, that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has been written out of this Act is untrue. The Minister for the Environment will play a decisive role with the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) in drawing up the national code with which the carriers will have to comply.

Furthermore, I must take exception to the suggestion that Senator Coulter has in some way discovered a flaw in the Government's approach to ensuring that both carriers comply with the highest environmental protection standards. I have already pointed out that this code represents a fundamental reversal of the wide-ranging powers and immunities that Telecom currently enjoys, and has always enjoyed in the past-a blanket exemption from State and local environmental and planning laws. We are fixing that.

The reason why the Government decided to adopt an industry specific code is clear. We are now to have a competitor to Telecom which has the task of building an alternative network to Telecom. Telecom built its network, which now reaches 96 per cent of Australian homes, while it had almost total immunity from environmental law. If the second carrier were to compete with Telecom on the level playing field that we hear so much about, logic might have dictated that we give it the same immunities as Telecom has enjoyed in the past and, indeed, currently enjoys. Obviously, the Government did not do that.

Instead, the Government sensibly decided to adopt a national code, specific to this industry, which would ensure that both carriers would be subject to the same planning laws on a uniform basis throughout Australia. It is totally mischievous to say that this Government has been negligent of environmental concerns. On the contrary, this code represents the imposition, for the first time, of a comprehensive and coordinated approach to environmental compliance by the telecommunications industry.
I conclude by saying that I know that these matters will be canvassed more comprehensively during the committee stage of the debate and I thank all honourable senators for their support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The normal way that I would proceed would be to put the amendment moved by Senator Alston and then to put the question that the Bills be now read a second time or, alternatively, that the Bills be taken separately. Senator Coulter has asked me whether a certain procedure could follow and I ask him to explain the way that he would like to proceed.

—by leave-The Australian Democrats understand that the Government has agreed to the removal of clause 30 from the Australian and Overseas Telecommunication Corporation Bill. I was expecting the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) to give that undertaking in the course of his speech so that we would know which way to vote. I see the Minister nodding, but I would like to have that undertaking.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I understood that the assurance had already been given. We are people of honour here. I am happy to do it now. I had intended to do this during the committee stage. I understand that this assurance has already been given in consultation with the Democrats. Having clarified the Government's position on environmental protection, I happily assure the Democrats that we will agree to their amendment. I concede that it applies an additional measure of protection, pending the implementation of the national code.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy President, I invite you to proceed to deal with the amendment standing in my name and then to have a second reading vote on the batch of Bills, other than the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Bill. That Bill should be voted on separately, and we will be dividing on it.
—The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Alston be agreed to.

—The question is that the Telecommunications Bill 1991, the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1991, the Telecommunications (Application Fees) Bill 1991, the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Bill 1991, the Telecommunications (Numbering Fees) Bill 1991 and the Telecommunications (Universal Service Levy) Bill 1991 be read a second time.
—The question is that the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Bill be read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the Bills in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for a later hour of the day.
