DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991][COGNATE BILLS:PETROLEUM (SUBMERGED LANDS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991PETROLEUM (SUBMERGED LANDS) (ROYALTY) AMENDMENT 1991]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 May, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991]

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —With the concurrence of the Senate, I suggest that the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 be debated cognately with the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill 1991 and the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Royalty) Amendment Bill 1991.
— There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill 1991 and Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Royalty) Amendment Bill 1991 which we are now debating cognately are important Bills. The Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, in particular, is important and it is to that Bill that I will be directing my comments in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 is to make various changes to the petroleum resource rent tax, or PRRT, and to excise and royalties laws. It will extend PRRT from 1 July 1990-in other words, it is retrospective legislation-to petroleum recovered from Bass Strait. It also has provisions to provide for the interim collection arrangements in relation to Bass Strait petroleum production. It has welcome provisions to provide wider deductibility of exploration expenditure and it also changes the compounding rate for carried forward undeducted expenditure.

It will have a negative financial impact, according to the Government, over the next two years of $755m. The cost to revenue in 1990-91 is estimated at $305m and in 1991-92 at $450m. According to the Government, a positive revenue outcome is expected in 1992-93. The measure was announced in the 1990-91 Budget and it is, therefore, being treated by the Government and, of course, by the coalition as a Budget Bill. Therefore, we will not be opposing the Bill although we do have some considerable concerns about which I and my colleagues-particularly Senator Kemp and Senator Watson who have been members of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration which considered this Bill last week-will be having further things to say.

It was interesting, and significant, to see the disagreement between the producers-Esso-BHP-and the Government in the committee hearing last week concerning just what the financial impact was. The Government undertook to provide a reconciliation between the $750m stated as the financial impact in the explanatory memorandum and the considerably lower figure that was being quoted by the gas producers and, I think, some of the gas users. To my knowledge, that reconciliation has not been provided and I hope that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) will be able to provide that information in the course of this debate.

The main part of the Bill relates to the application, for the first time, of resource rent tax to Bass Strait oil and gas production. So far as Bass Strait oil is concerned, there is general agreement on all sides, I think, that the application of RRT will be beneficial. It is said-and there is no reason to doubt this-that it will unlock 200 million to 300 million barrels of oil which, because of the existing excise and royalty regime, it is not economic to produce now. So it will be beneficial because the oil will be unlocked. As well as that-and this applies to more than Bass Strait-the decision to extend tax deductibility of exploration and expenditure to a company-wide basis, rather than on a project basis, for the purpose of RRT will also be beneficial.

Against that, however, in this Bill the Government is reducing the carry forward rate for general expenditures incurred from 1 July 1990 from the previous long term bond rate plus 15 per cent to the long term bond rate plus 5 per cent. Undeducted exploration expenditure will continue to be eligible for compounding at the bond rate plus 15 per cent for the first five years, but down to the gross domestic product deflator thereafter.

There is some concern on our part about both of those proposals and that concern was reflected by witnesses who appeared before the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, particularly by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association (APEA), in relation to the reduction from the long term bond plus 15 per cent down to 5 per cent. The spokesman for the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association said that APEA:

. . . believes the change to the general project expenditure uplift from the long term bond rate-a reduction from the long term bond rate plus 15 to the long term bond rate plus 5 on the general project; which are the development costs-does not adequately take care of the development risks associated with petroleum development and production.

That appears on page 127 of the Committee Hansard of 31 May 1991. So a concern was expressed there. There is also some concern that the Bill provides that the five-year rule start from the date of issue of a production licence rather than from the date of application.

The concern of the industry and the Opposition relates to the possibility of there being a significant time gap between the date of application and the date of issue. In the Committee last week, the Department of Shipping and Aviation Support and the Minister assured us that that would not occur. An Opposition amendment to make sure that that did not occur-in other words, an Opposition amendment to relate the starting date to the date of application rather than the date of issue-was lost in committee.

I understand that the Australian Democrats will not be supporting that amendment today, so we will not be progressing with that. But that is on the firm understanding that Senator McMullan gave us earlier in the week that he will make a statement in the course of his summary on the second reading debate that the Government will take steps to ensure that the slippage that is of concern to the producers does not in fact happen at the bureaucratic level.

It is to the effect of this Bill on Bass Strait gas that I wish to devote the remainder of my remarks. The decision to apply resource rent tax to Bass Strait production was announced by the former Treasurer in the Budget Speech last year. It is quite clear from his remarks in the Budget speech that he had in mind Bass Strait oil, because he said that the decision was being taken in the following context:
. . . as recent events in the Middle East have emphasised, Australia's oil reserves are a scarce resource that must be carefully husbanded in the national interest.

The remainder of his very brief comments announcing the decision were all in that context. There was no intimation at all in what the Treasurer said last year in the Budget Speech that the situation of Bass Strait gas had specifically been taken into account.

Quite frankly, it is my view and the coalition's view that the Budget decision just forgot about Bass Strait gas. The decision was specifically oriented towards oil, and gas has got caught up in that process. That means, of course, that there is now a major differentiation in the tax treatment of the two major offshore gas projects in Australia, namely, Bass Strait and North West Shelf, because North West Shelf is not subject to the resource rent tax regime. Whilst explanations were given to justify the differentiation in the Committee hearing last week, I did not find them by any means an adequate explanation of the differentiation that has now occurred.

The other matter of great concern to the coalition is that there was virtually no consultation at all between the Federal Government and the gas users in Victoria before this Budget decision was taken last year. All of the Victorian users of gas, in the sense of being customers of Esso-BHP, appeared before the Committee last week. All of them were unanimous that there had been no consultation at all with them on this matter before the Budget decision was taken. There had been some consultation, apparently, with the Victorian Government, which is to be condemned for not having taken the issue to the producers or, more particularly, to the users, to see what they thought about it and what the impact was. To the extent that there is a negative impact in Victoria of this Bill-and that is a matter for further debate-the Kirner Government stands full square with the responsibility for that.

The impact on gas users in Victoria could be very significant. It all depends on the extent to which the Bass Strait producers, namely, Esso-BHP, attempt to pass on the RRT to their customers. If they do, the increase in the price of gas to both industrial and domestic users in Victoria will be very significant indeed. The increase will range between 20 per cent to 30 per cent. There are various estimates of the impact but, if there is full pass on, the impact will be very considerable.

That is in marked contrast to the assurance that the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) gave a couple of months ago-on 9 April-at the APEA annual conference in Melbourne when he assured Victorian consumers that they would not be paying any more for natural gas in spite of RRT. That view was obviously not fully shared by his counterpart in the Victorian Parliament, David White. It was only after the Federal Government had announced a compensation package of $60m to Victoria to ease the transitional price impact of the RRT that Victorian Minister David White said that he then did not think there would be much impact on prices. In turn, that conflicts with the views that the former Federal Treasurer expressed when he was introducing this legislation in the House a couple of weeks ago. It is another example of the inability of the Government to get its act together internally. In terms of relationships between the Federal Government and the Victorian Government, it is another example of divisions and incompetence.

If this impact eventuates, it will do so at a time when industry in Victoria is being battered by the recession that was engineered by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the discredited former Treasurer, Mr Keating, and by the criminally incompetent Cain and Kirner governments in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: I object to that. It is not parliamentary to attribute criminal incompetence to members of another parliament or to Ministers in another government.
—That comment was certainly not parliamentary, Senator Short. I ask you to withdraw it.
—I withdraw the word `criminally' and substitute the word `unbelievably'. I think that those governments are unbelievably incompetent.

SPEECH.PARA: The impact on industry could be very widespread. It would include the Victorian producers of bricks, cement and paper. On behalf of a wide range of other users, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures made representations pointing out quite clearly the detrimental impact that a full pass-on of the tax would have on them. Very importantly, because there is a difference, the petrochemical industry, which is basically centred in Victoria, also made representations, because its feed stock is ethane. The ethane also comes from Bass Strait, so the petrochemical industry stands to be hit both ways-by an increase in the price of its fuel, namely, gas, and, more importantly, by the impact on its feed stock, ethane. Those industries are in deep international competition and have no ability to take account of any prices passed on to them as a result of the tax.

Therefore, the Federal Government is now attempting to alleviate the potential damage by giving Victoria a special grant of $30m for each of the two years 1990-91 and 1991-92 to offset the impact of the RRT on industry. As Senator McMullan said in the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration last week, that $60m package will, according to the Commonwealth Government, only go to alleviate something like one half of the possible price impact.

It is very significant and very important to record that the Federal Government expects the Victorian Government to assist with absorbing any pass-on of the resource rent tax that the Bass Strait producers may attempt. We would certainly agree with the proposition that the Victorian Government bears an important responsibility to do that, particularly as it has been absolutely ripping off revenue from the Bass Strait producers through the public account contribution, which has escalated remarkably in recent years from something like $90m to well over $300m in the space of the last eight years alone.

One would hope and expect that the producers will also be a party to absorbing the resource rent tax. Theoretically, RRT should be borne fully by the producers. RRT is not a tax which should be passed on to users. Therefore, we would certainly expect the producers-namely, Esso and BHP-to absorb a significant part of the tax. But it needs to be shared between the Victorian Government, the producers and the Federal Government, which is now making the $60m grant, in such a way that the price impact will be minimal on end users.

Consideration was given by the coalition as to whether the Bill should include a clause prohibiting the pass-on from the producers. We considered it very carefully. There are some important problems with such a proposition. First of all, it would completely absolve the Victorian Government from any responsibility to absorb; I think that would be wrong. It would also be a massive interference by government in the operations of the marketplace. Therefore, I believe that it would have potential for considerable damage in the longer term. It would also run the risk of setting a dangerous precedent in taxation policy.

However, having said that, I also emphasise that the coalition fully shares the very real concerns of the Victorian customers of Esso-BHP about the possible pass-on to them of the RRT. My colleagues Senator Kemp and Senator Watson will elaborate on this point in their remarks because it is very important. I will not take up any further time of the Senate on that point. As I say, these concerns were expressed in detail and at length by Senator Kemp, Senator Watson and me during the consideration of the Bill in the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. We will be coming back to that again. We would urge the producers and the Victorian Government to ensure that any pass-on is minimal.

It is particularly because of those concerns that the coalition will be moving two amendments to the Bill before the Senate. One of those amendments also reflects our additional concern that, to date, neither the Federal Government nor the Victorian Government has given any guarantee that the $60m grant by the Commonwealth to Victoria will be used for the purposes for which it is intended.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say you were going to move the amendments?
—They have been moved; they are in the report.
—They have been considered by the Committee.
—They have been considered by the Committee, but they will be dealt with here. They are in the Committee's report.
—But you are not proposing to move them again?
—We have already moved them, but we will be voting on them if a vote is required.
—No. We have already done that.
—Order! We will work out the procedure when it comes before the Chair. Let the Chair decide. We will continue with the debate.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Because the grant appears completely untied at this stage-there is no mention of it in the Bill-we are very concerned that it could be completely swallowed up in the voracious financial jaws of the incompetent Victorian Government. The first amendment will make it clear in the Act that the $60m must be used for the purpose for which it is intended, namely, to minimise the transitional pressure on gas prices on an equitable basis.

SPEECH.PARA: Our second amendment reflects our concern and the concern of the Victorian gas users about the possible impact of the application of the resource rent tax to Bass Strait gas. This is an amendment that the Government will be supporting. I am very disappointed that the Government is not proposing to support, and did not support in the legislation committee, the previous amendment to which I have just referred. It appears the Government and the Democrats share the coalition's view that it would be quite remiss of this Parliament to wash its hands of this Bill once it is enacted, given the concern of all sides about the possible impact of the implication of RRT to Bass Strait gas. The impact is uncertain; we do not know what it will be. Therefore, we believe that it is necessary for the Federal Parliament to follow up on what actually happens as a result of the operation of the Act and its application to Bass Strait.

For that reason, the coalition moved the amendment in the legislation committee requiring the Government to report to the Parliament by 30 November 1992, five months after the end of the two years after the effective starting date of the application of RRT to Bass Strait. The Government has accepted this amendment and the Democrats have expressed their support for it too. The amendment requires the Government to report to the Parliament on the operation of the Act. That report is to include, firstly, whether the Act has been effective in achieving its objectives; secondly, the impact on prices and on industry-the point that has been of such great concern to us all on this side of the chamber-and, thirdly, the impact on the development of new offshore petroleum projects as a result of the changes that have been made. I am pleased that that amendment will be fully supported and that the coalition has moved it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't support the other one.

—As I said earlier, and as Senator Watson again points out, it is unfortunate that the second amendment we have moved is not supported by the Government. However, it is being supported by the Democrats. I have taken more time than I had intended, given the truncated time allowed for the debate. I will not continue my remarks any further. We will be pursuing this subject further in the remarks of my colleagues later in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address my remarks to the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. Before considering the proposals put forward in the Bill, it may be appropriate to consider the existing situation and to advert to some historical matters that are important, in order to put this Bill into context. In 1987 this Parliament passed a package of Bills which levied a special tax, known as the petroleum resource rent tax, on the economic rent which is earned by producers of petroleum products that are extracted from offshore areas outside the territorial seas. Two areas were excluded from the tax base in 1987, namely, the North West Shelf and Bass Strait.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before the Senate today extends the application of the resource rent tax of 40 per cent to Bass Strait. The tax applies only to economic rent, that is, only that return which is in excess of the return necessary for the investment to proceed will be taxable. Clearly, the minimum level of acceptable return is a difficult figure to calculate; however, it is clearly above the zero risk return that is available from government guaranteed securities. The legislation recognises that and adds an indexation factor for exploration and development expenditure in addition to the bond rate.

The crucial factor in the design of the tax is that economic rent, known in the legislation as `taxable profit', is taxable on a project specific basis; that is, liability arises and continues in respect of a particular production licence area, irrespective of any other activity undertaken by the producer-and here I am still referring to the 1987 legislation. This means that, once the exploration and development costs have been recouped by the producer, the community enjoys a large slice of the additional super profits which accrue to the producer.

It was only with the support of the Australian Democrats that the legislation passed in 1987, and that was contingent on the adequate funding of research into alternative renewable energy supplies. The Government at the time issued a statement promising that $5m would be placed into an account, to be committed and spent over five years for renewable energy, energy conservation and efficiency research. As a result of that, the Renewable Energy Research Trust Account, the so-called Sunshine Fund, was then duly set up.

In fact, most of the promised $5m has since been disbursed or committed. The Minister's words suggested, though, that the total funding for renewable research and development would increase as a result of the new fund. This was indeed an important point, because even then some general funding was already available for renewable energy through the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council. That council was then to be made responsible for managing the Sunshine Fund as well. Our then resources and energy spokesperson, Senator Norm Sanders, was told by ministerial and departmental staff that the Sunshine Fund would indeed provide additional funding. That commitment has not been met, and in fact solar energy researcher, Professor Stephen Kaneff, has shown that, after a one-off jump in renewable energy research and development funds in 1988-89, funding in 1989-90 was the lowest in real terms in the period after 1978 and that the 1990-91 level was the third lowest and only marginally more than in 1989-90.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to order, I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —During this debate on matters of public interest I wish to outline the problems that have evolved from the implementation of the Disability Services Act, particularly those relating to the closing down of sheltered employment services in Victoria. During the debate on the Disability Services Act, then Minister Grimes claimed:

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation tries to provide the capacity for people to change and be innovative and the capacity for government to respond to people's ideas rather than people having to follow rigid government guidelines.

We all know that there was appropriate reason for looking at disability services because some of them had been paternalistic or maternalistic. There was need for change; and the industry agreed that there was need for change. However, the changes are not working. They are not working to the satisfaction of the sector nor of the people that the sector is there to provide for-the people with whom they are working; the people with disabilities.

As I will show today, the Disability Services Act has failed to meet the objective as outlined by former Senator Grimes in the area of providing employment services for people with disabilities. The Act provides for a five-year transitional funding arrangement ending in July 1992 at which time all sheltered workshops will be replaced by competitive employment training and placement services and supported employment services.

In layman's terms, this means that the larger multipurpose workshops with which many of us are familiar will be replaced by smaller, more concentrated units whose primary task will be to prepare disabled people for employment in the general community. The transition would be facilitated by Commonwealth recurrent and capital funding as well as assistance from departmental project officers. The aim of the program is to provide an accountable and more effective avenue through which people with disabilities can access mainstream employment.

Despite the fact that the disability services sector generally agrees to the principles and objectives of the Act, this transition phase continues to be fraught with problems. The people caught between the stools are the people with disabilities. The June 1992 deadline will not be met. In the April Estimates, the Department recognised that the transitional phase would extend beyond 1992 and claimed that any workshops which have made the commitment to move towards open employment would not be closed down. Despite this admission, there has been no official extension. The coalition has recognised this problem and proposed an extension until 1995.

Many services are finding that the mobile work crews, the disabled enclaves and the small business projects outlined in the Act are simply unworkable. Many projects simply are not viable in this, ex-Treasurer Keating's, recession. The jobs simply are not there, set-up costs can be prohibitive, and sufficient Commonwealth funding is not available. In the April Estimates, the Department admitted that there are not enough funds to meet the present demand. The persistent complaints from the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled about the costs involved in setting up these programs continue to fall on deaf ears in the Government. New services do not sufficiently cater for people who are not capable of accessing mainstream employment but who, quite rightly, do not want to remain at home day after day. In many cases their lives have revolved around the sheltered workshop for up to 20 years or even more. While this intransigent Act forces these larger factory-style centres to close down, there remains a continued, pent-up demand for services.

As I have moved around Victoria and visited a number of these workshops many service providers have expressed to me their concern about the never-ending array of reports, discussion papers, conferences and briefings that they have had to undertake during this transition phase. I guess everyone is getting a dose of government interference under the philosophy of a Labor government. What we get is poking around, a never-ending array of reports, discussion papers, conferences, et cetera. Both the shadow Minister and I have received a range of complaints about heavy-handed departmental project officers who do not see eye to eye with service providers. There is widespread concern that a number of those departmental officers have no direct hands-on experience in the provision of services to disabled people.

I believe that many of these administrative problems stem from the lack of genuine consultation prior to the drafting of the Disability Services Act. This has resulted in an inflexible Act and confusion both within the Department and amongst service providers. A classic example that I have been informed about is a Victorian service which has set up a viable business venture-in fact, one I visited-but it is risking its funding because the number of participants exceeds the magical number set down in the Act. Here we have a centre in a rural area that is at a point where it is now almost financially viable. It manufactures clothes horses and other products and has a large order to fill. The centre is now one of the major suppliers of clothes horses in Victoria-if not Australia.

There are a number of innovative industries. When one goes into these workshops one sees people happy in their jobs, and they are productive jobs. However, because this workshop exceeds the number in the Act, it might be closed down. That seems farcical to me. There needs to be much greater flexibility.

I notice Senator Button looking up. I could take him to see this centre in Shepparton. It is a tremendous set-up. I could take him to the Horsham wool factory and show him a most innovative program where they are growing fine merino wool and selling it to a Japanese company, at a huge price per bale. This wool is grown in controlled climatic conditions and the fibre is totally constant throughout. In that same workshop projects are being undertaken for the State Electricity Commission. A number of printing works are being done. People are shifted around and they are multi-skilled. An effort is being made on the part of those people to get their employees into open employment.

One of the things that are very obvious to me as I move around, especially in rural Victoria, is that it is very difficult for people with disabilities to find work in open employment, given our current youth unemployment figure in Victoria of 30.6 per cent. Almost one in every three young people in Victoria is unemployed. Yet we have a government program, designed to place people with disabilities in open employment, doomed to failure. Successful projects which have the possibility of becoming viable businesses are closing down. There is no consideration of the fact that we may need different services for different areas-rural and city. There is a formula coming out of Canberra which is supposed to apply across-the-board. One of the things that I am constantly told is that, with all the goodwill in the world, it is very difficult, in rural Victoria in particular but also in the metropolitan areas, to find open employment. So what will we have by 1992? People with disabilities will be on the scrap heap alongside the youth of our country.

The Disability Services Act heralded this Government's policy of open employment for people with disabilities but it is time for the Government to start getting its own house in order. Between 1987 and 1990 a mere two out of 51 Commonwealth agencies improved their disabled employee ratio, whilst 44 went backwards. The question I asked of the Department of Community Services and Health in Estimates was: how many departments have increased their employment of people with disabilities since the Government has had a program of open employment for people with disabilities? The answer was two: two Federal government departments had increased their employment of people with disabilities. Who is supposed to bear the brunt of this? It is the private sector and/or people with disabilities who cannot find jobs, and/or the sector looking after people with disabilities. That is who bears the burden. The Government has got only two of its own departments responding to the need that is created by this Act.

It is little wonder that many service providers tell me how hard it is to obtain employment for disabled people in State and Commonwealth public services. As I said, it is a particular problem in rural areas where alternative employment options for disabled people are minimal. When one asks service providers in those rural areas, `Why won't the government departments employ them?', they say things such as, `The unions say there could be an industrial relations problem. They may cause accidents so we cannot have them in the statutory authority or government department'. Little is done by Brian Howe stamping his fists on the desk unless he has the courage to rectify the problem.

How do we rectify the problems that the Disability Services Act has brought upon people with disabilities in this country? The Act itself must be made more flexible and there must also be greater flexibility in how the Act is interpreted and implemented. There may be natural contracting of the original sheltered workshops with the entrance of new participants, but the old and the new services should be able to coexist happily. We are not going to change this situation overnight. There must be greater recognition that people with differing disabilities have differing employment and accommodation needs. We have to recognise that some people have been in institutions or in sheltered workshops for long periods, and for them the transition is going to take a long time. It may be easier with young people moving straight from school into the new concept that the Act brings in. As I said, the sector and the Opposition support the basic objectives of the Act. However, its implementation has been appalling.

The Government should recognise the continuing need for a diverse and flexible range of choices and opportunities for disabled people, including sheltered workshops and activity centres-ones that reflect a new view and the change that has occurred. Let us admit that across all sectors-aged care, disability services, education-there are constant changes. Those services adapt to those changes, and sheltered workshops and activity centres also can adapt and address the new views. The centres do not have to be bad just because they are larger. If we do not respond in this way, there will be a failure to provide a smooth transition from school to service and then to employment and community living for a very important group of people-that is, those who have a disability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow Senator Patterson on the same issue of people with disabilities and their providers who are attempting at the moment to work under the Disability Services Act. Indeed, the providers are very concerned about the implementation of the Act. I want to quote from just a few of the many letters I have received pointing out that the same problem occurs over and over again with the various providers.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the letters I received said that in the early stages funding was to be determined by client needs-that is, a maximum of 35 hours a week per client with high needs at a set rate of up to $18 an hour. When agreement was reached, we were advised that these rates would apply only to new services: existing services would continue to be funded at the level currently agreed to. However, to maintain even that level we were to change the service to meet the guidelines of the Act.

All the letters say-and virtually every organisation says-that the intention, the aim, of the Disability Services Act is superb and they agree with it; it is the implementation that they have great difficulty with. They say they find that provision of the service, which means the guidelines of the Disability Services Act, is considerably more costly to deliver than in the past. They say that costs have gone up generally through inflation and the indexation applies to annual block grants and does not meet the increased costs. Consequently, they find themselves falling further and further behind each year. One group states:

We have recently graduated 9 people from our Life Skills Service. They have acquired the skills our service provides. They have now returned to their own home and in many cases will regress within a period of six months. They will then need to return to the service for retraining. This will remain the case in the majority of graduates as they have no `next step' to move on to.
Unfortunately, we have now been forced to set an occupancy limit of 21 clients for Life Skill Service.

So it has had to decrease the number of disabled to whom it has in the past been able to provide a service. The letter from the group then points out that if its funding deteriorates further, it will be forced to reduce staff and services to 16 clients by the end of 1991. The group is very concerned, as is every organisation, that the Disability Services Act, with its very good aims and intentions, is so far behind in terms of funding that it makes it impossible for it to carry out the intention of the Act. I am told in another letter that the Disability Services Act:

. . . also promised to offer flexibility and freedom to choose. Yet the people who are quite happy living in smaller supported accommodation services, say, 20-bed homes, are told they do not meet the criteria for section 10 of the Act. They will need to move to a group home or community accommodation to meet the guidelines of the Act.

Those people were told that they had to move to a home of five, even though they had been used to 20 and wanted to stay where they were. They were told that they were going to be offered flexibility and freedom to choose, but that flexibility and freedom have been taken away and they have been told they must move out into smaller accommodation. The letter goes on to say:

As stated in the beginning of the letter, the Act is in line with our ideals and aspirations and it would be a shame if organisations providing these outcomes were forced to the wall whilst those who have not moved on to adopt the objectives of the Act continue to hold people with disability back.
Another letter says:

To summarise, I can honestly say the Disability Services Act has been great for people with disability who are already in a section 10-13 service. It has been difficult for the service providers who have been forced to `rattle the can' to survive and an absolute disaster for those people who have not entered a service and are trying to obtain assistance in their own home.

Time and time again children coming out of school are not looked after. We have some very good sheltered workshops in our State, as I am sure you would agree, Mr Acting Deputy President. There are some very good workshops making highclass furniture and, indeed, they export the result of their work to other States. But they are not allowed to backfill, so we have 18-year-olds coming out of special schools who cannot get the service because there is nowhere they can go to be trained in these ways.

Other providers looking after children and younger people include St Giles Society in Tasmania and the Launceston Student Workshop, which I have mentioned in this place before. They are doing a magnificent job, but they cannot understand why the Commonwealth picks up only the disabled aged from 18 to 65. They say there is very little difference between a 17-year-old and an 18-year-old, and why a 16-year-old and a 17-year-old should be funded under State legislation while those aged 18 and over are funded under Commonwealth legislation is a mystery to them.

These providers ask, `Please let us get under the same funding so we can have some continuity for various age groups'. Continuity is absolutely essential. Several people have written and I have said that all this goes back to the same old thing-this service is no longer client driven. If clients prefer an option at odds with the Act-say another group-and wish to remain within the service, it appears that is recorded as a failure on behalf of the service providers to facilitate integration. The groups also complain that the total lack of services for young school leavers and people not previously registered with agencies-due to the closed door policy-is a disaster for those newly requiring disability accommodation and services of any sort.

Another group tells me that the Department of Community Services and Health cannot guarantee funding for programs that are required to be implemented under the Disability Services Act-in that group's case, the implementation of outcomes of the individual program plans. The departmental officers cannot and will not guarantee funding for next year. The group says that this lack of confidence in forward funding means that its planning is hesitant and that its confidence is being undermined. It says that the Disability Services Act has to be looked at again.

A very big provider says that there still remains an immovable, stubborn bureaucracy led by a similarly endowed Minister that believes, or is led to believe, that each and every disabled person can find meaningful, fully paid employment within our community. That is impossible at the best of times, let alone in the current recession. This belief has many consequences in the implementation of the Disability Services Act. First and foremost is the lack of practical knowledge of the transient staff from the Department of Community Services and Health which, if anything, has worsened over the last 12 months. That complaint is made so often. The provider says that it speaks to one departmental officer one day and that the following week or month when it goes back and looks for that officer it finds the officer has gone and there is a new one. So the provider has to start all over again. Transient staff, we are told, is one of the main concerns that the providers have; they never speak to the same officer twice. It is a real problem for them.

The providers say that a second impediment is the equally acute lack of resources. One provider says that there is an acute lack of resources both in manpower and finance to effectively implement the desired strategies, due partly to priorities being established to fund new model services at the expense of current services. They say that the defunding of services has been brought to the attention of project officers and departmental staff on numerous occasions, always with the same response-and I have had that response given to me by the Minister in this place-which is, `More money than ever has gone into the Disability Services Act and what you are saying is not true'. One group states:

. . . however they conveniently miss out on the fact that a lot more services are being funded by the same pool of money, all existing services with whom I have contact, without exception, have experienced a defunding in their subsidies over the last three or four years.

The Department has put out a minimum outcomes booklet. Minister, please take note of this debate. We are coming to you in the Senate from the various organisations that are putting to you their problems. They all complain about transient staff. They all complain that there is not the flexibility that was originally promised to them. They all complain that they have not got the funding. They all complain about the lack of ability to backfill. Minister, you sit there reading something else, taking little notice, or no notice at all, of what we are saying.

It seems to me that if the officers in the various States are not getting through to the Minister in this regard, at least senators ought to be able to. Yet he sits there reading something totally different, not taking the slightest interest in what I am speaking about-the lifeblood of the disabled in my State.

TALK.START.PARA: —In all States.

—Yes, in all States. At the moment, they are being told that the aims of the Disability Services Act-with which they all agree; which they all think is fantastic-ought to be able to be carried out with the amount of money that has been made available. They are saying to the Government, `We cannot, and because we cannot, for heaven's sake allow us backfilling, allow us more flexibility, allow us to be able to talk at least to the same officer every time'-and there is no response. It is of great concern to me that the Government is far more concerned with infighting over who will be the next leader, and with the lies that have been going on over the last few days, than it is at all concerned about how the disabled in our community are being looked after.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to raise a subject which is of great concern to the already crippled rural sector, and that is the question of imported pigmeat. There remains a massive anxiety among pig producers in Western Australia, and I believe the anxiety is shared across the country, that the health of their herds and the profitability of their industry are being jeopardised by the continued imports of Canadian pigmeat. On the evidence, they have a deep concern that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) has significantly underestimated the risk of infection from the transmissible gastroenteritis (TGE) virus.

SPEECH.PARA: In raising this matter, I do not in any way support the use of quarantine as a disguised measure of trade protection, and I fully appreciate that Australia must set a positive example in this respect. This is not a trade issue. This is a quarantine issue, it is a health issue, and it is an issue that goes right across this country and has the potential to impact on our export markets, to say nothing of the serious impact on the rural sector itself.

Accordingly, I would not criticise the Lindsay model of bio-economic analysis based upon minimal risk rather than no risk. Under this model, however, imports should not proceed where there is a high risk of infection together with severe consequences should it take hold. I know that you yourself, Mr Acting Deputy President, have been very involved in a number of these areas of concern to the rural sector, and this is one subject I would hope that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, who is on duty in the chamber at the moment, would listen to, even though he sought not to listen to the very serious speech that my colleague Senator Walters made before me. There is some very impressive evidence assembled by the Australian Veterinary Association (AVA) that shows that a high risk of TGE infection could be present in frozen imports from a country where the virus is endemic. While this evidence may not be conclusive, it is surely sufficiently compelling to justify more experimentation and argument from AQIS than has been the case so far.

We are talking about a disease that entrenched itself across the Northern Hemisphere in 20 years after its first occurrence in the United States of America (US) in 1946. Recovered pigs continue to shed the virus for at least another three weeks, and the disease spreads rapidly among live animals at collection points, requiring an extremely small dose, as transmission can be effected with a one part per million dilution of gastrointestinal filtrates from infected pigs. A study in Iowa showed that carcass contamination rates can reach 1 : 250 in endemic areas. To say the least, this is at variance with the Canadian assessment of a carcass contamination rate of less than 1 : 10 million.

Where the disease is endemic, it can be expected that the virus will be present in 20 to 35 per cent of market age animals, and, in such areas as the US Mid West, herd prevalence reaches 50 per cent. That is of great concern in Australia and I encourage the Government to relook at all of this and make sure that what has happened in the United States and Canada does not happen in this country.

As TGE was first reported in Canada in 1964 and herd prevalence had reached 19 per cent in Quebec in 1971, we can safely assume that a far higher rate is evident in Canada today. The virus is widely distributed about the body, making it likely to survive the slaughtering process, and is stable for long periods when frozen for several days at 21 degrees Centigrade, and for several hours when exposed to ultraviolet radiation.

The evidence of research from Drs Baldock and Webster, of the Australian Veterinary Association, from which I am quoting, casts doubts upon the AQIS estimate of an annual TGE risk of 1 : 3.3 million from Canadian pigmeat. They conclude that the annual risk is 1 : 30, which over 10 years would accumulate to a rate of 1 : 3.5. This is certainly a worst case scenario and it may be open to challenge, but it must not be dismissed out of hand. Their belief is based upon a study of literature, results from experiments at the Australian Animal Health Laboratory, demonstrating that the virus survives freezing, and a study made in Iowa by Dr Cook of the Queensland Department of Primary Industries. To say the least, it is evidence that deserves the most careful attention by AQIS and the Minister for Resources. Given the seriousness of TGE, I do not believe that sufficiently close attention has been paid to this evidence, either now or in the past.

In a practical sense, transmission of the virus is possible from imported pigmeat should it end up on the rubbish dumps to which feral pigs have access, with risk increasing the more widely the product is distributed. Again, it is fair to ask whether the investigations by AQIS took into account the reservoir effect that feral pigs can have in the long term spread of the disease. The virus can be spread via dogs, cats, foxes and rodents, and, sadly, even house flies. Once in Australia it would disseminate rapidly.

We should question the assurance given by Senator Cook as Minister for Resources on 27 September 1989 that any outbreak of TGE would be contained by internal quarantine, slaughter and disinfecting of the piggery concerned. Unfortunately, Senator Cook has shown, on that occasion and subsequently, a great lack of understanding of the seriousness of this problem with TGE. Until such time as the Government is prepared to relook at this, this has the potential to run wild right through the industry.

I am very much aware of the argument raised in defence of the decision to allow Canadian pigmeat imports-that they have occurred in New Zealand for a number of years without ill effect. However, risk increases with volume and we are talking about minor imports to a small market. The pigmeat industry in New Zealand is not significant.

In this context there is a feeling that, if the Australian pigmeat industry were larger, greater attention would be paid to its quarantine requirements. I do not think we should necessarily try to look only at ensuring that a particularly large industry is safe; we must look at the whole industry. If it is a relatively small industry such as the pigmeat industry, that should not preclude it from close attention.

I stress that once the TGE virus takes hold, it will have severe consequences for Australian producers of pigmeat. The TGE virus causes vomiting and diarrhoea that can cause 100 per cent mortality in piglets under three weeks old and it reduces the production efficiency of lactating sows. The disease can escape diagnosis among older pigs, but once established it remains in larger herds as new litters are successively infected.

The resulting loss would reduce cash surplus for an average piggery with 100 sows from $26,300 to $11,500. We must remember that this represents only the cost of the initial outbreak, without estimating ongoing losses once the TGE virus is established. Prospects of exporting pigmeat to Asia would be dashed through the loss of our disease-free status, and that is yet another area in which I do not believe we can put this industry at risk. If ever there were a time in this country that we needed to make sure that every export market is rock solid and able to be extended, not restricted, then that time is now. If we lose that disease-free status, then the whole export market is a goner.

Producers in an efficient rural industry have a right to be gravely concerned at the possibility that AQIS has not done a sufficiently thorough job of risk assessment under the Lindsay model. AQIS has failed to treat the TGE virus as a major disease, thus requiring a full economic assessment, and it has not given sufficient weight to the objections of agricultural authorities in Western Australia and Queensland.

AQIS appears to differ from the AVA in respect of the significance of resistance to freezing by the TGE virus, but it has not addressed that point. There is disquiet as to whether reports provided to AQIS by the Bureau of Rural Research have been fully considered by AQIS and the Minister for Resources. Such a report as that of 10 August 1990 does not endorse the Baldock and Webster paper but differs significantly from the sweeping criticism from AQIS. At the same time, we would wish to be assured that the advice from AQIS was not in any way coloured by Canadian pressure to finalise the matter last year.

Certainly, I stand strongly by the criticism that I made in October 1989, when the former Minister for Resources, now Minister for Industrial Relations, stated that Canadian pigmeats proved an acceptable risk without further discussions with pig veterinarians and prior to the receipt of an assessment by Dr Baldock. As I say, it was almost two years ago that I raised this issue in the Senate, and today we are still no further advanced because, on 5 September 1989, Senator Cook had stated:
. . . there are further assessments to be made and the decision will be made in due course . . .

And yet, three days later, the initial decision to approve imports was made. He also assured the Senate that the decision would be made upon quarantine grounds alone. Since the final announcement was made in July 1990 and imports commenced in August, 800 tonnes of Canadian pigmeat have been imported. Producers have the right to know that the risk assessment was thoroughly investigated, that opposing points of view received due consideration from AQIS, and that if risks could not be ascertained, a conservative approach would be adopted. Producers are still waiting for the TGE virus to become a compensable disease should it be discovered that the 1 : 3.3 million risk assessment was indeed way off beam.

It is not my intention in raising this matter to imply any generalised censure of AQIS in terms of the professionalism of its officers. It is, however, a fact that an organisation and its Ministers can get something wrong, and I am strongly suggesting that there is a weight of evidence that the decision to allow the importation of Canadian pigmeat posed a greater quarantine risk than is acceptable under the principles of the Lindsay model.

Producers have all the more right to know that AQIS and the Minister will give the fullest consideration to effective minimal quarantine given the spread of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome, or mystery swine disease (MSD), in North America and northern Europe. This disease causes stillbirths, piglet deaths and loss of growth, and the outbreak of MSD in a 250-sow piggery cost one US producer $A86,000.

Unless we know there is minimal risk of it being carried in carcasses and meat products, AQIS and this Government have a responsibility to look again at the import of pigmeat from any country, such as Canada, where MSD is spreading rapidly. I repeat: Australia must adhere to a minimal risk quarantine policy and practise what it preaches. This must not, however, involve us in failing to investigate all possible threats to the viability of a rural industry from an introduced disease.

The new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) would do well to direct the Minister for Resources to look again at all evidence regarding TGE and to ensure that AQIS has considered it. Pigmeat producers, and rural industry generally, deserve no less. I am greatly disturbed that the Government, over almost two years, has seen fit to do absolutely nothing about assuring the industry that it will be safe and assuring Australians generally that the importation of Canadian pigmeat is not creating a risk in this country that could spread rapidly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to be brief so that I could get up and have lunch, but after Senator Knowles's raising of the issues affecting pigmeat I certainly will not be going to the dining room and eating pork today-unless it is Australian pork! Obviously, Senator Knowles, that was a pig of an issue to have to deal with in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: Unemployment statistics will be the focus of public attention today. I do not want to focus on today's release of statistics; I want to look at unemployment statistics in a way in which they are not generally publicly understood. They are normally looked at on a State-by-State basis, with various Premiers claiming that their States are doing better than other States. During the New South Wales election, we saw the comparison between New South Wales, with an unemployment rate then of 8.9 per cent, and other rates in the vicinity of 10 per cent. From such statistics one can draw what comparisons one can about the management State by State.

The other way that unemployment statistics are dealt with in Australia is by putting a very proper focus on the effect of unemployment on young Australians. I think the figures we will be seeing today show another disastrous rise in youth unemployment statistics as opposed to the general unemployment rate. The way I would like to look at unemployment today is to do some comparisons of industry sectors. They show some alarming trends which I think are worth while putting on the record and bringing to the attention and the interest of the public in this public interest discussion.

Across Australia we have had a massive increase in unemployment, but it has affected some industry sectors far worse than others. The retail sector is the hardest hit sector, according to the statistics that I have been able to find. In terms of job losses, the retail sector has seen a loss across Australia of 54,000 people in the last 12 months. The next hardest hit sector is construction, which has seen 40,000 people lose their jobs during that same 12-month period.

The other sectors which have been very badly hit are agriculture and agricultural services. I do not have national figures for them, but in my State of Western Australia the increase in unemployment has been about 163 per cent in the agricultural sector alone and 345 per cent in agricultural services-which, obviously, has a significant effect in the country, particularly in rural and regional centres, where people are losing their jobs and leaving, and I guess they are returning to the capital cities, with consequent increases in demand for services and in crime rates and so on in those cities.

There are, however, some bright spots on the employment picture. One of them is the communications industry. I referred to some figures in my contribution to the debate on the Telecommunications Bill last night. The communications industry has noticed an increase in employment and it has experienced the lowest growth in unemployment. In other words, the growth there has been just 5 per cent and it currently has an unemployment rate of 2.6 per cent.

The other important industry that has suffered very badly during this downturn is the recreation and tourism industry. That has been hit very hard. In Western Australia there has been a loss of about 5,000 jobs in that sector alone.

The effect on youth is interesting. Across the sectors that I have referred to already, particularly the retail sector and the tourism and accommodation sectors, one would naturally assume that they are sectors which have a large capacity to employ young Australians. The massive unemployment increases in these sectors have affected the prospects of young Australians more than increases in any other sector.

It is also important to look at what has happened to public sector employment during this period. With job losses I have already described in construction of 40,000 people and in the retail sector of 54,000 people across Australia, what, you may well ask, has happened to Federal Government and State Government employment during this period? The answer is quite alarming. There has actually been an increase of 13,000 people across Australia under the employment of Federal and State governments during the past 12 months. So at a time when the productive sectors of the Australian economy-the private sector, the various sectors that I have referred to-are laying off tens of thousands of Australian workers who want to work and to contribute and who want to look after their families and pay their own way in this society, and at a time when Federal and State Labor governments across this nation are preaching the rhetoric of cutting government, making things more efficient and reducing taxation and micro-reforming, the reality is that there has been an increase of 13,000 people in the public sector. This is a matter of some concern because, obviously, for every person put onto the payroll of the State and Federal governments, someone will have to pay for it and, of course, it is usually the poor old PAYE taxpayer.

It is also interesting to look at what has happened in one particular sector, clearly a very featherbedded and protected sector when it comes to employment, and that is the waterfront. We have had an economic downturn-a recession we had to have from a Treasurer we did not have to have-and across all of the areas of employment we have seen massive increases of unemployment. But let us look at the waterfront, where we have this much-vaunted policy of waterfront reform defended on a daily basis by the Minister responsible, Senator Collins. We have seen a downturn in trade through the waterfront across Australia's ports of about 35 per cent. We have a redundancy program which he keeps defending. Figures released recently by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority show that his number of redundancies is only 85 per cent of the level he should have achieved by October last year. So the program is a long way behind even though he is not prepared to admit it. Here we have a sector where there is a massive downturn in the amount of throughput and where employment is very high, remaining stubbornly opposed to the redundancy program of this Government.

What we have to look at in response to all of these fairly boring statistics is the sort of balance we want between the public and private sectors in Australia. The approach of the Opposition clearly is to ensure that government is looked at very objectively. We have to look at the role of government, and the only way one can reduce government is to start privatising, contracting out some of the services provided by government, and to ensure that the public sector does not become too great a burden on the private sector.

This Government and its Labor State cronies have got it all wrong. At a time when there have been massive increases in unemployment across the productive sectors of this economy, and at a time when we can least afford it, we are seeing increasing numbers of people being put on Federal and State payrolls at great expense to this nation.
