SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the chamber, particularly the Minister, to the matters I raised on this Bill on 8 May 1991. I particularly raised this question so as to get a response from the Government. The question is the discrimination that is experienced by a number of women in regard to superannuation policies. I referred particularly to the submission that I think most, if not all, senators received-presumably the leaders of the parties received it-from Women's Action Alliance on superannuation policy. I had hoped that the Government would have considered this matter and been able to respond to some of the questions that I raised in the debate on 8 May on this legislation. I pointed out then the very severe discrimination, taxation-wise and otherwise, experienced by women who are part of a one-income family. Here we have a matter of major sex discrimination whereby women who are employed full time in the task of child rearing are discriminated against by virtue of this Government's current policies. I quote from what was said on that occasion:

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, women at home are not able to cover themselves for superannuation, yet for the reasons already indicated it is as important for them as for women in paid employment.

Then I pointed out that there is particularly discrimination against women in one-income families in the matter of contributions, in the matter of reasonable benefits limits, and in the area of taxation of lump sum. In all of those areas, as I pointed out on 8 May, there is significant discrimination against these women.

Why has the Minister not focused on the matters that I raised on that occasion? Why have they been ignored? Why have his officials not at least given him a brief about this matter? It is a very serious matter; it affects a lot of people. I had deliberately asked in my speech for the Government to have a good look at what I had stated. I am expecting a reply now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The paper to which Senator Harradine refers has been drawn to my attention. The whole question of superannuation is important and is under major review and examination by the Government. The paper that the honourable senator has referred to has been discussed with the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, which I think is the appropriate body to discuss it with in the first place, and it will be high on the agenda of papers drawn to the attention of the new Treasurer. The honourable senator would understand that that transition has delayed some of the decision making at that level, but I am conscious of the point he raised. It is not being ignored or underestimated.

SPEECH.PARA: Without giving a detailed response, because this is not in my area of expertise, I can say that it is a matter that we have already discussed with the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and which the new Treasurer will be giving consideration to. I cannot go any further than that today, but I assure Senator Harradine that it is not being brushed under the carpet, ignored or not being considered at the appropriate levels. It is being considered; it is being taken seriously; and it will continue to be a matter that the officers, and I, if necessary, bring to the attention of the Treasurer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are three comments I want to make, and I think I might as well make them on this motion. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs considered the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill. It was referred to the Committee because of the complex areas of law involved in the interrelationship between sex discrimination and superannuation. In that Committee the Opposition moved two amendments which were unsuccessful.

SPEECH.PARA: As you would be aware, Mr Chairman, at present there are exemptions from the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act with respect to superannuation and insurance. It was always intended that these exemptions would operate for only a limited period. The then Human Rights Commission report on the superannuation exemption was tabled as long ago as 1986. It recommended that superannuation schemes should be made to comply with the anti-discrimination provisions of the sex discrimination legislation. This Bill, in fact, represents the Government's third attempt to pass legislation to reduce the number of circumstances in which superannuation funds may discriminate on the grounds of sex or marital status.

I said some time ago, at the second reading stage, that the Opposition supported the Bill because it introduced what has been described as modest and sensible reform-although, as I indicated, it has been a long time in coming. However, there were two aspects of the Bill with which we had considerable difficulty and which we took to the Committee in the form of amendments.

The first of those amendments related to clause 7, which deals with acts done under statutory authority. This Bill amends the Act by replacing the existing system, whereby exemptions to the Act are effected by way of regulation, with a system of specifically naming the legislation from which exemptions have been provided. The Opposition is of the view that an exemption should be provided in relation to the Migration Act.

Our concern was particularly in relation to sham marriages. The concern arises because, unlike any other country, we provide for the entry of people to Australia who are in de facto relationships. We do not discriminate on the grounds of marital status in our migration laws. But examination of behaviour profiles has shown that there is a greater chance of people using the change of status mechanism to obtain entry into Australia against our law if they are living in a de facto relationship than if they are living in a marriage relationship.

The Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations came to the view that, in considering de facto relationships, the first thing that should be established is whether the relationship is a proven relationship of cohabitation for at least 12 months. However, the Committee was told that, under the Sex Discrimination Act, that requirement was unreasonable because it was not being asked of marriage partners.

The Committee suggested that another way of checking the bona fides of de facto couples would be to see whether they remained together after they were allowed entry, by having a period of two years temporary entry to Australia after which a fresh assessment could be made. The Government decided that the two-year conditional residence period should apply in all cases, bearing in mind the implications of the Sex Discrimination Act and the fact that abuse of the change of status mechanism also arises in the case of legal marriage.

Yet, whilst there was some abuse in the case of legally married couples, it was not of the same order as that occurring in de facto relationships. The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs now has to check every case of both marriage and de facto change of status application within two years of entry to Australia which is, in our view, an unnecessary drain on the Department's resources.

For those reasons, the Opposition takes the view that the decisions taken in compliance with the Migration Act should be exempt from the operation of the sex discrimination legislation. On behalf of the Opposition, I moved an amendment in the Standing Committee to that effect but, regrettably, it did not receive the necessary support-which means that the Democrats opposed it.

The Opposition's second amendment related to the option to transfer to non-discriminatory benefits for the purposes of proposed section 41b. For those purposes, such an option must be offered and exercised within a two-month period and before the commencement of that section. Pursuant to this Opposition amendment, the option must still have been exercisable within a two-month period, but the outer limit would have been up to 12 months after commencement of the section.

As I noted during the second reading, the Bill provides for a two-year period from the date on which the Act receives royal assent before the commencement of those sections containing exemptions relating to superannuation and insurance schemes. This falls short of the three-year transition period recommended by the Human Rights Commission in its reports. The Opposition amendment, effectively, was to increase the transition period to three years in relation to the option to transfer to non-discriminatory benefits. The purpose of the Opposition's amendment was to allow the superannuation industry time to adjust to the new requirements.

As I said in the Committee, the question really comes down to whether two years is an adequate time in which to undertake this very major structural alteration and to ensure that all options have been covered and the rights of individual policy holders have been properly taken into account. It was pointed out by Mr Stevens, on behalf of the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia, that the superannuation industry comprises in excess of 100,000 funds operated by diverse groups and individuals all over the country. Although the Association is committed to keeping its members well-informed, and it probably covers about 80 per cent of the total membership of funds, it covers only about 750 of the 100,000 funds as direct members. There would be a large number of funds which would not be prepared for this change in the legislation.

The Opposition shares the industry's view that two years is an inadequate time to adjust to the new provisions and, therefore, I moved an amendment to extend the limit by up to 12 months. Again, unfortunately, the amendment was unsuccessful, as the Democrats voted with the Government. We can only hope, for the sake of members of the superannuation industry and its many thousands of contributors, that time does not prove us right with our concerns. Therefore, whilst we are disappointed that our amendments were unsuccessful, nevertheless, in accordance with the sentiment that I expressed in my second reading contribution to this debate, the Opposition will support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of getting the legislation passed and acknowledging the terms in which Senator Hill put his concerns, which was a reiteration for the record of the positions he had expressed in the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I do not think I should respond in detail simply to reiterate the fundamental positions of the Government with regard to the adequacy of the transitional arrangements and the migration matter-the adequacy of the alternative arrangements that have been put in place-but I understand the legitimacy with which alternative views are held. I welcome the fact that, nevertheless, the Bill has the support of the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and other members. I thank them for their support.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator McMullan) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator McMullan)-by leave-agreed to:

That orders of the day no. 10 (Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1991), no. 11 (Veterans' Entitlements (Rewrite) Transition Bill 1991) and no. 12 (Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1991) be taken together for their remaining stages.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL 1991VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS (REWRITE) TRANSITION BILL 1991VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 and 29 May and 5 June, on motions by Senator Tate, Senator Cook and Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are Bills on which anybody might speak for half an hour on each if the time were available. However, I think that we will be doing veterans a service if we pass them by 2 o'clock. I will speak very briefly on behalf of Senator Newman.

SPEECH.PARA: The Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 was a significant development in veterans' legislation and at the time was seen to be a major simplification-and perhaps it was-but five years later that is no longer the case. For a long time veterans and war widows have expressed their exasperation with the way it was operating and the amendments made to it. We welcome this Bill as one which we hope will simplify and bring together the legislation, making it operate. It is widely welcomed by the veteran community. I shall not go into the details of it other than to say that it comes into the category of the plain English version; it has alphabetical listing of terms, definitions and an index and, hopefully, its objectives will be achieved.

The Veterans' Entitlements (Rewrite) Transition Bill 1991 is, as stated, a transitional Bill, the most salient point being, perhaps, the Budget changes to part 3 of the Act which are the deeming provisions relating to income assessment for the service pension. The deeming provisions have, in many instances, proved very difficult for aged pensioners and service pensioners. This Bill will significantly assist in the operation of those matters.

The Minister has stated that the rewrite legislation will not in any way affect the responsibilities of the Repatriation Commission towards veterans and their dependants. I think it is important that that should be the case. However, the Opposition puts the Government on notice that it must honour its promise to quickly and effectively address any unforeseen anomalies should they emerge at a later date.

The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 deals with entitlements. Under the Veterans' Entitlements Act, as it stands, dependants of female veterans do not have the same access to benefits as dependants of male veterans and are not entitled to defence service home loans. We welcome this Bill because it corrects these inequalities. The extension of the repatriation benefits will be backdated to 22 January but the defence service home entitlement only takes effect from the time of royal assent to this Bill.

It also includes provision for automatic indexation of the pharmaceutical allowance and introduces a number of minor changes associated with the administration of service pensions. We believe that all anomalies and discrimination should be removed, that is those which are on the ground of the Veteran's gender, such as discrimination against the widower of an ex-service woman. The Gulf war highlighted the need for this. We were initially dismayed when the Government publicly indicated that it would not be doing anything about it in January, and we were pleased that by 22 January it announced that these anomalies would be redressed.

We support all three of these Bills. I do not want the brevity of the Opposition's remarks on them in any way to indicate lack of desire to support them or lack of concern about the veterans' community. It is merely to take the opportunity to have the Bills passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also want these Veterans' Entitlements Bills to be passed as quickly as possible; therefore I will keep my remarks, which are being made on behalf of Senator McLean, brief. The Democrats welcome what appears to be a genuine attempt on the part of the Government to correct some serious anomalies and to make changes that will benefit many veterans. In particular, in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 a very important change has been made to extend benefits to dependants of female veterans on the same basis as the benefits applying to dependants of male veterans-at last.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the Veterans' Entitlement Amendment Bill 1991, this is the plain English version and we are very pleased to note that it has been done in consultation with the ex-service organisations. The Democrats fully support these three Bills and are moving no amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators speaking on behalf of the Opposition and the Democrats, and also the Independents, for their support for this important package of legislation to deal with matters in relation to the Australian community's care and concern for veterans. In particular, it will be extremely helpful to veterans that the legislation will be expressed in very clear, plain English. That will be of great assistance to the veterans and to their advocates and friends who take up causes on their behalf. I thank those honourable senators who have spoken with such concern for the veterans. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement last night in which he denied that the Government has ever used phone tap material improperly and, in particular, politically. In view of the Prime Minister's confession that he lied to the Australian people about his secret agreement with Mr Keating, why should anyone believe this denial? Will the Minister investigate the allegation that the Prime Minister used Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) phone tap material to rebuke Senator Walsh over a political matter and advise the Senate whether there has been any breach of the law?

—Senator Durack, of all Ministers, having been Attorney-General with responsibility for Australia's security organisations, would know that it is the practice neither to confirm nor deny speculation about ASIO operations and I certainly do not enter into that realm of speculation. I do accept the Prime Minister's quite categorical denial that the Government has ever used phone tap materials improperly, in particular politically, or has ever sought material for those purposes. I will not be carrying that matter any further.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. With the result of a survey of best quality cars, conducted jointly by Wheels magazine and the National Roads and Motorists Association, revealing that Japanese cars head the list of best quality cars, with Australian produced Ford and Holden thirteenth and fourteenth respectively, what action has the Government taken to improve the quality of Australian made cars? Can the Minister explain why Australian made cars compare badly with their Japanese counterparts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question could be asked in any country except Japan, with the possible exception of Germany, relating to one or maybe two car manufacturers. An improvement in the quality of locally produced cars, of course, continues to be an objective of the Government's policy for the automotive industry. Quality is a significant determinant of competitiveness against imports and in entering potential export markets.

ANSWER.PARA: The Automotive Industry Authority monitors the quality of Australian made and imported cars. This information is published by the Automotive Industry Authority in its annual Report on the State of the Automotive Industry report. In its 1990 report, that Authority found there had been a general improvement in the quality of locally produced cars. However, it also confirmed that there was a quality gap between locally produced and imported Japanese cars.

This disparity arises from several sources. Clearly, the nature of quality control procedures incorporated into production is critical. Australian car makers are achieving significant gains in this area. However, the survey shows that it is how these gains measure up relative to the procedures adopted by overseas competitors that is critical. It is very important to recognise the disparity in economies of scale between Australian and Japanese producers. This disparity is reflected in the lower levels of investment which Australian firms are able to make in improving production, efficiency and quality control. I make the observation that certain statements made by the Opposition spokesman on this issue showed a total ignorance of that fact.

I should make the point, which I referred to at the beginning, that Japanese built cars are now considered to have the best build quality in the world. In this respect, they set a very exacting standard that car manufacturers in the United States and Europe are having difficulty in competing against. Indeed, there are import restraint measures imposed by the European Community for countries within the European Community and, of course, by the United States against imported cars.

The new automotive arrangements announced by the Government on 12 March will create an environment where local producers must respond to the competitive pressures arising from reduced government assistance and develop export markets in order to capture the benefits of increased economies of scale in production. Arrangements will therefore provide the competitive pressure for the Australian industry to improve its product quality, as well as the opportunity through expanded export production to do so.

In a more direct manner, the Government is also assisting groups, such as the component industry in Australia, to develop links with the Japanese automotive industry as a means of stimulating improvements in quality control. I must add that, on my visit to Japan in February, some of the Japanese car manufacturers made the observation-which was not gratuitous and they did not need to make it-that the quality of the production of their cars in Australia had improved immensely in the last year or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. What hope does the Minister hold for the near record 27.5 per cent of young Australians aged between 15 and 19 years who are shown in today's official statistics as unable to find full time jobs? Why is the worst youth unemployment in the Labor States of Tasmania with 31.6 per cent, Victoria with 30.6 per cent, Queensland with 29.5 per cent, South Australia with 27.5 per cent and Western Australia with 25.1 per cent-all worse than one in four jobless-while Liberal-led New South Wales has the lowest youth unemployment rate of 23.1 per cent? When will the Hawke Government take its mind off its internal leadership squabbles to do something about ending the wiping out of 107,300 full time under twenties jobs over the last 12 months as revealed in today's horrific youth unemployment statistics?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is really probably only Senator Michael Baume who could ask this question with such pompous indignation. The reason why he does it, of course, is that he expected the unemployment figures released today to be worse.
—They are worse.
—No, I am talking about the aggregate unemployment figures.
—I am the shadow Minister for youth affairs; or hadn't you noticed?

—So Senator Baume is now the shadow Minister for youth affairs? He used to be the shadow Minister for health and what did he do then? If anybody got the figures wrong, it was the shadow Minister for health when Senator Baume was in that job.
—My figures were right. You are wrong again.

—Anyway, Senator Baume's figures, whether they be given as the shadow Minister for health or the shadow Minister for youth affairs, are wrong. I am grateful to the honourable senator for one piece of information. I did not know, nor I think does anybody on this side of the Senate, that Senator Baume was shadow Minister for youth affairs, but now we know that and that is worth while.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition has been luxuriating in unemployment figures for a long time. After the figures came out today showing a fall in the participation rate, I thought there would be some genuine response from the Opposition in relation to those figures. Instead, we get this sort of question from Senator Baume.

The Opposition emerges in this question as the same bunch of cynical operators who left the government benches in 1983. For the Opposition, a fall in unemployment is bad news, not good news. Opposition members were waiting this morning for the unemployment figures to be released but, instead of the question coming from the person it usually comes from-Senator Short-it came from Senator Baume, who is not concerned about the aggregate unemployment figures but raises the question in the light of his shadow portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: —I always ask about youth unemployment and you always give me a dopey answer.

—There is a lot of excitement on the other side. Honourable senators opposite should simmer down and listen to the answer. I take it that Senator Baume is one of those who offer some sort of blind allegiance. He certainly used to when Margaret Thatcher was leader of the Tories in the United Kingdom. In the absence of any idea to fill the vacuum in Opposition members' heads, off they used to trot to get some ideology from Margaret Thatcher-Margaret Thatcher, who produced 12.5 per cent unemployment in Great Britain. Now the latest trips are being made to New Zealand to get some wisdom from Mr Bolger about how to conduct economic policy- Mr Bolger, who presides over a figure of 9.6 per cent unemployment in New Zealand. This is the sort of context in which this question must be seen.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the employment figures are concerned, let me make this point: it is true that the number of employed persons fell marginally, but the participation rate fell markedly, by 0.4 per cent, and the participation rate in Australia remained artificially high in the figures produced in previous months which the Opposition was so happy about. The net result is a marked fall of 40,000 in the number of unemployed persons in Australia. These figures are not ones which bring any joy to the Government, but I must say that, in the light of anticipation of a higher unemployment figure than was actually produced in today's announcement, the Government has some satisfaction in them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some satisfaction in these youth unemployment figures.

—I was not talking about the youth unemployment figures. Senator Baume cannot talk about anything else. As far as the youth unemployment figures are concerned, I will provide Senator Baume with a further answer on that issue. I am not disagreeing with his figures, but how does he put those figures to me? Is the Government not concerned about this issue? Of course we are concerned about it. I have said that on numerous occasions in the past. Senator Baume is trying to rival everybody else in moral indignation about this issue. I am sorry, but Senator Baume cannot do that. We are very concerned about it too, as I have said on numerous occasions in the Senate.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his non-answer to the question, which was about youth unemployment. I remind the Minister that I did not ask him whether he was concerned. We found out when I asked about this last October that he was not concerned when he said that youth unemployment was falling. I now ask the Minister once again: what hope does the Minister hold out for the near record 27.5 per cent of young Australians aged between 15 and 19 years who are shown in today's official statistics as unable to find full time work? I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that, rather than there being a fall, as he tried to obfuscate the situation, there has been a 30 per cent increase over the past 12 months in the number of young people out of work, which figure now totals 116,400 looking for full time work. I ask the Minister to address himself to the question.
—I have addressed myself to that question on numerous occasions when I have been asked about the state of the economy in Australia. The state of the economy in Australia is one of a deep recession.
—They are interested up there.
—I thank Senator Patterson. What is she going to do about them-interject in the Senate?
—What will you do about it?
—We will provide some leadership.
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—Oh! Senator Watson will provide some leadership. That is a new challenge to Senator Hill and Dr Hewson from Senator Watson, for goodness sake. On numerous occasions we have had some question about unemployment, about business failures, reduction in corporate profits, and so on, all of which are consequences of the recession. On numerous occasions we have said here that we expect the economy to show some return to growth later this year. When that begins to happen, there will be some alleviation of the employment problem. The Government has never said, with employment being a lagged indicator of a recession, that in the next year there will be a return to the employment levels which we obtained in 1990. Those employment figures represented an increase of 1.5 million in the number of employed people in Australia.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to an article in the latest edition of the Bulletin magazine concerning the search for the yacht Rockin' Robin. Are the claims made in the article accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. They are comprehensively inaccurate. I must say, having had some personal dealings with Mr Gruzman over the Rockin' Robin loss, that I am profoundly disappointed, in consideration of the conversations I had with him privately, that he could be the author of such an appallingly inaccurate article which was given such comprehensive coverage by the Bulletin. I was particularly disturbed and regretful about the extraordinary picture he painted of the manner in which the men lost in that incident died. It must have been of some distress to the families of those men who died to read Mr Gruzman's account of it in the Bulletin, because his account of it is totally at variance with the facts that are known about the loss.

ANSWER.PARA: Unfortunately, I have to say that in the comprehensively executed investigation that was subsequently carried out into the incident, the report of which was tabled in the Senate, the sad fact is that in all these circumstances it is most probable that they died in those appalling weather conditions on the same night that the yacht was lost. All of the evidence points to that. That is the conclusion that the post-accident investigation came to. It accords precisely--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is speculation.
—I am sure that it is a report that Senator Bishop has not even read. It accords precisely with the facts that are known.
—Has Senator Bishop read it?

—Of course she has not. The appalling weather conditions at the time were, as experienced crewmen who were rescued in a separate rescue said, the worst conditions that they had seen in 30 years of sailing. The yacht was lost at a great distance from the Australian coast. I was profoundly disappointed to see in that article that the only reference to the involvement of the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) was a claim that it inaccurately dropped rescue equipment, with not a single word about the 50 personnel who literally risked their lives in the most appalling weather conditions, flying Orion aircraft in 70-knot winds below a cloud base that got down to 500 feet, in an attempt to save the lives of those men. Not a single word was said about the people who risked their lives to try to rescue those men.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that, in appalling weather conditions, with extremely rough seas and winds gusting to 70 knots, the RAAF aircraft, far from being inaccurate-in fact, with considerable accuracy and skill-dropped the life raft in precisely the correct position upwind of the disabled yacht. In fact, that equipment landed in precisely the spot where it was supposed to land. This feat was made more difficult by the fact that the yacht was sailing across the wind at 6 knots at the time. The article is riddled with inaccuracies.

The incident itself was thoroughly investigated. The report of the investigation was comprehensive. It was based on eye witness accounts and not the flights of fancy indulged in by Mr Gruzman, and they do him no credit. The investigation concluded that, on the heavy balance of probabilities, as I have already said, at least two persons, and probably three, were unsupported in the heavy seas by midday on the first day, that is, 8 June 1990, and in the severe conditions they probably died shortly thereafter.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have already said that.

—It is an important issue, particularly for the families of the people who were lost. The final sighting of the raft, which had been occupied, was in mid-afternoon, when it was reported as being badly deflated and in a sinking condition, with only one person seen lying across it. The raft was never seen again and it has to be assumed that it either sank very soon after or became so badly deflated that it provided no effective means of life support.

ANSWER.PARA: I have nothing but the highest praise for the courage and skill of all the aircraft and ship crews involved in the attempt to rescue these four people. The conditions out there could only be described as atrocious. They were described by the senior RAAF officer at the time as `extremely hazardous' for flying. They presented a considerable danger to the potential rescuers, and Mr Gruzman's article is in fact absolutely scurrilous to the people who were involved in that rescue.

In discussions I had with Mr Gruzman, I agreed to the purchase of the necessary pump equipment that he sells. I directed the organisation to purchase that equipment on a trial basis, and it was purchased. In closing, I must say that I intend to write to the Bulletin a rebuttal of that article, and I am sure that it will have the courtesy to publish it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to his letter to me dated 4 June-the dates here are important-admitting that Senator Richardson's statement to the Senate on 29 May that no new tracks had been bulldozed and no trees had been cut on Beecroft Peninsula at Jervis Bay during Exercise Termite Spray was `not correct'. I further note the Minister's statement that he was `advised that it was not clear until . . . 1 June that some new tracks had . . . been cut', and that `there is no direct evidence that the trees were cut down by Army during the exercise'. I also note that on 4 May a local resident, Mr Arvan Pritchard, saw an army truck laden with cut casuarina trees and a chain saw about 300 metres from fresh stumps and that Beecroft Range Commander David Minolis was sent a report of this sighting by rangers on 23 May. I ask the Minister: why has he failed to inform the Senate that it had been misinformed by Senator Richardson, using advice supplied by Minister Ray. Secondly, given that I have reliable evidence that all relevant officials-namely, Commodore Rob Partington, Lieutenant-Colonel Michael Cullen, Range Commander Minolis, and the Defence facilities branch-knew of the new tracks and the cut trees by 25 May at the latest, why was the Minister advised that these facts did not become clear until 1 June? Given that direct evidence that the trees were cut by the Army was provided to Range Commander Minolis on 23 May, why was the Minister advised that no such evidence existed? Finally, in order to clarify this serious matter, will the Minister undertake to table all documents and correspondence on Termite Spray?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts of the situation as it currently stands are as follows. The advice given by Senator Richardson was on the basis of advice from the Department of Defence, and therefore he has no responsibility in the sense of that advice. Firstly, I have to say that, despite Senator Coulter's assertion that service officials had prior knowledge of the cutting of these trees and the opening of new tracks, no doubt on this matter had been raised with me until 30 May-that is, subsequent to Senator Coulter's question, subsequent to the additional information provided by Senator Richardson and subsequent to Senator Coulter's own press release on the subject, which I think was on 29 May.

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed, once we received that sort of information, I instructed my staff to inquire of the Department to have these allegations double-checked, following the honourable senator's question and press release. It was on the basis of that checking that I sent a senior official to that area on 1 June. I do not think any of that is contested by Senator Coulter or myself. I have directed my Department to inquire into if and why service officers did not properly respond to any earlier advice they may have received. I am also indicating that if that is the case disciplinary action will be taken. I also say for the sake of the Senate that when Senator Richardson gave his additional information he used the words `I am advised that'. Therefore, if that advice is misleading, it cannot be in any way attributed to my colleague.

As I have said, as soon as I became aware that information may have been given to Senator Coulter or the Senate in an incorrect way, I informed Senator Coulter, I think before Question Time on Monday, that information had arrived and that I would be sending him that information, which I subsequently did on Tuesday. I had it hand delivered to his office. I also convened a meeting of officials for 3 o'clock on Tuesday to go back over this material and to make sure that, if there had been one fault, there would not be a second fault. As Senator Coulter would know, I did not attend that meeting. I was in this chamber while there was a censure motion against my colleague. Nevertheless, my staff instructed those officials that, before we respond in the Senate, they are to double-check the information in order to make sure that there could be no further misleading of the Senate or misinformation given to the Senate.

Concerning the third part of Senator Coulter's question, I do not know whether he has misinterpreted my letter. I have said that evidence exists that some trees were cut down. That is beyond doubt. I also have to say that there is no direct evidence that the Army cut down those trees, but I also acknowledge that the circumstantial evidence available to both Senator Coulter and me certainly points in that direction and further investigation will be carried out in this area.

Whatever happened in that exercise cannot excuse any environmental damage that might have been done during the exercise. I have directed that my departmental officers promptly carry out remedial works, undertake a full investigation of this episode and report to me and ensure that they fully cooperate with relevant parks and environmental authorities in the conduct of future exercises on Beecroft Peninsula.

As to the fourth part of Senator Coulter's question, I have requested an examination of the files with a view to tabling the documents requested by him. I must also point out that Beecroft Peninsula is first and foremost a defence gunnery range, an exercise area, the only one of its nature that exists in Australia. The fact that the vast majority of it remains in an unspoiled state is a testament to the normal, careful management and stewardship by Defence over the years. The fact that this area is there and available for public access and enjoyment when not required for defence activities compares most favourably to the situation in many other coastal areas. I add that most of the repair work that we carry out in the Jervis Bay area is not from defence bombardment but from that time when we open it up for eight months a year for others to come in and use it as a recreational resource.

However, I think the key part of the honourable senator's question which I would like to stress asks the reason why I am yet to put a correction to the Senate. It was in my own mind, and certainly in my staff's minds, whether we had been given the full story. If there has been misleading information given to the Senate, I am not going to compound that by providing other information that I am not fully satisfied with. When I have satisfied myself, I will make that statement in the Senate, correcting previous poor advice. I believe that I and certainly Senator Richardson have acted with total propriety in this matter. If the Senate has been misled by the incompetence of officials or if there has been any attempt to cover up this, the necessary action will be taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Firstly, in view of the fact that charges have been made both by me and in the newspapers before I asked the question of Senator Richardson, why were investigations not carried out before the advice was given to Senator Richardson which, as we now know, was incorrect when it was given to the Senate? Secondly, are we to assume that the information which has been provided to me in a private letter but not to the Senate is also suspect as to its accuracy because Senator Ray is not prepared to provide it to the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question of inaccuracy, I say to my colleagues in the Senate that I have not been asked to table that letter in the Senate. I am happy to do so right now, so Senator Coulter should not charge me with not being happy to do it and with saying that it is just a private letter. I am happy to table it myself; I am happy for him to table it.
—It is the fact that the information in the letter is wrong.

—The inference was that I was not prepared to table it; I am prepared to table that letter. But I would not be taking the action I am in having the whole matter investigated if I were totally convinced that there had been no further misinformation put out. That would be the end of the matter. I should at least say to the Senate that what is in contest here is whether Defence cut some new tracks and cut down some trees with a diameter of 20 centimetres or less-which it is entitled to do, incidentally, without reference to any other plan, provided the tree is less than 20 centimetres.

ANSWER.PARA: The real nub of the question is whether those who were involved in the exercise and those people at Jervis Bay provided correct advice to be passed on to Senator Richardson and, if not, why not? That is precisely the point I am investigating at the moment. I do not have that letter with me here, but if the honourable senator has it here, he should feel free to table it. There will be no objection from me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of two members of the Slovak National Assembly who are visiting Australia to attend a conference. On behalf of all honourable senators I wish them well. I also note the presence in my gallery of a distinguished former senator, John Stone. Again on behalf of all honourable senators I wish him well.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the series of Israeli bombing attacks on southern Lebanon which seems to be an incredibly inappropriate action at a time when there is some hope of a peaceful solution to Middle East tensions. What is the attitude of the Australian Government to these bombing attacks and what messages have been conveyed to the Israeli Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government deplores the Israeli bombing raids into Lebanon which have taken place in recent days and which are reportedly among the heaviest in recent years. There have been three separate raids into Lebanon since Tuesday, 4 June by Israeli war planes. They have been directed against Palestinian bases in the vicinity of the city of Sidon in southern Lebanon. I have no firm information on the number of casualties so far, but it appears from reports that they include civilians as well as Palestinian guerillas.

ANSWER.PARA: These operations coincide with the coming into force of the treaty of fraternity, cooperation and coordination between Lebanon and Syria. Israel opposes this treaty because it believes that the treaty will be a vehicle for the extension of Syrian influence in Lebanon. Whatever the possible provocation, the raids represent a serious violation of Lebanon's integrity and sovereignty. They will only serve to exacerbate tensions in the Middle East and could lead to retaliatory violence. The situation in southern Lebanon highlights the need for all parties involved in the Arab-Israeli conflict to exercise maximum restraint, particularly at this time as moves are under way to set in motion a peace process to resolve the dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate representing the Treasurer and the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the policy commitment of his prime ministerial candidate, the honourable member for Blaxland, on the recent Sunday program to deliver a pension of 70 per cent of pre-retirement earnings to the average worker by the year 2000. As this would require contributions of at least 15 per cent, and probably closer to 20 per cent, of wages over at least 35 years, and given that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has recently said that even an increase of one per cent per year is not on, does the Minister agree that this promise is not only totally unrealistic but yet another prime example of truth being the first casualty in an election campaign?
—Mr President, that is not a question that has anything to do with my portfolio responsibilities.
—Truth certainly does not have anything to do with your portfolio responsibility.
—Keep quiet, you windbag!

—I ask a supplementary question. I understand the Minister's sensitivity, but I trust that the Minister understands the seriousness of the proposition put. Therefore, I ask him to direct his attention to whether that is a realistic promise. In other words, given that we have 3 per cent award superannuation in place at the moment and Mr Keating is saying that one can get up to 15 to 20 per cent within nine years, does the Minister agree that that is totally unrealistic?

—Mr Keating is a member of the back bench in the House of Representatives. Senator Alston might as well ask me what I think about some proposition emanating from Senator Walters or Senator Lewis back there. It is not a relevant question for my portfolio.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to last week's tragic accident in Thailand involving a Boeing 767 aircraft. Was the aircraft of exactly the same type as operated by Qantas Airways Ltd on its regional services from cities such as Adelaide, Perth and Brisbane? Is the Minister aware that one possible cause of the accident now being examined is that one engine went into reverse thrust mode, normally used to slow down an aircraft after it has landed on a runway? Can reverse thrust only be used when an aircraft's wheels are down and locked in position? Are Australia's civil aviation authorities being kept fully informed on the accident investigation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last part of Senator Maguire's question is yes.
—How about Meekathara?
—I was briefed--
—He knows everything else but he doesn't know that.

— That was such an idiotic interjection, Senator Knowles, that I was temporarily rendered speechless. I was briefed on this incident by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation yesterday. I think that what the investigation is revealing in this tragic event is that it is very foolish indeed to leap too quickly to judgment ever incidents involving aircraft. The investigation has been hampered to a very significant extent because the flight data recorder has been destroyed. The cockpit voice recorder has been recovered. The flight data recorder boxes are designed to withstand temperatures of 1200 degrees for up to half an hour, but clearly the post-crash fire exceeded these conditions and all the internal contents of the box have been reduced to ash. The cockpit voice recorder, however, which has been recovered has been analysed, but it still leaves many questions unanswered as to whether this tragic accident was caused by sabotage or related to a technical failure.

ANSWER.PARA: The investigating team, which comprises both Thai and United States officials, has just returned to the crash site. They will be there for at least the remainder of this week and have no easy communications at the site. I would also add that the investigating conditions are very difficult at the site. For example, just the other day to turn one of the engines over to recover an important part involved with the reverse thrust, an elephant had to be used to move the engine, so conditions at the site are very difficult. The team will return at the end of this week and further information will be gathered. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation is in constant touch with the investigating team and is being fully briefed on the issue.

The Boeing 767 aircraft which are used in Australia by Ansett Airlines of Australia and Qantas are of the same general type as the one that was lost, but the engines are different; they are of different manufacture and different models. If it comes to light-and it has not yet been established-that a malfunction in the reverse thrust mechanism was the cause of the accident, such an incident is not a potential problem here with the engine types that are used in Australia, because the control mechanisms used on these engines for reverse thrust are completely different.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. I ask him a question about integrity. Two and a half years ago the Minister in his role as Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories praised a Tasmanian Minister for having the courage and integrity to stand up and reveal to the Tasmanian Parliament that his Government had misled the public on a matter of fact over the Wesley Vale pulp mill. Does the Minister still maintain that in the face of denials, lies and deceptions, the courageous path, the path of integrity, is to speak up and tell the Parliament the truth, and if the Minister does not, why not?
—All I can say in answer to Senator Walters's question is that I have always told the Parliament the truth and will continue to do so.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister says that he has always told the Parliament the truth-I presume he also means that he has always told the truth outside the Parliament, in his ministerial capacity. Can he explain an answer he gave only yesterday on the John Laws program in which he was busy defending the integrity of Mr Keating, and did not reveal that he knew that his leader was deliberately misleading the public in order to win the spoils of office? So my supplementary question is in two parts. First, does the Minister always tell the truth in his ministerial capacity outside the Parliament or only in the Parliament, and the second part concerns the John Laws program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I am asked whether I have always told the truth outside Parliament. I am going to make a particularly major admission: I am not perfect, I have sinned on occasion.
—What!
—I know that Senator Maguire finds this hard to believe; I can see the disbelief in his eyes. There have been times when I might have told an untruth to another person.
—When was that?

—I know that Senator Faulkner does not believe it, but it is true. Yesterday I received some photographs taken of my family and me with the Pope. I think he might be the only person I have been with in recent times who could actually make the claim that he has never told an untruth-and I am not sure that he would try to make that claim. No-one here would try to make it. What a ridiculous assertion.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as the question relating to the John Laws program is concerned--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is well aware that I said, `in his capacity as Minister'.

—Mr President, on the point of order: it is becoming a regular practice that Senator Walters gets up and makes debating points which have no relevance to the Standing Orders. I think that this has to be ruled on now and the necessary action taken if this is to become a repetitive thing in the chamber. Everyone takes an occasional burst like this one with good humour, but Senator Walters gets up every time now and takes points of order which are merely matters of debate.
—Order! There is no point of order. I have warned Senator Walters about this before.
—Mr President, I acknowledge that you have warned me before, but you have not warned Senator Ray. I ask you to warn Senator Ray.
—Order! Senator Walters, I have warned all honourable senators about taking these dubious points of order.

—I am not certain of the exact quote to which Senator Walters is referring from the interview that I did on the John Laws program yesterday. I made the point here a few days ago that I do not intend to continually answer questions that are outside my portfolio, and I will not. I made myself available for an hour on a national radio program, covered by television, so that everyone could hear the questions that were asked and hear them answered-and they were.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. I refer to a report tabled at the National Health and Medical Research Council meeting in Brisbane today which states that about 5,000 Australian babies are born each year with genetically inherited disorders, and that the best way to diagnose or predict the disorders is to keep detailed registers of genetic information on affected people and their families. Is it a fact that the National Health and Medical Research Council is encouraging the establishment of national computer registers of persons and families with genetic disorders? Is it also a fact that the main purpose of these registers is not the cure of disorders but the prevention of the birth of babies with particular genetically inherited disorders, including by means of prenatal diagnosis and abortion? If that is the main purpose of the registers-that is to say, the detection of individuals deemed to have life unworthy of life-how are they to be distinguished from the national card index of persons with genetic taints established by the Nazi doctors under the Third Reich?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of a meeting of the National Health and Medical Research Council, or a committee of it, in Brisbane today dealing with the possible compilation of a register of genetic defects which may be handed on from generation to generation. Therefore, I am not in a position to answer Senator Harradine's question as to whether such a register is being proposed with the main purpose of facilitating diagnosis of a baby carrying such a defect within the womb and, therefore, presenting the woman bearing that child with an opportunity to make a decision as to whether to carry on the pregnancy.

ANSWER.PARA: I am unable to answer the question, although I would say that surely in the Australian community there would be complete revulsion at the idea that the genetic practices of the Nazis might be reproduced in any form in Australian society. I am quite sure that the international medical ethics which were the result of the world's revulsion at those Nazi practices would provide sure guidance and criteria for the National Health and Medical Research Council in making any decision in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Yesterday Senator Bolkus failed to answer a question put to him and I ask him if he will now answer that question. What hope is there for the proper conduct of free and fair elections if the Prime Minister and other Ministers are prepared to lie to or mislead the Australian public at election time?

—Senator Vanstone asked this question yesterday, but it seems that she has left out the second part of it. I do not know how this fits within my responsibility, but I can tell her that I have been in this place for almost 10 years now, and before every election we have heard rantings and ravings from the other side about how it will win, and expectations to that effect. The reality has been that every time it has come to an election, the people have made their decisions on the Government's record and its proposals for the future. What will happen next time will be the same. I will give you some advice, Senator Vanstone, advice which maybe you should have taken before previous elections. To the extent that you try to dwell on these issues-issues which run second to bread and butter issues in the electorate-you will find yourself on the other side forever.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, this fits into your responsibility for the Commonwealth Electoral Act which obviously covers the conduct of elections. You know that quite well. You still have not answered the question, so let me rephrase it for you: do you think it is acceptable for Ministers, in particular the Prime Minister, to deliberately lie to or mislead the Australian public at election time, and do you really mean to say in your answer that truth in politics is not a matter of concern to the Australian people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am reminded of a speech that the former Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, made about politics. I am sorry that I did not have the time to find the quote this morning but, basically, he said, `There is something inevitable about politics. When you are on one side of the House you run certain arguments and when you are on the other you run arguments that are totally opposite to the ones that you used to run before'. Senator Chaney was probably an expert in that respect.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is quite fair to indicate that the Prime Minister has already handled this question. If the Liberals are so concerned about truth in campaigning and if they are so concerned about undertakings to the electorate, they only have to look at their record consistently over a number of years in that regard. At this moment one is also reminded of the fact that in the current debate on political advertising a proposal which has been put up by the Australian Democrats has been given serious consideration by the Government. That proposal goes towards truth in advertising. Very soon we will be able to see what sort of hypocrisy or honesty those opposite have on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Powell, I ask honourable senators asking questions not to refer to the Minister as `You' but to ask the question through the Chair.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to an article which appeared in the Australian of 5 June 1991 headed `Fast Train Project back on the Rails'. This article quotes Senator Button as saying that the issue of tax changes to promote private investment in large capital works projects is a `live one'. I ask the Minister: firstly, is the issue now more live because of the departure of the former Treasurer who opposed such tax concessions? Secondly, is it true that Mr Kerin is more sympathetic to the very fast train (VFT) project? Thirdly, who is the chair of the Cabinet subcommittee looking into the issue? Fourthly, is it now the Government's view that there is some discrimination in the tax laws against private investors in large scale projects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I said to the journalists who asked those questions which led to the comments which appeared in the Australian was that the question of private sector participation in infrastructure development normally associated with government expenditure was being looked at and that there was some uncertainty. For example, there is a claim that the present tax structure does not discriminate against private sector participation in infrastructure development; others say that it does, and those two points of view are being examined.

ANSWER.PARA: The former Treasurer, Mr Keating, was, essentially, chairman of the subcommittee that is looking at that issue. I am quite unable to say whether the issue is more live as a result of the change in Treasurer. The purpose of the subcommittee was not solely a question of dealing with the problems of the VFT consortium; it was a broader inquiry. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health and regards the concerns of the ACT-UP lobby on the subject of HIV-AIDS. Why does the Government consider that the personal importation scheme, where ill people must pay to import their own drugs from overseas because they are not available in Australia, enables fair and equitable access to lifesaving drugs when many people facing these illnesses are already seriously disadvantaged financially and on sickness benefits and invalid pensions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I answered a question somewhat along these lines from Senator Lees yesterday. I think what I was indicating was that the Government has, in contrast with many other overseas countries, tried to create a situation whereby those people suffering from HIV infection or full-blown AIDS are in fact shown compassion and given practical care by this community in a way which does not lead to their impoverishment. In fact, the whole Medicare system is a very firm foundation for enabling the treatment of persons suffering from the virus or AIDS in a way which does not burden them with those horrendous costs which is their fate in many other countries around the world.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, I think what I indicated was that the therapeutic goods regulations have been altered to allow individual importation of treatments not registered in Australia provided they are prescribed by a medical practitioner. I believe this should be regarded as an advance on what was previously the case, although it is a fact that in some circumstances persons who bring in such medicines do have to pay the cost. As Senator Vallentine will know, we are certainly not attempting to be complacent or satisfied with the way in which drugs are evaluated, registered and permitted to be prescribed in a way which attracts a benefit here in Australia. Not only is the Dr Peter Baume inquiry being undertaken, but also I believe the Government is trying to ensure that, as far as possible, those who suffer from this terrible illness can get such treatment and drugs as they require.

It is the case that in Australia at the moment only one treatment is approved as acting specifically on the virus HIV. That treatment is of course approved in Australia with government subsidy. Once again, I contrast that with the situation in the United States where the drug is not available with a government subsidy. I believe that certainly indicates the attitude of the Government. I believe that other drugs may come onto the market and be given registration and approval, and the Government will then be in a position to consider the proper subsidy that might apply.

In general, the Government has endeavoured to undertake such changes as are necessary to the various regulations to ensure that either by way of a subsidy offered by the rest of the community in relation to approved drugs and medicines, or at least by permitting the import of certain other medicines and drugs from overseas, those who suffer from this illness are given an opportunity to have the treatment that they require in order to deal with this terrible disease.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his answer, but it is obvious from the answer, which is very similar to the one he gave Senator Lees yesterday, that he did not have a briefing from the Minister for Community Services and Health. I ask that he bring this matter to the attention of the Minister for a more considered, urgent and compassionate reply. This is now the fifth report on this issue in this country. —I undertake to make sure that the Minister is made aware of Senator Vallentine's concerns, which I believe are the concerns of all members of this Parliament-that compassionate and practical care be available to those suffering from the HIV virus.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Yesterday the Senate discussed my action in calling Senator McMullan in the debate on the motion by Senator Lewis to take note of an answer to a question given by Senator Button. SPEECH.PARA: Subject to the practices of the Senate relating to the call to speak, when two or more Senators rise together to speak, the President shall call upon the Senator who, in the President's opinion, first rose in the Senator's place.

The practices followed by the Chair in giving the call, based on past rulings of Presidents, were set out in a paper which was circulated by the then Deputy President with the approval of the President in November 1987. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall incorporate the paper in Hansard at the end of this statement.

One of these practices is stated to be that, `Senators are usually called from each side of the chamber alternately'. This practice is modified in some circumstances. As I indicated yesterday, in calling Senator McMullan after Senator Button had spoken I was influenced by the fact that there had been five speakers in succession from the Opposition side of the chamber. As I also indicated yesterday, I was influenced by the fact that Senator McMullan, as a Parliamentary Secretary, acts for Ministers in the Senate and is regarded as the equivalent of a Minister for some purposes.

On reflection, I probably overstated the position yesterday in suggesting that a Parliamentary Secretary has the same procedural status as a Minister. Perhaps I should have given more weight to the fact that Senator McMullan was moving the closure and therefore potentially terminating the debate. But, as honourable senators will appreciate, giving the call is a split-second decision and there is sometimes not sufficient time properly to weigh all the competing factors in one's mind.

I do not consider that this statement requires debate again today because, as I indicated yesterday, I will refer the matter to the Procedure Committee. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a document headed `The Call to Speak in Debate'.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE CALL TO SPEAK IN DEBATE
Standing Order 186(2) provides:

``Subject to the practices of the Senate relating to the call to speak, when 2 or more Senators rise together to speak, the President shall call upon the Senator who, in the President's opinion, first rose in the Senator's place.''
In its application the standing order is governed by a number of practices giving certain Senators priority in the call.
Presidential rulings of the past have explicitly identified the following practices:
(a) Senators are usually called from each side of the Chamber alternately.
(b) The call is given to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate before other Senators.
(c) A minister in charge of a bill or other matter before the Senate is usually given the call before other Senators.
The following practices have also been followed:
(d) An Opposition Senator leading for the Opposition in relation to a bill or other matter before the Senate is usually given the call before other Senators.
(e) Leaders of other non-government parties are usually given the call before other Senators, subject to the foregoing practices.
(f) Senators who have a right to the call under these practices are discouraged from exercising it if that would have the effect of closing the debate and other Senators wish to speak.

These practices should be regarded as being applied in the order indicated, so that each practice is subject to those that precede it in the list. If interpreted in this way, the various practices are consistent with each other.

In many debates an agreed speakers' list is compiled by the Whips and provided to the Chair, and Senators normally seek and receive the call in accordance with the list. The Standing Orders Committee in 1974 considered the status of this list and agreed that the list is ``unofficial and not a curb on the President, whose duty and privilege it [is] to say which Senator . . . [has] a prior right to speak'', and that the list could be used ``on the understanding that it is unofficial and must not be referred to in debate''. The Senate adopted the Committee's report. The list should also be regarded as subject to each of the practices listed above.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Walters this day, relating to the leadership of the Government.

This Senate has asked several Ministers in this chamber about their feelings on whether the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) should have told a lie and about the integrity of the Government generally. Let me go from the top to the bottom. Senator Button has said that it is quite all right to tell a lie as has Senator Robert Ray, Senator Richardson, Senator Bolkus and Senator Collins. Indeed, Senator Collins today said that the Opposition is being sanctimonious when we say we believe that there should be integrity and truth from Ministers. I remarked earlier on the right of the public to have confidence in the integrity of its elected representatives.

Richard Carleton then turned to the Treasurer, who was sitting beside the Prime Minister, and asked whether he would be happy to hang around for that period of time. Mr Keating said:

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN OFFSETS PROGRAM-INCLUDING PARTNERSHIPS FOR DEVELOPMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I want to make a few remarks on this report. I saw the draft of this report at the time of the Estimates committees. There are two things I want to say about it. First, the nature of the report has improved over the last year and I think that that probably has something to do with the fact that there is a new person in charge of light industry within the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce (DITAC), a change which has taken place after many years of criticising the work of that Department with regard to the administration of the offsets program and partnerships for development program.

A read of the report itself-although it is improved in terms of the information-still leaves people such as I with great disquiet over the effectiveness of both of those programs, particularly in chapter 6, when dealing with the partnerships for development program, where one sees that the reports concerning the effectiveness of this program are always in global terms and there is no breakdown. So, one really does not know whether individual firms are truly performing, because the simple fact of the matter is that when a firm enters the program, when a firm enters a so-called partnership agreement with the Government, it has seven years in which to perform its obligations. Indeed, there is no requirement that it has to reach any particular benchmark on an annual basis.

There is no reporting of the success or adjudged failure of progress being made by individual firms. Indeed, one could be forgiven for saying that the partnerships program was a very clever manoeuvre to allow some firms to get around the offsets obligation program. There is really no deterrent against breaching the partnership agreement. The real downside of the program is that, in order to do business with the Government in terms of selling information technology (IT), a firm really has to join the club, and that is the partnerships program, and this in fact adds to the cost of acquiring IT. When one realises that, in the last financial year, the total import bill for information technology into this country was $5.2 billion, the single largest import into this country, and one realises that despite the fact that we are a relatively small country we are the eighth largest market in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries for information technology, and that the lion's share of that market for private firms to sell to is the Government, one does really wonder whether or not we require to make the purchases that are in fact made. The matter of scrutiny is not adequate to see whether IT that is purchased is in fact used effectively. The whole paraphernalia of offsets and partnerships is just adding to the mystique and adding to costs.

It was interesting when in this chamber in the past day or two Senator Button announced that a new agreement had been entered into in the aerospace industry area, that in fact this is another mechanism which enables people to get around the offsets program, and when I interjected and said `Why don't you just scrap the programs?', I think one will find from a read of the Hansard that he thought that could be a good idea. So, in speaking to the report, I say that the report has certainly improved since the removal, or movement of Dr Fitzpatrick away from the light industries area but, at the same time, the programs themselves remain subject to strict scrutiny and indeed doubt as to their worthiness.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDEPENDENT REVIEW OF ASBESTOS IN DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.

The report of Mr Enfield, on asbestos in the Department of Defence and affecting Defence personnel, is a valuable document. Inquiries have been carried out expeditiously. He was asked to carry out an inquiry in August and the report was given to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) in March this year. The asbestos hazard in the Department of Defence has been known for a long time. Indeed, action has been taken in recognition of that within the Department. The first action was taken as long ago as 1968. So, it cannot be said that the Department of Defence has ignored this serious problem. Fortunately, Mr Enfield has found that a relatively small number of Defence personnel have been affected by asbestos related illnesses. Nevertheless, it is clearly a responsibility of the Department to ensure that this is kept to a minimum. The Minister recognises that and he has stated that as the Government's policy.

What concerns me about the report, in the short time that I have had to look at it, relates to some of the conclusions that Mr Enfield has made in relation to Defence policy on this matter. He says that there has been a multitude of instructions relating to asbestos but that the instructions were inadequate and a new approach was needed. He said that there was no framework of policy for commanders and managers in Defence and instructions were produced in a variety of areas within the Department and services, leading to internal inconsistencies. He concluded:
The instructions seemed to me to reflect the concerns of the originators rather than the needs of users.

He then gives examples of some of the inconsistencies that have appeared in instructions and he sets out his recommendations for a policy framework and the sort of instructions that should be given to commanders and managers. I am pleased to see the Minister has agreed and accepted a large number of Mr Enfield's recommendations dealing with training, identification of asbestos, development of management policies, medical counselling and so on.

However, on this particular recommendation of policy framework, he says that this is being addressed by the Department as a high priority, and so it should be. I find it disturbing that no policy framework has been developed in the Department over a period of 23 years in which this subject has been recognised as a problem. The hit and miss approach that has been adopted reflects badly on the administration of the Department of Defence. It is by no means confined to this particular problem and it is certainly one that presents as a fundamental problem in the administration of defence.

I hope the Government will move, as the Minister says, as a high priority. I hope the Minister will have more success in improving the administration of the Department in this regard than has been achieved in other aspects of its administration. I am pleased that this matter has been attended to in this report and that these failings will be rectified in the Department as soon as possible.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
