DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on a visit to Papua New Guinea (PNG), February-March 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade I present the Committee's report entitled Report of a Visit to Papua New Guinea. This report is the result of a visit in February this year, undertaken by a working group selected from Committee members. The Committee consisted of some 10 members, although a lot more members of the overall Committee wanted to go on that visit, which indicates the great interest of both the Committee and the Australian Parliament in Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea.

The purpose of the visit was to study conditions and attitudes in Papua New Guinea as a background to our current inquiry into Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea. While parliamentary committees have no authority to gather official evidence outside Australian territory, and do not generally travel overseas in the course of inquiries, it was considered essential in this case to make an exception.

It was important to pay our neighbours the courtesy of considering the relationship from their point of view. More importantly, during the course of the visit it became obvious that we could learn a great deal about improving the relationship from our Papua New Guinean neighbours. We are therefore very grateful to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for personally intervening to ensure the Committee could make the visit and also to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) for providing a Royal Australian Air Force plane.

While the visit was associated with a Committee inquiry, the report now being tabled is simply a report of the visit. It does not address the matters which are the subject of the inquiry itself. That report will be presented to the Parliament later this year.

The visit took place over eight hectic days from 23 February to 1 March 1991. During this time we were privileged to hold discussions with the Acting Governor-General, with senior Cabinet Ministers including the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister, with the premiers and cabinets of six provinces, with many of the leading citizens of the country and with many ordinary Papua New Guineans in the cities, towns and villages.

The Committee wishes to place on record its thanks to all these people, who so generously gave their time, their hospitality and their ideas to help the working group to explore the many dimensions of the Australian-Papua New Guinean relationship. We would also like to thank the crew of the RAAF Hercules, who made the covering of large distances in a short time both possible and enjoyable. We thank the High Commissioner and his staff and the Speaker and Sergeant-at-Arms of the Papua New Guinea Parliament who contributed enormously to the success of the visit.

It is not generally realised that PNG is the largest South Pacific nation after Australia, its population having recently surpassed that of New Zealand. Its known natural resources are enormous, and the discovery of new riches is a relatively common occurrence. PNG is also our nearest neighbour. What happens there affects Australia. But it is not mere geographic proximity which ties Australia to PNG and vice versa; the historical connections cannot be ignored.

Australia has been associated with the country since 1884, having ruled Papua as a Territory from 1906 and administered New Guinea from 1914. The formal relationship ended in 1975. On the evening of 15 September 1975 the Australian flag was lowered at the Sir Hubert Murray Stadium in Port Moresby. A Warrant Officer of the Pacific Islands Regiment presented it to Sir John Guise, Governor-General designate of PNG, who called on everybody to note, `We are lowering it, not tearing it down'.

The sentiment expressed then seems to live on. The working group was impressed with the obvious affection felt by so many Papua New Guineas for Australians-an affection that is returned by the many Australians who have lived and worked in the country.

Nostalgia for the past is an important foundation stone of the current relationship, but it is not the cornerstone. Respect for the past should not blur the focus on the present and future. Our relationship is one which both sides need to work for-taking nothing for granted. In this regard we were greatly encouraged by the care with which the Papua New Guineans with whom we met had prepared for our visit.

Members of the working group returned to Australia with vivid impressions of the variety and vitality of PNG. While it has many problems to overcome, it is difficult not to feel optimistic about its future. As chairman of the working group and Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I thoroughly enjoyed the visit. I have come away from PNG, despite all its problems, with a more optimistic feeling than expressed in some of the coverage PNG has received in the Australian media. It is unfortunate that there are some things that get sensationalised coverage in Australia which do not reflect the country's many achievements.

This report is only of the visit of the working party. It in no way attempts to prejudge any of the recommendations that the Joint Committee will bring down in its report on the present inquiry. That report, which is anticipated to be tabled later this year, will be a substantial report. Already the Committee has put many hours and hours of work into the report in assessing many submissions and having public hearings.

When the report is tabled it will be a benchmark for improving already good relations but even making them better with PNG. It will help many people in academia, the Australian community and PNG understand how our relationship can be improved. There is no doubt that when the report is tabled it will be greatly enhanced by the fact that 10 members of the Committee, and the secretary, Judy Middlebrook, had the opportunity to visit PNG for eight days.

Though it was unusual for the Committee to be able to send a working party to visit PNG, it will certainly enhance the credibility of the report. In future, both the Parliament and the Government should look at ensuring that, where inquiries are being conducted by standing committees of the Parliament with our near neighbours, despite the expense it is appropriate that members of those committees visit countries such as PNG to ensure that the report they table and finally come down with has the extra dimension of on hand experience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to travel over the territory that has just been traversed by Senator Schacht, except to say that I agree with all the comments he made. There is great virtue in the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade travelling to the countries that it is addressing in terms of a reference given to it by the Senate. I well remember the visit that a delegation made to the South Pacific when that was subject to a reference from this Parliament. Unfortunately, at the last minute I was unable to attend. I felt that there was a very real gulf, when it came to writing that report, between my working understanding of those nations and the understanding of those who had been on the trip. I felt a real sense of inadequacy in seeking to make a contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, I think there is something slightly obscene about this Parliament having a view, taking evidence and writing a report about our near neighbours but not, during the course of that deliberation, making a deliberate trip to the particular nation. I am sure that all who went on this delegation would agree that their knowledge was enhanced and their confidence that the report would reflect their understanding of the country and would be much more precise as a result of this visit was increased.

It is also true to say that there has been a paucity, in terms of visits and communications, between the Australian Parliament and the people of Papua New Guinea (PNG) in recent times. There is a temptation to overfly it on our way to more exotic destinations and that is not lost on PNG. We would be very unwise to take our relationship for granted. There is an enormous amount of intrinsic goodwill for us. It is our responsibility in all relationships to keep them in good repair. That could best be achieved by ensuring that there are regular visits between this Parliament and the Parliament of New Guinea. It is simply inadequate and unsatisfactory for it to be on a leader to leader basis, and it should not be party by party either. There really needs to be demonstrable interest shown by this Parliament in our northern neighbour. Papua New Guinea is one of the few countries where we can say that we do have a very special and almost unique relationship. Of course, it is the only country with which we are involved, as a colony, in some way.

There are all sorts of very good and natural reasons why we should maintain the goodwill and relationship that we presently have. Senator Schacht was quite right. From time to time, there is some adverse and unfortunate press in Australia in terms of events that take place in PNG. I feel that I came away recognising many of the problems but with a renewed sense of hope and optimism for that country, as well as recognising the very real advancement that it has made in the last 20 or 30 years.

I conclude on a parochial note by saying that the delegation was well and competently led by Senator Chris Schacht. We received excellent attention and dedicated commitment from Judy Middlebrook, who discharged her responsibilities with due care and goodwill. It is an accurate statement to reflect that the delegation worked well as a team, even though it was made up of a group of disparate people with varying attitudes and outlooks. We managed to get a refined and collective view about the events in PNG and, to an extent, our visit will help us all to write a majority report which will reflect the views of the whole committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commend Judy Middlebrook, the then secretary of the foreign affairs subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, for writing this Report on a Visit to Papua New Guinea so well due to her diligent note taking during the journey. Apart from diligent note taking, she managed the visit extremely well and we owe our thanks to her. I endorse all the thanks in the report and those mentioned by Senators Crichton-Browne and Schacht just now, and I also especially mention those listed in sections 2.5 to 2.9 of the report itself. The vibrancy and generosity of the welcomes from the people of Papua New Guinea (PNG) wherever we went were quite remarkable. I am sure all the delegation will treasure those memories.

SPEECH.PARA: This, of course, is only a short report of the visit and discussion should not pre-empt the findings of the Committee's considered report on Australia's relationship with PNG, which will be completed in a few months time. I would like to briefly comment on two aspects not covered in the report. As the report states, we were unable to visit the East Awin refugee camp, which would have been of great interest to us especially as a considerable amount of Australian aid has helped in that area.

Another area which was not even considered for the agenda, because of its extreme sensitivity, was Bougainville. Yet this was one of the most discussed issues of the visit. Everywhere we went, we were interested to hear people's views which were very wide-ranging on the subject of Bougainville. However, an Australian Council for Overseas Aid team recently went there and there was also a seminar on Bougainville at the Australian National University on 17 May. I want to mention a couple of points about the situation on Bougainville, some of which have further developed in the months since February when we were in PNG.

I am perturbed by the apparent failure of the PNG Government to fulfil its part of the agreement with the islanders, so they are still without fuel, medical supplies and things that they vitally need; and also the Australian Government's equal unwillingness to provide relief supplies until formally requested by the PNG Government. There have been plenty of discussions and requests, both at the ministerial and Australian High Commission level. But our Government-according to Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, in a reply to a question from me the other day-is waiting for the full commitment of the PNG Government to the Honiara declaration and also for acceptance of it by Bougainvilleans as a pre-condition for Australian assistance. This is thus putting more hurdles in the way of immediate aid provision.

There have been many meetings, as I have said, which have given strong indications of calls by some PNG ministers for help but it seems that the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is erring on the side of caution and waiting for a formally written request. For example, within a couple of days of the Honiara declaration, Sir Michael Somare at a news conference called for an Australian Hercules to fly straight into Bougainville with a load of medical supplies. But this has not happened yet.

We do not know exactly how many people have died in Bougainville during this crisis. Michael Ogio, the member of parliament for Bougainville North and who spoke in the PNG Parliament last month after 17 months of house arrest in Bougainville, estimates that 1,500 people died during the armed conflict in 1989 and early 1990, with another 3,000 dead as a result of the blockade. Some of the very ill population have gone over to the Solomon Islands for medical treatment and the hospital at Gizo is now desperately short of the necessary supplies and equipment to meet those needs.

It is the women and children who suffer most. They are, of course, the least likely to have their voices heard in the all male PNG Parliament. As the only woman on the Australian delegation, I feel that this is very important to emphasise because it is always the women and children who suffer most in wars.
An article in the Weekend Australian on 1 June put it:
Bougainville's women are tired of ill-health and violence. They perform most of the work on the island, have been the victims of rape by both the PNGDF and BRA, and are denied a voice.

I am not surprised that, following a church service in Arawa, Catholic women gathered to sing for the reporter from the Australian John Lennon's song with revised lyrics. They sang: `Lord, we are praying, give peace a chance'. Yet we have the Australian Government not wanting to be seen to give any credibility to the Bougainvilleans' call for self-determination. On the one hand that is understandable in the political context of our relationship between the two countries, but on the other hand we willingly supply extra aid materials to the PNG defence forces, which have been responsible for some gross violations of human rights on the island. We do not seem to have such a sensitivity as far as that goes, or such a reluctance to be helpful.

The Australian relief team which recently visited Bougainville found that almost every family it visited had lost a relative to curable illnesses such as malaria, because medical supplies, facilities and access had virtually disappeared. All children born since the crisis remain unvaccinated against preventable diseases. I question why we are letting this happen on our doorstep. Bougainvilleans are Papua New Guinean citizens, too. We have an enduring responsibility to them which, given the emergency situation, should be very important and should stand aside from the very delicate political considerations. If we can give assistance to people in far away places on an emergency relief basis, I think that we ought also to be able to do it as far as the Bougainvilleans are concerned.

The Australian relief team was a humanitarian mission. The Deputy Director of Australian Catholic Relief, Denis Tamplin, said that he hoped the group's reaction would spur the PNG Government to ship in more supplies and that the Australian Government's support for stepping up aid into Bougainville would be forthcoming immediately. I find it ironic that Australia can increase military aid from $19m to $50m in just two years without any hesitation virtually as a result of the Bougainville crisis but dallies over supplies that could save people's lives every day.

The blockade was officially lifted five months ago, so there is really no excuse for this continued delay. On the whole the PNG Government is subservient to the military. It is interesting to note the comments of the PNG Defence Minister, Benais Sabumei, in early May this year when he presented his annual report to the PNG Parliament:
I must say that the Bougainville crisis was a blessing in disguise for the PNGDF where we have recognised our weaknesses and areas we should improve on.

Aid agencies are quite clear what the people of Bougainville need at this moment, so we hope that the Australian Government will get on, in advance of the considered report of the Committee about the relationship, and step up the humanitarian aid.

On a more positive note, another aspect of the visit which was not covered in the report due to its brevity was the excellent discussion with women's leaders which took place at the Australian High Commission, I think on the last day of our visit. The Commission staff looked after us extremely well in all respects during our visit there, and we thank them for that. This sort of a round table discussion with a women's group was a first for them, too. I am sure that it will not be the last. Unfortunately, not all of the Australian delegation was present, which was a great pity as it was a particularly illuminating couple of hours. Papua New Guinea is a very male dominated society and, quite frankly, we had hardly heard women's viewpoints until that meeting. Currently there is not one woman member in the PNG Parliament, and we did not meet any women representatives in the provincial governments either. Yet, interestingly, often the male expatriats would voluntarily comment on the strength of PNG women in holding the fabric of PNG society together. Their voices must be heard.

This was a group of well-educated women from various professions who informed us about a range of issues including bride price traditions, family planning programs and the domestic violence aspect of the law and order problem. It was a privilege to meet with this group, the only regret being that, because we were late for the meeting, it seemed very short. The PNG women realised the necessity to get to their homes before dark because of the security problems and we could not extend that meeting.

I endorse the conclusions of the report wholeheartedly. It is very important to actively pursue close contact with our nearest neighbour. We have much to learn from each other. I agree with what Senator Crichton-Browne said on that point: we must not take this relationship for granted. I also agree with Senator Schacht that, despite PNG's many problems, the energy of its people left me, too, with a sense of optimism for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only just received a copy of the report on a visit to Papua New Guinea by certain members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I am not able to comment on the report, not having read it thoroughly, but I want to echo the views that have been expressed here today that Papua New Guinea is clearly our closest neighbour and the country with which we should have the closest relationship. The people of Papua New Guinea are people of great resourcefulness. I have had the pleasure of visiting Papua New Guinea on a number of occasions and, indeed, I was the only back-bench member of this Federal Parliament to be invited to the opening of the new Parliament House in Papua New Guinea some years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I am somewhat perturbed about some views that have been around for a while and have been publicly expressed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in respect of population growth in Papua New Guinea. The Minister is on the record the other day as saying that we are getting concerned about the population growth in Papua New Guinea. We can see what he has done as a result. The Australian International Development Assistance Bureau has diverted moneys that were going to an environmental program in the agricultural field to a United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) population program in Papua New Guinea which relies heavily on the controversial drug depo-provera. I sincerely hope that Senator Evans does not get concerned about the population growth in Tasmania, if there is such. I think it is quite disgraceful, frankly, to support a program which relies on a birth control drug which is not an approved indication in Australia.

We have had this out in the Estimates hearings and I do not want to labour the point, but I want to put the record straight-because the record was not put straight previously-and say that the UNFPA, with its associations with the drug companies, does not support a method which has been developed by Australian doctors John and Evelyn Billings, both of whom have received recognition for their services to the community, namely, the Billings ovulation method.

This is a readily accepted and understood method, particularly in rural areas. It is particularly understood by those who are illiterate, those who know how to recognise cycles. In trials done by a number of groups, including recent tests in Indonesia and India by international organisations which do not share my views, this method has come through with flying colours.

Whatever we do so far as Papua New Guinea is concerned, we must respect the individual rights of the people of that country. We must respect their culture and not have this type of cultural imperialism as was inherent in the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade that he is getting worried about the population growth in Papua New Guinea. I caution any group that might be considering a report on Papua New Guinea about that sort of attitude. I know that this is not the time to debate fully that question here today, but I merely raise it because I believe it is important that full consideration be given to the rights of individuals and families in Papua New Guinea and to uphold the dignity of their culture. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Vanstone, I present the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority on the examination of the National Crime Authority annual report for 1989-90, and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address briefly the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority on the examination of the National Crime Authority annual report for 1989-90. It is worth noting that this report covers a period before the present Chairman, Mr Justice Phillips, commenced his work at the National Crime Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: In the view of the Committee, the report is a workmanlike document, with the exception of two matters-the name of a person who should not have been mentioned under the terms of the legislation which established the National Crime Authority and some incorrect figures. Both of these matters were dealt with constructively, expeditiously and without any fuss whatsoever by the National Crime Authority. I believe that this reflects the current situation at the Authority, which is proceeding in new directions, as outlined in a document prepared and published by the Chairman, Mr Justice Phillips, entitled New Directions.

It may be an opportune moment to advert briefly to these `directions' and to put on record my reaction to them. In the document, Mr Justice Phillips states that the National Crime Authority will depart from its previous emphasis, which largely concentrated on drug trafficking, and take as a major long term concern serious white collar crime, which is currently on the ascendancy in Australia.

But, apart from such a broad reference and any specific ones that the Authority will deal with which will be not openended but will have a firm time line, the Authority also intends to adopt a different mode of operation and to place a lot more emphasis on partnership activities with particular reference to intelligence-sharing; to monitoring trends, particularly in the area of white collar crime; to law reform activities-in other words, advice to the Government where changes to legislation are indicated-and generally to a sharing of information in the community.

An example of the latter attempt is the forthcoming conference in July called `Presentation of Complex Corporate Prosecutions to Juries'. In recognition that this mode of operation is not as easily monitored and assessed as work primarily directed towards obtaining convictions, the Authority is developing a corporate plan and performance criteria which will enable the Authority and the Committee to assess the work of the Authority and its performance.

I do not wish to in any way pre-empt the current evaluation of the Authority's work which is being carried out by the Committee, but I would like to say that at a recent visit to the headquarters of the Authority by the Committee I was particularly impressed with the new spirit of active cooperation and the evidence that the dedicated staff are working enthusiastically under enlightened direction. I believe that the National Crime Authority has embarked on a positive path for its future work and its contribution to the detection of crime in Australia. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991[COGNATE BILLSPETROLEUM (SUBMERGED LANDS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991PETROLEUM (SUBMERGED LANDS) (ROYALTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1991]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before the luncheon adjournment I was documenting that the Government had not met its substantive undertaking to provide additional funds for renewable energy research, yet the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill that is now before the Senate is offering several hundred million dollars in incentives for exploration and development, and contains several provisions designed to enhance the concession offered to oil producers. This is despite the greenhouse effect that is threatening our climatic conditions and our environment, and the Government's professed commitment to the reduction of targets and emissions.

SPEECH.PARA: In assessing the current unsatisfactory state of research on renewable energy sources, the Australian Democrats felt that it was incumbent on the Senate to consider an amendment to ensure that the Government allocate out of the resource rent tax which is being raised by this legislation funds to promote the research and development of renewable resources. Accordingly, I moved at the legislation committee an amendment which would have provided $2m in the year ending 30 June 1991, $3.5m in the year ending 30 June 1992 and $5m per annum in each subsequent year.

I would have thought that this proposal, modest as it is compared with the hundreds of millions of dollars which are being offered to oil exploration companies, would have been fastened on by the Government and by the Opposition parties with alacrity. Unfortunately, that was not the case. In the legislation committee both major parties decided not to support this amendment. I believe that it is an indication of the fact that both parties pay lip service to environmental and energy conservation measures, but are not prepared to follow through with even such a modest initiative.

I return to the other provisions of the Bill. The Bill first of all provides that a single petroleum project known as the Bass Strait project will exist in relation to all current and future production licences that are related to the exploration permit known as VIC/P1, which covers the Bass Strait area. This could have been achieved by using section 20 of the principal Act to combine all Bass Strait production licences. I wonder why that easy route was not taken.

However, more importantly, the Bill allows the transfer of exploration expenses from another project to be deducted against taxable profits from a producing oil field, thus severely reducing potentially the revenue derived from resource rent tax. The Government has already provided this type of assistance to industry in general by allowing the transfer of losses within a company group for income tax purposes-that happened in 1984-85-and more recently by the disgraceful decision in 1987 to re-introduce negative gearing on income producing properties.

The proposal in this Bill is unique in our taxation law in that clause 19 of the Bill actually creates an offence punishable by a fine not exceeding $2,000 for not claiming the appropriate amount of expenditure. However, the purpose is quite clearly evident. It is to prevent companies leaving funds to accumulate at an augmented bond rate plus 5 per cent, which is the new rate introduced by the Bill. It is a measure that is welcome because previously the augmentation rate of 15 per cent allowed oil producers to collect returns on the banked up entitlements at the compounding rate of up to 28 per cent. This underlines the oil companies' talents to maximise their returns.

In passing, I refer briefly to the Australian Automobile Association's recent statement in which it pointed to the fact that the oil companies are pocketing some $30m in excise collected on behalf of the Federal Government by using the temperature variation when petrol is dispensed at the bowser. The legislation provides that excise is paid at a certain temperature at 15 per cent. However, if companies sell at, say, 20 per cent they can make an annual saving of $30m. I say this in passing to indicate that the oil companies are not slow to look after their own affairs.

I now turn to the amendment that the Australian Democrats moved in the legislation committee to deal with this situation. We believe that there is no reason to provide incentives to oil exploration companies at the expense of Australian taxpayers. Therefore, we have sought to remove those provisions in the Bill which enable companies to claim tax deductibility for oil exploration expenses on a company basis. That means that even beyond the Bass Strait principal project, they are able to deduct oil exploration expenses in any offshore area in Australia.

The argument is put that this is necessary to ensure that oil companies will carry out exploration in marginal areas and will unlock marginal oilfields. However, when we look at the number of exploration wells drilled in Australia between 1986 and 1990, we find that activity has not been declining. We find that in 1986 offshore drilling was concerned with 28 wells, in 1989 with 39 wells and in 1990 with 64 wells. Therefore, it can hardly be suggested that we need to incite petroleum companies to engage in further exploration.

We need to ensure that Australia looks to the long term future and develops alternative renewable energy sources. As I have already documented, both the Opposition and the Government have rejected an amendment that would have made that possible. They have also rejected the amendment which gives the oil exploration companies over two years a figure in excess of $700m, although that particular figure is being questioned.

A significant by-product of imposing this resource rent tax is the effect on the price of methane and ethane available to both commercial and domestic consumers in Victoria. The Government announced that compensation will be paid to Victoria in respect of forgone royalty receipts, and a further amount of $60m will be payable in two annual instalments of $30m each, which the second reading speech tells us will minimise any transitional pressure on gas prices.

However, the increase in prices, which would potentially affect manufacturers and domestic gas users in Victoria, is of the order of $60m. A higher figure of $90m has been floated, but there seems to be general agreement on $60m, which means that the compensation that the Government has offered is barely half the increased costs that Victorian manufacturers, employers and private gas users are expected to bear.

The Australian Democrats have received representations, as have the other parties, from the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, the Victorian Gas Users Group and the Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria; individual firms such as Blue Circle Southern Cement Ltd and Australian Cement Ltd; and companies such as Chemplex and Altona Petrochemical Co. Ltd which use ethane to manufacture plastic resins. We have also had a submission from the Australian Chemical Industry Council. The Australian Democrats believe that these submissions should have been taken seriously by all the parties. However, it fell to us to move an amendment which would have made it impossible for the gas producers to pass on the additional cost. Had the amendment been successful, it would also have provided Commonwealth revenue with a windfall of $30m which, I am sure, in the current climate would have been welcome.

The Democrats believe that a resource rent tax should be paid by the producers rather than passed on to consumers. Accordingly, the Australian Democrats moved an amendment to produce just that result, by defining the tax as an income tax-a term which is used in the contractual documents-and preventing producers passing it on. However, once again, both the Opposition and the Government decided that they did not really care about Victorian gas users and Victorian employers or the workers who are employed in those enterprises. This amendment also was not passed.

The position adopted by both old parties on this Bill shows, quite clearly, where they stand on a number of issues: the concern that they profess to have for people and manufacturers that are hit by the current economic recession, the environment and energy conservation.

I believe that the Government will say, `We cannot upset the equilibrium of this Bill. It is finely tuned. It has counter balances with concessions to business and reductions in the augmented bond rate that businesses are able to claim on banked up exploration expenses'. That may well be true, but it should not prevent the Senate from changing the direction of legislation which is clearly misshapen, misplaced, and misdirected.
The other argument that I expect the Minister to bring up is that piecemeal reform of this type, through individual amendments, is not something that the Government will engage in.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does so all the time.

—As Senator Watson rightly says, it is an argument which the Government provides quite frequently in answer to individual amendments. I remind honourable senators that I have now moved twice for the removal of sales tax on recycled plastic, only to be met by the response from the Government that this will be done in due course in a comprehensive manner. The net result of that delay is that for almost a year we have put an impediment in the way of using recycled plastics. The same applies to an amendment to remove sales tax from wheelchairs and other equipment used by disabled people. Once again, we were told that individual amendments are not something that the Government would care to engage in. The net result is that disabled people have been suffering. It is the same with this Bill. Individual amendments combine to create a direction for legislation which, in this particular case, is misconceived. I close by expressing my regret that neither the Opposition parties nor the Government was able to see the good sense in looking at our energy future in the long term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 is designed to amend from 1 July 1990 the petroleum resource rent excise and royalty laws. I condemn the Government for being so late in introducing this legislation into the Parliament. This legislation should have been debated 12 months ago. In that event, there would have been substantive amendments because this legislation is substantially flawed.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the legislation is to extend the petroleum resource rent tax (PRRT) regime-a fairly novel concept around the world-to Bass Strait production of all petroleum including crude oil, condensate, natural gas, liquid petroleum gas and ethane in place of the excise and royalty regimes.

The resource rent tax will be amended to allow a company to deduct exploration costs incurred on or after 1 July 1990 against any of its RRT liability. The threshold rate for carrying forward the undeducted capital project or development expenditure is to be reduced from the long term bond rate plus 15 per cent that existed in the earlier legislation that was enacted in the late 1980s, which had limited application and which this legislation now extends to include Bass Strait-for what is known as the development expenditure, as opposed to the exploration component of the expenditure-to the long term bond rate, plus 5 per cent.

I remind the Senate that this 5 per cent added to the long term bond rate does not cover the cost of capital. That is an immediate signal that the Government does not want to encourage this sort of investment. If the Government is not prepared to put in place a proper RRT regime which acknowledges the need for an adequate return on the cost of capital, this legislation is either flawed or the Government does not want to encourage gas and oil exploration offshore. It is as simple as that. Furthermore, the Government denies an appropriate deduction regime to those operators and producers exploring and developing offshore in Australia because it fails to provide the full deductibility of all costs.

While all the parties agree that some changes to the secondary taxation regime in Bass Strait are necessary, the Opposition parties have expressed some misgivings in relation to the legislation before us. That concern extends very widely in the State of Victoria to industries which will be particularly hit by this legislation.

Since the introduction of the resource rent tax, the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association (APEA), amongst others, has had concerns and, after all, it must be one of the foremost authorities. It acknowledges that these amendments will improve the legislation to the extent that some allowance will be made for failed exploration-one of the small pluses of this legislation; also, the decision to allow wider deductibility for exploration expenditure will remove a fundamental flaw in the design of the PRRT regime which has impeded exploration in relation to the unexplored frontier areas; but it skews the legislation in terms of the two principal players in Bass Strait.

One of the players has quite a large exploration program offshore, the other, in earlier times, in accordance with government legislation and initiatives, went onshore. Consequently, much of this tax will be skewed against one of the principal producers, namely Esso Australia Ltd. However, APEA remains concerned, as do so many others, that this legislation is basically flawed, for other reasons. Its concerns are also the concerns of others within industry who will feel the real impact of the RRT tax-some industries will be wiped out.

I would have thought it was contrary to the environmental philosophy of the Government for it to impose taxes on an industry that is basically non-polluting, because that will provide a greater impetus to the use of coal and other resources. I remind the Senate that, where Australia has this tremendous comparative advantage in natural resources, its economy would benefit from a better balance between the development of resources on the one hand and downstream processing, including other manufacturing and service industries, on the other. This is the important point-and I notice that the press are more interested in talking about social activities than in this fundamental point that could affect the future of Australia.

Governments must therefore be very conscious of the need to set secondary taxes so as to avoid this loss of comparative advantage in the secondary and tertiary sectors. I remind the Senate-and this was picked up in the minority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration-that the inappropriate design of the resource rent legislation could have an effect in two ways: if producers of a resource are able to pass on the tax to processors, a bias may be created in favour of the export of raw materials rather than their further processing in Australia; if the tax can be passed on to the users of this resource, the cost structure of export and import competing industries outside the resource sector will be increased, thereby reducing their international competitiveness.

A couple of matters associated with this Bill were announced in the explanatory memorandum but have not been included in this legislation. The first matter concerns the payment of $60m in the form of compensation to the Victorian State Government over the financial years 1990-91 and 1991-92. The former Treasurer, Mr Keating, in his second reading speech said:

The Government has . . . decided to provide the Victorian Government with a special grant of $30m for each of the first two years of application of resource rent tax to minimise any transitional pressures on gas prices.

He implied the right to pass on. The transitional pressures to which he refers are the loss of income from offshore royalties from Bass Strait, which are currently shared with Victoria, and the increased tax, and thus the cost of gas as a result of that resource rent tax.

I understand that the granting of any compensation to Victoria was a last minute political solution to an intractable problem. This was evidenced by the fact that reference to the compensation was not made in the Bill itself and it was certainly very evident from the concerns of the witnesses who were present at the Committee hearing last week. The Opposition sought, by amendment, to ensure that these funds were directed to the users on an equitable basis. But on the occasion of the Committee hearing the amendment was defeated.

Other matters which seem to have been dealt with in the second reading speech but are not in the legislation itself include the announcement by the former Treasurer regarding the treatment of resource rent tax payments under income tax law. The former Treasurer said:

Under existing provisions RRT is deductible for income tax purposes only after the final assessment has been made. The Government has decided that instalments of RRT should be deductible for income tax purposes in the income tax year in which they are paid. This change, which will apply to payments of instalments made on or after 1 July 1991, is consistent with general principle that an income tax deduction should arise when a payment is made.

This is particularly important when one considers that many of the principal players affected by this legislation need to self-assess their taxation liabilities by the financial year ended 28 May and pay the tax within 28 days of that date. It is just not good enough that we do not have complementary income tax legislation which will enable that deduction to take place and that change of regime to be effected. So I ask the Government to confirm when it intends to introduce the necessary amendment into income tax law.

In relation to proposed new section 24A, this Bill will extend the petroleum resource rent tax to Bass Strait production of all petroleum, including natural gas, liquid petroleum gas and ethane. Previously these products were subject only to royalty at 10 per cent to 12.5 per cent of revenue net of allowable costs. They have never been subject to excise. It has been suggested that the RRT, if imposed at 40 per cent on revenue net of cash operating capital costs, will increase the level of secondary tax on these products by an estimated 200 per cent to 300 per cent. This will be even higher if one considers the non-allowable costs.

I make the point that it is not a 40 per cent tax regime in terms of an RRT; it is considerably higher because of the non-allowable proportions and as a result of the form of application. As any mathematician will say, it is effectively a percentage rate equivalent to the mid-sixties. Before the relevant Victorian Minister was placated by the $60m worth of compensation he made a statement to the Victorian Legislative Council on 29 November last year:

If the Federal Government introduces a resource rent tax in the autumn session of 1991 it will have the impact of increasing costs in real terms by 8 per cent for large industrial consumers and 5 per cent for domestic consumers. It will also have the impact of increasing costs by between one and 2 per cent for the State Electricity Commission consumers because of the purchase of natural gas by the SEC.

In fact, we had the curious situation of provisional invoices being introduced in Victoria for large and small recipients of gas. These recipients were advised that their invoices were provisional and subject to the passage of this legislation. Subsequent to the compensation offer, the same Victorian Minister is on record as having said:
There should be no gas charge increase as a result of the RRT legislation.

But who will pay for this inevitable increase which has been estimated at anywhere between $50m and $80m per year? The Government's $30m compensation per year will not cover it and will not cover all users. I think we have had confirmation to that effect.

The Minister for Resources, Mr Alan Griffiths, in his statement to the APEA Annual Conference on 9 May 1991 stated that Victorian consumers would not pay more for their natural gas as a result of this legislation. This statement was made to the peak body. This statement by Mr Griffiths reiterated his earlier comments made on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in February that:
If there is any attempt to pass on these gas prices to, in particular, industrial users in Victoria, then those people can assume that they are being treated unfairly.

Whatever his plan, 80 per cent of the gas is sold to the Gas and Fuel Corporation on long term contracts which allow the passing on of the RRT to consumers. Naturally, this is of great concern to Victorian gas consumers-be they companies or individuals. I have great concern for companies, particularly those in the ethane industry, which have these sorts of long term contracts and will be caught in this price cost squeeze in an environment of reduced tariffs.

One of the concerns raised by Victorian manufacturers is higher industrial gas prices seriously disadvantaging Victorian manufacturers against interstate and overseas goods and reducing the potential to export goods. Their concern is certainly justified on the basis that the RRT creates an inequality between Gippsland-produced gas and other onshore or North West Shelf gas fields. The North West Shelf gas is transhipped to Japan and people there will not suffer a resource rent tax. Why? Because they have long term contracts which make that area marginal and to put a tax on the oil field in the North West Shelf might interfere with the viability of the gas field. They are not so worried about the Bass Strait, though.

The situation for ethane is much the same as for gas. Ethane produced from Bass Strait is a major raw material for Victoria's petrochemical industry-an important industry for that State. The industry produces plastic resins which are sold at prices determined by import competition. With historic and future tariff declines, these prices are falling. An increase in secondary tax on ethane cannot, therefore, be passed on to the consumer and must be absorbed collectively by the producers of ethane, ethylene and polyethylene-the petrochemical chain.

The imposition of this secondary tax is discriminatory against the petrochemical industry versus competing products-I cannot understand it-and an arbitrary impost of $10m to $15m a year on the struggling Victorian petrochemical industry. Ironically, as I said previously, that coincides with tariff cuts. It is recognised that the replacement of excise royalties with the RRT will in the near future reduce the Government's secondary taxes on oil production-however, not by nearly the amount that the Government claims. Investment decisions on gas production, ethane extraction and petrochemical plastics productions are independent of oil production economics, and the cost structure of this chain has to compete in the world market. The Government's secondary taxes are effectively destroying downstream industry.

The RRT on ethane represents something like one per cent of the Government's revenue from the RRT Bill. As such, the ethane issue is not a fundraising issue in principle. Thus, those in the Victorian petrochemical industry would argue that the proposed secondary tax increase on ethane should be eliminated from the Bill. The Government is not prepared to acknowledge that. An alternative to elimination is that the petroleum resource rent tax on gas and ethane be made financially equivalent to a royalty so that equity for the producers can be restored and the price rises can be avoided. We would not object to that procedure. I understand that a specific proposal to achieve this has been put to the Government.

Due to the pressure of time, I now move to clause 19, which involves a broadening of exploration deductibility provisions. The coalition and the industry welcome the amendment to broaden the exploration deductibility provisions. The allowable exploration deductions will be amended by this Bill from being limited to a particular project to being company-wide. Again, that is a plus for the legislation. It is a significant reform which will tend to encourage exploration in frontier areas, since companies with revenue streams from successful ventures will be able immediately to reduce their RRT liability by offsetting exploration expenditure in any offshore area against their revenue. That is a key feature of a good RRT regime. But I fail to reconcile this measure with the Government's reluctance to provide an adequate add-on to the long term bond rate to provide an adequate cost of capital return in a risky enterprise. The stock exchange investors demand a higher return in terms of these sorts of enterprises than they do, for example, for a retail operation in central Melbourne.

The key word here is `offshore', because these broadened deduction criteria applies only to offshore operations. The two operators in Bass Strait are Esso and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP). BHP has more offshore operations than does Esso; thus it is advantaged more by this amendment than is Esso, whose operations tend to be onshore. I suppose that it is the Government's intention to try to encourage Esso to move more offshore. That is fine, but the Government will not do that if it does not provide an adequate return on capital or if it does not allow full deductibility of costs, even in terms of Esso's offshore operations. A further point in clause 18 concerning allowable expenditure is that all expenditure prior to 1 July 1990 will be deemed to have been deducted. That is an extraordinary situation. It raises a problem for more recently established oil sites, which I will discuss in just a moment, time permitting.

I am disappointed that the Government has not recognised exploration-related environmental costs in the definition of exploration costs. Environmental costs fall within the definition of general project expenditure and therefore are not considered a valid deduction under exploration expenditure. As there is an increasing amount of environmental expenditure being required specifically for exploration these days, it seems incongruous that this is excluded. I hope that Senator Coulter takes up this point.

The application date for the amendments proposed by this Bill is 1 July 1990. This raises the issue of retrospectivity. While generally opposed to retrospective taxation measures, the coalition will not object, although we believe that this legislation should have been debated 12 months ago. Having RRT apply from 1 July 1990 is possibly the lesser evil. The other option would be for it to apply from the date of the announcement or perhaps from the date of the implementation. In both instances, the Bass Strait producers would suffer a significant loss versus the royalty excise arrangements. The coalition has as an objective the reduction of excessive oil taxation on Bass Strait, and to alter the commencement date and impose additional costs on the industry would be contrary to that objective. But how Victorian gas and ethane producers will recoup their costs retrospectively is a problem for the Federal Government and for the State Government to sort out jointly.

I mentioned a few moments ago that there was a problem with declaring recent investments as fully deducted from 1 July 1990. The problem is that this overturns the agreed basis on which investments in recent developments were undertaken and, in the case of Esso, severely handicaps the company as a result. Esso's case is important. I do not generally go into particular issues involving particular firms, but this case is so discriminatory that it must be raised in this Parliament. A commitment was made to five new oilfields following the 1987 excise negotiations on the understanding that the first 30 million barrels of production from each field would be exempt from excise. The excise exempt quota of 30 million barrels was designed to permit development of small reserves which might be uneconomic if subject to excise.

Based on those negotiations with the Government, the investment by Esso in those fields to date has been $567m. The expected excise-exempt quota for the field was about 82.9 million barrels. The production to 30 June 1990-that is, until the RRT regime came into play-was only 21 million barrels-about a quarter of the expected exempt amount. How discriminatory. Therefore, for equity reasons it has been suggested that unrecovered investment in this case should be deductible in accordance with the philosophy of the resource rent tax. The suggestion is that a proportion of investment related to the unproduced excise-exempt quota for each project should be deductible for the purposes of the RRT. I believe that this is a matter in which the Government should give consideration to a later amendment in the spring session of Parliament.

While on this topic of allowable deductions, I also wish to mention the problem that the current legislation does not allow what might be termed as private royalties as a deduction for the purpose of calculating RRT. This royalty in the case of the Gippsland field is very much at arms length. It is not in-house, in-company or anything else like that. Under the terms of a 1961 agreement, a royalty is payable to Oil Basins Ltd (OBL) on the value of all Bass Strait production. There are three arguments why the OBL royalty is a legitimate business cost to producers-but denied under this legislation-and should be deductible for the purposes of assessing RRT. The first of those reasons is that the Government stated in its December 1983 discussion paper on RRT that `override royalties can be said to be a legitimate deduction for RRT purposes'. That is another statement which has been overridden.

The OBL royalty is recognised as a legitimate business cost for income tax purposes, but not for RRT purposes. How inconsistent; how discriminatory. As a longstanding commitment, OBL is clearly not a loophole. That is the argument that the Government uses. Perhaps we could put `any future royalties', but an existing allowable deduction recognised as being at arm's length certainly should be an allowable deduction for RRT purposes. To the extent that the RRT is not deductible, unlike excise, there will be a windfall gain to OBL and an unjustifiable loss to the producers.

With respect to clause 14, a further area of concern relates to the threshold rate for carrying forward undeducted general project, or development expenditure, being reduced from the long term bond rate plus 15 per cent, and the same as for exploration expenditure, to the long term bond rate plus 5 percentage points. In terms of exploration, people do not invest if they do not think they will get an adequate return on the development once they have found that oil; it just does not make sense.

I reiterate that the important point concerns the cost of capital. In any RRT regime, governments must be cognisant of allowing a return in excess of the cost of capital, not below it. The failure to provide such a return on investment will result in the deployment of resources to the less riskier investment and thereby discourage exploration and development, contrary to what this country really needs. In fact, APEA, the peak body, submitted that the carry forward rates did not cover the cost of capital and provide an adequate rate of return. The reduction in the development rate could adversely affect the impact on gas projects, since these are characterised by limited profitability with long operating times and high development costs. It would also appear that perhaps the Government is willing to encourage the exploration of potential oil sites but is not encouraging their development to the production stage.

A further problem arising from the threshold rate changes is the so-called five-year rule. However, expenditure incurred more than five years prior to the issue of a licence can only be compounded forward at the rate equal to the gross domestic product deflator-again, a disincentive factor built in. This rule is completely inconsistent with the RRT philosophy. We are using the RRT philosophy but not applying it in its proper form. We are applying it for the benefit of revenue to the Government to the detriment of downstream processors and the producers themselves.

One of my greatest concerns is the effect that secondary taxation will have on both the Victorian economy and the Australian economy generally. In practice, it is possible to satisfy all the desirable criteria for a system of resource royalty. The best that can be achieved is to minimise the disadvantages. I have highlighted some of the disadvantages which I believe exist under the resource rent tax as per this Bill. Hopefully, as a result of what is a very significant and important committee process, for which I thank the Minister for his patience, those disadvantages will be minimised. Through this Bill, I ask the Government to look at the issues that have been raised in that committee stage debate very forcefully and with a great deal of feeling, acknowledge the matters that have been raised here by the industry and pass subsequent amendments at an early opportunity to minimise the disadvantages that will be forthcoming.

I remind the Senate that the Opposition's ability to change substantially this legislation has been hindered by the fact that it is a Budget and revenue Bill with significant revenue implications. We are a party of principle. We do not intend to walk away from our responsibility in that area. It was indeed a difficult decision, knowing the suffering and the harm that will be caused to many people and many industries in Australia. The legislation is badly flawed. We ask the Government to implement legislation at an early opportunity to overcome the flaws and recognise the need for income tax legislation to support this RRT Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating in the second reading stage three cognate Bills. The first is the so-called Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. I point out that it does not involve a resource rent at all; it is misnamed. I will pick up that point later. The other two Bills are the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill 1991 and the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Royalty) Amendment Bill 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: I will pick up the second Bill first, which is the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill, because what I want to say later on is very critical of the Government. In relation to the second Bill, I want to give some credit to the Government for passing a very useful and very good piece of legislation from an environmental point of view.

The Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill seeks to do several things which have the strong endorsement of the Australian Democrats. It seeks, for instance, among other things, to require the holders of offshore petroleum titles to lodge securities with mandatory requirements for title holders to take out insurance against potential liabilities arising from their operations. At present, that requirement is not mandatory and this replacement should ensure that adequate insurance is in place should something like a major oil spill occur in the marine environment, such as the Exxon Valdez disaster or something like that, for which the costs are absolutely astronomical. Appropriately, those who explore for and those who exploit oil in the marine environment should carry adequate insurance to pick up the costs to ensure that the environmental clean-up costs are fully met by the operators and their insurers and not picked up by the Government through public taxation.

Secondly, this Bill seeks to further protect the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park in that a number of inactive permits which have been inactive, as we were told in the second reading speech of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), since 1971 will be rescinded. I believe that that further protects the Great Barrier Reef in that it removes once and for all the potential threat which hung over the park as long as the permits to explore for and exploit oil on the Great Barrier Reef were in place.

The Bill links in with another piece of legislation, which we will be dealing with shortly, which seeks to ensure that ships passing through the channel on the inner side of the northern part of the Great Barrier Reef will be piloted. I notice in that legislation that currently some 200 ships per year go through that area without a pilot. Some of those ships could be carrying oil or toxic chemicals and, in the event of an accident, could cause very significant damage. I congratulate and warmly support the Government for that piece of legislation and also the other legislation which we will be dealing with perhaps the week after next.

I turn to the principal piece of legislation, the so-called resource rent tax legislation. This is not a resource rent tax because a resource rent tax would be just that-it would be a rent which is paid for the exploitation of a resource, specifically a non-renewable resource or a renewable resource which was being exploited beyond the rate at which it could be sustained. To pick up Senator Watson's words, the philosophy which should lie behind such a piece of legislation would ensure two things: that, in the case of a non-renewable resource which is being exploited beyond the level of sustainability, the extent or the rate at which that resource is being exploited will be reduced by the imposition of the tax-in other words, positive discouragement of over exploitation; and that the exploitation would be brought back to a point where the use of that renewable resource is sustainable.

In the case of a non-renewable resource, any exploitation of that resource is not sustainable because, by its very definition, it will run out. So the resource rent tax on the amount actually taken out of the ground or exploited in that case seeks to do several things. It seeks to provide a fund from which alternatives to that non-renewable resource can be developed. So when that non-renewable resource runs out eventually, our descendants are not left without a replacement. The imposition of a tax and the reduction in the use of that resource at present will also pick up the issue of intergenerational equity. In other words, it will cause the public in the present generation to pay something for the use of that resource, which will be denied to future generations if it is no longer available or if, through its depletion, it becomes a great deal more expensive.

I want to pick up several things that the Opposition said in its minority report to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, to illustrate the point. In their report, Opposition members said that the principle underlying the tax is that it should be a return to the public from those who develop non-renewable, natural resources. There is nothing wrong with that, except that the public also includes-and this is apparent to those of us who are alive to these things-future generations who may lay claim to the use of that resource. So, the question of intergenerational equity is clearly not picked up in what the Opposition is saying.

Members of the Opposition also say that the tax should not be passed on to the public, to the consumers. It is precisely because the tax is passed on to consumers that they will alter their behaviour because of the increase in price. They will use less of the resource and, therefore, will leave more of the resource for future generations, and the use of the resource will move closer towards a balance between this generation and later generations, while at the same time the tax which is levied against the current use of that resource can be used to research alternatives.

The interests of future generations are also picked up by a proper resource rent tax which, as I have indicated, this is not. This is not a tax that is levied on the amount of petroleum, gas or ethane which comes out of the ground, by barrels or trillions of cubic feet but it is a tax that is levied against profits. It is simply a tax, like any other tax. Should there be no profits in the exploration or exploitation, there will be no tax. So there will be no impact in relation to the environmental considerations, which a proper resource rent tax should have.

Interestingly, members of the Opposition also talk about its effect on downstream industries, and this was also picked up in Senator Watson's speech. As far as I am aware, in the petroleum industry taken as a whole, there are only two products that are not burnt. One is ethane, which is turned into a range of petrochemicals, particularly plastics, which Senator Watson mentioned, and of course there are the heavy fractions that are left over-the bitumen that finishes up on roads. As far as I am aware, every other fraction is burnt and there is no downstream processing. Senator Watson rather disingenuously said that the petroleum industry causes no pollution. Of course, the petroleum industry, precisely because its products are burnt, is one of the significant polluters.

That is the point I wish to pick up now in criticising more trenchantly this legislation brought forward by the Government. As I said the other day, this Government is looking backwards. It is putting in place legislation which addresses the problems of yesterday rather than those of today and tomorrow. I shall provide a few figures as a basis for what I want to say further. There is no doubt, and it is widely accepted, that the levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere are rapidly increasing, and the rate itself is increasing. The best scientific opinion at the present time says that that will have very significant effects on every single aspect of human activity and that while at present there is no unequivocal evidence that we are already in a greenhouse situation, by early next century that evidence will become unequivocal.

The likelihood, then, is that politically and socially there will be wide acceptance of the need to make drastic reductions in every single carbon-based fuel. That includes coal, to pick up Senator Watson's point, but also hydrocarbons. There will have to be drastic reductions in their use only 10 to 15 years from now. Certainly by then-as there should be now-there will be a wide acceptance of the need for that drastic reduction.

The primary purpose of this legislation is to encourage further exploration for petroleum-the petroleum that is causing the major global environmental damage at the present time. I simply pose the question: is it wise to put in place legislation to encourage the discovery of more of a resource which, from all the indicators, we will be using less of in the very near future, with that lessened use being widely accepted by the community?
In his second reading speech, the Minister said that the measure is to encourage:
. . . the producers to efficiently drain the Bass Strait province in a manner which has greater regard to the producers' capacity to pay . . .
The resource rent tax is based on achieved profits rather than production levels . . .
He correctly identifies that it is not a resource rent tax at all. He then says:
The current disincentive to explore in frontier areas will, therefore, be removed.

In other words, it is not basically designed to achieve the objectives that I outlined before: to address the problem of inter-generational equity, to reduce the amount of the resource actually used, and to move the money that is raised from the resource rent tax into the discovery of alternatives so that when the resource runs out the next generation and later generations will have available to them alternative technologies.

According to the Minister, it is to overcome the current disincentive to explore in frontier areas. So, further hydrocarbons will be discovered and, of course, the implication is that they will then be used. But as I have indicated, I believe that to be a misreading of the future. Again, it is an indication that this Government is not looking forward. It is not looking at where we are now and at the environmental consequences of what it is doing. It is simply looking at an economic situation without reference to the environment and is addressing past problems rather than future problems.

I refer to some of the points made by Senator Watson in relation to costs, which also have a bearing on this. Senator Watson has said that the figures are wrong; they may well be wrong, but that is not my point. According to the Minister, there will be a cost to revenue of $305m in 1990-91 and $450m in 1991-92 and that later on an improvement is expected, with a positive return to revenue. I see Senator Watson is nodding. The figures may be wrong, but the point I want to make is quite simple-and I am glad that the House is saving some energy while I am speaking, Mr Acting Deputy President, by turning off the lights; it is something I have been asking them to do for quite a long time.

These figures indicate that this is not a measure that will have a positive benefit to Government revenue in the first couple of years-accepting those figures for the moment-with the positive benefit expected later on. However, that will be closer to the time when the evidence in relation to the greenhouse effect and the need to cut back drastically on our use of this resource will be less uncertain and more positive. Therefore, it is more likely that people will accept the measures that will lead to a reduction in the resource. My concern is that a large amount of revenue will have been inappropriately spent in the meantime.

Senator Spindler said that in an earlier Bill of this kind the Australian Democrats sought and achieved an undertaking from this Government that as little as $5m would be set aside from an earlier fund of this type to be spent on renewable energy. Senator Spindler also mentioned that in the first year after the creation of that fund, an increased amount of money was spent for that purpose but that subsequently, not only with respect to that fund was the money not spent but also on what were then National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council funds generally, there was a progressive and disastrous run-down in the money this Government was spending on renewable energy research.

If a resource rent tax is to meet the proper criterion of reducing, and I stress `reducing', the use of a non-renewable resource, there must be an increase in the costs passed on to the consumer so that a price signal is given within the market mechanism which will reduce the use of that resource, encourage its efficient use and, at the same time, create the fund which will be used to research the alternatives for that non-renewable resource when that non-renewable resource runs out because we have a responsibility to later generations.

We are not here simply to use up non-renewable resources profligately and leave nothing behind. If we are going to use non-renewable resources at all then we have a responsibility to put in place the alternatives which later generations can use for their energy needs. This Bill is not designed to achieve that. This Bill is not a resource rent tax; it is simply a general tax on profits of a particular kind and it is wrong to call it a resource rent tax.

The Democrats are committed to resource rent taxes. To the extent that the Opposition talks about a consumption tax, it would have our support if a consumption tax were a tax levied against the non-renewable component of consumption if that became the principal source of Australia's revenue. It is ridiculous to impose a consumption tax which is also a tax against the labour component of goods and services. Rather than opposing a resource rent tax, we are strongly in favour of a resource rent tax. A major portion of the Government's revenue should ultimately be raised in that way. If passed on that would eventually become a consumption tax but a very specific type of consumption tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have to explain it more clearly.
—Senator Kemp asks me to explain it more clearly. I should have thought it is fairly clear that in every--
—No, you will not convince him.

—I will try to see how intelligent Senator Kemp is. I will spell it out for him and see how he goes. In every good and service which is consumed there are essentially two components, labour and resource. Looking at this glass, for example, sand and soda have gone into its manufacture, as well as labour costs.

SPEECH.PARA: An appropriate consumption tax would place a tax on the resources which have gone into that glass-the exploitation of sand and soda to the extent that they are non-renewable-but not on the labour component. It would be a much simpler tax to collect if it were levied at the source and it would pass through the economy to consumers of a particular kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are advocating a consumption tax.
—Yes, Senator Watson, of a particular kind but not on the labour component of goods and services, which is ridiculous in a time of high unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not a resource rent tax. It is not forward-looking. A proper resource rent tax should be put in place not only on this resource but also a great deal on all the other non-renewable resources which we are exploiting because we have a responsibility to later generations. That is the philosophy which should underlie a resource rent tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Government's legislation to widen the application of a resource rent tax on offshore oil and gas developments. This is an important package of legislative measures, with considerable significance to the petroleum and exploration industries. The legislation will have a major impact on Victoria and could well have serious consequences for Victorian industry and the wider community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government argues that the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill and cognate Bills will lead to the recovery of a further 200 to 300 million barrels of oil from Bass Strait over the longer term. It expects that gas production will, in the longer term, be enhanced.

In many ways, this legislation highlights the great uncertainty afflicting our industries as a result of Government policies. Like other sectors of the economy, mining, exploration and secondary processing industries have been greatly harmed by the Government's economic policies, which have led to record high interest rates, an overvalued dollar and the worst recession in 60 years.

In addition, there have been extra burdens laid on this vital sector of the economy by the Government's confused and often inconsistent environmental policies. On top of these massive problems the Government is now imposing a new tax regime-the consequences of which have not been clearly established-particularly on downstream user industries.

It was fortunate that the Senate had in place the comparatively new procedure of referring Bills to committee. These important and complex Bills were rushed through the House of Representatives on 16 May under the Government's guillotine, which allowed only 90 minutes of debate.

The hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, chaired by Senator Coates, provided an appropriate forum for witnesses, both supportive and opposed to aspects of the Bill, and enabled their views to be heard. In addition to the oil and gas producers, all the major gas users were represented before the Committee. Their views and those of Ministers and officials could be tested and evaluated.

I have to say the evidence put before the Committee indicated that, despite the claims by the Government, clearly inadequate consultation was carried out by the Government with the major end-users of Bass Strait gas and ethane. In particular, it appears no prior consultations were held with the State Electricity Commission of Victoria and the Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria.

For the first time a number of the companies involved in this industry were provided, through their representatives, with an appropriate forum to bring to the Parliament, their concerns about the Government's resource rent tax (RRT). A diversity of views was put to the Senate Committee. BHP Petroleum pointed out that it had committed very large resources based on the understanding that the RRT would come into effect on 1 July 1990.
