While BHP put to the Committee that there were deficiencies in the RRT legislation, Mr McCammon, the General Manager for BHP Petroleum, believed that it would, without a doubt, lead to increased exploration and production around Australia. Esso Australia Ltd pointed out that the RRT had to commence from 1 July 1990 but it opposed a number of other aspects of the legislation, including the increased tax on natural gas and ethane. The Victorian Gas Users Group and Australian Chamber of Manufactures indicated a range of problems relating to the legislation that they felt could have a particularly savage effect on Victorian industry. Their submission to the Committee pointed to the possible increase in the price of gas to the Victorian manufacturers. They argued, among other things, that the proposed resource rent tax legislation, as it applies to natural gas and ethane, will not achieve the Government's objectives. Australian Cement Ltd, Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd (APEA), APM, Chemplex Australia Ltd and Altona Petrochemical Co. Ltd all brought their various concerns to the attention of various members of the Committee.

In the brief time I have available, I want to concentrate on one of the major concerns about this legislation-the effect that the application of RRT on natural gas and ethane could have on prices paid by end-users. On 9 April in a major speech at a conference, the Hon. Alan Griffiths, Minister for Resources, argued that:
The Government also has been consulting very widely on the issue of potential effects of RRT on gas costs in Victoria. The consultations are nearing conclusion.
He went on to say:
The final arrangements on natural gas pricing are primarily a matter for the Victorian Government and Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria.
Most importantly, he concluded:
However, as a result of these consultations, I am confident that any impact on gas prices from RRT will be minimal and that Victorian industry will not be disrupted by the RRT initiative.

This confirmed the earlier assurances that Minister Griffiths gave to Mr Jim Plowman, shadow Minister for energy and minerals in Victoria, in a February radio debate on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation that there was no reason why any manufacturer should be disadvantaged. On this occasion, Mr Griffiths said:
. . . if there is any attempt to pass on these gas prices to, in particular, industrial users in Victoria, then those people can assume they are being treated unfairly.
He went on to say:
I am quietly confident that Esso and BHP will not be passing on the gas prices in the way that might have been indicated.
During these hearings, Senator McMullan on behalf of the Minister did not resile from any of these statements. In relation to the ethane sector, Senator McMullan in the Committee hearings said:

It is our view that there is ample capacity in the surplus generated by Esso and BHP in ethane production from Bass Strait to absorb the RRT factor. Those companies are conscious and will remain conscious of the market consequences of further price increases.

Mr Keating-the Government's failed Treasurer-in his second reading speech on this Bill indicated that the Government would be providing the Victorian Government with a special grant of $30m for each of the first two years of application of the RRT to minimise any transitional pressures on gas prices. There was some concern among people appearing before the Committee about whether this money would be appropriately applied for the purposes for which it was granted. The coalition, as signalled by Senator Short, will move an amendment to ensure that the Victorian Government gives effect to the Commonwealth's intention.

While there is some debate on the actual cost effect of the RRT, this package, depending on whether the industry's or the Government's estimates are accepted, represents between one-third and one-half of the cost impact of the RRT on natural gas. The estimates given to the Committee ranged from $60m to $90m a year. It is clear from Senator McMullan's comments that both the Victorian Government and the producers are also expected to play a role in absorbing any additional cost pressures.

Senator McMullan made it clear in his statements to the Committee that the Victorian Government should also absorb part of the cost increase from RRT over and above the $30m provided by the Commonwealth. Possibly Senator McMullan had in mind that the Victorian Government's take from natural gas through the Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria from its public accounts committee and public authority dividends rose from $92m in the last year of the Thompson Government in Victoria to over $320m today in real terms; that is, in the eight years between 1982 and 1990 during the term of the Cain and Kirner Governments.

It is also clear that the Government expects that producers, particularly in the short term, will be in a position to help absorb some of the costs involved in the application of RRT to natural gas and ethane. The Commonwealth Government argues that it is losing $750m in revenue over two years as a result of the RRT legislation. Mr Keating, in his second reading speech on this Bill, argued that the producers had secured a windfall benefit in the early years of the new arrangement.

The companies, however, pointed out that the actual benefit to them would be substantially less than this figure. They certainly do not share the same confidence as the Government in their capacity to help absorb some of the additional costs of RRT on natural gas and ethane. However, BHP said that the company is committed to long term development and marketing of gas resources. A spokesman for the company made the important statement that `it would not jeopardise this position for short term advantage'. Mr McCammon went on to say:
Pass-on of RRT is a matter of commercial negotiation under the terms of our contracts but these negotiations would take into account where our customers are currently paying fair value for gas.

It is clear that the Government sees absorption of the costs of RRT on natural gas and ethane to be shared by the Commonwealth Government, Victorian Government and producers in a way which will minimise costs to end-users.

Both the Victorian Government and producers, at least publicly, are not prepared to give any assurances. That can be judged from the quotations that I made from BHP. This is quite rightly causing a high degree of nervousness amongst end-users. In fact, witnesses before the Committee gave forecasts of possible price increases which could result from the RRT, and this evidence was outlined by Senator Watson in his speech in the chamber.

Senator Short has outlined why the coalition is not prepared to accept the Democrats' amendment relating to tax liability. Instead, the coalition has proposed an alternative course which will not interfere with contractual obligations and which will not absolve the Victorian Government from playing its role in meeting at least some of the additional costs of RRT.

The hypocrisy of the Australian Democrats knows no bounds. One of the amendments that they put before the Committee would have imposed heavier costs on producers by limiting the deductibility for exploration expenditures. Senator Spindler has put forward in this chamber a long list of tax increases in the Democrats alternative budget, including increased petrol excises, higher company taxes and so on. The Democrats have supported extremist environmental actions which, among other things, if successful could effectively stop exploration activities for minerals, including natural gas. I think this was actually confirmed in another way in Senator Coulter's speech.

All these Democrat policies would impose higher costs on Victorian industries and consumers. Senator Spindler knows that his amendment could not be accepted because of the precedent it sets for tax policies. As I have mentioned, Senator Short has set out in his speech on this Bill our views on that particular amendment. Let me just add one point: with the Spindler precedent, governments could determine whether any taxes, such as fuel tax, excises, royalties and so on, should or should not be passed on to the consumer. I suggest it is a precedent that no company would really want opened up in the Income Tax Assessment Act. Senator Spindler and his colleagues are not the slightest bit concerned about cutting costs to consumers. The Democrats' tax policies, as set out in their alternative Budget and other statements, are an invitation to the Government to bring in a new range of taxes to hit productive industries and consumers. I regret that the amendment Senator Spindler moved was just another cynical Democrat stunt.

In contrast to the Australian Democrats, the coalition has moved a constructive amendment which should give some comfort to end users. As a result of the coalition's amendment, the full impact of the legislation will be assessed in two years time to see whether it has been successful in meeting its objectives. Bearing in mind the Government's view that the impact of RRT on gas prices will be minimal, our amendment will require the Government to report to the Parliament and indicate whether this objective has been met. I might say that the Government, to its credit, has indicated that it will agree to this amendment in the committee stage.

If this Bill has unintended consequences which are adverse to Victorian industry because the Government's expectations have not been met-and we remember the promises of Alan Griffiths which I quoted earlier-I believe that action can then be taken. The Government expects this Bill to provide stability and a more certain framework for long term planning by the industry. I do not share this Government's confidence. Regrettably, this Bill will impose heavier taxes in the long term on resource development in this country, and I think that can only have the effect in the end of providing less resource development and higher costs to end users. The report required by the Opposition's amendment to this Bill will allow a proper parliamentary assessment of the consequences of this hastily enacted legislation to ensure that its benefits are not greatly outweighed by its costs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 has been very well debated by my colleagues Senator Short, Senator Watson and Senator Kemp, who have all elaborated very well on our position. The Bill, in essence, extends the petroleum resource rent tax (RRT) to Bass Strait oil and gas from 1 July 1990 and terminates from that date the excise and royalties scheme currently applying to Bass Strait production. I must say that, in line with much of what the Government is presenting by way of legislation, this Bill has had a chequered career and a much delayed start which, frankly, I believe is quite ridiculous.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government were unable to get legislation in the appropriate form, taking into consideration the impact it would have, why did it bother to include it in the consideration of the 1990 Budget? Why this Government never seems to do its homework is beyond me, but some of the goings-on that we have seen over the past week in this place may be the cause of the problem with some of the legislation that has been drafted. The Bill has been fiddled with since it was first announced in the Budget. It was pushed through the House of Representatives under guillotine and the final draft version has been available for only about seven days, which does not make scrutiny very easy. As the shadow Minister for energy and resources said earlier, so much for legislation by careful discernment and consideration.

This country's mineral resources, like agriculture, are valuable and vital commodities. They generate enormous wealth and are responsible for our high standard of living. It is therefore somewhat indicative of the decline of the Government that a Bill as complex as this, on issues as vital as ones which affect a major section of the economy, ought to be debated first in the other place under the threat of the guillotine and then come to this place flawed.

It is a Budget Bill, although one could be excused for asking for which year. Obviously, on that basis alone, the Opposition would not oppose it. But one has to question the standards of the Government in taking so long to frame legislation, to present a final draft only seven days before it gets pushed through the other place and still have major concerns expressed about it by a Senate committee when it arrives here.

The Bill contains a number of complex proposals and I do not propose to canvass the issues that other speakers, as I have already said, have covered perfectly adequately. However, I would like to raise one or two points about the legislation. The question of the starting date of the five-year rule is one issue that arose from consideration by a Senate standing committee. The five-year rule reduces the amount of exploration expenditure that a company can carry forward to be offset against revenue and hence RRT liability.

The oil industry, naturally, has argued that the starting date for the rule should be the date of application for a production licence rather than the date of issue. We can understand the oil companies wanting to ensure any additional revenue and tax relief that they can find. For companies involved in oil exploration in this country, it has not been easy to understand and interpret the changes to the rules attached to exploration in this country. Successive governments have made considerable moneys from Bass Strait oil over the years, but they have also been willing to change the game plan when it suits them. In the past that has made it difficult for oil companies to plan future investments. In respect of Bass Strait, the oil companies will need to review their plans in light of the legislation.

We need to continue to provide incentives for exploration, as I think Senator Kemp and Senator Watson elucidated in an eloquent fashion in this debate some time ago, and we need to be careful in legislation such as we have in front of us today that we provide industry with the right incentives and the right assurances that we will not keep changing the rules. Concerns have already been raised in respect of ethane users with the potential for a retrospective tax being applied as a result of this legislation. The Government appears to have either ignored or forgotten about the effects on ethane producers and, more particularly, the ethane users.

I know that Senator Kemp and Senator Short, both from Victoria, have the interests of their State at heart and I know that my National Party colleagues in the other place have expressed concern at what would have happened about the natural gas prices as a consequence of the Bill. The Government has announced a $60m package to ease the transition, but it has not yet included that in this legislation. Given the parlous state of the Victorian economy, I also want to express concern as to what guarantees we will have that the Victorian Government will, indeed, use this grant of $30m a year-$60 over two years-appropriately. I am advised that $60m is only half the expected cost and it is hoped that the Victorian Government and the oil companies will absorb the rest. I can only say that the Federal Government has great expectations if it thinks that the Victorian Government will be able to give anybody anything, although I note that the Victorian Government already takes a good slug out of gas sales through its so-called public authority contribution, which is a State tax on gas.

The Opposition has also suggested a phase in or additional transitional arrangements for ethane because ethane has been excluded from the $60m package. These are but two issues that the Federal Government has ignored or not been aware of in the drafting, but the Bill was introduced into the other place by the ex-Treasurer, Mr Keating, whose ideas have been flawed on many economic issues over many years in this country. In fact, the former Treasurer of this country has driven this country to the brink of bankruptcy.

TALK.START.PARA: —A planned recession.

—That is right. It was a recession planned by the ex-Treasurer of this country, a recession which has brought so much misery and despair to so many people and to a lot of the industries in Australia that have been trying to do their little bit for our export income.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the issues that came out of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. In the evidence given, it was suggested that the Bill was poorly drafted and that there was no consultation at all with gas users in the lead-up to the decision. People who sat in at the meeting said that it was very clear that the Government had given no consideration to the impact of the decision on downstream gas users in Victoria, particularly the industrial users. Of course, the $60m compensation package designed to cover only half of the costs to which I have already alluded was also raised.

The Committee in its wisdom-and particularly in the wisdom of those who made the dissenting report: Senator Campbell, Senator Kemp and Senator Watson-looked at all these concerns. It is a great pity that the minority report was not the majority report because it has summed up the issues in this Bill which are of concern. I am not going to hold the Senate up any longer because we have a lot of legislation to go on with. I believe that the case has been very well put on behalf of the Opposition by the previous Opposition speakers in this place.

I finish by saying that I naturally support the Opposition proposals that the Government report to this Parliament in September 1992 on what effects the legislation is having on prices and on the industry. If we are going to slam our resource industries in this country to the extent that they are not going to look for further discoveries and that they are not going to have the money or the will to look for further discoveries because they are taxed out of existence, taxed in an incorrect way or the rules are changed too many times, we are going to kill the goose that laid the golden egg.

It is very important that in the future the Government consults a little more with the industry before it changes the rules. If it does not, this country will be what we all were told it was going to be some years ago by the ex-Treasurer of this country, Mr Keating, who has caused so many problems--

TALK.START.PARA: —Discredited.

—The discredited ex-Treasurer of this country. We will be a Third World power-we will not be a Second World power or a First World power in the future. I support the Opposition's point of view on this Bill, and I reiterate that we must not kill the goose that lays the golden egg as far as our resource industries in Australia are concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill is very important. I think it justifies the seriousness with which it is being debated by the Senate. It is a Bill of fundamental importance to the Australian petroleum production industry. The reforms in the Bill will increase production in Bass Strait and broaden Australia's petroleum exploration effort. I have been a little surprised to hear some of the views expressed, which seem to fly in the face of both the predictable outcome of such legislation and the actual outcome of the announcement of the legislation in the 1990 Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already indicated this in the committee stage, but let me put it on the record here: the Government will accept the amendment put by the Opposition in the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration that requires the Government to report to Parliament by 30 November 1992 on the operation of the legislation. There was never a problem from our point of view with providing a report. At some stage we were apprehensive about the nature of the amendment as originally proposed, and we thought that perhaps the idea of putting in such a report would generate some of that uncertainty which several speakers have been concerned about, but I think we now have a form of words that is acceptable to everybody and that will meet the interests of the Opposition without causing any potential problems; so we accept that amendment. I am not sure that we would have sought to initiate such an amendment, but we are not unhappy about it.

I will go on to talk to one other amendment, which was not proceeded with but about which I gave some assurances in the Committee, and I reiterate those here. There were concerns raised in connection with the production licence application process and I am prepared, on the behalf of the Government, to give an undertaking or an assurance that that process will be covered by this report. More specifically, the Government will carefully monitor the administration of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act to ensure that the period between the application and issue of production licences is minimised and will include in its report the time between the application for and the date of issue of licences. Those are the explicit things about which people sought assurances; they are reasonable, and I reiterate them here.

I also indicated in the Committee that it is not my intention that the report should duplicate the report required of the Tax Commissioner under section 16 of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987. The Act requires certain other reports, and obviously we will seek to minimise duplication in some manner or other. In those two matters, I think we now have a satisfactory and agreed outcome.

I want to express serious concern about the Opposition's persistence with the second amendment-in fact, the only outstanding matter now, the one concerning the attempt to put in the legislation a provision that purports to ensure that the Commonwealth's $60m is spent in the way intended. Obviously, we do not disagree with the fact that that must happen, and I am happy patiently to explain again why there are better mechanisms to ensure that this will happen, mechanisms which will be undertaken. I am prepared to give that assurance here. The difference between what we will do and what the Opposition is seeking to do is that what we will do will work and what the Opposition is seeking to do will not work. It will not achieve the purpose. I think it is bad principle and bad practice and, as usual with such things, it will not work.

However, the amendment relating to the grant to minimise transitional pressures on gas prices will not be agreed to by the Government. The grant is not directly related to the resource rent tax (RRT). I have been surprised that some people have expressed concern that the money is not referred to in this legislation. Of course, it is not. It will be appropriated in the Budget. Any attempts to ensure that Victoria use the grant for its intended purpose will not be effected by referring to the grant in the legislation. I cannot see how anybody can conceive that the amendment as drafted will achieve the purpose for which it is intended. Given that Opposition senators can read, I cannot believe that it is other than an attempt to try to prove to people that they have done something when it is unnecessary to do so and when it will be ineffective.

The Commonwealth decision to pay $30m to Victoria in each of the next two financial years is an explicit public commitment. Gas consumers will be aware of the arrangements, and we will be scrutinising their accounts accordingly. The Victorian Government also will be mindful of the explicit public commitment. The Victorian Government has assured the Commonwealth that the grant will be fully passed on to minimise any potential effect of RRT.

The payment will be made through an appropriation to be brought before the Parliament in the Budget session. The safeguards provided by the standard provision of the appropriation process more directly and-if I can say this somewhat more forcefully-more appropriately deal with the concerns raised by the Opposition.

That is the way in which the Commonwealth Government ensures that money it appropriates to go to the States is spent in the manner intended through the standard process of appropriation. Let me clarify that. For example, page 156 of Budget Paper No. 2 for the 1990-91 Budget-and this is standard; the same process will apply this year-deals with appropriations for payments to the States, which is the exact issue we are now debating. Section 5 of the Appropriation Act deals with payments to the States. It reads:
Payments that are made to a State for a purpose specified must be made:
(a) on such terms and conditions, if any, as are from time to time determined in writing for the purposes of the Appropriation Acts by the Minister specified.

That is the standard mechanism, it has worked and it has had its full force on each occasion that it has been used and, contrary to this silly amendment, it will achieve its purpose. The Government is on public record-and I will put it on record again-that the $60m is being provided to the Victorian Government to minimise any transitional pressures on gas. The payment to Victoria will be made on the condition that the $60m is to be used to minimise any transitional pressure. That condition will be enforced. The Opposition has the Government's assurance that such a condition will be stipulated in the exchange of letters which will occur, as is normal for the special one-off appropriation to the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —For ethane.

—Well, it is much more likely to have any useful impact on ethane than your amendment, which does not refer to it. That is not a matter about which I am in a position to give an assurance but, as Senator Watson knows, his amendment has no relationship to that whatever and cannot assist in that matter.
—If you give us some assurances, maybe it will not be necessary.

—I cannot give you assurances about matters for which I am not responsible and about which I do not have information. That would be irresponsible. Senator Watson knows that the matter on which he seeks assurance is not referred to at all in his amendments. It seems to me that the question before the Senate, is that we are trying to say how we rationally deal with implementing the agreed purpose. I would think that every honourable senator in the chamber at the moment agrees, and everyone if briefed would agree, that we share the purpose that if the Commonwealth appropriates $60m to go a State to achieve a purpose, it should be used for that purpose. But we have the question of what is the best manner in which the interests of Australian taxpayers as a whole on whose behalf the money is appropriated-Victorian taxpayers and the affected Victorian consumers in particular in whose interests the money is being appropriated-are pursued. It is not a question of whether we should do this, but of how we should do it and to make sure that we do it in a manner that is effective.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose the clearest example of the fact that we need to do it in a manner other than that which Senator Watson specifies is that, even if he carries this amendment, it is my view, which I think is the correct one, that we will still have to undertake the exchange of correspondence arising out of the Appropriation Bill. We will achieve the purpose in spite of Senator Watson, but it seems that we are littering the Bill with unnecessary, counterproductive matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Littering the report.

—If Senator Watson carries it, he will be littering the Act with unnecessary and counterproductive sections, which can only do one of two things. They will create a false impression that a purpose has been achieved which has not in fact been achieved; or they will confuse and make more complex the interpretation and understanding of the legislation. Senator Watson has a longstanding and proper concern about the proper nature of the legislative process. It may not be shared by his colleague sitting behind him, Senator Kemp, who has not yet understood the point. But Senator Watson is correct in the way in which he pursues these matters in general. If we amend the Bill in such manner as this, it is entirely inappropriate, it is bad practice and the Government will not accept the amendment. The amendment is extraordinarily ill-advised and inappropriate. The best thing that can be said for it is that it probably does not do much harm; it does absolutely no good.
—It is a signal.
—What more of a signal is it than that--
—You can't be believed on anything. You have a security problem.

—I can rely on Senator Kemp for a cheap political shot in what otherwise would be the most properly conducted debate. The only way in which Senator Kemp is consistent is that he lowers the level of anything he touches. I address myself to his colleagues who have participated in the debate usefully and constructively, even though on this matter I disagree with them.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been some concern-and if it were well-founded it would be proper concern-that the tax regime that is being introduced may lead to a reduction in investment. People have been saying that the companies will not invest under this regime. The fact is that it is because the companies are confident that this regime will be introduced that they have been investing. Major investments have been made because people are convinced that this is the appropriate mechanism for the taxation of these sorts of projects, and that investment will continue.

Everybody else having been reasonably concise in their contributions to this debate, I do not want to make too lengthy a contribution. I will try to respond to some of the explicit points which Senator Watson raised more particularly about investment, and if I get time I will do so. I would like to turn to some of the points that honourable senators made in the debate. I have already dealt with several of the points raised by Senator Short which related explicitly to the amendments. I will come back to them, if I can. Senator Watson raised a concern about--

TALK.START.PARA: —The cost of capital.

—I will come to the point about the cost of capital, but Senator Watson also asked about the 30 million barrel excise exemption. With regard to all these matters-I said this before the legislation committee-we are dealing with a balanced package of measures. I understand that we are entitled to disagree as to whether the balance has been appropriately struck, but when one tries to excise any one of the elements of a package and analyses it in isolation, one often achieves a false impression of the fairness and the nature of the balance. There are a whole series of checks, balances and offsets in this package which make the net result, we think, fair and reasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that the producers have argued that the imposition of RRT on revenues from small reserves developed in Bass Strait on the basis of the 30 million barrel excise concession given in 1987 is a problem for them. Our view is that in terms of the balance of the package the impact of the RRT on the investments which no longer will be excise-exempt has to be balanced against the likely producer gains from the lower effective tax rate applicable in the first two years of RRT. In addition, Bass Strait producers will benefit from company-wide exploration deductibility, which will permit the deductibility of any offshore exploration in RRT areas against Bass Strait RRT liability.

We can argue about whether the balance is right, and Senator Watson is entitled to his view. I said in a philosophical moment in the legislation committee that one of the great difficulties of any proponents of change is to prove that certain adverse consequences will not happen. It is only after the event that one can establish that certain things did happen and sometimes, more to the pity, it is proved that one is wrong. That has happened. People raise concerns and say that A, B, C or X concern may occur if one makes changes. One can only say on the balance of evidence, `We think that we have struck the appropriate balance'. The responses to date tend to reinforce that view.

Nobody in this chamber will be surprised that certain of the people likely to be affected by the tax would like to change the balance so that the tax is less. Perhaps the least surprising representation any of us ever receive is a representation from a group of taxpayers saying, `Please make a change to the law so we don't have to pay so much tax'. That is not the world's most surprising submission. Those people came before the Committee and made those submissions and Senator Watson has taken up that point. I do not share their view; I think the balance is more fairly struck.

Senator Watson raised his concern in respect of the cost of capital. Essentially, this comes under the same heading as how we judge the balance of return. The carry forward rate for undeducted expenditures and the RRT rate operate together to ensure that the industry obtains a fair return on its investment. The carry forward rate maintains the real value of funds invested and include a risk premium. The tax rate of 40 per cent generally extracts less than full economic rent. If the carry forward rate were to be adjusted upwards, a compensating rise in the tax rate would need to be considered. In other words, we have struck a lower rate than otherwise might be struck because of the changes that are being made in the carry forward rate. If we were to change the carry forward rate, we would want to make consequential changes to the 40 per cent rate at which the tax has been struck.

I reinforce that point by saying that Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) knew last August that the carry forward rate was the long term bond rate plus 5 per cent-it was mentioned in the Budget last August. Since that time, there has been a substantial exploration program based on the understanding that the RRT would come into effect. Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd indicated to the Committee that--

TALK.START.PARA: —That was really committed before August though. An exploration program is planned over a long period of years. That was committed under the old regime.

—If Senator Watson thinks that BHP, having made a decision, is incapable of changing it if it found it to be uneconomic, he has less faith in its judgment and competence than I do; BHP is well aware of the circumstances. Senator Watson is putting a very strange argument-that somehow or other a company which makes a decision inexorably drifts on with other decisions because `they are unprofitable now, but we made them a while ago'. People have accused BHP of being a bit bureaucratised but I would not have thought they would accuse it of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate the point by saying that BHP has spent $66m in RRT areas in the belief that offshore exploration will attract wider deductibility from that date. It has entered into major commitments since July last year totalling up to $90m for new acreage in the Upwey and Duntroon basins, and has placed bids for acreage elsewhere in Australia. In other words, BHP has gone on with previously planned exploration encouraged by the deductibility arrangements and has entered into new and major commitments, so I have to tell Senator Watson that I think that concern is ill-founded.

There has also been concern about when the Government will change the Income Tax Act flowing from this. I expect that to take place in the Budget session. I have made a number of comments about amendments because I want to minimise the committee stage debate if I can. I think we all have that view; we have all used the second reading stage in the same manner, and I understand that.

Overall, this package is important in the national interest. It will significantly enhance the efficiency of the tax regime for the petroleum industry and it will encourage more exploration in a manner that is required and appropriate. The indications are that the understanding that the legislation is to come into effect is already having that desirable effect, and it is important that it should continue to do so.

The least surprising bit of information that came out before the Committee, which seems to have been seized upon by some people with enthusiasm, is that the instrumentalities of the Victorian Government, BHP and Esso would not give commitments in advance that they would absorb all of these costs. It seems to me highly unlikely that anybody about to enter into a commercial negotiation would come before a Senate committee and say to the party with whom it is about to negotiate, `Don't bother, don't worry, we'll absorb all these costs for you. There is nothing to worry about'. I have to say that although I thought the indications from BHP, in particular, were encouraging and the sort of sign which I would expect, and the commitment from the Victorian Government is appropriate and one on which we will insist when the appropriation is made, to place great store on the fact that no such prior commitment has been made seems to me to be a little unrealistic, to put it politely.

I appreciate the fact that honourable senators, for a variety of reasons and with a range of misgivings, will be supporting this legislation. I welcome that because this is an important package in the overall program of the Government both in budgetary terms and in setting the framework for this industry. I appreciate that support and I look forward to the committee stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the leave of the Committee, having previously obtained the assent of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), to incorporate in Hansard the minority report of Senator Campbell, Senator Kemp and Senator Watson on the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 and associated Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The report read as follows-
MINORITY REPORT
The Liberal National Parties' concern

Conceptually, a resource rent tax (RRT) should not be passed on to users. The principle underlying the tax is that it should be a return to the public from those who develop non-renewable natural resources. The evidence before the Committee suggests that the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill may breach this principle to some degree.

If a flow on of resource rent tax were to occur in this case, it could work against the further development of downstream processing of natural resources in Australia. This would be a particularly unfortunate result.

It is widely accepted that, while Australia has a comparative advantage in natural resources, its economy would benefit from a better balance between development of resources on the one hand and downstream processing, other manufacturing and service industries on the other. Governments must be conscious of the need to set secondary taxes so as to avoid loss of competitive advantage in the secondary and tertiary sectors.

Inappropriate design of resource rent tax legislation could have such an effect in two ways. If producers of a resource are able to pass on the tax to processors, a bias may be created in favour of the export of raw materials rather than their further processing within Australia. If the tax can be passed on to users of the resource, the cost structure of export and import-competing industries outside the resource sector will be increased, reducing their international competitiveness.
The Coalition is concerned that these effects could occur to some degree as a result of the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation.
Cost of Capital

In the establishment of an RRT regime governments must be cognisant of allowing a return in excess of the cost of capital. Failure to provide such a return on investment will result in the deployment of resources to less riskier investments and thereby discourage exploration and development.

APEA submitted that the carry forward rates did not cover the cost of capital and provide an adequate rate of return commensurate with the rates involved in the circumstances of limited deductibility of costs.
Natural Gas

Bass Strait natural gas is sold to two major Victorian Government instrumentalities, the State Electricity Commission of Victoria (SECV) and the Gas and Fuel Corporation. Representatives of the producers told the Committee that their contracts with these bodies would permit the pass on of RRT on natural gas and that they proposed to enter into negotiations on the exercise of that right. Representatives of the SECV and the Gas and Fuel Corporation told the Committee that any pass on of the RRT would in turn be passed on into the prices they charge to industrial and domestic consumers.

The extent of any price effects of the pass on is not clear at this stage of negotiations. Mr McCammon of BHP told the Committee ``We are in the business of making money, not losing customers'' (Evidence, p. [1/29]). The extent to which RRT is passed on will depend to some degree on the availability and pricing of substitutes.
The final price of natural gas to the SECV and the Gas and Fuel Corporation and the effects on the prices charged by those bodies will depend on negotiations still to take place.

The Committee heard evidence based on current speculation about possible price effects which suggested that a paper recycling operation may become so marginal as to warrant closure. It was also suggested that a major cement producer might substitute coal for gas with adverse environmental effects.
Savings to Producers
In the 1990-91 Budget, the change in Commonwealth Government revenue due to changes to PRRT is estimated as $305 million in 1990-91 and $450 million in 1991-92, a total of $755 million.

Both producers claim that the net benefit due to the Bass Strait PRRT has been overstated. A detailed submission to this effect was made by Esso Australia Ltd. which questioned the Government's figures.
Ethane

Ethane from Bass Strait is used as feedstock for two large petrochemical plants in Melbourne, one of which is associated with one of the producers. The Committee was informed that these plants will be unable to pass on to their customers any cost increases associated with RRT as they sell in an internationally competitive market. It was further claimed that their competitors mostly operate in countries in which the cost of chemical feedstock is already below the Australian cost. The two processors will also be affected in the next few years by substantial tariff reductions.
Multiplier effect

Several witnesses pointed out that, if some or all of the RRT is passed on by the producers, there will be a multiplier effect. The higher prices charged by the producers as a result of the RRT will increase the revenue base on which the tax is calculated, leading in turn to even higher prices. As a result, the RRT on gas and ethane may finally be levied at a considerably higher rate than that originally intended by the Government.

The extent of this effect will depend, of course, on the extent to which the RRT is actually passed on. A pass on of the full 40% RRT and of all the increases in the tax base caused by the full pass on would produce an effective RRT of 66%.
Joint costs

Another potential problem raised in evidence was that the producers' costs, which may be offset against revenue in calculating the tax base, are incurred jointly across the three products they produce. If the RRT on gas and ethane can be passed on while the RRT on oil cannot, scope might exist for the producers to allocate their costs to maximise the pass on benefits of the RRT. This would increase the proportion of tax paid by their customers relative to the proportion that they would bear themselves.
Consultation

Virtually all witnesses claimed that there had been little or no consultation between Government and industry prior to the introduction of the tax. The Parliamentary Secretary and officers disputed this.

However, there was a strong view in relevant industry circles that the Government had not understood the potential for pass on of RRT on gas and ethane and that the effects of any such pass on would be unintended side effects of the legislation.
Greenhouse Impact

The Australian Chamber of Manufactures submitted that ``the increase in industrial gas price as a result of RRT will cause some industry to convert to coal, resulting in dramatically higher greenhouse emissions, energy efficiency opportunities such as co-generation will be lost, sacrificing opportunities for reduction in greenhouse emissions. Allowing an increase in the gas price as a result of government legislation is contradictory to the government's adoption of the Toronto goals'' (Evidence, p. FPA114).
Witnesses' views
Written or oral evidence from the following firms and organisations proposed measures either to ban the passing on of RRT on gas and/or ethane, or to limit the effect of any pass on:
State Electricity Commission of Victoria
Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria
Chemplex Australia Ltd
Australian Chemical Industry Council
Altona Petrochemical Ltd
Australian Chamber of Manufactures/Victorian Gas Users Group
Esso Australia Ltd

BHP Petroleum Pty Ltd, while expressing initial opposition to the RRT on gas, expressed its support for the RRT package as a whole and stressed that it had taken major investment decisions on the basis that it would be enacted. Mr Brian McCammon, who represented BHP at the Committee's hearing expressed some scepticism at the potential in practice for pass on of the RRT.
Potential for pass on

The Committee received written submissions and heard oral evidence from the representatives of several groups representing producers, processors and users of Bass Strait oil, gas and ethane. The Committee also heard oral evidence from Senator the Hon. Bob McMullan, Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and officers of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.There was a clear consensus in this evidence that there was no scope for pass on of the RRT on oil as that commodity is priced locally at world market price and any attempt by the producers to pass on the tax would be immediately undercut by imported product. However, the position on gas and ethane was less clear.
The Coalition acknowledges the argument advanced by Senator McMullan that it would be difficult for the Coalition or the Senate to:

. . . resolve . . . all the problems which will subsequently be resolved in commercial or market discussions between the parties. To try to determine who is going to pass what cost on to whom, under what circumstances, is not a role for the legislation of the Commonwealth. It is not a function which Government can reasonably perform (Evidence, p. FPA135).

The Minister for Resources, Alan Griffiths statement to the APEA Annual Conference on 9th April, 1991 stated that Victorian consumers would not pay more for their natural gas as a result of this legislation. This statement by Hon Alan Griffiths reiterated his earlier comments made on ABC radio in February that ``if there is any attempt to pass on these gas prices to, in particular, industrial users in Victoria, then those people can assume that they are being treated unfairly . . . ''
Compensation

The Government's decision to provide transitional compensation through the Victorian Government of $30m per annum for the first two years of the RRT recognises that the measure will have significant effects. Some witnesses stressed that this compensation would not necessarily be available to all gas users, and was below the expected additional cost to the community.

There was concern that this grant was untied. However, Senator McMullan pointed out that ``it is not necessarily going to be an untied grant; that is not a matter about which a final decision has been made'' (Evidence, p. FPA134). He also acknowledged that the compensation would cover only approximately half of the Government's estimate of the potential price impact.
Impact on Victoria

A Report by the Victorian Gas Users Group and the Australian Chamber of Manufactures indicated that the approximate annual cost impact of the Resource Rent Tax on the Gas and Fuel Corporation customers, SECV, and Ethane Users could total $90 million.

Among other things the Report suggested the legislation could have serious, adverse and unintended consequences on Victoria, including Victorian manufacturers being disadvantaged against imports, the potential for exports being reduced, a policy conflict with environmental goals and reduced employment levels.
In addition APM pointed to the fact that an increase in the gas price could jeopardise future investment decisions.
The problem of retrospective accounts to users was also raised during the hearings by Mr. Palmer of Gas and Fuel Corporation.
Other concerns

The Committee also heard evidence of concerns on the part of the producers about technical aspects of the legislation. BHP, Esso and the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association all argued for changes to two provisions:
* retention of the carry forward rate for deductible general expenditure at the long-term bond rate plus 15% rather than the proposal for the long-term bond rate plus 5%; and

* providing for exploration expenses to retain deductible status for five years from the date of issue of a production licence and (as argued by some witnesses) for deductibility to continue for longer than five years.

Esso also argued for changes which would permit deductibility of a proportion of the investment in recent Bass Strait developments and allowing deductibility for Oil Basins Limited (OBL or ``Weeks'') royalty.
The failure to allow full deductibility of all investment expenditure in this bill effectively increases the 40% RRT.

The Coalition believes that the Government and the producers should further negotiate on these issues with a view to raising the percentage increment faster on the carry forward rate to accommodate more closely the cost of capital.
Implications for Income Tax Assessment Act

RRT is currently deductible for income tax purposes only after the final assessment has been made. The Government has decided that RRT instalments under the new system should be deductible for income tax purposes in the income year in which they are paid. However, this will require an amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Act and no Bill containing such an amendment has yet been introduced.

The new RRT system has effect from 1 July 1990 and the Coalition would consider it unsatisfactory for the related income tax provisions not to be enacted in the 1990-91 financial year. The Coalition believes that the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Bill should be accompanied by a bill to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act.
Importance of the legislation

The Coalition accepts that it is important that the Bill be passed in this session to give a proper legislative base to the petroleum resource rent tax system. The Government's proposed changes have been followed by significant investment and other decisions by the producers and, in their central provisions and aims, have general support. The Coalition accepts that an RRT appropriately structured could be a more efficient system than that it replaces, providing that it does not lead to any increase in the burden of tax.

However, the Committee notes that the Government has been aware of concerns about the impact of RRT on gas and ethane users and about a possibly disruptive transition to the more efficient tax system. It is regrettable that these concerns were not addressed more effectively in the several months between announcement of the scheme and the arrival of the Bill in the Senate.
Conclusion

The Legislation is a budget bill with significant revenue implications. Further substantial investment has taken place based on the assurance of the passage of this legislation, its potential impact on user industries and consumers.
However, evidence was presented to the Committee which indicated that there are some basic defects in the bill and that there could be a number of unintended consequences.

It was argued strongly by BHP that most of these problems could be addressed following passage of the legislation. On the other hand a number of other witnesses sought significant amendments immediately.
Despite the assurances of the Minister there was great concern about a possible rise in gas prices resulting from this legislation.

The Government accepted a Coalition amendment that the Government be required to report to the Parliament by 30th November, 1992 on the operation of the Act including its impact on prices and industry and on the development of new offshore petroleum prospects.

The Government refused to accept the Opposition's amendment to include in the Bill a guarantee that the $60 million compensation package to the Victorian Government be made specifically to minimise transitional pressures on gas prices.

The Government refused to accept an amendment to the starting date for the application of the five year rule governing expenditure write-off to the date of application for a development licence rather that the date of issue.
Senator Jim Short, a Senator for Victoria, also took part in the Committee hearings and wished to be associated with this minority report.
Ian Campbell
Senator for W.A.
Rod Kemp
Senator for Victoria
John Watson
Senator for Tasmania

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Before I address my remarks to the Bill, I would like to know whether this amendment is in order. It may be that the issues I am raising go to the constitutionality of the amendment rather than a question of it being in order. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will now address my remarks to the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 and speak in the debate on the Opposition's amendment. —Senator Watson says that it is just another reminder, but I would have thought that people ought to have more respect for the drafting of the laws of the nation rather than to put poorly drafted little reminders in a Bill which will be sitting there for years to come. SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the Australian Democrats will be supporting the amendment, and they should be embarrassed to be doing so.
