TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Fisheries Administration Bill 1991. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
FISHERIES ADMINISTRATION BILL 1991

Since coming to power in 1983 the Government has committed itself to improving the management of Commonwealth fisheries. In December 1989 the Government released a major policy statement setting out the future directions for Commonwealth fisheries management. The policy statement emphasised four objectives for fisheries management:
- To ensure that fisheries resources are not over-exploited and that any exploitation is at a level which can be sustained while maintaining the surrounding environment;
- To enable commercial fishing operations to be as economically efficient as possible, using the most appropriate technology to achieve the greatest net returns;

- To create conditions where fishermen are able to make a payment to the community for the right to exploit a public resource for private gain, recognising that such a payment should not reduce the profitability of fishing operations to less than their current levels; and
- To ensure that the administration of Commonwealth fisheries should be conducted on the most efficient and effective basis.

Legislation designed to achieve the first three objectives, (which comprise the essence of the Government's fisheries management policies) is being drafted and will be put before Parliament in the autumn sittings next year. In addition to introducing new policies arising from the Government's policy statement this legislation will replace the Fisheries Act 1952 which will be repealed.

The legislation before us now concerns the administration of fisheries management. The Government recognises the importance of an effective and efficient administrative structure if the fisheries management objectives which I have outlined are to be achieved and sustained.

This legislation establishes a new statutory authority-the Australian Fisheries Management Authority-to undertake the Government's fisheries management responsibilities. It also establishes a fishing industry policy council to provide advice to the Government on matters affecting the fishing industry and an Australian Fisheries Management Authority Selection Committee.

An associated Fisheries Research and Development Corporation will also be established under the auspices of the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 to commence from 1 July 1991.
My remarks will be primarily about the new Authority, although at the end I will come back to the selection processes and the role and composition of the policy council.

The Government has decided to establish the Australian Fisheries Management Authority to undertake its fisheries management responsibilities which will be included in the Fisheries Management Bill to be introduced in the autumn sitting. It has done this because it believes that the statutory authority model of public administration has a number of important advantages.
These advantages include:

- Increased industry and community involvement in decision making through an enhanced role for the management advisory committees, and industry and community involvement in selecting the governing board;
- Increased flexibility of operations, without the constraints of a departmental structure;
- Increased public accountability for the Authority for both decision making and expenditure;
- Increased independence in day to day decision making, with ministerial involvement at a strategic level rather than on-going involvement in operational matters; and
- Increased incentives to ensure that all of the Authority's operations are conducted in a cost efficient manner.

In order to ensure that these advantages are realised, the charter of the new Authority will be exclusively fisheries management. The Authority will not have to undertake the additional broad policy functions currently being performed by the Australian Fisheries Service. A policy branch will remain within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to handle those matters. In most cases the functions of these two bodies will be quite distinct.
The Authority will be required to manage the marine resources of the Australian fishing zone in accordance with the Government's sustainable development objectives and policies.
The Authority's principal responsibilities will be:
- To develop and implement fishery-specific management plans;
- To set sustainable catch quotas for our fish stocks;
- To grant on-going or temporary access to fish resources;
- To effectively monitor the activities of Australian and foreign fishermen licensed to exploit our fish resources; and
- To monitor the general performance of each fishery and introduce, where necessary, appropriate restructuring programs.

In order to undertake these responsibilities the Authority will have an important role in identifying research and development requirements for fisheries and commissioning expert assistance from organisations such as the CSIRO, the Bureau of Rural Resources and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics.

The policy branch within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy will retain its responsibility for advising the Government on broad strategic fisheries policy matters. These will include the development of resource use and environmental policies, advising on policy matters concerning foreign access to the Australian fishing zone, developing policy on fisheries access rights and the collection of community returns from the fishing industry, monitoring the effect of taxation rulings on fisheries management and developing policy that will reduce domestic and international marketing impediments for Australian fish products. The fisheries policy branch will also be required to monitor the overall performance of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority in regard to its implementation of the Government's fisheries management objectives and the general performance and profitability of the fishing industry.

As indicated and in keeping with the principle that formal inter-government negotiations are lead by Ministers and their officials, the Department will generally take the leading role in delegations to inter-Governmental negotiations on fisheries matters and will represent the Government on multilateral fisheries fora.

The Authority will also have a role in inter-Governmental negotiations where these relate to fisheries management. It will assist the Department as required in such negotiations, as for example in the bilateral and trilateral arrangements with Japan concerning the international management of the southern bluefin tuna stocks, and the arrangements with Papua New Guinea on the management of Torres Strait fisheries, and with New Zealand on the driftnet surveillance program.

Under the new arrangements there will be a need to continue and where possible strengthen the close working relationship which currently exists between the Australian Fisheries Service, the Bureau of Rural Resources, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and relevant external agencies like the CSIRO. Because of the particular importance which the Minister places on the work of the Bureau of Rural Resources he will ensure that additional staff resources are made available to it from within his portfolio.

I also note, in keeping with the undertaking in the policy statement, that one quarter of a per cent of the gross value of fisheries production, will be provided by the Government for fisheries research, and these funds will be distributed between the Authority, the Bureau of Rural Resources and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics at the discretion of the Minister.

An important feature of the new administrative arrangement is the enhanced role which the Authority will be able to give (at its discretion) to management advisory committees. In order to meet the challenging responsibilities which I have outlined above the Authority will be able to devolve functions to these committees to perform on behalf of AFMA. The Authority will still be the body which will be held accountable for meeting the fisheries management objectives, but nevertheless, provided that the Authority has confidence in a particular management advisory committee, that committee will be able to exercise considerable influence in the management of the fishery concerned.

The functions of the management advisory committees are to advise the Authority in relation to fisheries management, to act as a liaison mechanism between the Authority and the fishermen concerned, and to assist in keeping the Authority informed about the biological and economic status of the fishery.

Management advisory committees will consist of a chairperson (to be selected by the Authority), the fishery manager and up to seven members selected by the Authority after consultation with the industry, relevant state or territory governments and relevant members of the research community.

The Government recognises that the strength and success of the Authority will depend on the quality and calibre of its board. The Government is firmly convinced that it is highly desirable to select the board on the basis of expertise, and this legislation establishes a selection committee which will choose five of the board members. The selection committee itself will consist of two industry representatives to be nominated by the peak industry body, two community representatives, nominee of the Australian Fisheries Council, and a presiding member to be selected by the Minister. The Minister hopes to be in a position to announce the name of the presiding member within the next few weeks. The National Fishing Industry Council will be specified in the regulations as the peak industry body.

There are clear parallels between these selection procedures for the Authority's board and those which are used for the statutory marketing authorities and the research and development corporations associated with the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio. However there are also some important differences. The most important difference is the role which industry will play. Industry quite rightly has an influential role in the outlook and activities of the statutory marketing authorities and the research and development corporations, and is a key participant in the formation of industry commercial philosophy of those organisations.

On the other hand, the Australian Fisheries Management Authority will have the task of enforcing regulations which will prevent fisheries from being over-exploited or over-capitalised. At times the collective interest of all the fishermen in the fishery and of the broader community may be at odds with the self interest of individual fishermen. Since the Authority will be a Government body undertaking the Government's regulatory role in fisheries management it would be inappropriate for industry to have a dominant influence. To do so would be like asking the players to umpire their own football match. At the same time it is highly desirable for some board members of the Authority to have fishing industry experience.

For this reason the Minister has decided that the board of the Authority will consist of a chairperson and a Government member to be selected by the Minister, with five directors to be selected by the special selection committee on the basis of their expertise. The areas of expertise will include commercial fishing; fishing industry operations other than fishing; fisheries science, natural resource management, economics and business management. There will be a requirement that no more than two directors be currently engaged in the fishing industry. The managing director of the Authority will be chosen by these seven directors and will be an ex-officio member of the board.

Having given the Authority some independence from the industry and indeed from day to day ministerial control, it is important that there are mechanisms through which the Authority will be held accountable.

The Authority will be accountable at three levels. It will be required to submit both a longer term corporate plan and an annual operational plan to the Minister setting out the means by which it will achieve its statutory objectives. The Minister may approve or seek a variation to these documents.

The Authority will be required to provide an annual report to Parliament, and will be subject to the scrutiny of parliamentary committees. As well it will be subject to an annual audit by the Auditor General. The Minister will have the power to direct the Authority in exceptional circumstances, but it will be a requirement that any such direction be presented to both houses of Parliament and reported in the authority's annual report.

The Authority will be required to have a high degree of disclosure in its annual report. It will be required to focus in that document on strategic reporting against the goals and key parameters for performance outlined in its corporate and annual operational plans.

The Authority will also be accountable to the fishing industry and the general public. In addition to the annual report the Authority will be required to hold public meetings at least once each year in order to ensure that the fishing industry and the community in general have an opportunity to consult the board, to question them and to have them justify their management actions.

I turn now to the matter of staffing for the new Authority. The Minister has consistently stressed that he wants the employment conditions of the current staff in the Australian Fisheries Service to be safeguarded, and for employees transferring from the Australian Fisheries Service to the Australian Fisheries Management Authority to continue to work under the Public Service Act 1922 and to enjoy their current conditions of service, including superannuation entitlements.

The Minister also recognises the importance of providing the Authority with the flexibility to develop remuneration packages to attract and reward staff with particular skills. For this reason the legislation will give the Authority the power to set the terms and conditions of those employees who are recruited from outside the Australian Fisheries Service.

I also wish to make some brief remarks about the Fishing Industry Policy Council. This legislation establishes a statutory fishing industry policy council which will advise the Minister on matters which have been referred to it, or indeed on any other matters affecting the well-being of the industry. The Council will convene meetings and conferences, produce reports, consult with other persons as necessary, and generally provide the Minister with an independent and wide-ranging source of information on the fishing industry.

The composition of the Council will be broad. It will consist of a chairperson, the chairperson of the Authority, the chairperson of the Fishing Industry Research and Development Corporation, a representative of the National Fishing Industry Training Council Limited, two industry representatives representing the spectrum of catching, processing and marketing interests to be nominated by the peak industry body, a representative of recreational fishermen, and a person having an interest in environmental and/or consumer aspects. This membership may be widened to include representatives of other groups at a later stage at the discretion of the Minister.

The Bill will not have any significant effect on Government expenditure. The Authority will be funded on the same basis as that currently in place for the Australian Fisheries Service of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, with 90% of attributable management costs being recovered from the fishing industry. Some additional Government funding may initially be required to cover transitional arrangements. The Industry Commission is to review the basis of cost recovery for fisheries management prior to December 1991 and every five years thereafter. However it is worth remembering that the Government, as custodian of the marine resources of the Australian fishing zone, will always retain certain responsibilities and meet the costs associated with the management of those resources. Examples of such responsibilities are surveillance costs to detect illegal foreign fishing activities, and protecting the traditional way of life of Torres Strait Islanders in joint Authority with Queensland and in treaty with Papua New Guinea.

In drafting this legislation the Government intends, where relevant, the new policy adjustments for statutory marketing authorities arising from the report of the Davis Committee be included in the arrangements for the Authority. In line with this the legislation does not contain any restrictions on the appointment of directors because of their age and limits the duration of their tenure to three consecutive terms. It also requires the Authority to identify key indicators of its performance in its corporate and annual operational plans and to report on these in its annual report.

The industry, through representatives of the National Fishing Industry Council, have been kept informed of the development of this legislation and have actively participated in ensuring a smooth transition to the new Authority through a special liaison committee. They have been supportive and constructive and many of their suggestions are embodied in this Bill. The Minister thanks them for their assistance and looks forward to continuing productive consultations. With their assistance the Government believes that the target date for the establishment of the Authority on or before 1 July 1991 can be achieved.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
FISHERIES MANAGEMENT BILL 1991

The Government regards the effective management of the Commonwealth's fisheries as a very important responsibility and throughout its term it has been committed to improving that management. Last December the Fisheries Administration Bill was introduced into Parliament. That Bill will establish a new statutory authority-the Australian Fisheries Management Authority-to undertake the Government's fisheries management responsibilities.

The Bill before us now, together with supporting legislation, provides the powers for the new Authority to undertake the Government's fisheries management responsibilities. This new legislation will replace both the Fisheries Act 1952 and the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act 1968 and will establish a framework for the management of Commonwealth fisheries well into the twenty-first century.

This Bill has been the result of the most intensive review and examination of Commonwealth fisheries management since the 1950s-a review which culminated in the policy statement released in December 1989 `New Directions for Commonwealth Fisheries Management in the 1990s'.
The Bill will give effect to the three objectives of fisheries management identified in the policy statement:
- To ensure that fisheries resources are not over-exploited and that any exploitation is at a level which can be sustained while maintaining the surrounding environment;
- To enable commercial fishing operations to be as economically efficient as possible, using the most appropriate technology to achieve the greatest net returns; and

- To create conditions where fishermen are able to earn significant profits from which to make a payment to the community for the right to exploit a public resource for private gain, recognising that such a payment should not reduce the profitability of fishing operations to less than their current levels.
The first of these objectives concerns the conservation of the resource, and more generally, the conservation of the marine environment.

The Government regards the protection of fisheries from over-exploitation as a matter of the utmost importance. Honourable senators would be aware that the Government has consistently emphasised the importance of sustainable development, and sustainable resource management policies. Put simply, the Government believes it has a duty to the community to ensure that the nation's resources are protected and preserved so that future generations can continue to benefit from them.

This Bill also has specific provisions to control fishing activities which are harmful to the marine environment, such as driftnet fishing. The Prime Minister has consistently emphasised Australia's policy of seeking a global ban on large scale driftnet fishing. This legislation bans pelagic driftnet fishing in the Australian Fishing Zone and will also enable the Government to ratify the convention for the prohibition of fishing with long driftnets in the South Pacific.

The fisheries resource is an excellent example of a renewable natural resource that can be managed in a balanced way so as to yield returns in both the present and the future. Of course the resource also has uses other than commercial fishing, and these too must be managed in an ecologically sustainable framework. These broader aspects of aquatic resource management are now being examined through the ecologically sustainable development process that the Government initiated last year.

At various times there have been suggestions from some that fisheries should be treated as though they were a resource to be mined and that it would not matter if a fishery or fish species was pushed to the verge of extinction if that maximised profits.

The Government does not accept this argument and I wish to make it perfectly clear that the conservation objective of fisheries management may in some cases limit our ability to achieve the second objective of achieving the maximum economic return from the resource.

For example in a multi species fishery it may be necessary to limit the catch of species which are not under threat if continued fishing were to endanger other species that were part of the catch. Fortunately this situation is not likely to occur frequently, and in most cases the most efficient level of exploitation of fisheries resources will be quite consistent with the conservation objective.
Having said this it should be emphasised that the Government is also committed to ensuring that fishing is undertaken as economically and efficiently as possible.

This means reducing excessive levels of fishing capacity, keeping regulations, especially those which impede efficiency, to a minimum and ensuring that fisheries administration is results oriented and cost effective. In this regard the Government's northern prawn fishery restructuring arrangements will be a most significant achievement and will significantly increase fishing efficiency while reducing pressure on the resource in the Commonwealth's most valuable fishery.

The third objective of management, that of creating conditions where the industry is able to pay a return to the community for the use of its resource, has been widely misunderstood and misrepresented. This Government is not about to take steps which will frustrate, impede or restrict commercial initiatives. Nor will it take actions which would reduce the valuable contribution which the fishing industry makes to the national economy.

However, the Government does accept the principle that our scarce and valuable fisheries resources should, where possible, be priced so that sensible decisions about exploitation are taken. This is entirely consistent with our sustainable development policies. In practice what this means is that our scarce fisheries resources will be carefully husbanded in both a biological and economic sense so that many generations of Australians will benefit from their use. It also means that fishermen who are given privileged access to public resources which enable them to make very large profits-super profits which exceed normal levels of profitability-should pay a share of these super profits to the community.

The fisheries policy statement made it quite clear that a community return would only be sought where new super profits were generated-mainly from restructuring existing fisheries to make them more profitable.

At this stage the most likely fishery in which the Government can foresee super profits arising from restructuring is the northern prawn fishery. While the details of the community return in the northern prawn fishery have not been finalised, industry can be assured that it will not be introduced until after the restructuring is complete, that the new arrangements will not be onerous, and that the industry will have the opportunity to be involved before the details are finalised.

It is also appropriate to take this opportunity to reassure the industry on another matter. Honourable senators would be aware that the Industry Commission is currently investigating the appropriate level of cost recovery which the industry is to pay for the management of Commonwealth fisheries. This reference to the Industry Commission is not intended to delay the establishment of the new management authority-it is not to be a further review of Commonwealth fisheries management per se, but rather a very focussed review of cost recovery levels and procedures.

The National Fishing Industry Council has sought assurance that cost recovery levels will not be changed from the current arrangements until the Industry Commission review is complete and has been considered by the Government. The Government is happy to give this assurance, and it is appropriate to reiterate a commitment made in the fisheries policy statement, namely that `as an interim arrangement (until the Industry Commission review is complete), the Government will require the industry to meet the same proportion of the combined costs of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy Fisheries Group that it meets of the total costs of the Australian Fisheries Service's operations in the final two years of existence'. (Page 111).

I turn now to the Bill before us and the significant changes it makes to the way fishing in the Australian Fishing Zone is to be administered-particularly in relation to the role of plans of management and the new arrangements to be introduced for Commonwealth fishing licences.

In 1985 this Government introduced the first plan of management for a Commonwealth fishery into Parliament. The plan was for the Southern Bluefin Tuna fishery. Since that time the usefulness of plans of management for fisheries administration has been repeatedly demonstrated, and fisheries plans of management will continue to be central to this legislation. A plan of management will contain all the necessary information about the fishery including a description of the fishery either by area, species or fishing method used, or some combination of these. It will contain all the rules of the fishery and will describe what the statutory fishing right is, including any conditions such as constraints on transferability. The board of the new Fisheries Management Authority will establish management advisory committees containing industry representatives and these committees will play a fundamental role in the development of the plans of management. The management advisory committees will of course be accountable to the board of the Authority.

In conjunction with the increased emphasis on plans of management the Government is making some important changes to Commonwealth fishing boat licences in order to achieve greater certainty and control over fishing operations in Commonwealth waters.

There are two reasons for these changes. First, the Government believes it is appropriate for the ongoing nature of fishing rights in established fisheries-those administered through a plan of management-to be recognised and recorded in a formal fishing rights register. This will give fishermen greater security, and will establish the rights as an asset against which they can borrow.

At the same time, it is important for the Government to have greater knowledge about, and control of, fishing activities being undertaken in parts of the Australian Fishing Zone which are not subject to formal management arrangements. The existing Commonwealth fishing boat licence which allowed holders to fish anywhere in the Australian Fishing Zone other than in a managed fishery did not allow this control and this has inevitably contributed to some of the problems of excessive fishing capacity which are now being faced.The new licensing arrangements will result in the existing Commonwealth fishing boat licence being phased out after 1 July 1991, and in its place there will be various types of fishery-specific entitlements. These entitlements will authorise fishing activities in specific areas of Commonwealth waters.

One of the main forms of fishery-specific entitlement will be a statutory fishing right created through a plan of management, which will recognise longer term access to established fisheries. This level of access can be compared to the endorsement of the current licence to operate in a managed fishery; under the existing system licences are only issued for 12 months and could at least theoretically not be reissued. Under the new licence system, provided that levies are paid, and that fisheries regulations are adhered to, it will normally be ongoing in nature and will provide guaranteed access beyond the current one-year licensing period.

Details of statutory fishing rights will be recorded in a statutory fishing rights register which will also record third party (or mortgage holder) interests. The register will merely be a record of a third party interest and will not give that interest any effect or validity it does not otherwise have. Any transactions relative to a statutory fishing right must involve all parties with a recorded interest in that right. Where a third party has an interest in a statutory fishing right it will be the responsibility of that party to ensure their interests are protected by recording that interest in the register.
The Australian Fisheries Management Authority will not recognise any interest unless it is recorded in the register.

Another type of fishery-specific entitlement will be a fishing permit. Fishing permits will normally apply in those fisheries where there is no plan of management, and they will be issued for fixed periods of time up to five years. They will not confer an ongoing right to the fishery and will not be recorded in the statutory fishing rights register. The fishing permit will apply to a specified boat and will define the area, species and gear which can be used for fishing. It will also contain the conditions with which the holder must comply. The application for a fishing permit will seek details of the proposed operations, and the fishing permit will limit operations to those specified in the permit. Fishing permits will also be used for fishing related activities including the operation of fish processing or carrier boats or to allow the testing of fishing gear in otherwise closed areas.
The Fisheries Levy Act 1984 will be replaced by the Fisheries Levy Bill 1991. This will enable levy payments for both of these new fishery-specific entitlements to be collected.

This legislation will contain provisions similar to those of the Fisheries Act 1952 for scientific exploration and foreign fishing activity in the Australian Fishing Zone through the issue of scientific permits and foreign fishing licences.

A scientific permit will provide for short term access and allow a specific program of scientific work or exploratory fishing to be undertaken. There will be no charge for a scientific permit, and the fishing operations undertaken with it will be closely controlled by the Australian Fisheries Management Authority in consultation with appropriate research agencies. Conditions will be attached to a scientific permit as appropriate, such as the provision of research data and the carriage of scientific observers.

A foreign fishing licence will also be fishery specific, will be valid for up to one year, and will be subject to the payment of fees and levies, as well as other fishery specific conditions. The Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Act 1981 will be replaced by the Foreign Fishing Licences Levy Bill 1991 in order to collect the levy payments and the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Act 1981 will be replaced by the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Bill 1991 to collect payments from overseas governments or commercial interests for access to the Australian Fishing Zone. These new levy Bills do not change the basis of levy collection from foreign fishing boats but simply place that collection within the framework of the new legislative instruments and administrative arrangements.

The Government recognises that effective fisheries management and scientific research depend on accurate and timely records of fish caught and fishing operations. One focus of this package of legislation is to improve both of these areas of activity, and an improvement in the quality of fishing logbook information is critical to this. Under this Bill fishermen will be required to complete their logbooks in an accurate and timely manner, and there will be penalties for failing to submit logbooks and for providing false information.

The fisheries policy statement clearly indicated that the Government would not auction the access rights of existing fishermen in developed fisheries, but that there could be circumstances in which some of the rights in new fisheries would be subject to competitive bidding. This policy is given effect in the associated Bill, the Statutory Fishing Rights Charge Bill 1991.

I hasten to add that the Government clearly recognises that it is most important to provide incentives for exploration and development of new fisheries, otherwise no new fisheries will be found. Consequently any decisions to embark on an auction of new fishing rights will only be undertaken after the Australian Fisheries Management Authority is satisfied that the interests of the discoverer(s) of the new resource have been catered for or that they received an adequate return to justify their risk and their investment.
I now wish to make a few remarks about surveillance and enforcement of fisheries management.

The best system of fisheries management will only work if it is effectively enforced. The Government recognises that the best way of encouraging fishermen to comply with regulations is to involve them in the decision making process, and is achieving this through the management advisory committees. However it is also important for there to be an effective system of monitoring, control and surveillance in order to back up fisheries management decisions and this in turn will give the industry confidence in fisheries management. This legislation provides the powers for the Australian Fisheries Management Authority to carry out the necessary surveillance and enforcement actions.

While this section of the legislation is largely carried over from the Fisheries Act 1952 new provisions have been added to allow the licensing of fish receivers in order to facilitate the introduction of individual transferable quota schemes.

The Bill maintains the provisions in the Fisheries Act 1952 which give effect to the fisheries part of the offshore constitutional settlement. Quite clearly fisheries management is much more effective if it can be administered in a way which encompasses entire stocks rather than being constrained by arbitrary lines drawn on the sea. I note that we have moved some considerable distance with the States over the period in which this Government has been in office towards achieving this rationality of jurisdiction as a basis upon which to undertake effective management. However, there is still room to do more, particularly in relation to those fisheries where the same stock is caught in the waters off several different States. The new Authority will need to give this matter careful attention. The Southern Shark fishery is a clear example where further progress can be made, and indeed the best solution for this fishery may be to seek State agreement for the Commonwealth to assume management responsibility for all of the shark fishery.
I will now comment on the provisions which this Bill makes for the review of the allocation of statutory fishing rights.

This legislation establishes a specialist review panel-the Statutory Fishing Rights Allocation Review Panel-which will, upon application, review the allocation of statutory fishing rights created under a plan of management. The Government has been concerned that in the past the procedure for the review of fishing rights allocation decisions by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has not always taken sufficient account of the impact of the granting of additional rights to a particular fisherman on the total capacity of the fishery to sustain additional effort.

Under the new arrangements the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will retain responsibility for considering appeals as to whether an individual satisfies the conditions specified in a plan of management for entry to a fishery. Appeals about the manner in which the available fishing rights are to be distributed among those fishermen who satisfy the entry conditions will be considered by the Statutory Fishing Rights Allocation Review Panel. Where an appeal is made the Statutory Fishing Rights Allocation Review Panel will undertake a review of the allocation of all fishing rights of the same class, taking account of the comparative merits of all applicants. In arriving at its decisions the Panel will consider all matters affecting the well being of the fishery.

The Statutory Fishing Rights Allocation Review Panel will be quite independent from the management authority. Each case will be reviewed by three members-a principal member appointed by the Minister and two other members chosen by the principal member from a panel of members.

In the appointment of the principal member the intention is to consult with the Attorney-General as the Minister responsible for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on this matter. This will assist in ensuring that an appropriate link is maintained between the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the review panel.
The panel of members will be selected by the Australian Fisheries Management Authority selection committee, using the same selection criteria that the committee uses to select board members.

The Fishing Rights Allocation Review Panel will only be concerned with the review of decisions affecting the allocation of fishing rights and permits. Other decisions made under this legislation will continue to be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
My final remarks about this package of legislation deal with research and development in the fishing industry.

Fisheries research is vital to the successful management of Australia's fisheries. A sound understanding of the biology and distribution of fish stocks is essential if harvesting from these fisheries is to be sustained in the long term.
A number of fish stocks are already threatened by overfishing. There is a need for further research into the nature and distribution of stocks if this situation is not to become more widespread.
Assessing the size and condition of a specific fish stock which is constantly mobile and rarely completely isolated from other stocks is a costly and difficult exercise.
Research in this area is, therefore, inherently more difficult, more costly and more time consuming than that in most other industries in the primary industries and energy portfolio.

Nor is the need for research confined to biological aspects of fisheries. As in many other industries the post-harvest phase has become increasingly important in ensuring good returns are received by participants. This is especially true where the resource is limited and there is little opportunity to increase production. If Australia is to continue to compete on world markets, greater attention must be given to finding better and more efficient ways of handling and transporting fish products and ensuring that the product offered is of high quality so that it attracts high prices.

The Government's policy on research and development in the primary industries and energy sectors was set out in the report `Research, Innovation and Competitiveness', released in May 1989. The thrust of that report was the need to improve the funding, organisation and administration of research and development in these industries. The report recognised:

- the benefits of research and development corporations as appropriate structures for effectively administering portfolio research and development programs and for allowing industry an input into the decision-making process on research and development;
- that those who benefit directly from research and development should bear responsibility for funding that research;

- that the Government has a responsibility to prevent over-exploitation of community owned natural resources, such as fisheries, and must therefore be prepared to bear a larger proportion of research and development costs than might otherwise be the case.
In line with these policy guidelines the Government will replace the existing Fishing Industry Research and Development Council with the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation.
The Corporation will be established under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989, and amendments to that Act are included in this package of legislation.

The establishment of the new research corporation will lead to greater flexibility and autonomy of fisheries research and development administration, as well as providing an increased opportunity for industry involvement and ensuring that funds are directed to research areas of the greatest potential benefit.

The Government accepts that it has a responsibility to contribute funds for fisheries research and development but also believes that industry, as the major beneficiary of research, should share some of this responsibility. Neither State nor Commonwealth fishermen currently contribute to research and development funded by the current Fishing Industry Research and Development Council. In line with the Government's policy of ensuring that beneficiaries play a part in funding, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 will be amended to enable industry to contribute funds to the fisheries research and development corporation.

Revised funding arrangements for fisheries research and development were announced in the fisheries policy statement. Under the new arrangements the Commonwealth will provide funding equal to 0.5% Of the gross value of fisheries production and if the industry (including both State and Commonwealth licensed fishermen) contributes at the relatively low level of 0.25% of the gross value of fisheries production the Commonwealth will also match this amount of funding.

In addition the Government will provide funds equivalent to a further 0.25% of the gross value of production, for additional fisheries research to be undertaken or administered by the management authority, the Bureau of Rural Resources or the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics. This will take Government's total contribution for fisheries research and development to a maximum of 1.0% gross value of production and the total funds available for fisheries research to 1.25% gross value of production.
In summary, the changes to the administration and funding of fisheries research and development will
- mean more money for research,
- provide a more effective administrative framework for allocating funds and assessing research and development requirements,
- encourage industry participation in funding research and at the same time provide the opportunity for greater industry involvement in research and development decision making.

I will conclude by emphasising the Government's belief that the package of fisheries legislation before the House makes an important step forward in fisheries management. It implements the management initiatives contained in the fisheries policy statement, through the Fisheries Administration Bill it establishes the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, and it makes important changes to fisheries research arrangements. These changes build on the existing solid framework for fisheries management which has been progressively developed through the term of this Government.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
FISHING LEVY BILL 1991
This Bill complements the Fisheries Management Bill 1991, which I presented earlier.

The second reading speech for the Fisheries Management Bill 1991 outlined how the new arrangements for granting access to fisheries under the Commonwealth's jurisdiction would work. The purpose of this Bill is to collect a levy from those fishermen that have been granted access under the Fisheries Management Bill 1991. It replaces the Fisheries Levy Act 1984.
I commend this Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
STATUTORY FISHING RIGHTS CHARGE BILL 1991
This Bill also complements the Fisheries Management Bill 1991 which I presented earlier.

The second reading speech for the Fisheries Management Bill 1991 reiterated previous assurances to industry that the Government would not auction the access rights of existing fishermen in developed fisheries. It also clearly stated that while an auction or tender may be used to allocate new fishing rights, the Government would ensure that appropriate incentives were provided so that exploration for and development of new fisheries would continue. This Bill provides the means by which auctions or tenders can be used to allocate new fishing rights.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
FOREIGN FISHING LICENCES LEVY BILL 1991

This Bill also complements the Fisheries Management Bill 1991 which I presented earlier.The second reading speech of the Fisheries Management Bill 1991 indicated that foreign fishing licences would be fishery specific and would be subject to the payment of fees and levies. The fees and levies can be paid either by means of a formal agreement for access to the Australian fishing zone, or through specific levies imposed when the foreign fishing licence is granted. This Bill provides the mechanism through which the levies associated with foreign fishing licences are paid when there is no formal agreement with overseas governments or commercial interests.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
FISHERIES AGREEMENTS (PAYMENTS) BILL 1991
This Bill also complements the Fisheries Management Bill 1991 which I presented earlier.

The second reading speech for the Fisheries Management Bill outlined the new system for granting access to the Australian Fishing Zone. In doing this it indicated that the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Act 1981 would be replaced by a new Bill to collect payments from overseas governments or commercial interests for access to the Australian Fishing Zone where formal agreements are in place. This Bill gives effect to this and provides the Australian Fisheries Management Authority with the power to suspend a licence to operate in the Australian Fishing Zone if the amount specified in the access agreement is not paid.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
FISHERIES LEGISLATION (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1991
This Bill is the companion Bill to the Fisheries Management Bill 1991, which I presented earlier.
This Bill addresses a number of issues.

Firstly it provides for transitional arrangements as the Fisheries Act 1952 is replaced by the Fisheries Management Bill 1991. In particular it makes provision for the continuation of scientific permits and fishing licences issued under the Fisheries Act 1952 until they expire or are revoked even though most parts of the Fisheries Act 1952 will be repealed. This will give the Australian Fisheries Management Authority a short breathing space during which time the new register of statutory fishing rights, and the procedures for allocating fishing permits can be established.

This Bill also continues the arrangements for the sharing of fisheries management responsibilities with the states and Northern Territory which are currently under the Fisheries Act 1952 for a period of two years, after which the Fisheries Management Bill 1991 will take over these matters. This will provide the state and Northern Territory governments with sufficient time to amend their legislation so as to appropriately cross-reference the new Fisheries Management Bill 1991.

Another important provision contained in the Bill concerns the terms and conditions of the staff being transferred to the Australian Fisheries Management Authority from the Australian Fisheries Service. The Bill makes it absolutely clear that staff who are transferred to the new authority at its commencement will continue to be employed on the same terms and conditions and will be subject to the same industrial awards that they are under immediately prior to their transfer until the authority negotiates its own industrial awards.

This Bill also amends the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 in order to implement the changes in fisheries research and development arrangements outlined in the second reading speech of the Fisheries Management Bill 1991.

That speech explained why the Government is establishing a Fisheries Research and Development Corporation and the bases of the funding arrangements for that corporation. This Bill gives effect to these changes.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, on the proposed tax file number provisions and data-matching program, and I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

In its report the Committee concluded by a majority that the present circumstances are such as to justify the use of tax file numbers as proposed in the Bills which were under Committee consideration. The relevant Bills, namely the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 and the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill 1990 were subsequently passed by both Houses of Parliament, received Royal Assent and are now operative.
In its report the Committee noted several matters in respect of which I would like to comment.

In paragraphs 15, 16 and 17 of the report the Committee discussed the provisions in the Bills requiring certain social security recipients to provide to the Department of Social Security details of tax file numbers belonging to their spouses. The Committee noted the comments of some witnesses to the effect that the requirement would cause problems for some social security recipients, especially those who have been subject to domestic violence.

The legislation allows for waiver of this requirement by the Secretary to the Department of Social Security where the recipient does not know the spouse's tax file number and the Secretary is satisfied that the recipient could not obtain a statement or declaration relating to the spouse's tax file number.

I also assured the Committee that the Department of Social Security would be preparing guidelines as to how the Secretary to that Department will exercise his power to waive the spousal tax file number requirement. I further undertook to provide a copy of these guidelines to the Senate Standing Committee when they are available. I can now report that the process of drafting and consultation on the guidelines is almost complete and I expect the guidelines to be finalised by the end of June 1991. Until the guidelines are adopted no social security recipient will be required to provide a spousal tax file number.
The Committee noted in paragraph 20 of the report that the Department of Social Security would not normally require pensioners aged over 80 years to supply a tax file number.

Work is proceeding on defining the circumstances when a tax file number will be required of pensioners aged 80 years or over. Again I expect to have firm proposals put before me by the end of June 1991.

At paragraph 20 of its report the Committee noted the undertaking I gave its members that there would be no interconnection between the data-matching system in the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act and that proposed for the Law Enforcement Access Network (known as LEAN). I confirm this.

The Committee noted in the same paragraph that the Department of Social Security undertook to endeavour to inform affected recipients of income support payments on how data about them would be used in the data-matching program run under the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act. The Government confirms that this will be done. At present the Department of Social Security is finalising consideration of the most cost-efficient way of doing this.

The Committee noted also in paragraph 20 that the Department of Social Security would ensure that the Technical Standards Report to be prepared under guideline 4.1 of the Schedule to the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act would include details setting out the Privacy Commissioner's responsibilities in the event that the data-matching cycle is interrupted by a computer malfunction. This will be done as will be evident when the Technical Standards Report is published. Guideline 4.2 requires production of a draft Technical Standards Report by 31 March 1991 with a final version due by 30 June 1991. The draft was provided to interested parties at the end of March.

At paragraphs 23 to 26 of its report the Committee referred to a letter to it from the Privacy Commissioner in which he suggested a change to a provision of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. This would have changed a proposed amendment to an objects clause, paragraph 202 (e), of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 so that the use of tax file numbers contemplated by the relevant clause in the Bill would be narrowed further. The Committee recommended an amendment along lines proposed by the Privacy Commissioner. This proposal was acceptable to the Government but in the time available it was not possible to present an agreed amendment to Parliament. Since then a draft amendment satisfactory to all the interested parties has been settled and will be presented to Parliament at the earliest opportunity. The amendment will operate retrospectively to 1 January 1991 if the legislation is passed.
On behalf of the Government I thank the Committee for its report.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 November 1990, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Education Services (Export Regulation) Bill 1990 is to provide for regulation of the education export industry with respect to the marketing and provision of education services to the overseas student market through the registration of institutions and the regulation of handling of moneys received from overseas students. In recent years the Government has got this whole area in a huge mess. It thought that the best way to handle that mess was to bring forward some further provisions in this Bill, but that was in an even bigger mess. As a result, some consultations have been pushed upon the Government. As a result of those consultations, the Government has brought forward a great list of amendments. It was still inadequate, and the measure was forwarded to a Senate committee.

SPEECH.PARA: That committee brought forward a great number of amendments, in a very important report that is presently before us in the chamber. It was still not satisfactory and the Opposition then brought forward further recommendations, and I am in great heart because I see that, at the end of this evening, we will have all those amendments in place, and this will enormously change the Bill as originally conceived by the Government. We will then have some means to hope that we will come through this process with those educational institutions that are providing for overseas students in some good heart.

Prior to the change in visa procedures in the latter half of 1989, overseas students usually prepaid tuition fees and living expenses to Australian institutions. It would appear that these institutions were under no obligation to separate these prepayments from other funds and generally did not do so. However, there were usually contracts with overseas students providing that if a student failed to secure a visa, the moneys paid, less a registration fee, would be refunded to the student.

In the wake of events in Tiananmen Square and Beijing two years ago, the processing of visas ceased for several months. At this time a backlog of 26,000 had already developed. Consequently, several months elapsed between the time the overseas student paid fees to the institution and when that student's visa application was processed. In the interim, another turn of the screw: visa processing procedures, which had been irresponsibly loose under this Government, were eventually greatly tightened. One of the new requirements was that overseas students not prepay fees until such a time as their visa application had been accepted.

Nonetheless, during the period when visa processing ceased, it is alleged that Australian institutions accepted prepayments from an additional 12,000 overseas students. When the visa processing recommenced, the new visa processing procedures resulted in a visa rejection rate of 35 per cent with respect to 26,000 students and a rejection rate of 45 per cent for the 12,000 students. Institutions were thus obligated to commence refunding fees to these students who had prepaid their fees and then had their visa applications rejected.

Many institutions, not anticipating these major changes in government administration of this matter, had already spent the funds provided by these backlogged students in anticipation of a continuation of the spectacular growth in the industry. Furthermore, institutions were not receiving any funds for new visa applicants. Indeed, after the processing of the backlog, visa regulations were further tightened to the extent that the rejection rate rose to 94 per cent-nearly all of them rejected-from the People's Republic of China. And we have had other debates about the way the Government mishandled students from overseas and from China in particular.

The twin factors of the unforeseen need to refund significant amounts of money and the unforeseen decline in revenue inflows meant that many institutions were unable to refund these moneys and several colleges actually went into liquidation. Many of the education institutions went broke and the money was still owed to overseas students, many of whom had not even left their own home country. The Government has stepped in, in an attempt to solve the mess it created, by refunding these moneys through introducing the Overseas Students (Refunds) Bill, and this has facilitated at least some of those refunds.

The contents of the Education Services (Export Regulation) Bill attempt to address the two problems that emerged during these events that I have rehearsed: firstly, the past improprieties of the providers and, secondly, the unsatisfactory handling of funds received. This is where the Government thinks that because there has been a mess, which it caused, the best approach is to bring down regulations on every educational institution so that such moneys received are handled in a watertight way for refund to students.

More than half the education institutions, which have recorded no misdemeanours, no defaulting on repayments, now have to subscribe to extra regulations, rules and requirements to do the job they have already been doing. That is a huge impediment to the good performers in the industry. That is why we have looked with all the more carefulness at the Government's intention in the legislation and why we have sought to remove many of those regulations.

The Liberal-National Party coalition opposed the Bill in the House of Representatives on the grounds that the requirements for trust accounts, audited quarterly returns and insurance were all excessive. They were draconian and ignored industry schemes coming into place, that is, self-discipline by the education institutions. Also, the Commonwealth had handed regulation of the industry over to the States and was now seeking to re-enter the field without consultation so it could be seen to be doing something.

The phrase `doing something' is the Government's excuse for creating this further mess to overcome the original mess. The States do not like being interfered with when they believe they have already provided for the good conduct of education within New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia or wherever.

Moreover, the Bill unduly restricted the ability of providers to explore the market for the services they might be prepared to offer. It put a brake on them going to another country to see what possible students would enrol in their institution. Also, the rights of institutions to withdraw money from the trust accounts was to be determined by future regulations and might override contracts between the institution and the student. Regulations may be costly and commercially impracticable.

It was discriminatory also in that it conferred on overseas students but not on Australian students an entitlement to refunds if they withdrew, for any reason, from their course; there was no entitlement to the Australian student if he or she withdrew from the same course. The Opposition rejects legislation in the Parliament that discriminates against Australian citizens.

In providing for refunds, it also failed to adequately account for the type of parties who enter into contracts with institutions. Further, the Bill contained a major drafting error, as a result of which it applied to every provider of education services whether or not they provided courses to overseas students. So following the Opposition's criticism the Bill was referred to the first meeting of the National Consultative Committee on Export of Education and Training Services on 19 December 1990. This Committee happened to agree with all of the Opposition's criticism of the Bill. This Committee included State government representatives and representatives of peak industry provider bodies, together with officers of the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. At the end of the discussions, DEET officers indicated that a lot of amendments would need to be made.

At the beginning of this year the Government introduced six amendments to the Bill, which we will come to in the committee stage. The Opposition called for these and supports all six. But they only went some small part of the way to meet the necessary requirements. The Government amendments are principally designed to meet State objections that, having handed responsibility for regulation of the industry to the States, the Bill would then operate to force the States from the field. They also allow exemption of certain providers from the regulations to meet objections mainly from the universities.

The Government has also made available draft regulations that would operate under this new law but these draft regulations were only published on the very day that the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training met and none of the witnesses-and senators who were asking questions, including myself-had seen those regulations. So we were at a huge disadvantage. This has typified the Government's lack of courtesy and orderliness in its conduct of this matter in the past six months.

The Bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. We have in the chamber my colleagues Senator Tierney and Senator Crane, who served very capably on that Senate inquiry, and Senator Calvert. As a result, we have the report, to which I have referred, which brought down enormous criticism of the Bill, and 13 additional specific amendments, which were seen as necessary by not only my colleagues in the Opposition but also Government and Democrat senators. In fact, this very sensible committee inquiry alluded to even further defects. This led us in the Opposition to want to put forward even further amendments, which we are doing tonight.

I want to commend my three colleagues in the Opposition for the conscientiousness with which they went about that committee work; the way they contacted the industry; the way they listened carefully; and the way they tried to sort out the mess that this Government had placed the industry in by this pending legislation. In their remarks shortly, I know that Senators Tierney and Crane will refer to the Committee's report. So I do not have a need to refer to that any further.

At this stage, I was going to outline the six specific Government amendments but, owing to the restrictions on time, I will skip that part of my speech. I have already broadly described them as responding to that meeting in December and to the Opposition's remarks in the House of Representatives last year. The Committee amendments are 13 in number. Let me give the Senate four of the amendments. One of them redefines the word `course' to correct the effect of the drafting error by limiting courses to `courses of education and training provided to overseas students'.

Another recommendation replaces the schedule of exempt providers with a schedule exempting classes of providers. For example, it has always been my contention that this law should not affect any primary or secondary school in Australia. I am happy to see that by exempting a class, that is, all secondary schools, we will not make them liable to all the penalties, regulations and requirements that are set out in this new legislation. Another outcome from the Committee's work was to replace the concept of `trust accounts' that are in the Bill as it is before us now with `special accounts', thus removing the ambiguity surrounding the term `trust'. What is needed is not in fact what in law is termed a trust account. Another amendment alters the conditions applying to the withdrawal of funds from the special accounts.

Generally, the Committee's work supported the thrust of the Opposition's arguments and seeks, by its amendments, to make the Bill less regulatory. These amendments look more for self-discipline rather than for discipline by Commonwealth Government intervention.

The proposed amendments to this point-whether Government amendments or the so-called Committee amendments, that is, the six amendments and the 13-while meeting some of our objections to the original Bill do not address the concerns raised about the commercial practicability and equity of the proposed legislation. The oppressive provisions relating to financial arrangements and the inequity, to which the Bill gives rise between Australian and overseas students, still remains. Consequently, the Government amendments and even the Committee amendments do not go far enough to lead us to alter our inclination to oppose the Bill. However, I will come to that in my conclusion.

The key issue that remains is that we do not have a satisfactory legal regulatory framework within which the education export industry, including those institutions concerned with teaching the English language, can develop. A satisfactory framework would encourage, not inhibit, the development of an internationally competitive industry in Australia. The current proposed legislation results primarily from the Government's desire to be seen to be doing something. It is not good enough to lay all these regulations on all educational institutions alike, that is, on those which are blameless and which have been fully performing.

I do not have time to refer to the September 1990 report-available for nine months now-entitled Report on the Future Operations of the Non-Formal Export Education Industry by Tony Harris, the special adviser to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). I can only say that his findings support the thrust of my remarks and the Opposition's approach to this matter. Let me quote just one part of his report:

Regulation is also expensive to the taxpayer and to the institutions, can relieve overseas students from the obligation to act prudently in the way they deal with institutions, and can cause governments to intervene in the marketplace in order to validate past approval decisions. Regulatory regimes can be used to limit entry to the industry and thus reduce competition, innovation or growth.

That was the thrust of that report nine months ago and it was even commissioned by the Government. As a result, the Opposition was still to be convinced-until events that have happened in the last 24 hours-to even see this legislation remain permanently on the statute book.

I move quickly on to refer to Australia's competitiveness internationally. What is the situation in the United Kingdom, in the United States, in Canada or in any of the countries that are receiving overseas students? They do not have these regulations. They do not have such a Bill as we are debating here tonight. Why should we in Australia put our education providers at a disadvantage internationally?

I come now to refer to the three Opposition amendments. First of all, we are not happy about the requirement that there be insurance taken out, according to the definitions that the Government has imposed. In due course at the committee stage, we will move an amendment to that part which will, nevertheless, be satisfactory to ensure that the moneys are not at risk.

Secondly, we believe that quarterly auditing of accounts in these institutions-unheard of in other companies-is excessive. We will move to have annual audits unless there is reasonable cause to call for a shorter period for regular auditing. Finally-and this is the Opposition's main contention-we seek to place in the legislation a sunset clause so that the whole legislation collapses on the first day of January 1994, unless it has been repealed before that time. That is the critical matter, as far as the Opposition is concerned.

Even with all of the amendments that we have been able to gain in this legislation, we do not want to see this as anything other than as a transition out of the mess that the Government has brought upon itself. We do not want to put any permanent disadvantage upon the Australian education providers with regard to overseas students. In the committee stage we will seek to introduce a sunset clause which will mean that the legislation ceases to have effect from that date.

In my final remarks on this Bill I wish to refer to the important Industry Commission report that was published only two days ago. One would have to ask whether the Government's right hand knows what the left hand is doing. We have the Minister for Employment, Education and Training saying that this is urgent education export legislation which must be passed and the former Treasurer, former Deputy Prime Minister Keating, has commissioned the Industry Commission to look at education exports. This report has come down only two days ago, on 4 June, and it has not been taken into consideration by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training as having any relevance to this legislation, which is to govern all education exports.

The critical thing is that the industry report is entirely supportive of the thrust of the Opposition's approach to this matter and is directly critical of the Government. This has been a most important report in a critical week and it has come two days before this Senate debate. I point out to the Senate a couple of the references that it makes. On page 2 in the overview in this report there is a blast at the Government and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. It states:

Government regulation of this industry, since its beginnings in 1986, has been characterised by sudden shifts in policy direction, the effects of which have been made more serious by the way in which decisions were reached and subsequently communicated to those directly affected . . . when the brakes were put on, the policy stance changed abruptly from one which was fairly relaxed to one which some say is now too strict and poorly targeted.
The Government's reaction to the problems in the industry-
the $50m it had to refund to students in China alone-

was to attempt to tighten up immigration rules, and to place greater controls on educational institutions. Some say that too many changes were introduced, and that there was insufficient consultation.

There is also a blast on page 3 at the Government's requirement in the first place for prepayment of fees. There is also a direct criticism on page 4 of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and its conduct. The most important part of the report is on page 5, where it states:

The registration and accreditation requirements imposed on institutions are placing unnecessary burdens on the better institutions, both formal and non-formal, in an attempt to solve problems among a few providers in the non-formal sector.
It also says that these institutions have not been properly consulted. It then refers directly to the Bill that is before us. It says:

. . . there is reason to doubt that quality can be, or indeed, should be, regulated in this way. Regulating inputs can never guarantee output quality, and it is a costly process. It may also constrain innovative course design and act as a barrier to competition. Most importantly, it appears to overseas students that accreditation has given an institution a `stamp of approval' from the Commonwealth Government.

So I could go on. Toward the end of the report from the Industry Commission there is direct support for Opposition policy which would make Australian students able to gain the benefits that the overseas students have.

I note that on the day this report came out, just two days ago, the Australian Financial Review carried an editorial with the headline `IC lashes Govt on export policy'. It has a very quizzical cartoon of Mr Dawkins, the Minister, who has been stymied by this report. The Canberra Times carried a report entitled `Education for export: draft report calls for reforms'. Again, it is scathing of the Government, scathing of the way in which the Government is proceeding in this matter. The Australian carried a similar report, saying that it restricted the growth of worthy providers in a new industry.

I do not have time to refer to the statement made by my colleague Dr Kemp, the Opposition education spokesman in the House of Representatives, but he made it entirely clear that he welcomed the Industry Commission report on behalf of the Opposition and that it directly confirmed the stance that we were taking in this legislation. Not so Minister Bolkus in this chamber when two days ago, in answer to a question from Senator Tierney, he said that everything was on track and the Government was proceeding as usual.

We now come to the past 24 hours, when the Government completely collapsed regarding this legislation. The Government agreed to all of the Opposition amendments: agreed to the sunset clause; agreed to taking out the onerous restrictions on insurance and on quarterly accounting. I can only say that the Government is at last having a sensible day in which it has seen the merit of the argument and that it does not want to live with this legislation one day longer than is necessary, given the weight of argument that has been put by this Senate in committee, by the Opposition in the Parliament, by the industry itself and, indeed, by the Industry Commission report.

In the past 24 hours Mr Dawkins has given a direct assurance that all of the Opposition amendments that remain will be directly accepted by the Government. I regard this complete remaking of this legislation as a victory for maintaining a careful legislative process in this Parliament, for maintaining the Senate committee system. I regard this outcome as a victory for the Senate, a victory for the Senate committee system and, by the way, a victory for the Opposition. Most importantly-I see Senator Tate smiling with approval that so many Australians have benefited from my remarks-it is of considerable benefit to the education institutions themselves and to the whole of this important industry that it is not only serving Australia well but also serving overseas students from many countries who come to gain qualifications in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Education Services (Export Regulation) Bill. The purpose of this Bill is to establish a register of those institutions and individuals approved to provide educational services for overseas students and to require those providing courses to comply with a number of conditions. The coalition initially opposed this Bill in the House of Representatives for a number of reasons. Regulations may be costly and commercially impracticable. The requirement for trust accounts, audited quarterly returns and insurance was excessive and draconian. The right of institutions to withdraw money from the trust accounts was deemed by future regulations and might override contracts between the institutions and the students. In addition, it might not provide sufficient protection for student funds, depending on the signatory arrangements. It was discriminatory in that it conferred on overseas students, but not on Australian students, an entitlement to refunds if they withdrew for any reason from their course. In providing for refunds, it failed to account adequately for the types of parties who entered into contracts with institutions. The Bill contained a major drafting error, as a result of which it applied to every provider of educational services, irrespective of whether they provided courses to overseas students.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's six amendments met some of the Opposition's objections to the original Bill, but they did not address our concerns about the commercial impracticability and equity of the proposed legislation. There still persists the oppressive nature of the provisions related to financial arrangements. There still persists inequity between the Australian students and overseas students concerning the refund of fees. There does not appear to be any proposal at the present time to address the inequity with respect to refunds for overseas and Australian students. The Bill accords more protection to overseas students than has ever been accorded to those in Australia.
