The key issue remains the need to ensure that there is a satisfactory legal regulatory framework within which the educational export industry, including the teaching of English language, can develop. We need to encourage, not inhibit, a competitive education industry.

This point of view was supported by the Report on the Future Operations of the Non-formal Export Education Industry by Tony Harris, which the Government received in September 1990. The report noted that there was a general view in the private and public sectors of the industry that existing government policies were damaging the international competitiveness of Australian institutions and that the additional cost burdens imposed by this legislation would make the problem worse.

The report made a comparison with the United Kingdom, where there is no specific regulation of the providers of educational services to overseas students. The industry there is governed by the general laws relating to companies and commercial practice. The existing private sector providers are also unhappy with the legislation and, in particular, with the competitive advantage that will be given to public sector institutions through the exemption of the latter from the financial arrangement provisions.

For example, the main outstanding concerns of the Association of Recognised ELICOS Centres at this stage were the auditing and reporting requirements on the special accounts; the cash flow problems that are likely to be caused to providers by the regime of regulation of withdrawals; the unequal protection provided to overseas students as against Australian students; and the absence of any apparent Commonwealth intention to move to deregulate the education environment according to the recommendations of the Harris report. Additionally, the Association does not believe that the rolling back provisions of the Government amendments address its concerns with the Bill, as the Bill will apply where there is no State or Territory legislation.

Because of all these concerns, the Bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, which reported to the Senate in May. As a result of its deliberations, 13 amendments will be moved to the Bill in the committee stage. The key amendments include changes to provisions for trust accounts and insurance arrangements.

The original Bill highlighted trust accounts, but as defined in the Bill they were not true trust accounts. The Committee was advised that only one signature-that is, the signature of the provider-was required. The provider could still take the money and run, so the Bill which was intended to protect student funds was not achieving that in the provision for trust accounts.

The first major amendment of the Standing Committee changed the trust account to a special account which is defined as a separate account for holding funds in trust. However, it is not known at present what amendments might be made to the provisions governing withdrawals from the special accounts. The Opposition is still gravely concerned about these withdrawal provisions. We are concerned about whether there will be adequate protection for student funds in the future regulations.

The other main amendment proposed to include bond arrangements as an alternative to insurance. This is still a matter of major concern. The Department of Employment, Education and Training was unable to provide adequate advice to the Senate Standing Committee on the likely cost of insurance or bond arrangements to providers, particularly those not attached to any association. The expense could be onerous on companies trying to establish themselves initially in the industry. Some providers are unsure whether they will be able to find an insurer. The risk factor is very likely to prevent new classes of providers, in particular, from obtaining insurance coverage.

The Opposition proposed two further recommendations to the Senate Standing Committee. The Committee rejected these recommendations, and the Opposition will be moving them as separate amendments during the committee stage. One of these amendments relates to the requirement for quarterly returns. The Opposition will be seeking to change the requirement for quarterly returns to an annual report.

The Opposition will move a further amendment to clause 8 (4) so that, if there is a concern about a particular provider following an examination of annual reports by the Minister, he may then obtain further information about the return. This clause will also allow the Minister to obtain information about returns more frequently if it is thought to be necessary. The other amendment is for a sunset clause in line with the recommendations of the Harris report. The Opposition will be introducing an amendment to the Act to cease operation on 1 January 1994. The reason for doing this will be outlined later when I move the amendment in the committee stage of this Bill.

The more I read this Bill and the more I deliberated on what happened in the Committee, the more I became convinced that the Bill should be withdrawn. But, if the amendments that we have moved are accepted, the Opposition is prepared to support the amended legislation. What we have before us is a piece of legislation which has passed through the House of Representatives and is in its initial stage in the Senate but which is hasty and ill-conceived. It is a short Bill; it is not very complicated or complex. It has 17 clauses on roughly eight pages. Yet the Government had to make six amendments to five of the clauses and had to introduce a new clause before the Bill came into the Senate.

When the Bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, 13 more amendments were proposed to eight clauses. On top of this, the Opposition will be moving nine amendments, and there are likely to be other amendments coming forward as well. Even if these amendments are passed today, there are still serious problems with this Bill.

Because of the tardiness and the inadequacy of the advice from the Department, there are still unanswered questions on key aspects of this Bill. There are still unanswered questions relating to the operation of special accounts and the protection of student funds. There are still unanswered questions relating to the cost of insurance or bond arrangements. The Bill also violates one of the more important rights in law. In some of its provisions, there is a reversal of onus of proof by assuming the parties to be guilty until proved innocent.

This is not a Bill of which the Government can be proud. Even with all our bandaids, which have patched up the Bill into some sort of respectability, there are still many unsolved problems. In light of the Industry Commission report on the export of education services, the Bill should be revised severely. The Government should carefully draft a new Bill for the education export industry based on the findings of its own Industry Commission report.

We have the amazing situation where, at the same time as this legislation was in the Senate, the Government's Industry Commission was inquiring into the whole education export industry and was not due to finalise its report until the end of July. It is perhaps typical of this Labor Government that two Ministers and two government departments should be moving in exactly opposite directions, the ex-Treasurer Mr Keating and the Department of the Treasury moving to deregulate institutions and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) imposing more and more regulations on higher education and other educational services. One Minister moves to rush through a hastily drafted Bill on the export of education services, and the Treasurer gives a reference to his Industry Commission to inquire into the whole matter and make a final report by the end of July.

The Industry Commission released a draft report two days ago, and it represents a significant victory for the export of education industry. The Opposition welcomes the report because it supports our concern about the Government's handling of educational exports. Government regulation, which has grown at an enormous pace during the past few years, is affected by sudden shifts in policy direction, the effects of which have been made more serious by the way in which decisions have been reached and subsequently communicated to those directly affected in Australia and overseas.

Some of the main findings of the draft report of the Industry Commission are as follows. Government actions are impeding the efficient development of the export of education. An industry which is now worth up to $1.2 billion a year in exports has suffered at the hand of an over-zealous Government. Government policies have encouraged abuse by students and institutions in the educational sector and restricted the growth of worthy providers in the industry.

The report of the Industry Commission agrees with our worries that a rigid regulation of higher education is limiting Australia's capacity to compete in the world market of educational services. It is therefore necessary to make significant amendments to this Bill to protect the long term viability of this important education export industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Education Services (Export Regulation) Bill was hastily conceived, and indeed conceived in a particularly disastrous situation in the Australian industry. The format in which the Bill came to the Senate had already been rejected by the Opposition in the lower House, which is not surprising. What has now reached us in this chamber should be examined very closely-certainly by overseas students for whom we presume it was devised. I feel that it is necessary to warn overseas students that this legislation does not guarantee their education or their financial investment, nor does it improve the quality of the service in the national education sector. It should be emphasised that it does not guarantee an improvement in the quality of the education service which is to be delivered.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has admitted that a lack of effective regulation has caused many of the problems which have occurred in this area. Australia at the moment has an appalling reputation in the export of education. There are continuing problems which include false advertising, poor quality teaching and support, as well as fraud, theft, sexual abuse, non-attendance, overstays, collapses and non-payment of refunds. Those experiences, combined with a lack of government regulation, erratic changes in policy and exorbitant costs, have created a deserved reputation of exploitation rather than goodwill. Australia is already losing its tiny share-less than 5 per cent-of the world market for overseas students.

It was of particular concern to me during the legislation committee hearings to hear from expert witnesses that we are losing our tiny share of the world market for overseas students, but that fact was challenged. One witness was embarrassed by the grilling he received from one of our committee members to such an extent that extra information needed to be provided after the committee hearing. I think that it was particularly embarrassing that the facts which were presented to our committee were not welcomed by some of the committee members. In fact, it was almost a case of one committee member being unwilling to hear those facts. That is an embarrassment that we as a country have to carry-the fact that our reputation is such that people are walking away, voting with their feet, and are certainly not taking advantage of our education provision. We have become uncompetitive. We are a country with one of the most stringent, expensive and complicated sets of entry and admission requirements in the world, but when we have the opportunity to deliver our education provision we do not have the reputation of being able to provide it in an equitable and satisfactory manner.

In its publication Second Opinion, a recent report by the Overseas Students, Graduates and Nurses Association of Australia (OSGNAA) claims that Australia has become one of the three most expensive countries offering courses overseas. It has been suggested that the Government's `full fees' are inflated by some providers by up to 200 per cent. According to OSGNAA, the basic fee for an overseas student has gone from $1500 per year in 1979 to over $10,000 today, with some courses demanding an incredible $25,000 a year. There are very few scholarships for students from Third World countries, so Australian education is becoming increasingly elitist.

The coalition opposed this Bill in the lower House, but the Australian Democrats agree with students and providers that some Federal regulation is better than none. As has been described already, an attempt at bandaiding was made through the committee. The negotiations continued, with attempts at amendments past that time. The Australian Democrats requested initially that this Bill be referred to a committee in the hope that that would at least bring some sense to it in anticipation that the Government already had a considerable number of its own amendments. We were insistent that this matter go to a committee mainly because of complaints about the lack of consultation in the formulation of this legislation, and also the threat of duplication of State and industry regulation that already existed.

The Government's amendments and those proposed by the Senate committee tackled some of the problems that occurred in the original Bill, but this legislation still fails to achieve its stated aims, and is still too limited in scope. The current Bill represented an important opportunity to begin to get things right. But it was unfortunate that this legislation was drafted so quickly. It is amazing that since its drafting process, we have had a lot more time for the consultation that should have occurred initially to occur now. It seems that its urgency has been somewhat dissipated by other events, or perhaps it is because of the continued embarrassment of having such a Bill before us that it has been delayed so often.

That delay is particularly curious, given that the Federal Government's Industry Commission was asked in December 1990 to report on this whole area by the end of July. It was found to be a massive undertaking. What we have so far is a draft report which was received on 4 June, and the final report is not likely to reach us until August. Even so, I would suggest that that has not been made with full consultation, and the Industry Commission itself has found the task considerable. We had a hastily prepared Bill, and a hiatus between preparation and presentation here. Also we have had a coincidental report-indeed it is an amazing coincidence-prepared by another body. That other body, the Industry Commission, has rightly found a mishmash caused by the lack of regulation in this area. The Industry Commission's draft report was presented, as I said, on 4 June. The examination brought to the matter by the Australian Democrats in the time available has led us to regret the fact that the draft recommendations tend towards favouring less regulation rather than more regulation, which we believe is required.

The Commission has a narrow and limited view of the sector in terms of economic benefits to Australia, and the issue of possible displacement of Australian students seems to be of prime concern to the Commission. Traditionally-a tradition with which the Democrats identify-the provision of education to overseas students has involved cultural and educational exchange. But we see here emphasis on the economic benefits coming to Australia-an emphasis that I believe is undue and quite rude, which I think is the most suitable word to use in this context. It is rude to those from whom we ourselves can derive some cultural benefits, and it is rude to those who may be providing the opportunity for cultural and educational interchange.

It is not necessarily true that the money and the benefits to Australia should be paramount, but that is what we see as a flavour not only of this legislation but also of the Industry Commission's draft report. We believe that the goodwill and economic benefits to less well developed countries in the region should be taken into account. It is regrettable-actually, it is appalling-that on page 99 the Industry Commission's draft report states:
the objectives of ensuring the quality of courses, the safety of the students' investment and the financial viability of the institutions they attend are ``impossible to satisfy'' . . .

That is exactly what has been said in the draft report-the quality of the courses is impossible to satisfy. I would have thought that quality would have been paramount in our consideration of what we sell overseas. This is an export industry. We are being told by one of the bodies associated with surveying this that such a consideration is impossible to satisfy.

With that in mind, I am very pleased that this legislation is going through this place before we get a chance to consider the final report. That is an irony. In many cases it is nonsense that we have to consider the legislation while another government body is reviewing the area, but here I am saying that it is a relief that it is happening before those recommendations come down because if that is the style of the recommendations-that it is impossible to satisfy the consideration of quality-I would not be endorsing the Commission's report.

Two of the Commission's recommendations which the Democrats happily support, however, are for greater consultation about changes in policy and better information to students. I would have thought that that would be common sense anyway, so I quite happily support it. However, it is a nonsense for the Commission to suggest that information with minimal regulation replaces the need to ensure the quality of Australia's educational services. In a media release of November 1990, the Minister stated that it would `provide Australia's multi-million dollar export education industry with a solid base for its future operation'. According to that press release, Mr Dawkins `indicated that there was an urgency in preparing legislation to protect students and the integrity of the industry'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said it was urgent a year ago.

—That is quite right. The irony that I see there is that the aims of Mr Dawkins at that time seem at odds with the sorts of recommendations that the Industry Commission seems to think are not possible.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has claimed that the current Bill does two things to lift standards and to protect students. In the Sydney Morning Herald dated 17 April 1991, Mr Dawkins-during a rescue mission to China-is quoted as saying:
The legislation will require institutions to gain Commonwealth registration before recruiting overseas and will make it mandatory for fees to be placed in trust funds.

On the first point, Mr Dawkins stated in his second reading speech that a formal register of institutions and courses means that `students will only be granted a visa for travel to Australia for study purposes if they are accepted for registered courses in registered institutions'. However, this new register merely formalises or replaces the current record kept by his Department. Registration, in that sense, simply means re-listing all State approved institutions and courses. It is, therefore, based on the current diverse and flawed systems of accreditation and monitoring.

There is evidence, including submissions to the Senate committee, that the States have continued to admit unfit and shady operators. This is the sort of thing that this legislation was intended to prevent but, from what I have just said, it undoubtedly does not have the capacity to do so. The States have also failed to monitor the provision of the approved courses, staff and facilities and to investigate documented complaints about several colleges, many of which have collapsed.

Secondly, according to the Minister, the current Bill requires all providers to maintain trust accounts for overseas students' funds and to guarantee refunds from those accounts. However, contrary to the Minister's assurances, money advanced by students will not be held in trust accounts. Yet, that is what the Minister said in a press release when he went to China to explain what was going on. I suggest that the very mention of that word `trust' while that trip was going on is misleading and gives a false impression of what will eventually occur under this legislation. What will eventually occur under this legislation is not as the Minister described. This is the sort of misleading information which adds to, and is the very basic reason for, Australia's loss of reputation in this area. That is what this is all about.

The Democrats reject the use of the term `trust' because its use in this regard is false and misleading. We protest at its use by the Minister in trying to reassure our overseas neighbours. Its incorrect use was acknowledged by the Attorney-General's Department in a letter to the Department of Employment, Education and Training, dated 16 November 1990. The Senate committee has proposed that the term be changed to `a special account'. The Industry Commission itself also notes that the trust account proposed in the current Bill does not involve the trustee-agent relationship in law, so it really should never be referred to again as a `trust account'.
Page 118 of the draft report of the Industry Commission states:
the funds accounted for still belong to the institution, and would be lost to the student in the event of a collapse.
It also says:
Thus protection relies on the legal requirement that institutions enter into insurance or other arrangements satisfactory to the Government to protect students' funds.
Insurance is difficult to obtain and where available, expensive.

I stress the term `where available' because that was something that many witnesses who appeared before the committee had not been able to resolve. I wonder where it is available. The report also suggests that other arrangements, whatever they might be, are also likely to be complex and expensive. I object to the cavalier manner in which the committee was advised that insurance or other arrangements would be able to be obtained. Those who operate in the industry have not found such to be the case. In fact, so far, no insurer has been keen to offer insurance of any description to any of the colleges offering English language intensive courses for overseas students.

If the Government were serious about protecting students' funds, it would have considered the suggestion of a central fidelity fund as a standard, relatively straightforward safety net found in many trades and professions. Instead, this was wafted off into an ill-defined `other arrangements' suggestion. Students who appeared before the Senate committee suggested that the establishment of a contingency fund could be a security against default. Solicitors, real estate agents, builders and many other industry and professional groups have similar safeguards, but we were left without guidance from this legislation.

Students have also suggested that the interest on the moneys held in special accounts could go into a fund to guarantee refunds and perhaps provide loans to students if necessary. Witnesses made many valuable suggestions at our committee hearings but it was difficult to translate some of those valuable suggestions into legislation-firstly, because the legislation itself was clumsy and, secondly, because the preparers of the legislation were not keen to tamper with what they saw as a valuable document. I think what has been said already illustrates that the value of this document was really only as a very shaky foundation for an overwhelming number of suggested amendments which will come from the committee itself, from the coalition, from the Democrats and some of which should have come from the Government before that. Quite frankly, I am unsure as to what we will end up with because the hotchpotch of amendments and original legislation is really quite difficult to comprehend.

The Attorney-General's Department in a letter to the Department dated 16 November 1990 suggests that the regulations could make provision for the disposition of interest. Interest seemed to be a matter of some contention to members of the committee, students and the providers. The issue of interest, how it was to be administered and the fiduciary requirements of the providers were matters of some concern. Under this current set-up, providers would be subject to three sets of fiduciary requirements-Federal, State and industry. It is most confusing-even the legal advisers seemed confused-and I wonder whether it will be clear to providers as to what their actual obligations are and whether it will be clear to students as to what their own rights and obligations should be.

Surely that is a central point: somebody undertaking study in an overseas country and paying a considerable amount of money to do so should be able to determine, fairly easily and in simple straightforward language, what his or her rights and obligations are under the various circumstances which could arise while studying overseas. That is not the case with this legislation.

The maintenance of separate accounts, provision for quarterly audits, and the guarantee and payment of refunds are limited to private providers and do not necessarily apply to government institutions which are exempted from many other things. An exemption list, which comprises all government-funded schools and tertiary institutions-a total of 460- runs to 13 pages in a schedule to the draft regulations. It is an absurdity in legislation which applies only to the export education program. It cannot be paralleled in other legislation.

Private providers, including non-profit organisations, have complained about being targeted by this legislation. It seems ludicrous that government-funded institutions are not examined for quality, equity or reliability. I do not want to suggest that government organisations may collapse, go broke and keep students' money, but I suggest that there may be some doubt about the capacity of all 460 institutions to deliver a quality product, a product worthy of export.

The private providers argue that the costs involved place them at a significant commercial disadvantage compared with public institutions. Without agreeing or disagreeing with that claim, one can understand why it is made. While similar financial backup may not be necessary, there is evidence that many public institutions do require greater regulation and monitoring. Criticisms about false marketing, poor quality teaching and courses, and a lack of facilities and support have been levelled at mainstream universities and technical and further education colleges as well as at private colleges.

It should be noted that in this legislation `refund' refers only to tuition fees. Up to 50 per cent of forward paid moneys, including compulsory prepayment of accommodation and a living allowance, make up a sort of `bring your own' Austudy at substandard rates. This sort of thing really must be questioned.

The recent closure of Buckland College in Western Australia was the latest in a line of 17 collapses in less than a year-15 apparently within five months. The Buckland collapse sent nervous colleges scrambling to accommodate the students who came from that place. This Bill does not include any provision for transfer to a similar course without additional fees. That would be a good option if refunds were unavailable.

Australia could have become a well-respected learning centre in the Asia-Pacific region. Instead, our reputation now is appalling. I cannot see that this legislation, nor the current actions of the Minister, can lead to any ameliorating of that position. A concerted rescue effort requires a properly coordinated national approach. Students and providers support such a concept and the States all agree in principle about the necessary controls-although they have yet to deliver and prove that they agree by taking some action to bring about agreement on a code, method of conduct or provision of this sort.

The Democrats really do not share the glee of Senator Teague at this passage of legislation. With or without amendments, we are not convinced that what is promised or what is necessary can be provided through this legislation. We have attempted to amend it and we have contributed significantly to the plethora of amendments which honourable senators will find on their desks. Nevertheless, we feel it is necessary to ask the Minister to give his assurance that future development of the export education program will be properly coordinated and will be within a national regulatory framework.

We will be suggesting the inclusion of a nationally recognised code of conduct. Our amendments include a code which has the imprimatur of the Australian Education Council-the only body which could be considered to have in mind the interests of all national providers in this area. We have attempted, and we will continue to attempt, through our amendments to include a code of conduct from that body and ask that that be included in the legislation. We ask that this legislation not be considered the final result. We think it is necessary to tackle this issue again because the way in which it has been tackled so far leaves a lot to be desired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly because I am one of the newer members of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training-your Committee, Mr Acting Deputy President. I wish to make a couple of observations because I think it would be remiss of me if I did not. Firstly, I reiterate what my colleagues and Senator Bell have said about this hastily drawn legislation. It seems quite ridiculous to me that the Education Services (Export Regulation) Bill 1990 has been thrown at us in haste. I think there are eight pages to the Bill, yet we had to have 35 amendments in one form or another. I think that says it all. I think that shows us how inept the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) was in pushing the legislation through to us.
—It was a mess.

— As Senator Teague says, it certainly was a mess. The observation that I want to make tonight in the few short moments that I am talking relates to the innovative concept that the Senate has involved itself in by referring Bills to committees. I am a member of three committees-one select committee and two standing committees. This was the first time that a Bill has been referred to a committee of which I have been a member.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point that, warts and all, at least we have had the opportunity to take evidence from people in the industry. I believe that because we had people on the Committee like Senator Bell, an ex-school teacher at the Friend School in Hobart, and you, Mr Acting Deputy President, an ex-Minister for Education in Tasmania, we were able to get views from the industry itself and interpret those views into queries as to what the Government and Mr Dawkins have been trying to do.

I remember very well, for instance, evidence from Mr Fergus Thomson from the National Council of Independent Schools Association. He was very concerned about the over-regulation involved in the original concept in the Bill and he suggested it would break the industry. That message came as well from Jack Evans, a former Democrat senator from Western Australia. So I am giving the system a pat on the back because I believe that the system of referring selected Bills to committees has allowed this Parliament to involve people in decisions that have been made by the Parliament. That is something that we should remember.

This is probably the biggest innovation that has occurred in this place for many, many years. It has certainly caused complications. As Chairman of the Committee, you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, that we have had many meetings. There has been to-ing and fro-ing to the Minister on many occasions but I am pleased that, in the end, Mr Dawkins has seen common sense and has accepted not only the concerns of the Democrats but also, in the final analysis, our amendments.

In closing, I would like to compliment all the members of the Committee. I am looking forward to involving myself in committee work next week on a different subject. I certainly compliment the Deputy Chairman of the Committee and my colleague Senator Tierney, a new senator, for the involvement and work that he has put into this particular Bill. His former role and position in education has been an asset, as has Senator Bell's former expertise in education. For a couple of bushrangers like Senator Crane and me, it has certainly been an education to see how the system works and to put across our point of view.
All in all, I think that common sense has prevailed. I hope that the Democrats support our amendments and that this Bill passes without too much more fuss and bother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Education Services (Export Regulation) Bill 1990. There are a few points that I would like to bring out. Most of what has needed to be said has been said. I would just like to emphasise a few points. One must comment on how unsatisfactory and what a mess this Bill was when first it came to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. A couple of months or so ago, when it first came before us, Mr Dawkins was going overseas and he put a lot of emphasis on the importance of it at that particular time. I believe he was just looking for a comfort zone when he went over there so that he could say that he was doing something about it. Of course, we were presented with what can only be described as a mess.

SPEECH.PARA: All of the witnesses who came before us pointed out that the effects of this Bill were going to be onerous on the industry. They pointed out that it did not do the job for the students or the industry. I want to make particular comment on a couple of the clauses in the Bill. Clause 6 deals with trust accounts. I asked all witnesses what they thought that clause meant and none of them knew what it meant. Each one of them tried to provide an interpretation of what it meant and each interpretation was fundamentally different. Of course, that is one of the clauses that has been amended.

Another thing which I find very distasteful about this particular piece of legislation is that it discriminates against Australian students. My colleague Senator Teague has covered that point, so I shall not say any more about it.

I find clause 8 very distasteful. We on this side of the chamber have put forward a number of amendments to this clause. What I found distasteful about this particular clause was that it assumed that those people who had to report on their financial status were guilty and that they had to prove their innocence. We have set about to correct that situation and I am pleased to say that the Government has accepted the amendments that we have put forward. I will deal with that matter in a little more detail in a minute.

I also want to make brief reference to the Industry Commission report. I find it absolutely incredible-in fact it is amazing-that this Bill is being debated in this place now, I think two days after that report came out. It seems logical to me, by any fair judgment, that that report should have and could have been the basis for putting this legislation together. The situation would have been far more satisfactory if we had waited a little bit longer and taken into account the wisdom from the Industry Commission's report and incorporated in the legislation the line that it suggested should have been taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think the Government knew it was coming this week. One part of the Government didn't know what the other part was doing.

—That was obvious. The Government did not know what was going on with its own Industry Commission report. But then, I guess one can make an excuse for Mr Dawkins because while this has been going on, he has been very busy undermining the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). What has he produced? He has produced a discredited Treasurer who now sits on the back bench. I am quite certain that he is more interested in the power play going on within the Australian Labor Party than he is with getting this Bill right. One can only describe this Bill as a mickey mouse Bill because the whole area of education is really a State responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: As pointed out by my colleague, there are 35 amendments to an 8-page Bill containing 18 clauses. There are six amendments from the Government, 13 from the Committee, eight from the Opposition and eight, as I understand it, from the Australian Democrats. So in fact, the product that was first brought before us cannot be recognised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you call it a product?

—In reply to Senator Bell, no we cannot, but I cannot think of a better word at this stage. I deal now with the amendments that I will be moving in the committee stage. In clause 8, we are changing the onus of proof from the provider. We are changing clauses in the Bill to create a situation which fits with standard accounting provisions by making the specified time at the conclusion of each financial year instead of at each quarter.

SPEECH.PARA: We are also amending the Bill so that, if the Minister for Employment, Education and Training forms a reasonable belief that a registered provider may have failed to comply with the requirements of clause 8 (2)-and those are the areas that I talked about-failed to comply with the requirements of clause 6, or provided an annual return which contains misleading or deceptive information, he may then act to seek information rather than having the reverse. This puts the checks and balances into the Bill, but it lessens its onerous impact on the industry.

At the end of the day when we look at this export industry-and it is an export industry-we can see that we require an industry based on self-discipline but with the checks and balances that are needed to protect it and look after the interests of students, not only overseas students but also Australian students, and allows the industry to develop and grow. I am quite confident that over the years it will grow and prosper and become stronger.

The last point I want to touch on-although I will not be moving the amendment myself-is the agreement by the Government to have this Act repealed no later than 1 January 1994. That also is a very important step. It is one area relative to this Bill where I can compliment Minister Dawkins for at least coming to grips with one aspect of our concerns.

I wind up my remarks by endorsing the comments of my colleague Senator Calvert. I believe that the committee system in this case, with all committee members, has worked well. It has been my first experience of sitting down and going through a Bill in detail. I want to add my compliments to all the people who sat on the committee because they did produce a lot of satisfactory work. I also compliment the people who came before us and gave evidence because they were very constructive in what they did. My final comment is that, even though I acknowledge the last clause, which the Government has agreed to, this Bill certainly does no credit whatsoever to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am honoured to participate in this debate and am glad that it has been possible. I mention at the outset that, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I believe that the process we went through as a committee was a very productive one. Obviously, what was moved and amended in the Committee and the consensus we reached was not the total picture. There has to be a period in which the shadow Minister in the other House and the Minister discuss the issues, and I guess at the end of the day there is always some sort of political agreement reached which is appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: We have got out of this process the best possible Bill we can. I do not think it is possible to cover all the areas of concern. For example, how can we legislate adequately for quality? We can move to push the system towards the creation and the retention of quality, but we cannot legislate for it. The best that can be done is to set out to protect Australia's reputation overseas in terms of the type of service that is being offered to the students and the type of institutions which provide that service, and to ensure that the problems that exposed themselves over the last few years are, if not abolished, at least contained as much as any government working in the Federal system can contain them.

We know that within the system there have been dishonest providers of services. In other words, in some cases they have told blatant lies about the sort of service they were going to offer overseas students. We know that in some cases the students themselves have not been bona fide students; they have simply used the system to get into Australia and then deliberately overstayed and become de facto residents of Australia through that process. We know that on some occasions there have been inadequate and incompetently run institutions-institutions which may not have had the financial expertise, let alone anything else, to ensure their continued existence.

Obviously, this will happen in any industry which is new and in a position of rapid growth, as this industry is. I indicate at the outset some statistics which clearly point out that this is an industry in which there has been rapid growth. For example, by 1988 there were 25,000 outstanding applications for English language intensive courses for overseas students courses alone. That is, 25,000 students from overseas had indicated that they wanted to get into a course for which there was no room at that time. We have something like 70,000 overseas students in this country. About 44,000 are straight fee paying.

In 1986, the gross revenues or receipts from this industry were something like $10m. Four years later that figure grew to $636m-and that was only for the first nine months of last year. There were only about 250 students in informal studies in public institutions in 1986. That number had grown to 21,000 by the end of last year. Similarly, in short non-formal courses, the numbers have grown from 2,000 in 1986 to 23,000 at the end of last year, an enormous growth in that industry.

It might be worth noting at this stage that the sort of people who talk about improving Australia's balance of payments, those who talk about rejuvenating our manufacturing industries and those who talk about improving and downstreaming our primary industry processes and industries, have overlooked this area. It has not been a sexy subject. It is only when there is trouble in the initial stages of growth that the press, for example, decides that there is something interesting in this area. Once again, I would like to give members of the press in this place a good kick in the backside. They seem to be so intent on covering the presidential politics of both chambers and this institution and covering the hard economic growth areas that they have totally overlooked an industry which is now worth to us over $600m per annum and is still growing. The fact that that has hardly rated a mention in the columns of people such as Paul Kelly, Michelle Grattan and the other leaders of the Press Gallery in this place indicates quite clearly that sometimes their own areas of focus are totally out of touch with what is really going on in the big wide world outside Canberra.

I just make that point in passing, but I am going to make it over and over until the Press Gallery in this place starts to realise it, that it does have an obligation to the Australian community to cover more than just the in-fights, the slanging matches and the presidential campaigns that go on in this place and the hard, dry economic rationalist viewpoints that seem to prevail in the bureaucracy. Other things are going on and members of the press ought to be reporting them. If they did, they would actually find a willing readership and a willing audience. People would say, `Yes, something is going on in this country which is not always related to the activities of government'. The Government is not responsible for the boom that has occurred in this area, but at least it has tried to utilise that boom and has in this case tried to overcome some of the problems that occur as a result of a booming industry just getting off the ground.

Obviously, if we look at the question I just raised by implication-why the Government had to act now and what its motives really are in bringing down this Bill-it is fair to say that Minister Dawkins has tried not to bog this newly developing industry down in regulation and red tape. That is not easy because we are dealing with private and public institutions; six State governments, two Territory governments and a Federal government; and semi-autonomous institutions such as the universities. It is a very wide area for a government to legislate in. It would be very easy for a government to move in and with a very heavy hand say, `This is what will occur' to try to survive the challenges that some of the State governments and maybe some institutions may take against our constitutional right to do that. It would be very easy for the Government to say, `This is what will happen', and to regulate every part of this industry in order to ensure that it had a tight system.

I do not think we can do that in an era in which we are all learning. We are all learning what it is like to be a country that is offering education services to foreigners. It is a boom industry with such potential. It is an area in which there are certain qualitative decisions to be made, difficult qualitative decisions about the quality of education and the way that industry is sold overseas, and no government will be able to put it all in one box and say, `There is the Bill, there are the regulations that will in fact make this system work perfectly'. It will not work perfectly, because there are always humans involved in this area. There are people who want to make a fast buck because they see it as a developing area. There are students who are not bona fide students, who simply want to come to live in Australia and they do not care how they do it. If they have to breach the immigration regulations by coming in as a student and then simply overstaying, then they will do it. There are people who are simply not very good teachers, who set up an institution, a college, or a service provision arrangement that is not up to scratch.

We cannot legislate to ensure that all those people are first class teachers or first class providers of education services. But what we can do, and this is the important point of this Bill, is to say, `If you pay your money, that money will not be stolen from you as a student. If you enrol, the institution will be there when you arrive in Australia. If you ask for qualifications at the completion of a course, you will get those qualifications and they will be worth something. If you ask for a minimum level of educational standard to prevail in those institutions, then as a student you can demand it and there will be some guarantee you will get it'. Basically the Bill does that.

I agree that the report of the Industry Commission has looked at this legislation, at what the Government is doing, and at the whole situation. It has made criticisms, and that is to be expected, first of all, because the bias or bent of the Industry Commission is primarily an economic one, and that is appropriate. We do need bodies which say, when looking at things primarily from an economic or fiscal viewpoint, `This is what ought to be done'. But they are not educationists, not people who ask, `What is the final product? What do you really want out of the system that has been established throughout Australia?'.

So I do take on board the Industry Commission report. I think it has a number of good suggestions and it is an addition to the debate. But it is not the answer to what must be done. In concluding my speech, I must say that I was very impressed indeed at the way, first of all, the Committee worked. I think there was a genuine attempt on the part of every member of that Committee to try to improve the Bill, to debate the issues within the Committee and then to come up with the solutions, to force the bureaucracy to be more realistic about some of the provisions there. There was the matter that Senator Tierney raised, for example, of what constitutes an appropriate trust account, and Senator Bell also spoke very strongly about that. It is a very important matter. It is simply not good enough to tell someone that their money will be protected in a trust account if it is nothing other than a fancy investment account from which the money can be taken by the service provider at any point in time.

Similarly, the question of whether or not we should have quarterly audits was an interesting one. On the whole, I think the bureaucracy had the view that quarterly audits would be sufficient to stop shonky operators from pulling the money out of the system, winding up their institution and disappearing with the money, leaving the students high and dry. As someone pointed out quite succinctly, if one is a determined crook, quarterly audits will not stop that person, who simply waits until the quarterly audit is brought down and sets it up in such a way that the very next day the money the money can be pulled out and off they go. All of us have had some experience in corporate affairs matters where we have seen that type of thing done all the time. All the corporate affairs watchdogs in the world are never going to be able to get down to tintacks and stop those people if they are determined to be crooks.

What we can do is put in place a regime which at least minimises the possibility of that but which does not provide people with the false confidence that the system is absolutely airtight. I believe that in this case the amendments that will be moved by the Opposition-and with the acceptance of the Government-will do what we want to do, which basically is to have good annual audits but with the appropriate controls being put in the hands of the Minister.

So, that is the first point I want to make about the process, that the Committee itself worked very well. I think the Minister acknowledges that. I am sure that the shadow Minister acknowledged that because, let us face it, at the end of the discussions we had in the Committee and, at the time our suggested amendments were tabled, there were discussions that went on in the other place. Those discussions have basically led to a consensus viewpoint being taken in this place. I think we will get the best possible Bill that we can get out of this place, given that we are all politicians, that there is always the possibility of an Opposition wanting to score points or that a government might like to think it can do its duty by putting up a nice looking Bill and leaving it at that. Putting it another way, between the two extremes, I think we have the best of both worlds.

We do agree on one principle, though, and that is the principle that underlines this Bill, that this is an extremely valuable growth industry for Australia. It is part of the move towards a clever country. The protection of Australia's reputation overseas is absolutely vital. If this Bill does not work, the question of the sunset clause then becomes an important one. That is why the Government is accepting the sunset clause, with all the prescriptions that relate to that. We believe that, if this Bill does not work-and let us face it, the political process is not perfect-then we can review this Bill and the whole industry within a short period of time. I can assure the Senate that the Government of the day, that is, this Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —This government.

—Well, we will have to agree to differ on that one. But this Government does promise to take the review extremely seriously and we can look forward to an even better Bill being introduced. We hope, of course, instead of being worth $636m we will be talking in terms of probably $1.2 billion per annum-we will double it-and that finally the journalists, who should be in the gallery, and a lot of other people in the community who have been looking elsewhere for growth industries will realise that this is not a bad industry to have and that the growth potential here is something that ought to be looked at very closely by the rest of the community. It is something that we can be proud of, because Australia is the clever country, and exporting our education services is something that we can bequeath to future generations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I need to go into too much depth in responding at this stage. I think this Bill has had a fair hearing at the legislative committee. I want to place on record my thanks to all the members of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training for the work that they have done in applying themselves to this Bill. Although we do not necessarily come to an agreement on everything, one must acknowledge the work of the Committee in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: In summing up, probably three or four points can be made. As I say, most of the issues are covered by specific amendments, and to the extent necessary they will be debated at the relevant time. One must acknowledge that, as part of normal debate in this place, we do get allegations of shoddiness in legislation. It is always a reflection on the drafting people and it is one that I find very hard to tolerate. But we must acknowledge that that point has been made consistently.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't blame the drafters for Mr Dawkins.

—One probably cannot blame anyone! There is a conflict of direction from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. On one hand we are told that the legislation is over-regulatory and burdensome. On the other hand we are told by the Australian Democrats that it is not sufficiently interventionist because it does not look after students. In response to both those points, over recent years, in trying to find a mid course, we have had an experience in this sector and any response has to take that experience into account. The legislation provides protection for students and flexibility which allows exemption for the good citizen institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: In seeking to obtain a balance we have had criticisms from two different extremes of the argument. In terms of acknowledging the experience, the Industry Commission has expressed preliminary views about regulation of the system. If I can be intemperate enough, I would suggest that maybe it has not thought through the issues or presented a viable alternative. One has to look at the experience, constitutional structures, State responsibilities for education, including such factors as registration and accreditation, the trend towards accreditation and registration of courses and providers having regard to competency and educational outcomes, and the complexity of the scene that we are addressing and recent experience in it.

Often people feel good by coming up with ideal responses. But one cannot ignore the experience in both constitutional structures, and I say that in response to the report by the Industry Commission. We will encompass any major points of issue in the committee stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the Bill in the Committee of the Whole be an order of the day for a later hour this day.

CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

Mr President: The commencement of the new national companies and securities scheme on the first of January this year marked the completion of the first phase of this Government's program for the reform of corporate regulation in Australia after the excesses of the 1980s.

We now have in place in Australia a single national regulatory structure that provides an effective framework in which the Government can begin the major task of redressing the damage done to our business reputation and the confidence of investors in our markets during the ``Decade of Greed''.

The establishment of the Australian Securities Commission under the new national scheme, and the provision by the Government of substantially increased resources for corporate regulation and enforcement by comparison to that which was provided under the former co-operative scheme, is tangible evidence of this Government's determination to overcome these problems.

Equally as important as the need for the timely and effective enforcement of companies and securities laws, is the need for those laws themselves to clearly establish the standards of behaviour that the community is entitled to expect of its corporate directors and managers, and market participants.

At the time the legislative framework for the new national scheme was being prepared, the Attorney-General foreshadowed publicly that, following the establishment of the new scheme, the second phase of the Government's corporate reform program would commence. This second phase involves the reform of key areas of law that in the 1980s were shown to be deficient.
This Bill, Mr President, marks the first step in this second and most important phase of the reform of corporate regulation.

The major amendments contained in this Bill will bring about the necessary and long overdue reforms to require companies to consolidate their accounts and those of the entities they control, and to strengthen insider trading regulation.
The Bill also includes machinery amendments relating to the clarification and re-inforcement of the legislative framework of the new national scheme.

The key law reforms contained in this Bill will complement the very considerable law enforcement effort of the ASC to raise the level of compliance with the law and bring about proper standards of corporate and market behaviour.
As I have mentioned, this Government is committed to an ongoing program of key law reform. This will involve a major review of the substantive companies and securities laws over the next few years.
Mr President, it is an ambitious program. It must be: for too long important law reform was not undertaken under the former co-operative scheme.

The development of laws which establish proper standards of corporate and market behaviour, that are capable of being enforced effectively, and that will restore the confidence in Australian market for both Australian and foreign investors, is essential to our future economic prosperity.
As part of this process, the Government expects later this year to bring forward two further Bills to amend the Corporations Law.

The next Bill will deal with a number of important matters. In particular it will include proposals to facilitate shorter settlement periods for share transfers. This will enable the Australian Stock Exchange to improve its efficiency and increase the international competitiveness of our sharemarket. Further amendments will include proposals arising from the review of the Australian Company Number requirement, and the clarification of certain aspects of the fundraising provisions.
It is expected that this Bill will be released for public exposure in June this year and will be introduced for passage during the Budget Sittings.

The following Bill, the third in the program for 1991, will contain major reforms in relation to loans to directors and related party transactions, the framework for corporate insolvency, directors duties and the rights of shareholders.

A full process of consultation with business and the community generally, will be undertaken in relation to these proposed reforms. To this end it is envisaged that the third Bill will be released for public exposure during the Budget Sittings.
Having outlined the Government's future program, Mr President, I now turn to the specific reforms set out in this Bill.

There have been widespread abuses of the existing company accounting and reporting requirements under which the true financial position of a group of companies has been able to be disguised by ``off-balance sheet'' reporting. This has enabled the financial statements of the company to be manipulated in such a way as to mislead investors and the market generally regarding the real level of liabilities or performance of a company or the group as a whole.

These abuses have been possible because company reporting requirements apply to companies and their ``subsidiaries''. The definition of `subsidiary' has a rather technical meaning in the Law which does not reach non-corporate entities. Further, group accounts have not been required to be consolidated, with the result that they can be very difficult to analyse.

One of the consequences of these practices has been a significant loss of investor confidence, both amongst Australian and overseas investors, in the reliability of corporate financial information in Australia.

To address these problems, the Bill provides for amendments to require that a company's directors must produce a single profit and loss account and balance sheet for all companies and other incorporated or unincorporated entities controlled by that company. The Bill will include a broad definition of control which focuses on the reality of control rather than technicalities.

In order to reinforce the requirement to comply with accounting standards, and to bring about greater consistency in accounts, a related amendment is to be made to the Corporations Law. Currently, the Law provides that the directors need not ensure that financial statements are made out in accordance with an accounting standard if to do so would fail to give a true and fair view. This has provided the scope for some companies to use some dubious accounting treatments in reliance on the more general, and vaguer, ``true and fair'' test, rather than to comply with a relevant appropriate accounting standard.

Under the amendments, financial statements will have to both comply with the accounting standards and give a true and fair view. In this way the obligations under the Law in relation to accounting standards will be brought into line with the obligations under the Law applicable to the requirements of Schedule 5 of the Corporations Regulations.

Insider trading has become a matter of increasing concern within the securities industry and amongst the wider community, contributing to the deterioration of public confidence in the securities markets more generally.

The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on constitutional and Legal Affair (The Griffiths' Committee) ``fair shares for all: insider trading in Australia'' in November 1989, recommended significant legislative reform and administrative action in relation to the enforcement of the existing insider trading provisions. The Government's response to the report, tabled in Parliament on 11 October 1990, accepted the majority of the Committee's recommendations for legislative amendment, and in December 1990 draft legislation and an accompanying explanatory paper were released for public exposure.
The provisions in this Bill represent the outcome of the Government's consideration of that report in the light of public submissions on the exposure draft.
The key elements of the new provisions are as follows.

The definition of an ``insider'' will encompass corporations and partnerships as well as individuals. There will be no need for the prosecution to establish a connection between the person in possession of inside information and the company to which the information relates. Instead any person, including a tippee, who is in possession of inside information will be prohibited from using it to trade in or subscribe for securities of the company.

A statutory definition of inside information is to be included, based on a ``reasonable person'' test. A person will be prohibited from trading in securities whilst knowingly in possession of information that is not generally available and if it were generally available a reasonable person would expect it to have a material effect on the price or value of securities.

Information will be defined as being generally available where it is disclosed in a manner which would, or would be likely to, bring it to the attention of persons who commonly invest in securities of a kind whose price or value might be affected by the information and where a reasonable period of time for the dissemination of information has elapsed.

The offence will be extended to trading in prescribed interests, such as units of unit trusts, and other relevant securities. The definition of securities will be clarified to ensure that it includes prescribed interests, options and convertible securities.
Monetary penalties will be increased to:-
- in the case of a natural person, $200,000, or 5 years imprisonment or both or
- in the case of a body corporate, $1,000,000.

In addition, a body corporate that issued securities will be able to recover any profit accruing to the insider through dealing in those securities. Further, the ASC may bring an action in the name of, and for the benefit of, the body corporate.

The proposed provisions aim to strengthen the law relating to insider trading while at the same time not lessening the basic protections given to the accused under our criminal law. The provisions seek to ensure that legitimate business activity can continue.

Notwithstanding the abysmal failure of insider trading prosecutions, the onus of proof will remain on the prosecution in respect of all elements of the offence including knowledge that the information is inside information.
However, the operation of these provisions will be monitored to see whether they are effective in preventing insider trading and in restoring investor confidence in the securities markets.
The futures insider trading provisions are also being reviewed with a view to adopting similar provisions to those proposed for securities in this Bill.

Other significant amendments to the Corporations Law are proposed to be made in the Bill. To more effectively administer the unit trust industry and other prescribed interest schemes, the ASC will be given additional powers to regulate compliance with trust deeds by managers and trustees. The Bill proposes an amendment which will treat a breach of a covenant of a trust deed as a contravention of the Law. However, such a contravention will not amount to an offence. This will enable the ASC to investigate non-compliance with the provisions of deeds and to exercise its powers of civil enforcement where it discovers that such conduct has occurred.

A further proposed amendment will facilitate the maintenance of an accurate ASC information base relating to company officers. It will require the retiring directors, where more than half retire or resign at one time, to notify the ASC of that fact. This will overcome the substantial difficulties created for both the ASC and the former officers which presently arise when a company is in effect ``sold'', and the incoming directors do not lodge the appropriate forms as they are required to do under the Law.

In accordance with the decision of the Ministerial Council at its meeting in February 1991, the Bill proposes a statutory moratorium in relation to the requirement for companies to include their Australia Company Number on their business documents and negotiable instruments. This amendment will further minimise any cost or possible confusion for the business community in relation to the A.C.N. requirement. Companies and bodies will not have to comply with this requirement until after 31 December 1991. There is a corresponding proposed amendment in relation to the Australian Registered Body Number.
The Bill also contains proposed amendments to the Corporations Act and the ASC Act to deal with various machinery, jurisdictional and transitional matters.

As the functions of the NCSC have been assumed by the ASC, and the further existence of that body is redundant, the NCSC Act is to be repealed and the NCSC abolished. The Bill provides for the winding up of the NCSC and the disposition of its assets, rights and liabilities, and will deal with related consequential and transitional matters.
Provision is to be made for the preparation of a final report and financial statements, and the vesting of former assets of the NCSC in the ASC or the Commonwealth, as appropriate.

These machinery provisions deal with the legal ownership of NCSC assets and liabilities. They do not affect the joint commitments by the Commonwealth and the States under the Heads of Agreement to share financial responsibility for the liabilities of the NCSC, nor do they affect the obligation of the Commonwealth to account to the States for half the value of NCSC assets calculated in accordance with the Heads of Agreement.
Part 9 of the Corporations Act is to be amended to confer cross-vested jurisdiction under the Corporations Law on the Family Court of Australia and the Family Court of Western Australia.

The amendments will restore to the Family Courts the jurisdiction those courts had in relation to matters arising under companies and securities legislation immediately prior to the commencement of the Corporations Law on 1 January 1991.

Prior to the introduction of the Corporations Law, the Family Courts had jurisdiction to deal with matters under the co-operative companies and securities legislation by virtue of the general scheme for the cross vesting of jurisdiction for Australian courts. However, the Corporations Act excluded the general cross vesting scheme and replaced it with a special regime for the vesting and cross vesting of jurisdiction between the Federal Court and the State and Territory Courts on Corporations Law matters under which all those Courts have full co-ordinate jurisdiction under the Law.

In the present Bill, the approach has been taken to give the Family Courts the same status under the Corporations Law as they had under the general cross-vesting legislation in relation to jurisdiction under the former companies and securities codes. The Family Courts will be subject to requirements to transfer Corporations Law matters to other courts in accordance with provisions which follow closely the general jurisdiction of courts cross vesting legislation. This will enable the Family Courts to deal with Corporations Law matters when they arise in an ancillary way in relation to Family Law proceedings.
A Family Court will be able to transfer a case to any appropriate State Supreme Court or the Federal Court having jurisdiction under the Corporations Law.

Various amendments are proposed to the provisions of the Corporations Act to make more explicit and clarify, in relation to the national scheme laws applying in the A.C.T., the ``federalisation'' formula under the State Application Acts. That legislative device is the mechanism by which the Commonwealth Laws relating to the investigation and prosecution of offences, and the review of administrative decisions, apply to matters arising under the State Corporations Laws and ASC Laws as if those laws were Commonwealth and not State Laws.

One further feature of the Bill that it is appropriate to mention concerns the amendments contained in the Bill that are proposed to commence from the date when the new national scheme began operation.

The purpose of providing retrospective application for these amendments is to provide commercial certainty by avoiding the possibility of an unexpected and or unnecessary loss of rights, or the imposition of additional liabilities, on the business community and other persons. This is particularly the case in respect of those provisions which are intended to put beyond doubt that no substantive change in the law occurred on 1 January 1991, such as the provisions in the Bill recognising the national effect of the registration of company charges under the Corporations Law of a jurisdiction.

Other amending provisions to commence on 1 January 1991, such as those amendments relating to the legislative machinery of the new national scheme, reflect corresponding provisions in the State Application Laws and seek to reinforce the valid national operation of the new scheme, or make explicit what was intended to be implicit in the operation of the new national scheme laws when they came into force on 1 January 1991.

The remaining provisions of the Bill, Mr President, propose various technical and clarifying amendments and make minor drafting corrections to the Corporations Act, the Corporations Law and the ASC Act and ASC Law.

In accordance with the arrangements under the Heads of Agreement relating to the new national scheme, the members of the Ministerial Council for Corporations have been fully consulted on the Bill. Some members of the Ministerial Council made specific comments on the draft Bill. The Bill was also refined in the light of comments from the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee (and its various sub-committees) and the Australian Accounting Standards Board.

Following consideration of the comments from the Council and others a revised Bill was circulated to the members of the Council which has now voted to approve the Bill in the form in which it is being introduced today.

Mr President, the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill marks, as I have said, the first step under the new scheme on the path to restoring our international business reputation. It will assist in establishing a corporate and market environment in which business and investors may carry out their essential activities, and prosper, with confidence in the stability and fairness of that environment.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate.
COURTS (MEDIATION AND ARBITRATION) BILL

The introduction of this Bill honours a commitment made by the Prime Minister on 20 March 1990 that the Government would introduce legislation to facilitate alternative dispute resolution in the Federal Court of Australia and the Family Court of Australia.

This Bill enables the courts to provide parties with a greater choice of methods of dispute resolution. As well as the traditional methods of judicial determination, and those methods of alternative dispute resolution already provided by the courts, the Federal Court and the Family Court will be able to offer litigants, and potential litigants, the options of mediation and arbitration. These options can provide efficient and cost effective alternatives to the judicial process for the resolution of many disputes.

Fully contested litigation is invariably expensive and time consuming, both for the parties and the public in the provision of courts and judicial officers. The expense and stress involved in protracted litigation may mean that judicial determination of a dispute is not a practical or appropriate solution in many cases, and the availability of non-litigious methods of dispute resolution will provide savings in terms of cost and time while ensuring that there is a means whereby a dispute can be brought to an end.

The Bill allows for the development of mediation in both courts. In mediation, a neutral third person assists the parties to arrive at their own solution to their dispute. Mediation is particularly suitable for parties who need to preserve ongoing relationships. The essence of mediation is that the parties are empowered to produce the result that is best suited to their own individual and collective needs. Commercial litigants can benefit from speedy, cost efficient resolution of disputes without the strain to a business relationship that can result from protracted litigation. Other types of disputes can also benefit from a less hostile process of resolution. In family matters, even when a couple have decided to end their relationship, communication between them may need to be preserved over a long period where questions of the custody of, and access to, children are involved. Avoidance of a bitter and formal legal battle is to be preferred, allowing both parties to concentrate on the issues in dispute, including non-legal issues, and assisting them to find the solution that best provides for the welfare of their children.

Mediation may be more likely to lead to a final resolution of personal issues than litigation, as parties are able to fashion their solutions without being limited to legal remedies. It is well known that most cases are resolved without recourse to a fully contested hearing. However, many litigants incur expense and delay by waiting until a matter is ``at the door of the court'' before attempting to settle. It is expected that the availability of court-annexed mediation will encourage those parties who can settle to do so earlier in their proceedings. Even if the mediation is unsuccessful and the dispute is presented for judicial determination, the issues in dispute should be better defined, resulting in faster resolution by the court.

Arbitration is the determination of a dispute by a third person who is not a judge. It has been used to resolve commercial disputes for many years, and is particularly suitable for the determination of disputes that do not involve complex matters of law. While not offering the same non-financial benefits or cost efficiency as mediation, parties who choose to use an independent arbitrator may have their disputes resolved more quickly.

It is recognised by both the Government and the courts that not all disputes are suitable for resolution by mediation or arbitration. For example, in matters in which child abuse or domestic violence is alleged mediation is not appropriate. To be successful, mediation must have the cooperation and participation of both parties. If the power balance between the parties is unequal, or one party is not prepared to negotiate, then mediation may not be the best method for the resolution of the dispute. Arbitration may not be appropriate if the matter in dispute is one of public importance or involves complex questions of law. The legislation recognises these issues and limits the matters that may be heard by an arbitrator in the Family Court and gives both courts the power to make rules to determine those matters appropriate for referral to mediation or arbitration. Judicial determination of a dispute will always be available to those parties who do not wish to use arbitration or mediation or when mediation has been attempted but has been unsuccessful.

The Bill does not diminish the jurisdiction of either the Federal Court or the Family Court. It can be seen that the courts retain control over the enforcement of the outcomes of mediation and arbitration.
