Honourable senators have said that. They have all admitted it. They have said that Austel ought to be a regulatory authority for the environment in which these--
—It's quality, not quantity.

—I am talking about quality, too; I am talking about the quality of the environment, technically and in this standards area. There are no others. If honourable senators do not agree with this, the second carrier will be able to do what it likes with no regulatory control at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I want members of the Opposition to understand this because what they are doing here and now is to ensure that they do not give an opportunity to their backbenchers to understand what this is all about. What I am asking is very simple and very reasonable. I did not accuse the Government, as Senator Collins suggested, of unseemly haste. I did not do that. I am simply asking that the normal process be observed, and the normal process as was agreed around the place was that instead of having amendments coming before the Committee of the Whole, the Bill, together with amendments, go off to a committee.

That was the argument that was put forward by the Opposition and the Democrats. Why on this occasion should that not still occur? There are dozens of amendments. Despite all of the consultations that have taken place, dozens of amendments are now tabled to this legislation. Why should it not go to a committee? The Government has not given us any valid reason as to why it should be dealt with tonight.

Senator Richard Alston ought to know that we are not pulling stumps at half past 10 tonight. Presumably this measure will be determined tonight. I am saying to the Opposition: give yourselves the chance to understand what this is all about. It is about a very grave matter of principle, about which many of the Opposition senators are very concerned. Here is the opportunity to do something about it. All I want is to ensure that a standing committee runs its eyes over this legislation so that we could call the Department of Transport and Communications, and call various other interested groups, to see what they thought about it. The thought that some other regulatory body can do anything about it is a fallacy. It will not occur. Honourable senators have the opportunity tonight and I am asking all of them to vote for this measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. The question is that the motion moved by Senator Harradine be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Quorum formed)
TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1991
Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 3, page 2, at end of clause, add the following word and paragraphs:
``; and (j) promoting the development of Australia's telecommunications capabilities, industries and skills, for use in Australia and overseas; and
``; and (k) promoting research and development within Australia in relation to new and diverse telecommunications facilities and services for use in Australia and overseas; and
``; and (l) ensuring that all parts of the community benefit from lower prices for telecommunications facilities and services and from the future development of telecommunications networks.''.

The Australian Democrats are proposing this amendment to the objects of the Act because we want to see the insertion of these three paragraphs to strengthen the Government's stated intention of promoting and developing the local equipment manufacturing industry. I ask the Minister: when can we expect a statement to this effect on an industry policy? I know that the Government is prepared to have this amendment included in the objects of the Act. I would just like some more concrete indication of when we might expect to see something firmer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; I do not understand the question. This amendment actually goes into the legislation. Which statement is Senator Kernot talking about?
—I am comparing it with having a licence condition. This is going into the objects of the Act. That is a statement. I would like something firmer. I am asking when we will see something firmer.
—What is the difference between the amendment moved by the Democrats to clause 3, page 2 and the circulated Government amendment to clause 3, page 2?
—Quite honestly, I do not know.
—What is the argument then?
—Nothing. I am asking for clarification.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to confess that, in terms of providing a firmer statement of objectives, that is what this is. I am not trying to be thick, I can assure Senator Kernot. It is an addition promoting the enhancement of Australian communications, promoting research and development and so on. We are actually putting it into the Bill now.

—It gives a framework for interpretation further down the track, but nothing in this compels the Government. It is just a statement of intention. I am hoping to know when, further down the track, the Government is prepared to make a firmer commitment to industry.

—I am a little confused myself and I should like to resolve that confusion before we go any further. I have before me an amendment to be moved by the Government and an amendment to be moved by the Democrats. They appear to be identical. Are they identical?
—Yes, they are. But we are accepting the Democrats' amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments were discussed at the ministerial advisory committee of which, as I have mentioned before in debate, I have been a member. They were unanimously supported by all sections of the telecommunications industry at that time. Also the Government has indicated that, with these sorts of amendments coming in, which I support--
—That is our amendment.

—I must say to Senator Kernot that very similar amendments were raised at the ministerial advisory committee, which I and others indicated our support for. It is also a fact that, as part of the process of issuing a licence for a second carrier, there will be a very substantial industry development program outlined by the Government in which the points raised in the amendment under paragraphs (j), (k) and (l) will be substantially taken care of. That is the unanimous view of members of the industry who were represented at the ministerial advisory committee as well as within the various committees of the Government Party.

SPEECH.PARA: As to Senator Kernot's query as to whether we are committed to what is contained in the amendment, I certainly can see from every indication given by the Government that when we announce the industry package those matters will be taken up and I think people will be very pleased when they see that package announced as part of the licensing process for both the second carrier and the new merged carrier.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is quite simple. These paragraphs will go in as objects of the Act. That has been agreed. All that Senator Kernot is asking is, in relation to promoting the development of Australia's telecommunication capabilities, skills and industries, when we are actually likely to see some factories on the ground, some transistors coming out, some telephones-some action which will give effect to this objective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The actual specific detail will be incorporated into the licences, which will be available for scrutiny when they are drawn up by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 4 to 10-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 11.

TALK.START.PARA: —This clause as it stands in the Bill deals with a change in the network termination point in 1993 from the wall socket, where it now is, to a point outside the property boundary by regulation. We do not agree with that. We certainly do not want that to happen by regulation. We think that consumers will have to arrange their own cabling inside the property, and this will lead to so many questions. For example, with whom does the fault lie-is it the exchange, the cable, the subcontractor-whose responsibility is it if the line fails, who pays? All those sorts of questions will arise. We prefer the situation to remain as is.
—We will not be supporting the Australian Democrats' amendment but will be moving our own.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be supporting the clause as printed. The removal of the clause would prevent the legislation being updated in a flexible manner to keep up with rapid technological change. Rapid changes are occurring in the development of radio-based telecommunications systems, and the Bill in clauses 6 to 9 sets out in detail the boundaries of line networks.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 10 sets out the boundary for radio communication networks. The pace of technological change, as I have said, is extremely fast, and it is quite likely that regulations will be needed to flesh out the network boundaries in more detail, particularly in relation to radio communication systems as they continue to develop.

The regulations will be disallowable by the Parliament. Providing for modification of the boundaries by regulation would appear to strike an appropriate balance between the necessary need for flexibility in the face of technological change and the remaining involvement of this Parliament in terms of its oversight power in disallowing regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 11, page 11, lines 11 to 18, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Regulations may make determinations concerning network boundaries

``11. (1) The regulations may make provision for or in relation to determining the equipment, lines and other facilities that are to be beyond, or not beyond, the boundaries of a telecommunications network, provided that the boundary of a network shall be deemed to be the barge board on the outside wall or perimeter of a property.
``(2) In this section `property' has the same meaning as it has in section 7.

We accept the proposition that flexibility is desirable, but we also take the view that the barge board is the more appropriate position point. We believe that is in accordance with available technology, and would enable a much more competitive and robust approach to the whole question of the first telephone monopoly, which seems to be dragging on and on. We think that it would enable much better quality service to be provided by a range of independent technicians at a much quicker time than the Government would seem to contemplate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulty in accepting this amendment is that it will cause some inconvenience for the consumer-the customer-if the connection is moved to the barge board rather than to the socket. It will cause difficulties in two ways, and I feel that there will be very few people in this chamber who have ever had their phones repaired who are not aware of the effect that this amendment would have. First, it would remove the obligations of Telecom Australia to maintain the house wiring system past the barge board. It would also involve the consumer in a great deal of additional expenditure in having to have a separate operation in terms of wiring past the barge board. The Government opposes this amendment.
—The Australian Democrats oppose this amendment. We see it as worse than the Government's proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say in rebuttal that it would seem a classic case of the Government being afraid of competition in this area as it is not prepared to accept that some real competitive virtues might flow from having more than one service provider in the area. If that is an indication of the Government's approach to freeing up the network and the system generally, I have some real concerns about the Minister's indication that after 1993 the boundary may be the property boundary.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that international experience already demonstrates that there can be very effective competition. Undoubtedly, many current Telecom employees will be particularly interested in running around the back and setting up enterprises of their own. There would be a ready pool of talent able to carry out these functions just as effectively, much more competitively and, I would have thought, more productively for consumers as well. They would experience fewer delays and enjoy better quality and hopefully lower prices.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! It being about 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report progress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this matter of the termination point, I do not think in any debate over the past year, in the great sum of things that we are doing in telecommunications, that I have come across a matter that has been more hotly disputed than this specific point. It all has to do with the fact that we are dealing with an industry that has been in a monopoly position. It has been run very much as a public service for such a long time, with public service attitudes about regulation. I think that the Government's proposal is the best. Instead of trying to do what the Australian Democrats are suggesting and leaving the matter as it is, or doing what Senator Alston for the Opposition is suggesting and leaving the connection at the barge board, Senator Collins is quite correct to say that technologies are changing and that we should not put a prescription in the regulation or in the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Circumstances in the 1990s will change rapidly, but certainly the Government has indicated that there should be an orderly process of change in this area which has been negotiated in discussion with the unions and the management. Although the unions do not like the proposal-and one can anticipate why, because it changes a longstanding work practice in the industry-I think that they accept that there will be changes. They have a couple of years in which to adjust. I do not think there will be a cataclysmic loss of employment as a result of these changes of arrangements after 1993.

I think that the Bill's provisions should be left flexible. Clearly, the Government has to bring in regulations to lay down whether the connection will be at the socket, the barge board or the property boundary. Whichever one it is, it will be debated here at an appropriate time and can be changed under regulation. I think that is the sort of flexibility that is needed rather than putting it down now in a prescriptive way. I would expect that much of the concern that has been expressed, particularly that by unions, can be addressed in the next couple of years. I expect that the loss of jobs will not be as catastrophic as the unions fear as a result of this change.

Furthermore, the technological changes that are occurring mean that even the unions recognise that what was appropriate for the old copper wire system in telephone connections 20 or 30 years ago obviously will be under dramatic challenge when the cellular mobile system of telephones extends widely and other new technologies are introduced. Therefore, much of this argument may be unnecessary because the jobs that would be lost here will be made up elsewhere in the system as people adapt to the new technologies. I think that the Government has the right balance in its proposal, and I do not think that we should be as restrictive as either the Democrats or the Opposition propose.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 12 to 33-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clause 33a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. After clause 33, page 18, insert the following clause:
Act subject to Broadcasting Act
``33A. This Act has effect subject to the Broadcasting Act 1942.''.

I know that there is not a lot of support for what I am proposing in this amendment. Nevertheless, I want to make a point about it. Clause 33 exempts the Radiocommunications Act 1983 but not the Broadcasting Act 1942. We see a potential conflict between Austel's role and that of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal which are both statutory authorities and have the power to control the technical requirements of the broadcasting industry. We think that there is a public interest issue here and an opportunity to change this in the Broadcasting Act review. The fact that the Minister is to issue a directive to Austel to tell it not to use its power over the Broadcasting Act is really not the point. We think that the whole matter ought to be transparent in the Bill. I think there are enough problems in the Broadcasting Act and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal without adding another one to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing this amendment. We do not think it is reasonable to make the Telecommunications Act subject to the Broadcasting Act. They have quite separate objectives and while any overlap between the two regimes is minimal, it really does not make much sense to arbitrarily subject one to the other. This may result in the famous `unintended consequences'.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not clear what the Australian Democrats are trying to achieve, despite the explanation that has just been given. If the Democrats are trying to protect the broadcasters from having to comply with technical compliance obligations under the Telecommunications Act, this may be convenient for broadcasters but it will not necessarily serve the interests of protecting the safety and integrity of the public telecommunications network. If Austel imposes safety restrictions on the use of lines, why should the broadcasters be exempt from these requirements if they are necessary to protect the telecommunications network? I cannot understand, therefore, why the Democrats are looking after the interests of the commercial broadcasters in this matter.

Any additional obligations that Austel would be likely to impose on the broadcasters would relate to their use of lines. It would certainly not be appropriate to allow broadcasters to be exempted from the provisions of the Telecommunications Act governing resale and the provision of value added services on their networks. Any difficulties with the transmission that result in interference are dealt with under the Radiocommunications Act to which the Telecommunications Bill remains subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I also am not much the wiser having heard Senator Kernot's explanation. The only thought that occurred to me was that perhaps she has in mind that if and when we ever get around to pay television in this country, the Broadcasting Act 1942 may somehow be used to override provisions relating to the delivery of those services that would otherwise have been provided through the telecommunications system and, therefore, regulated by Austel. Although I do not think that one should have an iron view on the matter to the extent that the two should never overlap-and I refer in particular to what Senator Harradine has been indicating tonight, that there may well be a case for giving the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal certain powers in relation to certain subject matter-I certainly do not think that one should have a blanket approach, and certainly not on the basis of what we have heard tonight. The Opposition will be opposing this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats' amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: This Act has effect subject to the Broadcasting Act 1942.

It means, I assume, that the Broadcasting Act 1942 has precedence over the provisions of this legislation in so far as it affects broadcasting. I do not know-I think there is something to be said for that proposition provided that the same technical standards, or safety standards as the Minister indicated, were required of commercial broadcasters under that legislation.

I have not actually had the matter explained to me clearly, but I take up the point that was made by Senator Alston and reiterate the logic of the position that I mentioned previously. In respect of standards, for example, if we do not have Austel as a regulatory authority, we have absolutely nobody. Even if the Democrats' amendment were carried, I do not see that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal would be able to come into the situation with regard to message content, standards, codes of conduct and the rest.

Really we are back to the situation, irrespective of whether this amendment is carried or whether it is not, where it is only the technical environment that is actually regulated by Austel. That is despite the fact that Telecom Australia itself-and I want people to understand this-has been anxious for Austel to be involved in this question of code of conduct. Of course it would, for two reasons. The first is that it is an outside body-it is a regulatory body. Secondly, if it is not going to regulate the code of conduct, the new player-the new carrier-will be able to do anything it likes. I only raise this because it has been raised by Senator Richard Alston. I say that this idea that some time in the future the Broadcasting Tribunal may be able to be the regulatory authority with respect to this question is an absolute furphy. The Senate has the chance to do something about it tonight, and I hope it does.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand Senator Harradine's concern and I appreciate the subtlety of his invitation. The amendment that we are considering at the moment goes far beyond that. I could not, for a moment, predict the consequences that might flow from making every aspect of telecommunications subject to the whims of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The Tribunal is not qualified to make technical judgments. If it happens to be able to identify some jurisdiction that it can exercise, one would have thought that it would probably feel compelled to exercise it, and we would have an unholy conflict on our hands in a whole range of areas. I would have thought that if there is one single way of making the whole industry unworkable, it would be to have blanket authority conveyed in that way. Whilst, again, I think there may, and there should, be other ways of addressing Senator Harradine's specific concern, it is certainly not well addressed by giving a comprehensive and virtually unlimited power to the Tribunal in the manner proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government indicated some time ago that it is reviewing the Broadcasting Act in a major way-it is probably the most significant review of the Act for many years, if not decades. Part of that review will deal with some of the questions that Senator Kernot has raised-certainly the specific matters raised by Senator Harradine. In that process that the Government will be going through it will be calling for public submissions and I suggest they should take that opportunity to put submissions forward at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect what Senator Harradine is actually suggesting would mean that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal would become an equivalent of the Federal Communications Commission, the FCC, in the United States, which is really embarking upon quite a different regulatory body which is an enormous bureaucracy in that country. I am not quite sure that I am ready to jump on board a suggestion that we should have such an enormous bureaucracy. I think we ought to take small bites of the apple and see how we go with Austel for a while. Certainly, the review that the Government is conducting at the moment dealing with the Broadcasting Act affords an appropriate opportunity for those with concerns to raise them and hopefully we will have the legislation in this Parliament by the end of the year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There must be some misunderstanding. This is not my amendment; I was simply asking questions and responding to what Senator Alston said. I was trying to find out from the Australian Democrats what they actually meant by the amendment-that is all. I will deal with the other matters later-it is not appropriate for me to deal with them now. But I wanted to know what the amendment meant. I think I know now and I think I know how to vote.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clauses 34 to 37-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 38.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4. Clause 38, page 20, lines 1 and 2, omit all words from ``General'', substitute:
General functions-protection of public interest and consumers
``38. (1) The functions of AUSTEL include ensuring that the provisions of this Act are carried out with due regard to the public interest.
``(2) The functions of AUSTEL include protecting consumers from''.

In moving this amendment I will make some general comments about our amendments Nos. 5, 6 and 7. These amendments are similar to the Liberal Party amendment No. 2. We think that our amendments are more comprehensive. They include the protection of public interest clause under the general functions of Austel. They include monitoring and reporting on performance standards and strengthening the consumer protection-especially with regard to complaints about charging and billing, which we expect to be the motive for the majority of complaints.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be accepting this amendment. We are not opposed at all, in principle, to the amendment that Senator Alston is moving, it is simply that we prefer the drafting of the Australian Democrats amendment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Alston

TALK.START.PARA: —We take the same view.

INTERJECT.PARA: 5. Clause 38, page 20, paragraph (a) line 7, after ``complaints'', add ``, including complaints about charges for telecommunications services''.
7. Clause 38, page 20, after paragraph (b), insert the following paragraph:
``(ba) monitoring, and reporting to the Minister on, the performance of carriers and other persons in meeting the standards developed under paragraph (b); and''.
6. Clause 38, page 20, at end of clause, add the following subclause:
``(2) When developing standards under paragraph (b), AUSTEL must have regard to the best international practice performance indicators available to it.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is meant by `managing the numbering of telecommunications services in Australia'? As I understand it, under the current legislation Austel has the responsibility of managing the numbering of telecommunications services in Australia. I am sure that is one of its existing functions and, indeed, this is where the question of 0055 numbers comes in.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not understand it, Senator. Indeed, Telecom Australia has sought to have what is known as an opt-in service for some of the types of material about which there has been considerable objection. Telecom requires the approval of Austel for the numbering of that service, which it does not yet have. Whether it has sought it completely, I do not know. But this is where Austel indirectly, even now, comes into the question of codes of conduct because either it will be asked, or it is being asked now, by Telecom to provide a new numbering system-for what? For a type of opt-in service for telephone porn. Obviously, when Austel gives consideration to that matter it will have to--
—Are you moving an amendment?

—I am not moving an amendment; I am speaking to the clause. Austel will be obliged to consider why Telecom wants such a new numbering system. Ipso facto, it will be considering message content. I hope Senator Richard Alston is listening to this debate because by implication already Austel is involved in consideration of these matters as it has the management of the numbering of telecommunication services in Australia. Unless I am missing something here, this clause-as is the case with a lot of legislation-repeats what is already in the legislation. If there is anything else behind this particular clause, I would like to hear it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, nothing hangs on this matter. Quite simply, this clause is reasonable, sensible and provides for consumer protection. The reason that Austel has this power is that some numbers are more convenient than others and we do not want Telecom--
—More valuable.
—Indeed. We do not want Telecom to have the power to hog for itself--
—Allocate as they have been doing.
—Indeed. We think it is much more appropriate for an independent authority to dispense with what in fact does have commercial value.

—Senator Harradine misunderstands the impact of clause 39. It is to ensure that the competitor as the new carrier and Telecom both have equal access to numbering, so that one carrier does not get an advantage over the other in the numbers that are allocated. For example, Telecom might insist that its competitor has three extra digits in front of every number it issues to make it more difficult for the competitor to get business. It is nothing to do with the issues that Senator Harradine is concerned about, which is the content of issuing numbers for recorded messages. It is to ensure that both carriers are treated equally in providing services to the customers.

—I certainly echo the sentiments expressed by Senator Schacht. There is a whole series of numbers that can be used or abused by a carrier with monopoly rights over numbering. Senator Schacht is absolutely correct that overseas there have been instances of one carrier requiring its competitor to require people to dial four or five digits before getting into the system. I ask the Minister whether this clause will allow Austel to revisit current allocations and, if necessary, make judgments on whether the system is operating fairly to the extent that those numbers are already allocated and whether it is possible to redistribute.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very good question and the answer is yes.

—I did not need a lecture from Senator Schacht or from the Minister or from Senator Alston about the numbering. It is quite obvious that a regulatory authority like Austel should have the power to allocate numbering. I was saying that, as I understand it, Austel in a monopoly situation already has that power. I am asking the Minister quite directly: is it a fact that if Telecom, as a monopoly, requires a new numbering system for an opt-in service, it is required to make application to Austel and for that application to be approved by Austel prior to the allocation of that new numbering system?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not strictly correct. What will happen in practice is that Austel will in fact allocate blocks of numbers to the carriers and it will then be for the carriers to allocate those numbers to subscribers as they use the services.
—I am talking about the existing circumstance. Under the existing circumstance, is it or is it not a fact that Telecom has requested Austel for a particular number for that opt-in service?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just a little frustrating when one knows that what Senator Harradine wants to do in fact is to dispose of this service. I really do not want to get into an esoteric debate for an hour and a half about a matter on which there is no amendment before the chamber and which Senator Harradine is quite legitimately pursuing, but I have answered the question twice.

SPEECH.PARA: What will happen is that Austel will have an overall right to review this matter over time. There are transitional arrangements provided for that will not allow commercial interference with existing numbers. There is not going to be some arbitrary approach taken that will commercially disadvantage people that have existing services. There is a transitional provision provided for in the package of legislation, but Austel will have, over a period of time, the right to review the numbering.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that I asked the Minister has not been answered. The officials ought to know whether it is correct or whether it is not. I refer to the review of Telecom's 0055 message content advertising service. One of the recommendations arising out of that-and I do not agree with this-was that there be an opt-in service for the type of material that currently is available, `adult' material, over 0055. One of the recommendations was that there be an opt-in service with a new numbering system. My simple question to the Minister is: has Telecom requested Austel for that new numbering system and, if it has not, is it required to request Austel for that new numbering system?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not, of course, have the answer to the first part of that question and, frankly, it really is not an appropriate matter that would mean that I should have the answer. I do not know whether Telecom has actually made a request to Austel for a new number under the opt-in service under 0055, so I cannot answer that question. We all know that it is the substance, the material that is used on this service, that Senator Harradine is quite properly concerned about, so I cannot answer that question. I will in fact-and I have requested the officers to do so-make an inquiry and provide at a later stage Senator Harradine with the information as to whether Telecom has made such a request.

SPEECH.PARA: There are transitional provisions providing for this matter in the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1991, which is part of this package of Bills. The clause number in that Bill that covers this is clause 13.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 40.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Clause 40, page 20, paragraph (b), lines 31 and 32, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

``(b) carrier performance, measured against the best international practice performance indicators available to AUSTEL, and with particular reference to consumer satisfaction, consumer benefits and quality of service.''.
I do not know the attitude of the Government to this matter, but if Senator Collins is indicating support for our amendment-he is not? This is amendment No. 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the substance of this amendment has already been picked up in the amendment to clause 38.
—By the Democrats.

—That is when developing standards. We take the view that it ought to be much broader than that. I must say that I am heartened by the fairly dramatic change of attitude on the part of the Government over the last 12 months in this whole area of competition. That is why it is particularly important that we should be concerned that all functions of the Australian Telecommunications Authority (Austel), including reviewing, not just those relating to the development of standards, which is what the Democrat amendment goes to, ought to be guided by best international practice. That is something that has simply not been happening in this country to date. That is why I regard this as a fundamentally important motion.

SPEECH.PARA: If this amendment is carried, for the first time in many ways it will expose us to the real world. It will mean that we will have to measure ourselves against the rest of the world, not against where the Government was 12 months ago, which was opposed to competition or any sort of international comparisons and was merely looking back. This amendment will enable us to look forward at output and to ensure that, for the first time, we will have a system that is driven by the best possible alternatives. That will be a tremendous breakthrough. I am delighted that it would seem that the Government will be supporting that amendment.

In many respects, in terms of carrier performance, we have already given the rest of the world some seven years. This is a very good opportunity for Austel to keep the weights on both carriers and to ensure that, when the Minister is receiving reports, and hopefully when he is passing those reports on to the Parliament, we will be able to make our own proper comparative judgments and not simply relevant ones that might state that we have made progress from where we were the year before.

As I say, the Government has already made dramatic progress in having adopted our agenda in many respects. It has not gone the privatisation path as yet, but we understand the political constraints on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to support the merger Bill?
—No, I do not think we will be.
—If you stop talking, we will support it.
—I am delighted to hear it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just made an agreement with Senator Alston which I am now prepared to honour. I will support his amendment. I now understand the point that I think I heard Senator Kernot raising by interjection. I see the distinction. I really did think this amendment had been picked up satisfactorily in the Democrat amendment to clause 38. However, I notice that it does involve a separate section. Anyway, the sweet talking of Senator Alston has convinced me not to oppose his amendment.
—I think the amendment to this clause is the linchpin of competition between the two carriers.
—No, it is not.

—With respect to the Minister, I think it is, because when this is in action we will have a duopoly, and a duopoly can have cosy arrangements. As Senator Alston pointed out, we cannot compare a duopoly's charges and services with those of the rest of the world to make sure that they are comparable. To ensure that the two members of the duopoly are not playing a game alongside each other against the consumers, I believe this is a very necessary amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an attempt to define the quality of service concept, which is quite elusive. We have picked up most of this in our amendment. The Opposition has included it in the Austel functions section whereas we put it in a stronger position in a section on Austel review with reporting to the Minister. We support this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 41 to 46-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to general functions of licensing, I ask a specific question of the Minister relating to the term `class licences', the issue of which is a function of Austel. In terms of previous services which were covered by Telecom, what is contained in the term `class licences'? For example, one of the old terms that was used was `value added services'. In addition to `value added services', what is to be included in the term `class licences'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Senator Harradine referring to clause 41?
—Yes.
—All value added services are included under `class licences'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addition to value added services, what is included in the term `class licences'?
—Nothing.
—Is the Minister sure about that?
—Yes.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 47, page 22, after subclause (1), insert the following subclause:

``(1A) AUSTEL, the carriers, and the persons who supply eligible services, must give to officers and authorities of the Commonwealth and of the States and Territories such help as is reasonably necessary for any of the following purposes:
(a) enforcing the criminal law and laws imposing pecuniary penalties;
(b) protecting the public revenue;
(c) safeguarding national security.''.
(4) Clause 47, page 22, subclause (2), line 20, at end of subclause, add ``or (1A)''.
(5) Clause 47, page 22, paragraph (3)(a), line 24, after ``(1)'', insert ``or (1A)''.
(6) Clause 47, page 22, paragraphs (3)(b) and (c), lines 25 to 31, omit the paragraphs, substitute the following paragraphs:
``(b) in compliance or purported compliance with a condition of a general telecommunications licence or public mobile licence held by the carrier, being:
(i) a condition that is expressed to have the purpose of giving effect to subsection (1) or (1A); or
(ii) a condition of the kind referred to in paragraph 63(4)(1); or
(c) in compliance or purported compliance with a direction that AUSTEL has given in good faith:
(i) in performance or purported performance of the duty imposed by subsection (1) or (1A); or
(ii) under a condition of the kind referred to in paragraph 63(4)(1).''.
(7) Clause 47, page 22, paragraph (4)(a), line 36, after ``(1)'', insert ``or (1A)''.
(8) Clause 47, page 22, paragraph (4)(b), line 40, after ``(1)'', insert ``or (1A)''.
(9) Clause 47, page 22, paragraph (4)(c), lines 41 to 43, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:
``(c) in compliance or purported compliance with a direction that AUSTEL has given in good faith:
(i) in performance or purported performance of the duty imposed by subsection (1) or (1A); or
(ii) under a condition of a kind referred to in paragraph (b) of this subsection.''.
(10) Clause 47, page 23, at end of clause, add the following subclause:
``(6) Nothing in this section limits the generality of anything else in it.''.

Clause 47 imposes on Austel, the carriers and persons which supply eligible services, an obligation to cooperate with and provide assistance to Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities in relation to the enforcement of the criminal law or a law imposing a pecuniary penalty, the protection of public revenue or national security. The amendment ensures that licence holders alone will not have these law enforcement obligations imposed on them and that the other participants in the industry, who provide the full range of services allowed for under this legislation, will also be subject to clear and consistent obligations to cooperate with Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities in relation to law enforcement and associated matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, the Opposition supports these amendments. They achieve what we would all regard as desirable, namely, that these obligations of good citizenship ought to be imposed upon all players in the industry and not simply be included in particular carrier agreements by way of contract conditions. We therefore think this is an advance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats support the amendments as well, for very similar reasons, in the interests of equity.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 48 to 51-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the performance of Austel's functions in a manner consistent with any general functions by the Commonwealth, notified by the Minister, under clause 49, and any directions given by the Minister, under clause 50, how are the directions to be known by the Parliament or the public? Obviously, the carriers would know the directions, if they were to affect them, but the Government might give Austel certain directions in respect of certain major questions. How will we know about those directions, other than by reading about the fact that a Minister might have given the direction under clause 49 or under clause 50, other than by reading it 12 months later in the annual report? I assume that, as with some other government authorities, Austel would have to include those directions in its annual report-but I do not know.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, the last point that Senator Harradine made is correct. They do have an obligation to do that. That obligation is included in clause 393 of the Bill.

—I thank the Minister. That is sort of 12 months down the track, and if Austel is anything like some other authorities around the place, it might be 18 months down the track. Is there no other way that Parliament or the public, in matters of major questions of policy, could require the Minister to notify the Parliament in some way that directions have been given to Austel in major questions of Government policy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand again what Senator Harradine is in fact referring to. Frankly, I think, that the provisions--
—Actually, I wasn't.

—I do know what Senator Harradine was referring to. I think that reasonably the obligations that are provided to have these published-under clause 393-are reasonable. Clearly, if the Minister was intending to make major policy decisions-that is, significant changes of direction for the organisation-there is no question that that would be debated in Parliament. But in terms of a reasonable requirement and an obligation to make all of these matters public, I think the provisions of clause 393 are reasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: These matters do have to be made public and they are required to be made public in the annual report. In relation to the mass of technical matters, the Government believes they should be made public, but we do not believe that it is necessary to have them tabled in Parliament immediately they are made. There is an obligation to make them public in clause 393, and we think this is reasonable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not want the Minister to understand that I expected that Austel's decisions should be made public in the Parliament. It was only the question of the Minister's directions under clause 49 and clause 50 that I was interested in being made public and not being left in a situation in which they were just contained in the annual report. But I have got it clear; I know what the proposed legislation is. The Minister has explained it.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 52.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Clause 52, page 24, lines 6 to 10, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
``52. In performing its functions, AUSTEL must to the extent practicable consult with government, commercial, industrial, trade union, consumer and standards bodies and organisations.''.

I know it seems like a semantic quibble here, because we are changing the words `where it is appropriate' to `where practicable'. We think that `where it is appropriate' gives Austel more option in terms of consulting. We are attempting to just rebalance it sufficiently to tilt it in favour of consultation. The second part of the amendment adds `trade unions' to the list, and I would like to ask the Minister why trade unions were not in the list, and are they not the repositories of technical skills which are actually related to telecommunications?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Nice try, Senator. They are in fact included in the list under the general word `industrial', and we think that is appropriate. What is not appropriate is to remove the word `appropriate'. It will be a lawyers' gift-although I should not say that, I suppose; Senator Alston might support it. It will be a lawyers' gift in that it will in fact give rise to a mass of vexatious litigation, because Austel will be obliged by the Democrats' amendment to consult this whole range of bodies on each and every occasion that it has to consult, whether it is appropriate to consult all these bodies or not.

SPEECH.PARA: We could be put in a situation where the organisation would be involved in a massive exercise of having to consult by form-because it is required by legislation-organisations where it is totally inappropriate to consult them. Then, if they did not consult them, they would be liable to legal action under the Act. We think the existing wording of the Bill is reasonable.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Government's view, certainly on that matter. What the Australian Democrats would do is smother the industry in consultation, I would think, to ensure the whole process was so bogged down with consultation one would never get around to actually taking decisions. The more intriguing aspect is the Government's refusal to wear the specific reference to trade unions. The Democrats clearly do not take the view that the term `industrial organisations' necessarily embraces trade unions.
—It always has.

—The terms are not synonymous; there may be some overlap. To the extent that there was any doubt, I would have expected the Government to have wanted to put the matter beyond any doubt by specifically inserting the term. Not having done so, we will henceforth regard this as the Kevin Morgan amendment because the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association will regard it as a personal insult. Well it might, because it is probably the first indication that the Government realises that there is some wisdom that does not simply reside in the trade union movement. On that basis, I am delighted to support the Government on both counts.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rest my case. I should have to describe that as vexatious debate. I should like Senator Alston to name one court in the land that would take the view that a trade union was not an industrial organisation under the Act. But I am delighted to hear that the Opposition will support the Government on this matter.

—Senator Kernot claims that the Australian Democrats' amendment would give Austel more power but it would do exactly the opposite. In this duopoly, once again, Austel has been set up as the body that will make things work, that will provide competition. The Democrats' amendment seeks to put a tiger in place to keep the two carriers honest by shackling them to consultations with everybody in the land. It is a wonder Senator Kernot did not add the Country Womens Association, and I am not being disrespectful to the CWA. Senator Kernot is seeking to put a tiger there to guard them and then pull its teeth out.
—I often baulk at the idea that one has to discuss things with organisations. What does Telecom do now?
—This is Austel. It is different from Telecom.

—I know that. When we talk about Austel consulting with organisations, we refer to it consulting with carriers and so on. When Telecom wants to put a cable through a paddock or through a number of farming areas, it calls a meeting of the farmers.
—Just one by one so that they can knock them off one at a time.

—I can think of one occasion recently where that did not occur. Telecom explained fully what it was going to do to people in southern Tasmania, how it was going to improve the service, et cetera. It called a meeting of interested people, not organisations. I know this is talking about consultation, but I do not know why interested persons were not included, and I do not accept that the word `industrial' necessarily embraces `trade union'. I do not accept that that is necessarily correct.
—Did you hear that, Senator Collins? You have just had another legal opinion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did. I do not propose to add anything to what I have already said.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 53 to 56-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 57.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4. Clause 57, page 25, subclause (3), lines 35 and 36, omit the subclause.

This amendment would simply remove the exemption from providing reasons which are given under this section. This is an application for a licence, and it specifically provides that the Minister is not required to give reasons. We take the view that that is quite contrary to normal principles of administrative law and, in many respects, quite contrary to the principles of natural justice.

We are entitled, in most instances, to know on what basis a decision is made so that we can judge whether it is capricious or otherwise and we are able to exercise our legal rights. It may be that a lot of unnecessary time would be wasted in appeals being launched on a misconceived basis. Therefore, we think it is extremely regrettable that the concept of justice that does require reasons to be provided, which is otherwise so well embedded in many other areas of the law, has managed to escape the Government in this instance. I can understand the Government wanting to restrict rights of appeal and to put time limits, but surely the day has long since passed when a tribunal can simply say, `Guilty, and I'm not telling you why', or `No, and I won't explain myself'.

TALK.START.PARA: —British colonial days.

—It is going back a long way, and a great body of law has been built up in the last generation that makes this point abundantly clear. I am simply reflecting some of the concerns expressed to us, at the eleventh hour, by bodies such as the Law Council of Australia. I heartily agree with that concern.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like Senator Alston's view on this. The Government is not going to oppose this, but if it is carried-and if the amendment to clause 60 is also carried-I think we will then have to delete subclause (3) in clause 61 at the top of page 27. I am happy to do that at the appropriate time, but I want to explain that that will be the reason I am doing it.

—I indicate that the Australian Democrats support this and a number of other amendments which deal with making transparently clear and public why the Minister should give reasons for a range of things. We think it makes for open government and goodwill, and we will be supporting this amendment.

—If this subclause is deleted, what does the Minister envisage the Minister for Transport and Communications giving as a reason in the explanation of his decision? If we are looking at the issuing of the licence for the second carrier, which has gone through a process of tendering and so on, presumably such issues as price, industry policy and a whole range of things will be taken into consideration? If the subclause is removed, what sort of information is it incumbent on the Minister to give? It may well be details of why one bid was successful and this could affect future commercial operations. I wonder whether the Minister could give some details on that. I must also say that I am not automatically convinced that if the Law Council of Australia puts up proposals about its concern because it has a particular vested interest and so on--
—The answer is that the Minister would make a statement giving the reasons for such a decision.
—Yes, but he would make a statement anyway, I presume, at the time of the issuing the licence.
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that Senator Schacht's hostility to all things legal is very well known in this place and elsewhere. But it also ought to be understood that if Senator Schacht happened to be on the wrong end of the law, then I would have thought that he might be very interested in seeking its protection from time to time. If he was an applicant for a licence and he had invested a great amount of money in the process, at the very least he would expect to be given the opportunity of judging whether those reasons held up.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not follow that one would be able to go off and appeal and re-run the whole contest, but what it does ensure is that one is able to make a judgment about whether that decision is bona fide. Indeed, the superior court would then make a judgment as to whether those reasons were sustainable. It does not follow that one can simply have another go, but it does give one an opportunity to judge whether one has been fairly treated so that one feels much more comfortable that a decision has been made on the merits. I can assure the honourable senator that every losing litigant is always suspicious about why it really happened. We have long since passed the time when a magistrate can say, `I refuse to tell you'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very familiar with Senator Schacht's unreasoning hatred of lawyers. I commend him for initiating, as he did, the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs into legal fees but I am not swayed by anything Senator Schacht has said in terms of objections tonight. I am pursuing my agreement with the Opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Clause 57, page 25, at end of clause, add the following subclause:

``(4) The Minister must cause a copy of each licence to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the licence is granted, but failure to do so does not affect the validity of a licence.''.

Clause 57 of the Bill enables the Minister to grant licences for general and public mobile carriers. This amendment ensures that when the Minister grants such a licence, it will be required to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days. This will ensure that the Parliament is kept informed of who has been licensed under the Act and what the conditions are that have been included in that licence.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 58 and 59-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 60.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Clause 60, page 26, subclause (4), lines 28 and 29, omit the subclause.

I move this amendment for reasons previously given. I take the opportunity to say, particularly for the benefit of Senator Schacht, that representations made on behalf of the Law Council of Australia that the width of ministerial discretion is such that there ought to be greater guidance provided in the legislation as to the relevant criteria to be applied in the exercise of those discretions is not a proposition with which I agree.

I certainly accept that there are many areas of very wide discretion-I think in excess of 20. The idea that somehow one can not only fetter them but exhaustively specify the basis on which those discretions ought to be exercised is one that the Law Council itself would recognise to be impossible. I simply indicate to the Minister that we scrutinise these submissions made to us on their merits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this agreed to by the Government?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already indicated that the Government does agree with it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 61.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Clause 61, page 27, after subclause (3), add the following subclause:
``(4) A direction issued by the Minister pursuant to subsection (2) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.''.

This amendment comes under a large section dealing with the Minister's powers, particularly in regard to carriers' licensing conditions. The Minister has power to delegate this to his authority-in this case to Austel. We are of the firm opinion that any major decision Austel makes ought to be a disallowable instrument. I take the opportunity of asking the Minister whether, in theory, under this clause Austel could determine the amount of foreign ownership?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is no. The Government will make that determination, but this entire matter will still be subject to the provisions of foreign investment review.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will be opposing this amendment. It is completely unnecessary and it simply restricts the necessary commercial freedom that the organisation has to have. The reason that I make that point-so that I do not have to reiterate it at length elsewhere-is that there is a whole series of amendments that the Australian Democrats are moving in a similar vein which will effectively put the Senate in charge of running the organisation. With the greatest respect to the Senate, we do have a particular and important role to play in Australia, but I do not think that we are the best organisation in the world to make a continuing range of essential commercial decisions, which the organisation has to make. It will be publicly accountable for doing that and will either stand or fall on it.

It is important to point out to the Committee that this amendment just does not stand on its own. There is a whole series of these amendments which require absolutely everything to be subject to disallowance and debate in the Senate chamber. Even with all of its strengths, frankly, I do not think that one of the strengths of the Senate chamber is to run a business. That is the reason why--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell that to Bob McMullan.

—I am the Minister here currently, that is my view and I think it is the appropriate view. There is a whole string of these amendments in the amendment schedule, all of which require everything to be subject to disallowance. There are certain matters which the Government has agreed should be fundamental. However, on the question of the commercial running of the operation, we do not agree. We will be opposing the amendment on those grounds.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also point out further that there is a technical defect in this amendment because of the use of the word `direction' in the first line of (4) which results in any variation or revocation of such a direction not being subject to parliamentary disallowance, but we will be opposing it anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the Minister has misunderstood what the Australian Democrats are doing here. Clause 61 is in relation to the delegation of powers, not the actual exercise of those powers once delegated. It is the delegation of the power, which could be quite a broad power, which would simply come under review and be disallowable, but not the exercise of the power. If the Minister decided to grant quite wide-sweeping commercial powers to Austel, the decision would be whether it was appropriate to delegate. That is the disallowable bit, not the actual exercise of the powers once they are delegated. I think the Minister has perhaps misunderstood it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, I am not misunderstanding the import at all. It is, indeed, a wide-sweeping restraint that this amendment would place on the operations of the organisation. The Minister can, by right, delegate to Austel and that direction will be made subject to parliamentary disallowance. I do not expect two things: I do not expect the Minister to run Austel, neither does he, and that is why he will have to delegate; nor do I expect that the Senate chamber should appropriately run Austel. I did correctly point out, and Senator Kernot agreed across the chamber, that this is one of a number of Democrat amendments that provide for all of these matters to be brought back to the Senate for debate and potential disallowance.

SPEECH.PARA: I just do not think it is appropriate. It is not a secret organisation. The operations will be right up there for everyone to see. Parliamentary debate will be provided if inappropriate operations are given to Austel, but it has to be given an opportunity to run commercially. I am not misinterpreting the restraint that is applied here, with respect, and the Government opposes the amendment. We think it is technically deficient anyway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume the Minister would agree that if the power of delegation were made a disallowable instrument, we would effectively paralyse the ability of the regulator to actually get on with the business. For example, a power could be delegated now, and then 15 sitting days later in August it could be disallowed and Austel would have proceeded at its peril. It would not have proceeded. It would have done nothing for three months, waiting around to see whether the Democrats want to disallow the power of delegation. We oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Amendment (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
Clause 61, page 27, subclause (3), lines 1 and 2, omit the subclause.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 62 agreed to.
Clause 63.
(Quorum formed)
Friday, 7 June 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 6. Clause 63, page 28, after paragraph (4)(h), insert the following paragraph:
``(ha) a condition about how the holder is to ensure and maintain the quality of service to persons to whom it supplies telecommunications services;''.

Clause 63, which provides for certain conditions to be attached to the licence in relation to consumer interests, requires only information about how the carrier will deal with inquiries and complaints of customers. The amendment moved by the Opposition would strengthen these provisions relating to consumer interests. The amendment would include a condition about how the holder is to ensure and maintain the quality of services to persons to whom it supplies telecommunications services. We simply take the view that that is a strengthening of consumer interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not opposed in principle to the amendment that the Opposition has moved. We prefer to accept the Australian Democrats' version of the amendment to the same clause as to a condition about how the holder is to ensure and maintain quality in connection with the supply of telecommunications services.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.
Amendment (by Senator Kernot) proposed:
10. Clause 63, page 28, after paragraph 4(g), insert the following paragraph:
``(ga) a condition about how the holder is to ensure and maintain quality in connection with its supply of telecommunications services;''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the Government will be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Progress reported.

Fisheries Act-Agreements (3) between the Commonwealth of Australia and-

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 19 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many and what percentage of students applied for AUSTUDY at each tertiary and secondary institution in Australia in 1991 and 1990.
(2) How many and what percentage of students who applied for AUSTUDY in 1991 have been assessed to receive full AUSTUDY payment.
(3) How many and what percentage of students receive a reduced or part payment of AUSTUDY allowance in 1991 and what are the reasons for reductions to allowance.
(4) How many and what percentage of students who applied for and received AUSTUDY in 1991 have a home address in urban, rural and isolated areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The task of calculating percentages of students on AUSTUDY by institution would require a very large allocation of resources, but it would only produce a partial answer because student data is not yet available for 1991 and is not held on government secondary schools for 1990. It is considered that this allocation of resources is not warranted at this time.
(2) &(3) The rate of payment received by any individual client is determined by the income of the student, the adjusted parent income or spouse income.

It is not possible to identify those on part payment on a yearly basis because a range of other factors can impact on whether or not a person appears to have received part payment for the year. These include those clients who turn 16 part the way through the year, those who discontinue their studies and those who may be repaying an overpayment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What measures are in place to prevent cholera, which is sweeping Latin America and has already killed more than 1300 people, from entering Australia.
(2) Is there sufficient cholera vaccine in this country to tackle a full blown epidemic.

(3) With reports that up to 6 million people in Latin America could be affected by the bacteria, what restrictions, if any, are in place to ensure persons travelling to and from the area are vaccinated against cholera.
(4) Can a person carrying the disease be identified on landing in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Standards of public hygiene, including the handling and preparation of foods, and of the treatment of water supplies and sewage are adequate to prevent an outbreak of cholera in Australia. Cholera is a quarantinable disease under the Quarantine Act 1908 and persons suffering from cholera on entry to Australia are placed under quarantine. Cholera is effectively treated with modern drug regimes.

(2) Cholera vaccine does not prevent the spread of cholera from person to person, it has minimal efficacy and a short duration of action. Neither the World Health Organization nor Australia's National Health and Medical Research Council recommends use of the vaccine. Both these bodies recommend that emphasis should be placed on personal hygiene measures, particularly in the selection and handling of food and water where cholera is a risk. Australia has adequate resources to manage the unlikely event of a cholera epidemic.
(3) For the reasons given above, no restrictions are in place to ensure that persons travelling to or from cholera infected areas are vaccinated against cholera.

(4) Cholera symptoms are variable from patient to patient and the disease would not necessarily be identifiable in a person with mild symptoms on landing in Australia. Passengers reporting illness on landing are routinely referred to Commonwealth Medical Officers to investigate the possibility of quarantinable disease. If cholera is suspected, arrangements are made for confirmatory tests and treatment in hospital. Customs and quarantine officers at international ports of entry to Australia routinely seek advice from Commonwealth Medical Officers when they detect a passenger who shows signs or symptoms of any illness.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 8 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the estimate of the amount of oil that has spilled and is currently pouring into the Persian Gulf from Kuwait.
(2) What methods are being used to clean up the oil spills.
(3) Is Australia assisting Kuwait with the `clean up'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Estimates of the spill size range between 5 million and 11 million barrels of oil (795,000-1,745,000 tonnes). As the release of oil occurred in a war situation it has not been possible to determine an accurate figure. Oil continues to escape into the Arabian Gulf from a number of sources off Kuwait and Iraq at an estimated rate of 1500 to 6000 barrels per day.

(2) A variety of resources have been used to recover the oil, including offshore and inshore skimming vessels, static skimmers and vacuum trucks. A large offshore skimming vessel was used to collect oil off the Saudi Arabian coast in the early days of the spill before the slick moved inshore into shallower waters. It was not possible to operate this vessel off the Kuwaiti coast due to the threat of mines. Inshore operations were carried out in those areas where the oil concentrated either naturally or with the help of oil spill containment booms and sand berms. In these areas smaller skimmer units and vacuum trucks were used to recover large quantities of free floating oil. Recovered oil is being taken away for reprocessing in some instances and elsewhere it is being stored in large pits for subsequent disposal.

(3) The Government has responded in a positive manner to assist the Gulf clean up operations by sending experts and equipment to Saudi Arabia. This commenced on 4 March 1991 following a request by the Government of Saudi Arabia for international assistance. So far Australian oil pollution experts from the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, the Australian Institute of Petroleum and State marine authorities have been sent to Saudi Arabia on a rotation basis to act as advisers to local oil spill response authorities. This assistance is continuing. Australia has also donated two skimmers to the Government of Saudi Arabia to assist in oil recovery operations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 8 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Individual Patient Usage (IPU) arrangements under which medical practitioners may request approval to use certain drugs which are approved overseas but are still awaiting approval in Australia:
(1) On a state by state basis, for the financial year 1989-90 and the six months ended 31 December 1990, how many requests did the Government receive for IPUs.

(2) On a state by state basis, for the financial year 1989-90 and the six months ended 31 December 1990: (a) how many requests for IPU approval did the Government receive concerning patients who are HIV positive; (b) how many of these requests were approved; (c) for what conditions, forms of treatment and medication were these request sought; (d) for what conditions, forms of treatment and medication were these requests approved or rejected; and (e) what was the average waiting period between the date of a request for approval for IPU for a patient who is HIV positive and the date of notification of approval or rejection.

(3) On a state by state basis, for the financial year 1989-90 and the six months ended 31 December 1990: (a) how many requests for IPU approval did the Government receive concerning patients who are suffering from full-blown AIDS; (b) how many of these requests were approved; (c) for what conditions, forms of treatment and medication were these requests sought; (d) for what conditions, forms of treatment and medication were these requests approved or rejected; and (e) what was the average waiting period between the date of a request for approval for IPU for a patient suffering from AIDS and the date of notification of approval or rejection.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The number of IPU requests received in the financial year 1989-90 was 17,979. The number received in the six months ended 31 December 1990 was 9,419. State by State figures are not available from the IPU system.
(2) &(3) The information necessary to answer questions (2) and (3) is not recorded by the IPU system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why was the President of Turkey, Mr Turgut Ozal, made an honorary Companion of the Order of Australia.
(2) Was the award made at the suggestion of the Australian Decorations Advisory Committee; if not, on whose advice or at whose direction was it made.
(3) If the award was made on purely personal grounds, and not as an award virtually to the Turkish regime, why was the award not given, as is the custom when Mr Ozal retired from public office.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) His Excellency Mr Turgut Ozal, President of the Republic of Turkey, was made an honorary Companion of the Order of Australia for eminent service to Australian/Turkish relations, particularly in relation to his personal contribution to the celebration of the 75th anniversary of the Gallipoli campaign.

(2) The Australian Decorations Advisory Committee is the body that makes recommendations to the Governor-General for Australian Bravery Awards. Recommendations for honorary awards in the Order of Australia are made by the Prime Minister to the Governor-General who seeks The Queen's approval.

(3) There is no established custom that an honorary award in the Order of Australia to the holder of a public office is only made on the person's retirement. The award to President Ozal was proclaimed on 8 February 1991, as early as practicable after the celebrations of the 75th anniversary of the Gallipoli campaign, in order to emphasise Mr Ozal's outstanding personal contribution to this noteworthy event.

(2) How many people are currently participating in JOBTRAIN courses.
(3) How many people are currently participating in Job Search Training programs.
(4) How many people are participating in SkillShare.
(5) How many people are currently participating in the Australian Traineeship System.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As at 14 May 1991, 7,299 people were employed under the JOBSTART program.
(2) As at 14 May 1991, 13,574 people were participating in JOBTRAIN courses.
